webTitle: UK trailing in Europe's heart treatment league

fields.headline: UK trailing in Europe's heart treatment league
fields.trailText: The UK has one of the worst records in Europe for treating heart disease, according to a new study.
fields.body:
The UK has one of the worst records in Europe for treating heart disease, according to a new study.

The level of NHS care for patients with heart conditions was found to be well below that provided in Germany, Italy and France; seriously ill patients have far less chance of receiving proven life-saving treatments than similar patients in mainland Europe; and patients have less time in intensive care after surgery.

The research team, headed by the heart specialist Keith Fox of Edinburgh Royal infirmary, examined data from more than 3,000 patients in 29 countries, looking at heart attack victims and those with unstable angina.

It found that UK hospitals lagged far behind their European counterparts in providing the latest diagnostic tests, surgical treatments and drugs such as aspirin and beta blockers.

Professor Fox told Scotland on Sunday newspaper that differences "in the management of heart disease and in the use of the more expensive medical treatments" were worrying. In some instances the level of care was ranked alongside or below that offered in Greece and Turkey.

The survey showed that only 2% of UK heart patients could expect to be treated with new "super aspirin" drugs, which prevent blood clots in surgery.

Prof Fox said that more than 40% of heart patients in US centres received super aspirin, while his study indicated that 34% of German patients were given the drug.

Only 9% of UK patients with unstable angina received balloon angioplasty treatment, compared with 49% in France.

UK heart attack patients had the shortest hospital stays, averaging 7.9 days compared with more than 11 days in Germany, Switzerland and Austria.

Heart disease is one of the UK's biggest killers, accounting for 180,000 deaths a year.

Stuart Cobbe, cardiology professor at Glasgow University, said of the survey results: "Most other European countries have a substantially larger number of doctors and specialists per head of population than we have.

"When patients are treated by specialists they tend to receive more advanced treatments. Many patients in UK hospitals are treated by non-specialists, and even if they are treated by specialists these are hard-pressed and can't offer the same interventions as elsewhere in Europe."

This month the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced the establishment of 10 cardiac emergency response teams. In the long term there would be more specialist heart disease doctors and more cardiac centres.

Prof Fox's study will be presented at the European Society of Cardiology's annual conference in Amsterdam this week.

fields.headline: Great Fire of Torrington
fields.standfirst: Enthusiasts recreate 1666 London disaster
fields.trailText: For the best part of two years, the team of eccentric volunteers had laboured to create a perfect replica of a famous corner of 17th century London.
fields.body:
For the best part of two years, the team of eccentric volunteers had laboured to create a perfect replica of a famous corner of 17th century London.

Yesterday 100 square metres of smouldering ash was all that remained after the structure was torched in an extravagant re-enactment of the Great Fire of London.

An estimated 20,000 people turned out to view the spectacle on the common at Great Torrington in north Devon, a beauty spot normally reserved for picnickers and bargain hunters at the car boot sale.

The idea of acting out the Great Fire of 1666 was credited to the Torrington Cavaliers, a group which has raised many thousands of pounds for charity by, quite legally, raising fires.

Since its foundation in 1970, the group has set fire to replicas of a Spanish galleon, the battleship Bismarck, the local church - which had been destroyed in the Civil War - and even the Houses of Parliament. But to mark the millennium year, the Cavaliers set about the demanding task of recreating the streets around Pudding Lane where the Great Fire started.

Dave Kelly, chairman of the Cavaliers, carried out much of the research for the project, spending hours at Museum of London to make sure that the replica was as accurate as possible.

The framework was constructed from tree trunks removed from a nearby school, while roof supports were reclaimed from the local market hall when it was refurbished.

Other materials were donated by local builders, equipment was loaned and businesses chipped in with sponsorship.

A team of volunteers put in some 5,000 hours to build the structure, which required temporary planning permission. With three fire engines and two ambulances standing by, the buildings were finally set ablaze on Saturday evening.

Mr Kelly, 59, said the fire was his swansong. "I've done 11 bonfires and I've never been sentimental," he said. "I used to think 'bloody good job that's gone', but I was choked over this one because it was my last one. It's been a long, hard slog."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Rebecca | Without A Clue | La Fille De D'Artagnan | Dirty Harry
fields.body:
Rebecca

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1940)

8.45am, Carlton Cinema

Hitchcock's adaptation of the Daphne du Maurier tale about the dangers of marrying on the rebound is a droll gothic exercise. Joan Fontaine's newlywed goes to live at Manderlay, the vast stately pile owned by husband Maxim de Winter (Laurence Olivier), who is haunted by his dead first wife, Rebecca; Judith Anderson is Mrs Danvers.

Without A Clue

(Thom Eberhardt, 1988)

4pm, Sky Cinema

A mysterious and entertaining inversion of Conan Doyle's natural order: Dr Watson (Ben Kingsley) is actually the brilliant one, and Holmes (Michael Caine) the dimwit, a hammy, boozy actor playing the role of the great detective. But appearances are hard to maintain on the trail of Moriarty (Paul Freeman) and the nicked £5 note templates. Caine and Kingsley are a great double act.

La Fille De D'Artagnan (Bertrand Tavernier, 1994)

8pm, FilmFour

Sophie Marceau stars as Eloise, daughter of the great musketeer and a real chip off the old block. Spirited, and stylish with a sword, she nevertheless needs Dad Philippe Noiret's reluctant help in tackling the nefarious Duc de Crassac (Claude Rich). Tavernier said this was a homage to the swashbucklers of his youth, and he's produced one of the best of the many musketeers adventures, fast-paced, witty and action-packed.

Dirty Harry

(Don Siegel, 1971)

10pm, Sky Cinema

The first appearance of Clint Eastwood's semi-psychotic San Francisco cop Harry Callahan set a new yardstick for the detective movie, and few measure up to his .44 Magnum. He gives a performance of steely minimalism: a man of few words, dispatching "punks" effortlessly while munching a hotdog; yet he is a man at the end of his tether. His methods of catching Andy Robinson's revolting Scorpio killer inspired wide debate about the film's supposed fascist stance. Siegel's direction, though, is exemplary.

fields.headline: Close to the wind
fields.trailText: Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure | Hellraisers | Australia: Beyond The Fatal Shore
fields.body:
A racing trimaran sounds like some kind of pudding. "On this evening's dessert trolley, we have Baked Alaska, Sticky Toffee Pudding and Racing Trimaran - prunes in Armagnac in a meringue nest topped with chopped nuts and raspberry coulis go-faster stripes."

Alas, it's a boat (spare me the "technically, a trimaran is a yacht" letters please) so Lenny Henry in one of the aforementioned trimarans wasn't as tasty as it sounded.

Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure (Sat and Sun, BBC1) had all the ingredients of an energetic, interesting and funny bank holiday kind of a show. Henry and Tony Bullimore crossing the Atlantic in a 53ft boat from Plymouth to Montego Bay in Jamaica in 18 days.

A well-worn "celebrity amateur meets not-so-well-known professional" premise, with each learning from the other, the sparking of personalities made all the more intense thanks to the small space which they inhabit.

That, at least, was the plan. And it started well, with Henry and Bullimore getting acquainted and Henry taking part in sea survival courses, his face hilariously all squashed up against a life jacket (and you can bet that wouldn't have happened with that one Richard and Dick made on Better by Design last week). After an appearance by Dawn French, they were off. And that's where it started going wrong. Well, not so much wrong as uninteresting.

Lenny wanted to winch better, he told the camera. Lenny didn't like weeing in a bucket (very Anatomy Of Disgust), Lenny wanted to rise to the challenge of driving the boat when Tony was asleep. All completely valid responses to the situation in which he found himself. Unfortunately, they didn't make for great telly. Much as Henry is talented, here he seemed utterly devoid of charisma and hugely over-earnest about the joys of undertaking a big adventure. It was as if his agent had persuaded him to participate in the programme solely to improve his image. Often a parody of himself, when Henry hammed it up, it was like watching your dad gurning for the camera at a family wedding. Cringeworthy, not seaworthy. (And why would you want to be on the other side of the Atlantic when you're married to Dawn French anyway?)

Whatever, Henry underestimated Bullimore from the start. "I can't believe I've agreed to sail across the Atlantic with a man who is most famous for turning his boat upside down and surviving on a bar of chocolate." Hey, it isn't that easy surviving on a bar of chocolate without falling off. Unless it's one of those jumbo only-at-Christmas bars of Cadbury's.

Now, if Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure had - like that Murder Most Horrid which starred Dawn French and Sarah Lancashire as round-the-world yachtswomen - degenerated into murder and betrayal, that would have been fun.Not that bad behaviour is all that interesting either, no matter how much it's lionised. Hellraisers (Sat, C4) did just that with a gentle look at Richard Harris, Oliver Reed and Ozzy Osbourne, among others, and their fast-living ways. I like a drink as much as the next man, but this was the equivalent of sitting in the pub beside someone saying "I can drink 50 pints and still go for a curry then do my bird."

Having said that, Harris, Reed and Osbourne are interesting at some unspoken level. They embody the secret self-destructive streak many of us have. They have thrown off the shackles of civility, the conventions of society and embraced drunken debauchery. As much as we disapprove, we can't help but admire and, as in the likes of Robbie Williams' case, attempt to emulate their excesses to up our machismo rating. And that thought leads to the conclusion that, by undertaking his big adventure, Lenny Henry isn't so bad after all. Water, water everywhere but not a drop to drink.

Robert Hughes' journey to Australia was almost his last as, shortly after his arrival, he was involved in a near-fatal car crash. That would have been an awful shame. Not just because it would have been bad for his loved ones if he'd died, but because Australia: Beyond The Fatal Shore (Sun, BBC2) would never have been made. Selfish, I know, but it was a fantastic documentary full of personal insight, grand vision and a real, gritty feel for Australia in all its beauty, idiosyncrasies and contradictions, as well as Hughes' own endearing eccentricities. It almost made you want to set sail.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Forty Years On | Nature
fields.body:
A special 90-minute radio version of Alan Bennett's first play, Forty Years On (2.15pm, Radio 4), marks the 30th anniversary of the original West End production. Bennett (pictured, right) himself takes the role of the headmaster retiring after 50 years' teaching at Albion House. The dry pedantry of the character and his shock at the pupils' mockery of his golden memories in the end-of-term play are splendidly portrayed. Eleanor Bron plays Matron in Gordon House's rollicking production.

Another character whose golden years have tarnished is the opening subject of Mark Carwardine's new series for Nature (9.0pm, Radio 4). In the past 20 years Britain has lost two-thirds of its house sparrows, and no one knows why. There are now fewer than 100 breeding females left in central London, a sorry tale repeated across the kingdom. Among those being blamed are farmers, cats, magpies, and even house builders whose modern dwellings lack the bird's preferred nesting crannies.

webTitle: Straw bans Bronson jail terror video

fields.headline: Straw bans Bronson jail terror video
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been granted an injunction banning the release of a video which shows Charles Bronson, Britain's most violent prisoner, terrorising a teacher he took hostage last year.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been granted an injunction banning the release of a video which shows Charles Bronson, Britain's most violent prisoner, terrorising a teacher he took hostage last year.

The footage shows Bronson leading Phil Danielson by a skipping rope during a 44-hour ordeal.

Bare-chested and wearing a prison officer's hat, the convicted armed robber, who received a life sentence in February for the hostage-taking, which occurred in Hull prison, also brandishes a home-made spear.

He is later to be seen holding a broken beer bottle to his captive's chest before drawing it across his own head.

The film forms part of a three-hour documentary entitled Sincerely Yours, which also features footage of the 47-year-old being restrained by guards in Winson Green prison, Birmingham, in 1995.

The documentary, made by the Newcastle-based company Mirage Productions, has been on sale by post for two weeks and is advertised, at the price of £15.99, on Bronson's own website.

Attempts by the Treasury solicitor to force the company to withdraw it failed, and on Friday Mr Straw sought an emergency injunction to prevent its distribution on the grounds that the prison service owned the copyright to the footage.

Stephen Richards of Mirage Productions insisted it would not comply with the interim injunction.

"This is David against Golliath," he said. "I strongly believe it is in the public interest to have this shown. We are not going to budge."

fields.headline: 50p design honours libraries
fields.trailText: Compact discs are to feature on a new 50p coin being produced by the Royal Mint to mark 150 years of public libraries in Britain.
fields.body:
Compact discs are to feature on a new 50p coin being produced by the Royal Mint to mark 150 years of public libraries in Britain.

Millions of the new legal tender coins have been minted and will be issued through most post offices and some banks.

Their distinctive reverse design by Mary Milner Dickens shows the turning pages of a book resting on top of a public library building. CDs have been included in the design to show how libraries have kept pace with the times.

webTitle: Kray freed but too ill to be moved

fields.headline: Kray freed but too ill to be moved
fields.trailText: Reggie Kray, the East End gangster serving life for murder, has been freed from prison, according to staff at Norfolk and Norwich hospital, where he is being treated.
fields.body:
Reggie Kray, the East End gangster serving life for murder, has been freed from prison, according to staff at Norfolk and Norwich hospital, where he is being treated.

The Home Office took the decision on Saturday to free Kray on compassionate grounds, after a consultant said he had only days to live.

Trevor Linn, Kray's solicitor, said his client was overjoyed by the decision. "I am hoping Reggie Kray will confound all the experts and be leaving hospital soon," he said. "He's as tough as old boots."

Kray, 66, was moved to the hospital three weeks ago from Wayland prison near Watton, Norfolk. He has bladder cancer.

He and his twin, Ronnie, were jailed in 1969 for the murder of Jack "the Hat" McVitie. Ronnie died six years ago.

Anne Osborn, a hospital spokeswoman, said Kray was in a comfortable condition but was too ill to leave the hospital.

His wife, Roberta, who is staying with him there, said: "There are mixed emotions today. I'm pleased he has got his freedom. It is something he has been waiting so long for, but he is seriously ill.

"However, we're hoping that he will able to get out for a few days. He is conscious and able to speak, but it is a difficult time."

The EastEnders actor, Barbara Windsor, who campaigned for his release, said: "It's good news, but it's tinged with a lot of sadness."

Kray's friends also welcomed the news but they expressed anger that it had taken so long for the Home Office to act.

His former gangland accomplice, Tony Lambrianou, said: "Now after 32 years of imprisonment they have released him to a death sentence."

fields.headline: Phone saves woman from drowning
fields.trailText: A mobile phone helped to rescue a woman stuck in mud as she faced being drowned by an incoming tide.
fields.body:
A mobile phone helped to rescue a woman stuck in mud as she faced being drowned by an incoming tide.

The emergency was handled by Humber coastguard Mike Puplett, based at the marine rescue centre in Bridlington, East Yorkshire.

He took a 999 call from the woman, pleading for help as she struggled to free herself from the mud near Pleasure Island at Cleethorpes, Lincolnshire.

She was on a day trip from Lincoln, and had become trapped as she went to rescue her two children who had got stuck in the mud, but managed to free themselves.

Three men who went to help her also got trapped and were soon up to their knees in the notorious sinking sands. As the tide turned and threatened to drown them, the coastguard at the end of the phone kept the woman and the men calm. Then it emerged another woman who tried to help had also got trapped.

The coastguard scrambled a helicopter from RAF Leconfield in East Yorkshire and called out the coastguard rescue team from Cleethorpes.

Mr Puplet, who continued to speak to the trapped people over the mobile phone as the rescue services moved in, said: "They were sinking fast and soon up to their knees. The area is well known for being marshy and swampy. In the past many people have been cut off by the tide locally and the coastguard has had to help them to safety."

Duncan News Service

fields.headline: As time goes by
fields.standfirst: In the last of our series on summer nights,  Jacqueline Roy  recalls the long, hot, dark hours that followed the death of her father
fields.trailText: In the last of our series on summer nights,  Jacqueline Roy  recalls the long, hot, dark hours that followed the death of her father.
fields.body:
It's a summer night and my mother is not in the house. The Lady Who Lives Downstairs is keeping an eye on my brother, sister and me. I am the oldest so I must be calm, even though it feels as if we are alone. I'm too hot, so I kick back the sheet and lie in the dark, aware of the closeness of summer, the stuffiness of the room and my sister's even breathing from the other bed. Soon my mother will be home. It is the time between night and morning and it's deathly quiet with a stillness that makes me still, too, despite my restlessness. I listen for the sound of my mother's key in the lock.

"He'll be back soon," my mother said and I've been trying to believe her. I've lain awake, wondering why he hasn't asked to see me. "Children aren't allowed to visit the grown-up ward," my mother tells me. But he can do anything, anything at all. If he wanted me to come, he would make it possible. I keep beating back the fear that he's forgotten me. Or perhaps he knows how naughty I've been. "You must be good for Mummy," he said before he left and I've tried really hard but perhaps I haven't been good enough.

"Is Daddy going to die?" I asked my mother when she came in one night to see if I was sleeping.

"No, of course not," she replied, sounding cross. I waited for the safe feeling her answer should have brought but it wouldn't come.

Each long night, I feel the heat of summer. I am seven years old and it's the first time I've been aware of the changing seasons. When it is warm, Daddy plays with us outside; we suck lollies shaped like rockets from the ice cream van. This summer there is sun, but it feels dark. Even the days seem like night.

I sit up suddenly. My mother is home. The front door shuts. I run to the top of the stairs and look down at her. Something's wrong. She's crying. I go down slowly, not sure what to do. I wait beside her, wanting her to tell me what is wrong yet fearful of knowing the terrible thing that's made her cry. I reach up to touch her but she pushes me away. I look at her angrily. "I'm sorry, darling," she says and she holds me close but it's too tight, I want it to stop now, she's squashing me. "Daddy is dead," she says, in a distant voice. "He is never coming home."

In that moment, everything changes. It is daylight now, but the darkness grows deeper. I am sitting in my father's chair, holding a big handkerchief. My eyes burn. I don't remember coming into the living room and sitting here. When did I start to cry? When will I be able to stop?

"Dead, dead, I hate the word dead!" I shout, full of childish intensity. I'm trying to behave the way you should when someone dies. A grown-up would say these things and I know I must be grown up now.

My sister is sitting on the floor, nursing her doll. We are each alone. From his playpen, my brother asks for cake. My sister and I look at him scornfully. It's much too soon for ordinary things.

"He doesn't understand," my mother says. I don't understand either but I know I mustn't say it. I'm not a baby any more.

Day slips into night again, the cycles barely noticed. We have no sense of time passing. It is as if we are trapped in a single moment. We may never really move beyond it.

All around us, there are pieces of my father: his carvings and paintings, many only half completed, are spread all over the house. The sense of incompleteness terrifies my mother. "He still had so much left to do," she keeps repeating. He used to say that each figure was embedded in the piece of wood he chipped, he only brought it out. But the Madonnas and Christs, with their African features, rarely sold. "He was ahead of his time," my mother would say. He worked in a factory, leaving the house in the dark and returning home at night to sculpt and paint and write. "He had to work too hard. They killed him," my mother adds, "all those people who couldn't see his work or recognise the beauty of it."

Looking at my father's work starts to bring too much sadness. I begin to shut it out until it becomes part of the furniture. I tear up a picture he painted of my teddy bear and hide the pieces in a cupboard. In those summer nights, I learn to conceal things.

I make myself stop crying in the daytime. I want to be big and strong for my mother. In bed at night, I learn to cry without making any sound while I play back the memories: my father dancing like a bear to make us laugh; my father cooking rice and peas. I also remember when I was four, just before my brother was born. My mother was ill, so my sister and I were sent to stay with friends. In those summer nights, my father would visit after work. He would leave his black corduroy jacket hanging at the foot of my bed so I would sleep. I needed to know he was still there before I could close my eyes. The jacket smelled of wood and paint. Where is it now? If I can find it, maybe he'll come home. I search secretly, but it has gone.

"Daddy's never coming home." I try to imagine never. I play the word over and over in my head. It stands beside "forever" and "eternity"; terrible, powerful words that are impossible to understand even in adulthood. "You and Lucinda and Tamba must always be like your father," my mother says. "You must write and paint like him." My father was a Maroon; he was the carver and storyteller. These roles were passed down the generations. It's up to us now to keep them going.

My mother struggles on. My father is always in her thoughts. Their marriage was courageous; an English woman and a Jamaican man fell in love in 1953; they were verbally abused, spat upon, ostracised by many. They had the kind of romantic, passionate love that rarely exists beyond books. She was never to become involved with another man. "Our happiness was a once-in-a- lifetime thing," she would say. Sometimes she'd add: "We were too happy. I knew it couldn't last."

She kept a diary. A year after his death, she wrote: "I feel him so near me today. It was just as though his spirit was everywhere. I had the same peace and security that nothing could touch, that I sometimes had when I was with him, without the fears and the cares of the world crowding in. Everything I do, I try to put him in front of me, to do it because he would want it, or that is how he would do it. I hold his red pullover very tight and this helps to bring him close because I cannot see him."

I cannot see him either and his jacket is no longer there. He was the Caribbean part of my inheritance and now there are only empty spaces.

But slowly, through the months and years, the sadness starts to yield. He begins to come back into view. I start to hear his voice again and the Jamaican words that had been lost to me.

There comes a time when I can almost touch his jacket; I can smell the paint and wood. I can see his carvings and I feel my history as I look. There is colour and light in the pictures he painted. I read his books and feel his warmth as I recall the tales he used to tell of ancestral spirits. I look inside myself and I see the part of me that has always wanted to be like him.

Summer nights are long. They are full of the comfort of remembering.

 Jacqueline Roy is a senior lecturer at Manchester Metropolitan University. Her novel, The Fat Lady Sings, is published on September 14 by The Women's Press at £9.99.

fields.headline: Wild at heart
fields.trailText: Michelle Hanson: 'Rosemary and I are off to an Over Fifties Festival. Promises of wine-tasting and line-dancing have tempted us.'
fields.body:
Rosemary and I are off to an Over Fifties Festival. Promises of wine-tasting and line-dancing have tempted us. But as we follow the little black arrows pointing to Over Fifties, Over Fifties, Over Fifties, I begin to feel rather glum. We are trooping along with all the other old people, which means that we are old as well. I didn't think I minded, but I do. I should have brought my mother as a cover. Then I could have pretended it was all for her benefit. I would have been the young person shoving the old, infirm one about in a wheelchair, but this time I am here on my own account. Horrid.

Rosemary and I enter a large room full of tables covered in leaflets. We can do arts and crafts, gardening, IT courses, genealogy, bowls, sitting-down aerobics, reminisce, be feminists and have a health check or free massage. I am in there like a shot but Rosemary takes one look and runs away.

Who can blame her? This isn't your glamorous Covent Garden Sanctuary. It's lardy bodies covered in pale towels and flobbed about on tables - the last chance saloon.

That is the difference. Daughter is keen on exercise and healthy pursuits and alternative therapies for fun. I am grasping on to them like a drowning woman.

But just as we are about to run home and cry, we pass a hall full of people exercising sitting down to the music of the second world war. We join in. For some reason this perks Rosemary up. I can't think why. It only reminds us of Izal lavatory paper and rationing, which just shows how old we are. We plod on with our fun day out, have a divine ethnic lunch, but something is still wrong.

"Perhaps it's a bit earnest and worthy," says Rosemary. She is right. We fancy something more wild and pointless. My father may have been on the right track. At 79, he suddenly buzzed off to the south of France, didn't even book a seat, slept in the train corridor, arrived, hurried to the betting shop and won £1,100 (picked the first three horses home). Next day he won another £300, staggered round for days wine-tasting and gambling, and returned home a happier man.

Would he have found an appropriate leaflet at our Festival?

fields.headline: An unusual undertaking
fields.standfirst: Have you ever wondered what would happen if you died abroad?  Jonathan Margolis  meets the man who would probably bring you home again
fields.trailText: Have you ever wondered what would happen if you died abroad?  Jonathan Margolis  meets the man who would probably bring you home again.
fields.body:
If you are one of the 25m or so foreign visitors to Britain this year, you would do well to avoid meeting Christopher Henley, from Chiswick, west London. It's nothing personal. Henley is a pleasant, thoughtful and courteous chap. It's just that he happens to be in charge of one of the world's most specialised firms of undertakers - the man who is on 24-hour standby to ensure that if you are one of the 1,800 or so foreigners who annually have the misfortune to die on a trip here, your family, if they are with you, will be offered comfort by a multilingual grief expert, the complex bureaucracy of your untimely demise will be expedited and your remains airfreighted back to your home country in a suitably dignified manner.

Henley doesn't only look after foreign nationals who die here. If, as happened 1,581 times last year, you're a Brit and die abroad, he or one of his two competitor firms, will be on your case. His mobile phone awaits the call from your relatives, or more likely their travel insurers.

Indeed, as operations manager of Henley Wright, International Funeral Directors, Henley's renown and experience in the funereal customs of almost every nation and religion mean that even if you aren't British and die in a corner of some foreign beach, he may still be in the background, discreetly arranging your last journey by phone and fax from Putney.

As we chat in his office, he is dealing with a fax from a Danish insurance company asking for his best price to ship three deceased from a Greek island, the Canaries and Cyprus back to Norway, Denmark and Sweden. Happily, almost all deaths abroad are covered by insurance; if they are not, embassies, consulates or relatives back home invariably step in with payment.

The cost of preparing a body, placing it in a basic oak, zinc-lined coffin and handling is £950, with no charge at all made for under 16s. The company also has preferential airfreight rates, typically £315 for an average weight body, say, to the east coast of the States.

It is evident that Henley really does have the deepest sympathy. "People are at their lowest ebb when they see a funeral director," he says. "But when the person has died abroad, they're going to be at a lower ebb still, if that can be imagined."

However, Henley Wright is also a business, and at the same time, Henley is also buzzing about in preparation for the all-important US Embassy's occasional visit to Putney later in the week to check out that the facilities continue to be suitably excellent for the accommodation of deceased Americans.

The hiatus gives me a chance to acclimatise to the unsettling experience of being at a funeral director's while not a bereaved customer. There are certificates all around attesting to Henley's international qualifications. There are glossy coffin catalogues that prompt me to wonder why anyone would require a casket with 24 carat gold-plated fittings, or why anybody would pay extra for a sprung bed in their coffin - and what the heck is the attraction of buying a coffin which comes, as the best models do, with a guarantee.

Most oddly disturbing, however, is the office calendar, courtesy of United Airlines Cargo Division. I had given some thought to my meeting with Henley, but it had never occurred in such bald terms that if you're unfortunate enough to die abroad, whether you travelled out economy or club, you are flown back in the hold. To confirm this there are diplomas from airlines affirming that Henley has passed courses in the transport of infectious substances and in the freight of dangerous goods - that's you and me after being embalmed in formalin, which is hazardous to airplanes.

I wonder what kind of stories lead to tourists ending up in a deluxe coffin in Putney en route to a cargo hold. Henley is more than a little reticent here. Discretion and sensitivity in the extreme are the essentials of his business. That might mean anything from remaining totally mum about just whom Fred was with when he died to avoiding any suggestion of just how Jose came to die of a "fall".

Not that Henley would think of it. He is a fourth-generation funeral director and extremely proud of his profession. His retired father was awarded the OBE with the unique citation: "Desmond Charles Henley, Embalmer, for services in the aftermath of disasters." Henley, although he is managing a business, makes a point of getting involved when he can with the core skills of undertaking, handling the bodies, preparing the coffins - everything except embalming, which he is not qualified in.

It would be easy to imagine such technicalities, along with the legalities of dealing with and moving human remains around the world, swamping the need to be sensitive, but Henley has the bearing of a highly effectual vicar, dispensing sympathy while always ahead of the game. He knows precisely how one country insists on sealing at each end the coffins of its deceased in the presence of a vice consul, while another doesn't mind, and how particular countries will require an embassy official to view the body and match it up with the deceased's passport picture.

All the airlines, on the other hand, have similar rules on shipping bodies. Coffins must be metal-lined and carried in a hold designated only for human remains, normally called Hold 5. Airlines very rarely allow more than one coffin (internationally coded HUM for human remains) to be carried on a scheduled flight, as a mark of respect to the deceased. This rigid rule means that when an entire family dies, its members still often have to be shipped back one by one. And under no circumstances will any airline ship a coffin on the same aircraft as either food or live animals. I imagine knowing how grimly holidays can end would put a lot of people off the idea of going abroad at all. "Am I going to be a victim of my own success?" he replies, smiling. "Well, my job certainly makes you more aware of your own mortality."

webTitle: Tide of refugees floods Spanish beaches

fields.headline: Tide of refugees floods Spanish beaches
fields.trailText: At one time they were like ghosts, disembarking at night and hidden in the mountains by the time dawn revealed their footprints on the beach.
fields.body:
At one time they were like ghosts, disembarking at night and hidden in the mountains by the time dawn revealed their footprints on the beach.

Sunbathers might find plastic bags of soggy bread and soiled clothes, but uninvited entry into the first world was generally discreet.

They were Moroccans who had crossed the Gibraltar strait to southern Spain.

Capture meant instant deportation, so on sight of the police they fled into the upland pine forests and cacti. After a few days they would fan north and try to melt into the economies of Spain and northern Europe.

This summer something has changed. Thousands of sub-Saharan Africans have started following the Moroccans into overloaded dinghies for the two-hour moonlit ride. Staggering ashore are asylum seekers and immigrants from Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Cameroon, Ivory Coast and Senegal.

Unlike the Moroccans they do not run. They sit, or collapse, on the beach or motorway and wait to be picked up.

Police around the town of Tarifa, Spain's southernmost tip, have intercepted more than 600 people in the past 10 days alone - an unprecedented rate of entry which shows no sign of slowing.

The infrastructure to receive them is crumbling. A sports stadium is being used to supplement overflowing police cells. Stocks of shoes and clothes are running out. The arrivals are processed en masse rather than individually. The explanation is simple: Fortress Europe has shut one door, so the illegals are using another.

Prompted by its European Union partners, Spain has sealed off Ceuta and Melilla, its two enclaves on the Moroccan coast which for years attracted sub-Saharans fleeing poverty and oppression.

New fences ringed with razor wires, infra-red cameras and police patrols redirect the sub-Saharan traffic into the 12-mile Gibraltar strait.

The strait is so narrow that car headlights can be seen on the other side, but treacherous currents and winds have claimed an estimated 3,000 lives in the past five years.

"After all we'd been through, we discovered we'd have to take another boat. It was almost too much," said Kisley Osas, 22, from Nigeria.

With 26 other young men from his village, on June 28 he attached a motor to a fishing boat and started rowing. "If you saw our lives there you'd understand why. We have nothing," he said.

Using tyre tubes and air-filled plastic bottles as life-jackets, they stayed within sight of land and took turns rowing. They had hoped to avoid the Gibraltar crossing.

"About halfway across a wave from a tanker or something hit us. We were praying to God. Then a boat with white men in uniform came," he said.

Maria, 25, and her three-month-old daughter were picked up last week, eight months after she left her Nigerian village to trek across the Sahara. The birth of her daughter, she said, was not easy. "No professionals, no medicines."

Other survivors tell of women dying in childbirth, and of companions dying of thirst and disease. Women are routinely raped by bandits and border guards, they say.

With their livelihood threatened by civil guard naval patrols, the smugglers have raised the price of the crossing to £1,000. The higher stakes have increased the temptation to overload the inflatable speedboats, called Zodiacs.

The smugglers wait for calm weather, then race across in convoys of four or five to overwhelm the civil guards. Their "clients" are tossed overboard if a patrol boat approaches.

A new route that has opened this summer is the unguarded 60-mile stretch to the Canaries, where surfers have watched as the boatloads of human cargo struggled to shore.

The smugglers' tactics will have to become more ingenious - or brutal - in 2004, when Spain finishes installing an £80m radar system that will form a 350-mile electronic wall across the Mediterranean. It will be able to detect boats at distances of up to seven miles.

An underground network of activists has begun helping the new arrivals to elude police. They risk arrest but have the support of some civil guards.

Other officers could be bribed, said a restaurant owner in the port city of Algeciras. As he spoke two officers entered and a table of four Moroccans froze. They stopped talking while the officers ordered coffee. Ten minutes later the officers left and the Moroccans exchanged tense smiles. "If you look clean and well-dressed it tends to be OK," the owner said.

At the weekend the Catholic church echoed human rights activists, saying that the government's policy was incoherent and irresponsible.

A shrinking population and economic boom suggest that Spain will need 12m immigrants over the next 30 years. Farms and industry are crying out for labour.

But conservative lobbying and fears of a voter backlash have prompted the government to crack down. Under a law due to be passed in the autumn it will become harder for immigrants to become legal, and it will be easier to expel them.

This would make the traffic more expensive and dangerous, the church said, condemning the decision to seal off Ceuta and Melilla, which have orientation centres.

"It's tragic and stupid. No matter how many radars, police and boats we put on the beaches, these people will still come. The sooner Europe understands that the better," said Juan Maria Perez, an immigrant group coordinator.

At the moment, the new arrivals are taken to Algeciras, fingerprinted, given new clothes and ordered to leave within two weeks. Then they are dumped on the street.

They cluster around telephone boxes and the bus station, plotting to head north. Some ask the way to Italy, others have mobile phones, maps and contacts in Madrid.

After rowing thousands of miles, Kisley Osas was not going to allow a lack of cash stop him getting a bus to Madrid last night. "I'm going - just watch," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Standoff goes on for Suu Kyi
Burma's opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, spent a fourth day in her car south of Rangoon yesterday in a roadside test of wills with the military rulers who have asked her to go home for her own safety.
fields.body:
Standoff goes on for Suu Kyi
Burma's opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, spent a fourth day in her car south of Rangoon yesterday in a roadside test of wills with the military rulers who have asked her to go home for her own safety.

The Nobel laureate and members of her National League for Democracy were halted by police on Thursday as they headed south of the capital in two vehicles. The government insists that Ms Suu Kyi is being given ample food and water. [Reuters, Rangoon]

New president to unite Somalia
Abdiqassim Salad Hassan was sworn in as president of Somalia yesterday, with a mandate to form the country's first national government in nine years.

Mr Hassan, 58, was inaugurated at a ceremony attended by regional heads of state in Arta, in Djibouti. He pledged to bring peace to Somalia, which has had no national government since the fall of late dictator Mohammed Siad Barre in 1991. He was elected by a parliament set up by a peace conference sponsored by Djibouti. [Reuters, Mogadishu]

Children run down in Kosovo
Four Serb children died when a car ran them down in central Kosovo yesterday and police have detained an ethnic Albanian in connection with the incident, the province's UN-led administration said.

A fifth child was seriously injured in the incident in Skulanovo, south of the provincial capital, Pristina. An ethnic Albanian man was expected to be charged with vehicular homicide and drunk driving, UN officials said. [Reuters, Pristina]

Police attacked at rock concert
Punks and skinheads clashed at a rock concert in the western Polish city of Poznan, hurling paving stones and bottles before turning on police, police said yesterday.

Six police cars and a number of private vehicles were damaged during the disturbance on Saturday night and 14 rioters were detained, a police spokesman, Andrzej Borowiak, said. The trouble started when 300 youths were turned away from the concert for not having tickets, he said. [Reuters, Warsaw]

McDonald's in sweatshop row
Soft toys sold with meals at McDonald's in Hong Kong are made at a mainland Chinese sweatshop that illegally employs child labourers a newspaper reported yesterday.

Children, as young as 14, work a 16-hour day for about 23 Hong Kong dollars (£1.80), the Sunday Morning Post reported. McDonald's said it had no reason to believe that its Hong Kong toy supplier was in violation of its standards. [Reuters, Hong Kong]

webTitle: US deals blow to cocaine trade as 25 tonnes seized

fields.headline: US deals blow to cocaine trade as 25 tonnes seized
fields.trailText: US law enforcement officials have declared victory against an international drug-trafficking operation after a two-year effort ended in 43 arrests and the seizure of nearly 25 tonnes of cocaine worth an estimated $1bn (£670m).
fields.body:
US law enforcement officials have declared victory against an international drug-trafficking operation after a two-year effort ended in 43 arrests and the seizure of nearly 25 tonnes of cocaine worth an estimated $1bn (£670m).

Ivan de la Vega, the alleged leader of a smuggling ring that is believed to have shipped almost $3bn of cocaine around the world, and four others are to face drug-trafficking charges in Florida after a multinational law enforcement operation ended with a series of confrontations worthy of a Hollywood movie.

Speedboat gun battles, jungle raids and the seizure of a freighter marked the last days of an effort to crack down on a Colombian drugs operation which used a remote location in Venezuela and the global shipping industry to transport cocaine to Europe and the US.

In announcing the successful conclusion of Operation Journey on Saturday, Raymond Kelly, commissioner of the US customs service, said: "We wiped out a sprawling organisation whose tentacles reached around the world."

He described the organisation, allegedly run by Mr de la Vega from Colombia, as "one of the largest drug transportation groups ever targeted by law enforcement".

The smuggling operation transported drugs from Colombia by way of the Venezuelan jungle to Europe using a fleet of up to 10 commercial freighters.

Among those arrested in the international raids were understood to be several employees of the shipping industry in Europe.

Eastern Europe has become more and more involved in drug trafficking since the fall of the Berlin wall in November 1989.

US officials said the law-enforcement effort, which involved 12 countries, reflected the greater willingness of international agencies to work together to crack down on an increasingly global trade. Mr Kelly said in Washington that Operation Journey provided a "powerful new blueprint for fighting the international drug trade".

There was particular praise for the Venezuelan authorities, who seized nearly 10 tonnes of cocaine in the country's sparsely populated Orinoco river delta last week. The largest haul in Venezuelan history is expected to help ease tensions between the country and Washington, which arose when Venezuela refused to allow American planes to use its airspace to fight the drug war.

The end of the operation comes at a sensitive time for relations between several Latin America countries and their powerful neighbour. President Bill Clinton is due to arrive in Colombia on Wednesday to meet President Andres Pastrana. Last week, Mr Clinton authorised a $1.3bn aid package to help fight drug trafficking.

Among the five facing prosecution in Florida is Luis Antonio Navia, a Cuban fugitive facing previous US drug charges. Others were arrested in Greece, Italy and France, and the operation saw the involvement of security forces in the UK, Albania, Belgium, the Netherlands and Panama.

The Drugs Enforcement Administration said that it would continue to work with international agencies to end drug trafficking. Donnie Marshall at the DEA said yesterday: "Operation Journey is only the beginning."

fields.bylineHtml: Jane Martinson in New York

fields.headline: No: 1708
fields.standfirst: Guy Ritchie
fields.trailText: Guy Ritchie
fields.body:
I know that boat race. Pardon?

His physiognomy is familiar to me. That'll be because he's Madonna's better half and the director of one of Britain's most successful films ever.

Carry On Cleo? No. Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels.

Aha. Pretty boys with guns. MTV aesthetic. Bollock-squeezing footballer. That's the one.

This Ritchie character a bit of a hoodlum, then? He has a scar on his face which, he says, he picked up in a "rumble".

Gordon Bennett! "I've lived in the East End for 30 years," the hard man continues, "and let's just say that I've been in a load of mess-ups and I've lost a lot of money on cards."

Whereabouts in the East End did he grow up? Er, Fulham.

Come again? Ritchie, whose ad exec dad created the Hamlet cigar commercials, divided his youth between a series of private schools in London and a 17th century country pile in Shropshire.

Well, blow me daahn! "There were a lot of odd people at the house while he was growing up," says a friend - including dad's pal and cine-bigwig Alan Parker.

Sounds more kaftans than kipper ties. "Guy was keen on nature," his pal continues, "and at one time considered becoming a gamekeeper."

Aha! So the obsession with guns and violence is long-standing? Earlier this year, the father of Madonna's second child was arrested for allegedly beating up a fan outside their Kensington home - but he maintains in public that "I fucking disapprove of violence."

Papa don't preach, I should say. Touché.

So why's this mockney geezer in the news? His new film, the maturely titled Snatch, starring Brad Pitt and Vinnie Jones, is released this week.

Is it about boxers, gangsters and thieves up to no good within earshot of the Bow bells? How did you guess?

Most likely to say: "Stone me!"

Least likely to say: "Spiffing!"

Not to be confused with: Richie Rich, Damon Albarn, Dick van Dyke.

fields.headline: 'Dirty war' suspect faces extradition
fields.trailText: An Argentine businessman is facing possible extradition from Mexico to Spain, where he is wanted on charges of genocide, torture and terrorism arising from his former life as a naval officer during Argentina's 'dirty war'
fields.body:
An Argentine businessman is facing possible extradition from Mexico to Spain, where he is wanted on charges of genocide, torture and terrorism arising from his former life as a naval officer during Argentina's 'dirty war' A judge in Mexico City gave the green light on Saturday for extradition procedures to begin against Ricardo Cavallo, who until his arrest last week was director of Mexico's new vehicle registration programme.

The charges stem from an investigation headed by a Spanish judge, Baltasar Garzon, into human rights abuses committed during Argentina's 1973-1983 military regime. Mr Garzon has more than proven his determination to bring Latin America's dirty-war criminals to justice with his pursuit of the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet.

The extradition request, in its preliminary form, links Mr Cavallo directly to the murder of two women and the torture of a third at the notorious Naval Mechanical School, the Buenos Aires dirty-war nerve centre where then Captain Cavallo was allegedly a member of a crack operational unit.

Mr Cavallo is one of 98 military and civilian figures of the Argentine regime indicted by Judge Garzon last year. The vast majority of them live in Argentina and are protected by local amnesty laws and their government's reluctance to allow the Spanish judge to determine their affairs.

Human rights groups say that as many as 30,000 Argentines were killed or disappeared during military rule, and that many of those responsible not only escaped justice, but also pillaged the possessions of their victims.

Mr Cavallo' s alleged link to the Argentine dirty war, including a sideline in car theft, was revealed last week by the Mexican newspaper Reforma.

He was detained on a 48-hour order on Thursday at Cancun airport when his flight to Buenos Aires stopped for refuelling. Mr Cavallo said he was returning home to collect evidence to prove his innocence.

French investigators are also preparing a separate extradition request for Mr Cavallo in connection with the death of several French citizens in Argentina, including two nuns.

webTitle: Afghanistan crisis deepens as fighting blocks food aid

fields.headline: Afghanistan crisis deepens as fighting blocks food aid
fields.trailText: UN aid workers have warned that heavy fighting in Afghanistan is hampering efforts to help up to 4m people who have been seriously affected by the country's worst drought in 30 years.
fields.body:
UN aid workers have warned that heavy fighting in Afghanistan is hampering efforts to help up to 4m people who have been seriously affected by the country's worst drought in 30 years.

Roads into some of the worst hit areas pass through military frontlines and are heavily mined or blocked.

Last week the World Food Programme made the first delivery of 400 tonnes of wheat and seven tonnes of other food to Dara-e-Souf, near Samangan in the north. Children in the area are severely malnourished and some are eating roots and wild plants to survive.

The worsening conditions may force 100,000 people in the area from their homes and create a food crisis by the winter, said Michael Semple, the UN coordinator for the region.

Deliveries of another 15,000 tonnes of food needed in Dara-e-Souf will not get through unless roads are opened, he said. "If they open roads a famine will not happen."

The road used by the convoy is heavily mined and will be come blocked by heavy winter snow within three months.

"The problem will become acute when it becomes cold. People are waiting for a good winter rain. Otherwise the scale of disaster would be tough," Mr Semple said.

The severe drought covers a broad stretch of land from western Pakistan through Afghanistan into Iran and north into central Asia.

Crops across Afghanistan have been destroyed and nomadic herders have lost their animals. At least 2.3m tonnes of extra food will be needed in the country this year to make up for the effects of the drought, according to the UN. Refugees are expected to flood into neighbouring Iran and Pakistan.

The problem in Afghanistan is being complicated by a new outbreak of heavy fighting between the Islamic Taliban militia, who control most of the country, and forces from the ousted government.

Dara-e-Souf is still held by former government fighters who have held out against the Taliban for four years.

"The area was badly affected by the drought and by the war and it was a cross-line operation," said Mr Semple. "On one side was the Taliban and on the other the opposition."

In the past month the Taliban, a movement of religious students who seized Kabul in 1996, has led an offensive into the north, taking new ground and closing in on Taloqan, the administrative headquarters of the ousted government.

The Taliban's reclusive leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, said the drought was divine punishment for those who were not praying regularly and who failed to support the Islamic regime.

Alongside its latest military offensive, the Taliban has launched a new campaign to demand international recognition for its regime and prevent further sanctions.

Only Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates recognise the Taliban, while the ousted government still holds the country's seat at the UN in New York.

"Have mercy on the people of Afghanistan and give the United Nations seat to the true representatives of the people of Afghanistan whom the people like and support," the Taliban ambassador to Islamabad, Maulvi Mohammad Saeed Haqqani, said last week.

"Do not impose sanctions and bring more miseries for the people of Afghanistan."

The UN security council imposed financial and aviation sanctions on the Taliban regime in November and has threatened to introduce an arms embargo unless the latest round of fighting stops.

But a report from the UN office which provides aid in the country has warned that Afghanistan is too vulnerable to face economic sanctions, and that most people are already surviving at near subsistence levels.

fields.headline: Philippine rebels free five hostages
fields.trailText: Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines yesterday freed five of the 12 western hostages they have been holding for months, reportedly in exchange for $1m (£670,000) for each captive.
fields.body:
Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines yesterday freed five of the 12 western hostages they have been holding for months, reportedly in exchange for $1m (£670,000) for each captive.

The Abu Sayyaf rebels said the remaining prisoners, including a Malaysian and 12 Filipinos, would be released by next Friday. However, that is far from certain, as many such promises have been made since the crisis began on April 23, when the rebels seized 21 people from the Malaysian resort island of Sipadan and took them to their base on Jolo.

The five released yesterday include three French women, one South African woman and a German whose wife had been released in July after falling sick.

For four of those released, the sense of joy and relief at being freed was tempered by the loved ones or colleagues they had to leave behind in the hands of the Abu Sayyaf.

They were flown by helicop ter to the city of Zamboanga, on Mindanao island, where they met their respective ambassadors. Then, clutching their few personal possessions in rice sacks, they flew north to Cebu in the central Philippines. There, a jet belonging to Libya, representatives of which facilitated their release and paid the ransom, was waiting to fly them to Tripoli.

The freed German, Werner Wallert, 57, had to be torn away from his son Marc, one of the remaining prisoners, according to one of the intermediaries who escorted the group out of the Abu Sayyaf base. He said the father and son argued about who should go free.

The others released were a South African, Monique Strydom, who left behind her husband Carel, and three Frenchwomen, Sonia Wendling, whose boyfriend Stephane Loisy is still a prisoner, Marie Moarbes, and Maryse Burgot.

Ms Burgot was part of a French television crew that was kidnapped on July 9 while covering the story. The two remaining members of the team are still being held, as are two Finns and 12 Filipino evangelists who went into the Jolo jungle in July to pray for the captives, only to become hostages themselves.

The Philippine government's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, expressed his relief at yesterday's events, but said the crisis was not yet over.

"We are happy for the families and also for the countries and also for the Philippines," he said. "But there is still a lot of work to be done. We are not going to stop until we have been successful in releasing all of them."

Abu Sayyaf leaders had refused to release all their prisoners at once because they feared reprisals from the thousands of Philippine soldiers currently based on Jolo.

It is an open secret that, despite official denials, Libya arranged ransoms of $1m for each hostage and agreed to fund development projects in the impoverished southern Philippines.

In Tripoli, the freed hostages are expected to meet the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy.

webTitle: Ministers accused in Hungary's £220m oil rip-off

fields.headline: Ministers accused in Hungary's £220m oil rip-off
fields.standfirst: MPs, police and businessmen implicated in illegal trade
fields.trailText: Nine years after the first oil-stained banknotes reached the coffers of mafia-style gangs in Hungary, the investigation into the country's biggest corruption scandal is proceeding at a snail's pace.
fields.body:
Nine years after the first oil-stained banknotes reached the coffers of mafia-style gangs in Hungary, the investigation into the country's biggest corruption scandal is proceeding at a snail's pace.

According to the most far-reaching - some say far-fetched - allegations made by Zsolt Nogradi, a former member of the "oil-mafia", as he calls himself, 130 MPs, 365 entrepreneurs, one current minister and several former ministers have mafia contacts and were involved with illegal oil deals.

Mr Nogradi's allegations were made to an ad-hoc committee of parliament, set up to investigate the oil business, and were repeated in a subsequent television interview.

The committee's work is handicapped by conflict and distrust. Its president, the Independent Smallholders' party MP Laszlo Pallag, stands accused of slandering the interior minister and former national police chief, Sandor Pinter, and of keeping important information from other committee members.

And his "star-witness", Mr Nogradi, may now be subject to criminal charges from the public prosecutor's office for making false accusations.

The fallout has been damaging. According to one recent poll, only 20% of Hungarians believe that a large part of the truth will ever be known. And 49% find the allegations that leading politicians named in the affair are guilty, "credible" or "largely credible".

The oil scandal has centred on the illegal practices of "blonding" and "mixing". A third issue, involving the sale of arms and oil to Yugoslavia in breach of the UN embargo, is the least-investigated so far.

Diesel oil and heating oil are chemically almost identical, but from 1991 to 1995, heating oil enjoyed a far lower import duty. It came into Hungary in vast quantities by train, mainly from Romania and Russia.

To prevent its resale as diesel, a red dye was added to each wagon. But when supervising customs officers left, sulphuric acid was added, causing the red colouring to disappear - the so-called "blonding". Another chemical then caused the sulphuric acid to evaporate.

According to official estimates, the economy has lost £220m and the scam may be continuing.

When the import tax on heating oil was increased to the same level as diesel, "mixing" began. Various oil-based lubricants, each with a low import duty, were brought into the country, adulterated and resold.

Former Hungarian secret agents from the communist era are believed to have set up illegal businesses with their former colleagues from the KGB. The resulting criminal networks have proved extremely hard for the new police forces to crack.

The mafia are alleged to have bribed police officers, especially in Bekes county in south-eastern Hungary, bordering Romania, where the oil scandal originated.

"I still hope that the whole truth will be uncovered," a member of the parliamentary ad-hoc committee, the Hungarian Democratic Forum MP Laszlo Balogh, told the Guardian yesterday. "What has already been achieved is that no member of the oil-mafia can sleep peacefully."

He said the case had eroded public confidence in top officials. "The population has been made to believe that ministers are untrustworthy," he said, citing in particular Mr Nogradi's testimony, which he alleged was concocted by sources connected to the oil mafia.

Mr Balogh said that none of the documents which he had read had supported the allegations. He also feared that the media was being manipulated by organised crime - a view echoed by the embattled interior minister.

Mr Pinter - one of those named by Mr Nogradi - has suggested that the media have been infiltrated, with cars given to certain journalists as gifts. Mr Nogradi's most damaging interview was broadcast by the commercial channel, RTL Klub, which denies any such connections. Mr Nogradi also denies these allegations.

The public prosecutor, Peter Polt, now has a staff of 10 working full-time on the case. Last week he told a special session of parliament debating the oil affair that he had quashed investigations into leading officials for lack of evidence.

webTitle: From Greece to Corsica, wildfires take hold

fields.headline: Europe ablaze
fields.standfirst: From Greece to Corsica, wildfires take hold
fields.trailText: A state of emergency has been declared on the Greek island of Corfu as wildfires continue to burn throughout the Balkans and many Mediterranean regions.
fields.body:
A state of emergency has been declared on the Greek island of Corfu as wildfires continue to burn throughout the Balkans and many Mediterranean regions.

Blazes in the island's central mountainous region follow major outbreaks on mainland Greece. However, a Foreign Office spokesman says the holiday island is safe for British tourists.

Firefighters on the mainland are facing an uphill battle against a new fire along the border with Macedonia which threatens to spread into Greece, which has had its worst fire season in decades.

Areas near the Albanian border and in the southern Arcadia region remain in a state of emergency.

Croatia has closed sections of the Adriatic coastal road near Dubrovnik as firefighters struggle to contain blazes that have consumed hundreds of hectares of forest and brush, threatening coastal villages and resorts.

One volunteer firefighter has died and several have been injured in recent days.

Fire has engulfed several hundred hectares of pine forest and scrub in the hills 25 miles south-east of Podgorica, the capital of Yugoslavia's smaller republic, Montenegro.

The authorities on Corsica evacuated 30 people during the night from the village of Vivario when fires began to threaten homes. At least 10 fires were burning yesterday and more looked set to break out in strengthening winds.

fields.headline: Brussels for the birds
fields.standfirst:
They get better treatment there than here

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: This weekend, thousands of people will have been strolling over the heaths of Dorset and the New Forest, admiring the rare heather, birds - such as the Dartford warbler - insects and reptiles for whom such heathland is their only habitat. But it is unlikely that many will understand the vulnerability of such pockets of England's natural heritage.
fields.body:
This weekend, thousands of people will have been strolling over the heaths of Dorset and the New Forest, admiring the rare heather, birds - such as the Dartford warbler - insects and reptiles for whom such heathland is their only habitat. But it is unlikely that many will understand the vulnerability of such pockets of England's natural heritage.

Over the last 100 years, England has lost 80% of its lowland heaths. The system of sites of special scientific interest (SSSIs) has protected rare habitats like these which have managed to survive being covered over with concrete and tarmac. But it never had the powers to ensure the sites were managed properly. In terms of conservation, SSSIs were never more than a half-way house, failing to prevent neglect and damage from intensive agriculture. Heathlands become woods unless they are regularly grazed, mown or burnt. This loophole risked making a mockery of the attempt at conservation of British wildlife. That is why bodies such as the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds have campaigned for over a decade for tougher legislation.

Now concern is growing that the countryside and rights of way bill, which was to deliver Labour's manifesto plans for protecting wildlife, is in danger. It is caught in a logjam of nearly 30 bills going through parliament and the fear is that it could get bogged down in debate over the 300-odd amendments tabled - many by landowning Conservatives concerned at right-to-roam measures. Conservationists are also worried that the government might axe the bill to slim the parliamentary agenda.

This made the government's announcement proposing 80 sites for European protection as special areas of conservation (SACs) so important. Under this tough European directive, SSSIs get the kind of protection and duty to manage that they need. Being an SSSI did not protect the Hatfield moors from peat extraction, but being an SAC will. Until the countryside and rights of way bill is passed, our wildlife is better protected by European legislation.

webTitle: Jospin ally set to quit over Corsica

fields.headline: Jospin ally set to quit over Corsica
fields.trailText: The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, already facing the loss of several leading cabinet members in the coming months, will meet his interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, early this week to discuss his future in the government.
fields.body:
The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, already facing the loss of several leading cabinet members in the coming months, will meet his interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, early this week to discuss his future in the government.

The meeting, announced yesterday by Mr Jospin's office, is widely expected to end with Mr Chevènement's resignation over the socialist prime minister's plans to give limited autonomy to the rebellious Mediterranean island of Corsica, which falls under the interior minister's remit.

But with as many as five other key ministers likely to quit the cabinet before general and presidential elections in 2002, Mr Jospin is expected to try to persuade his close friend and political ally to accept an alternative portfolio.

Leftwing politicians are also keen to keep Mr Chevènement on board, fearing that without such a heavyweight the "plural left" coalition of socialists, greens, communists and radical republicans that has ruled France since 1997 will lose a big part of its broad-based appeal.

But Mr Chevènement, whose slogan is that a minister "should either shut his mouth or resign", is unlikely to go quietly. He is opposed on principle to the Jospin accords for Corsica, which would give the island - in exchange for peace - limited rights to pass its own laws from 2004.

And since the murder of a leading nationalist earlier this month and a rash of bomb attacks on government buildings, he has repeatedly said it would be "impossible" for him to present the devolution plan to parliament.

The plain-speaking interior minister heads the tiny Mouvement des Citoyens party, which enshrines a radical republican, secular and Jacobin strain in French politics stemming from the 1789 revolution. France's national identity and integrity, it believes, outweigh any regional or European ties.

In the last 17 years, Mr Chevènement has twice resigned from government on principle: in 1983 as industry minister, over economic policies, and again in 1991 as defence minister over France's particiation in the Gulf war.

Mr Jospin faces the problem of replacing many of his cabinet heavyweights. On taking power three years ago, he said he wanted his ministers to work full-time, signalling an end to the common French practice of combining a big portfolio with the office of mayor in a large town.

Ahead of local elections next year, the justice minister, Martine Aubry, the star of Mr Jospin's cabinet, has said she will leave the government in October to campaign for the mayor's job in Lille. But with as many as five other key ministers likely to quit the cabinet before general and presidential elections in 2002, Mr Jospin is expected to try to persuade his close friend and political ally to accept an alternative portfolio. Leftwing politicians are also keen to keep Mr Chevènement on board, fearing that without such a heavyweight the "plural left" coalition of socialists, greens, communists and radical republicans that has ruled France since 1997 will lose a big part of its broad-based appeal. fields.headline: Straw and Pschitt
fields.trailText: I don't have a soft spot for gangsters, but no one should be punished for who they are. An illiberal home secretary has plenty to be ashamed of, but keeping an elderly human being imprisoned until his dying days (well beyond the tariff) for his own political welfare deserves contempt.
fields.body:
I don't have a soft spot for gangsters, but no one should be punished for who they are. An illiberal home secretary has plenty to be ashamed of, but keeping an elderly human being imprisoned until his dying days (well beyond the tariff) for his own political welfare deserves contempt.

Suzon Forscey-Moore
Campaign for A Fair Hearing

 For the record, I am a British taxpaying individual (despite spending nearly 300 days a year working overseas). My personal bank accounts are also here in Britain. I don't open my bank accounts to public scrutiny any more than any of your journalists open theirs.

Richard Branson
Chairman, Virgin Group

 So the US does not need the rest of the world (Hate mail from the US, August 25)? What on earth will they do without adequate car fuel, coffee and crack cocaine?

John Spencer
London

 Wouldn't it be fine if the US decommissioned at least one nuclear submarine (Submarine disaster, August 25) against an undertaking the Kursk will not be replaced?

Michael Hoare
London

 I have just returned from Angers where I discovered that Pschitt (the lemonade drink you said was not available) has returned to the supermarkets (Turning the tide, Travel, August 19). With its hint of nostalgia for lost youth, it apparently appeals to adults in their 30s and 40s. (I have a photograph of myself with a bottle taken on a St Malo campsite when I was 19).

Sue Neale
Oxford

 I have been learning Spanish at evening classes. Did the fact that I am a male to female transsexual help me get my top-grade GCSE (Letters, August 26)?

Krystyna Wiczkowska
Manchester

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A story on the Gulf Air crash, page 1, August 24, quoted an expert as saying that the airline had never suffered anything "as catastrophic as losing a plane". In fact, a Gulf Air Boeing 737 crashed in the United Arab Emirates desert in 1983 killing all on board including several British citizens.
fields.body:
A story on the Gulf Air crash, page 1, August 24, quoted an expert as saying that the airline had never suffered anything "as catastrophic as losing a plane". In fact, a Gulf Air Boeing 737 crashed in the United Arab Emirates desert in 1983 killing all on board including several British citizens.

Homophone corner: just another month, said the Finance Notebook, page 31, August 25, and Sir Richard Branson should land the lottery of his dreams: "Queue the dewy eyes and the perma-grin." Nice, but cue correction.

Page 1, the Listings, in our Clearing 2000 education supplement, August 18, said one reason for the declining popularity of language degrees was that fees often had to be found for four years, one spent abroad. To clarify, some courses entail full fees for the year abroad, some a proportion, and others (eg the Erasmus programme) no fees.

In a feature on Naples, page 4, Travel, August 19, it was inferred from an incident involving a cafe receipt that a police operation was in progress against possible gangster racketeering. In fact, police monitoring of such receipts is standard in Italy, the object being to ensure cafes pay their taxes in full.

A reader had doubts when an article headed Albatross faces extinction, Page 9, August 17, said that the largest of the species - the wandering albatross - could fly at up to 100mph. The bird's normal speed is 40-60mph; it can hit 100mph in a steep dive.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Foxed by the carnival
fields.trailText: Joseph Harker (The carnival is over, August 26) inserts confusion into his helpful article by the contrast between the Notting Hill of the Rachman era and the present "gentrification" and "rows and rows of property millionaires".
fields.body:
Joseph Harker (The carnival is over, August 26) inserts confusion into his helpful article by the contrast between the Notting Hill of the Rachman era and the present "gentrification" and "rows and rows of property millionaires".

Though the polarisation is now sharper, there was in the 50s a sharp division between the Hill - very wealthy in those days too - and Notting Dale, Latimer Road etc. In fact, the word "gentrification" was invented in Notting Hill by Ruth Glass in her 1959 study of north Kensington housing.

Rev Dr Kenneth Leech
St Botolph's Church, London
KenLeech@aol.com

 Hey Mista Harker, just before I catch my train to London from Wales to play mas' with my band, Dragons, I just had to email you. Obviously you are not a West Indian or you would know that Trinidadians come in all colours - even white(ish). Although I am presently living and working in the UK, my family come from sixth generation Trinis - as long back as the Africans who came (and who were also not indigenous to the Caribbean).

Leave us "trendy whites" alone - I have played mas' in carnival all my life - from when I was small in San Fernando, where my mom used to win prizes for her costumes and my grandmother wrote and painted anancy stories for us; to now in Notting Hill. It makes me so mad when you journos criticise a good fete - either because it is too full of trouble or because it is too "civilised". Let us enjoy ourselves - even if we are white, we are still Trinis!

Diana Plummer
Newport
diana@bachanal.demon.co.uk

 I have a proposal to liven carnival up again: the introduction of a fox hunt. An invasion of foxes has become the greatest problem of living in Notting Hill. Every morning I wake up to find bird cadavers, empty packets of pork scratchings, and mine-size holes in the flowerbeds. I called the Countryside Alliance, but they denied it was a conspiracy to instil fox-hatred amongst liberal anti-hunting metropolitans. I then called the Kensington and Chelsea council whose spokesman said they had "no active anti-fox units", and referred me to a 24-hour fox hotline for further information. This service warned me that, while I was entitled to shoot them as pests, other foxes would take their place.

An August bank holiday fox hunt would not only rid the area of these gorgeous pests, it would also bring controversy and edginess back to carnival. I'm looking for support from our MP, Michael Portillo.

Sebastian Doggart
London
sebdooggart@aol.com

fields.headline: Paper chase
fields.trailText: Your leader (24 August) contrasts the good news that the Macclesfield collection of Isaac Newton's papers is likely to go to Cambridge University with a less happy story of general neglect by the nation of its scientists.
fields.body:
Your leader (24 August) contrasts the good news that the Macclesfield collection of Isaac Newton's papers is likely to go to Cambridge University with a less happy story of general neglect by the nation of its scientists.

The mission of my organisation has been locating, cataloguing and finding permanent homes in UK repositories for the archives of British scientists. The archives of over 200 scientists have passed through our hands including those of 21 Nobel Laureates. This has been made possible by the generosity of scientists and their families, the support of the Royal Society and numerous funding bodies, and the cooperation of professional colleagues in archive repositories.

Peter Harper
National Cataloguing Unit for the Archives of Contemporary Scientists

fields.headline: Horse sense
fields.trailText: I was not around when the "last" horse butcher closed in 1938, but I do remember a shop in Leeds in 1969 that sold "horse meat for human consumption" (Where horse is harnessed à la carte, August 25). It was opposite the main Kirkgate market and was very popular with older people.
fields.body:
I was not around when the "last" horse butcher closed in 1938, but I do remember a shop in Leeds in 1969 that sold "horse meat for human consumption" (Where horse is harnessed à la carte, August 25). It was opposite the main Kirkgate market and was very popular with older people.

I bought fillet steak there once. It wasn't the taste that made me feel squeamish, just the fact that the meat was handled by assistants who wore pink rubber gloves and hacked chunks off. The outside was a rather lurid shade of emerald green. With so little attention to ambience there was no temptation to return; a shame as we would have cheerfully used the considerable saving in the student union bar.

Bernard Hull
Maidstone, Kent
