fields.headline: Sold to the highest bidder
fields.trailText: There are other profound changes going on in television beside the move to digital (The BBC in a digital age, August 26). Television is a key influence on social culture, yet what it provides is increasingly dominated by the Gadarene rush to grab viewers.
fields.body:
There are other profound changes going on in television beside the move to digital (The BBC in a digital age, August 26). Television is a key influence on social culture, yet what it provides is increasingly dominated by the Gadarene rush to grab viewers.

Stimulation television is the result - the biggest earthquakes, the worst car crashes, the tackiest jokes, the most intrusive flies on the wall. We deplore casual violence and laddism in the real world and then watch as television uses them as a marketing device to gather young viewers. What we are losing is the capacity of TV to set standards of quality, to inform and to contribute to a developed human culture.

These changes are not inevitable and have nothing to do with new technology. They are largely a result of the 1990 Broadcasting Act, which effectively removed quality thresholds from Independent Television and enabled franchises to be given on the basis of who paid the most for them. This TV was only about money and its executives now had the green light to do whatever was necessary to hold viewers attention long enough to sell them something.

So away with expensive investigative journalism like World in Action and in with lifestyle, chat and junk TV. These trends were all apparant at the television festival, where broadcasters met in seminars with titles such as Can the news be sexy?, Black viewers - who gives a shit?, Cocks on the box, and Dear as fuck: is TV drama a waste of money? (all as published in the festival programme). If this is the future they plan for us, be warned.

Dr Greg Philo
Glasgow University Media Unit
g.philo@virgin.net

 Just as we enter the era of globalisation and the knowledge society, the BBC seems in danger of moving back from giving us the full picture of the wider world in which we live. If it does go ahead with the decision to split BBC channels largely by genre, this would remove all but a tiny part of international current affairs, cultural and religious coverage from the most important public service channel. It would be following ITV's progressive dumping of similar programming.

3WE, a coalition of development, environmental and human rights charities, welcomes many aspects of the convergence of communications because of its potential to make new information and knowledge available. The fact is, however, that the opposite is happening. 3WE's research, accepted by the BBC, shows that over the last decade, factual programming on the developing world carried by the free-to-air channels fell by 50% (by 37% on BBC2, raising the question as to whether it could really be trusted as the repository for serious international programming).

Much of the coverage which remains is "wildlife wallpaper" - nature programmes which ignore the social and environmental context. More in-depth programmes are moving to the schedule margins.

The BBC channel split would accelerate these trends. 3WE and many other voluntary sector groups are arguing for public service objectives to be upheld across the broadcasting spectrum.

Malcolm Harper
Chair, 3WE

 The research you report (TV ad breaks 'over the limit', August 24) refers only to ITV and Sky One. Why did it not include BBC1 and BBC2, whose promotions and trailers have also reached unprecedented lengths? Is this a softening up process to get us used to commercial breaks for real at some time in the future?

Barry Pemberton
Bury, Lancs

fields.headline: Driving up insurance costs
fields.trailText: You state (Motorists face 25% rise in insurance, August 23) that this increase was partly due to "the Ogden and Woolf changes - the Law Commission's recommendation, made last year ... which means victims of car crashes can now claim for future care costs and potential loss of earnings".
fields.body:
You state (Motorists face 25% rise in insurance, August 23) that this increase was partly due to "the Ogden and Woolf changes - the Law Commission's recommendation, made last year ... which means victims of car crashes can now claim for future care costs and potential loss of earnings".

In fact, victims of all accidents (including car crashes) have always been able to claim for future care and loss of earnings. The "Woolf reforms" introduced last year (named after Lord Woolf's report) concern procedure, not the level of damages awards.

On the "Ogden" tables (actuarial tables for calculating future compensation awards), there have been some changes, including a House of Lords decision that altered some of the underlying assumptions as to use of these tables. The upshot is an increase in some awards for future care and loss of earnings. What the Law Commission recommended was that awards for "general damages" (compensation for pain and suffering and loss of amenity) be increased, but the court of appeal was swayed by the arguments of the insurance industry and declined except in the most severe cases.

Ian Cross
Bristol

 A 25% rise is forecast for those of us honest enough to insure. Why is there no campaign to remove untaxed vehicles from our roads? Remember, you need insurance to obtain a road fund licence. It would bring in the missing millions, both for the insurance companies and for the exchequer.

C Mowat
London

fields.headline: Copper-bottomed debt
fields.trailText: Mr Hernandez-Cata (Letters, August 25) writes that the IMF is looking for additional ways to reduce Zambia's debt burden. One way is to cancel Zambia's debt - but this doesn't suit the IMF or the World Bank.
fields.body:
Mr Hernandez-Cata (Letters, August 25) writes that the IMF is looking for additional ways to reduce Zambia's debt burden. One way is to cancel Zambia's debt - but this doesn't suit the IMF or the World Bank.

For them, it makes sense to reschedule rather than cancel debts to have continued access to the meagre budget of the Zambian government. And the IMF can give new loans to cover debt repayments, thus adding to Zambia's debt burden. Furthermore, aid money given by bilateral creditors can be used to pay off multilateral debts (in Zambia, 70% of donor aid was used for debt repayments in 1999, according to Citibank).

Straightforward cancellation would mean that the $225m owed by Zambia in 2001 and payments in the fu ture could instead be used to fight extreme poverty.

Lucy Matthew
Jubilee 2000
lmatthew@jubilee2000uk.org

 Ernesto Hernandez-Cata's apologia for the IMF's latest swindle in Zambia omits what I understand to be a key condition of their debt-related "loans"; namely the privatisation of Zambia's copper mines. Deprived of income from its prime natural resource, how will the Zambian state ever be able to repay the IMF without diverting funds from public services like health, education and housing?

The bigger the demonstrations in Prague at the end of September, the greater the embarrassment for Hernandez-Cata and his ilk.

Nick Grant
London

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Friends Provident, the country's second biggest mutual life assurer which is planning a stock market float, is believed to have received a takeover approach from Barclays bank worth more than £4bn.

The bill for decommissioning British Nuclear Fuel's Magnox power stations has risen by £1.5bn to almost £13bn, casting a longer shadow over the government's plans for part privatisation in two years time.

The BBC is considering building an internet portal to deliver programmes on a pay-per-view basis.

Sunday Business

Allied Domecq is believed to be seeking an alliance with its Swedish rival Vin & Sprit as part of its attempt to buy Seagram's drinks business, worth around £5bn.

The government has ordered an inquiry into the health risks to air passengers, looking at threats ranging from poor air quality to the possibility of exposure to toxins from jet engine lubricants.

SFI, the pub company which owns the Slug & Lettuce chain, is thought to be in talks to takeover the rival Break For the Border chain.

fields.headline: How corporations absolve their sins
fields.trailText: In the sixteenth century, rich individuals could be absolved of their sins by purchasing an indulgence from the church. The flagrant flogging of indulgences by the Pope to raise funds to build St Peter's in Rome led Martin Luther to nail his 95 theses to the church door in Wittenberg, unleashing the Reformation.
fields.body:
In the sixteenth century, rich individuals could be absolved of their sins by purchasing an indulgence from the church. The flagrant flogging of indulgences by the Pope to raise funds to build St Peter's in Rome led Martin Luther to nail his 95 theses to the church door in Wittenberg, unleashing the Reformation.

The practice has been revived by international non-governmental organisations. Today corporations can purchase indulgences - or partnerships, to use the new lexicon - from NGOs to absolve their sins of corporate irresponsibility.

Practitioners of partnerships hail these business-NGO relationships as the way forward. Cross-sector collaboration, they say, is the new paradigm in sustainable development. Even the UN and the World Bank have started partnership programmes with corporations. But what are the real consequences for the poor?

Many long-standing corporate campaigning groups argue that partnerships run counter to the objectives of NGOs and are not effective ininfluencing corporate social responsibility. The genetically modified food debate is a case in point. Despite a number of successful local partnerships with NGOs, Monsanto continued to develop its controversial "terminator" seed programme which, if implemented, could have had devastating effects on farmers in developing countries.

In some cases, corporations use the partnerships to influence NGO behaviour. One international development agency was approached by a large tobacco manufacturer proposing a partnership to help communities in the developing world. But there was a proviso: that the NGO stop funding an anti-tobacco campaign in Asia.

Many campaigning groups are increasingly worried that corporations are entering relations with well-known NGOs to lend legitimacy to their operations abroad.

NGO independence is crucial. But the dynamics of these partnerships diminish confrontation, opposition and transparency.

In the end, traditional campaigning tactics remain the best way to make corporations address their business practices. The exposure by pressure group Global Witness of De Beers and the role of the diamond industry in perpetuating conflict in Angola, for example, has had international ramifications. The entire industry has reassessed its operations. Greenpeace's direct action in GM crop trials eventually drove Monsanto to shelve the terminator technology.

The problem with partnerships lies not so much in the nature of the relationship as in in objectives. Despite the grand rhetoric, when it comes to negotiating the terms of the partnerships, there is a tendency to revert to fundamental organisational aims: reputation enhancement at the local and international level for the business and access to financial resources for the NGO. Hence, most NGOs give the responsibility for corporate partnerships to the fund-raising department, rather than to their advocacy department.

The protests of Seattle are the modern day equivalent of Luther's theses on the church door. And, as the invention of the printing press in the 15th century gave momentum to the Reformation, the internet is fuelling another reformation of civil society. Campaigners will use it to denounce those who sell indulgences without demanding the redress of social injustices.

 Kelly Currah is a policy officer with World Vision. The views expressed in the article are his own.

webTitle: Obituary: Sir Lynden Pindling, Bahamian politician

fields.headline: Sir Lynden Pindling
fields.standfirst: Politician who broke three centuries of white elite dominance in the Bahamas
fields.trailText: Politician who broke three centuries of white elite dominance in the Bahamas
fields.body:
In January 1967, when the Bahamas was still a British colony, the black population of Nassau, New Providence, and of the other 700 or so islands of the far-flung archipelago, danced with delight as the news seeped through of a famous election victory. By a whisker, black majority rule had arrived.

The stranglehold on power of the entrenched white elite, the so-called "Bay Street Boys" (named after Nassau's main business street), had been broken. For three centuries, they had dominated commercial and political life, and had been the mainstay of the "colour bar" that controlled most areas of Bahamian life.

The man responsible for this historic electoral win was Sir Lynden Pindling, leader of the Bahamas for 25 years - both before and after its independence in 1973 - known as "Black Moses", who has died aged 70. Always ready to use robust language to denounce first, British colonialism, and later, American imperialism as the political occasion demanded, he deployed his considerable charm to court British, European and American investment and business activity.

Most Bahamians overlooked his dictatorial manner (often accompanied by intense staring through a slow eye) and questionable business deals, as he transformed the prospects of his fellow blacks. By the time he was voted out of office, in 1992, GNP per capita was $12,000, second only to the Caymans in the English-speaking Caribbean.

The son of a retired policeman, he did well enough at school to go to London university, from where he graduated with a law degree in 1952. He was called to the Bar at Middle Temple in early 1953 and to the Bahamian Bar in the following August. On his return home, he joined the minority black-led Progressive Liberal Party (PLP), which had been only recently formed.

He was elected to the House of Assembly in 1956 on a limited franchise and unremittingly campaigned for universal suffrage, always delayed by the white elite. Male universal suffrage was conceded in 1962, when older women also got the vote.

Contrary to expectations, the United Bahamian Party (UBP), which had been created by the white elite to counter the PLP, won the 1962 elections, although the PLP polled a majority of votes. Crisis gripped the PLP leadership and Pindling became leader soon after. His platform was to insist on constitutional advancement, and universal suffrage for both sexes came in 1964. Despite growing prosperity, the British government reserved considerable powers to itself, and this provided a further target for Pindling.

At the 1967 election, he switched his electoral base from New Providence to Kemp's Bay, Andros Island, where accusations of corruption against members of the UBP, vigorous PLP campaigning and support from the sole representative of the Negro Labour Party resulted in Pindling becoming premier. Shock waves rippled through the Bahamas. Racial strife and economic collapse were predicted. In fact, the white elite soon learned they could live with a PLP government, which was similarly interested in promoting business, tourism and offshore finance.

Almost at once, Pindling insisted on constitutional change: the Assembly was dissolved and an election called in 1968 to ensure a mandate for change, which returned the PLP to power. Independence followed five years later. Thereafter, Pindling led the PLP to win five successive elections. The UBP collapsed and it took years of confusion before the Free National Movement (FNM) eventually emerged as the opposition party. Pindling paid particular attention to immigration, in the hope that black Bahamians would benefit. Yet successive clampdowns on illegal Haitian immigrants and strict work permit rules for (mainly white) expatriates had unforeseen effects. Wages rose, but not in line with skills.

Despite impressive industrial and other development, notably at Freeport on Grand Bahama Island, black (especially youth) unemployment stubbornly remained and investment was often being directed at capital-intensive rather than labour-intensive projects.

By the late 1970s, the Bahamas had become associated with drug trafficking and money laundering, being en route between south America and the United States. The FNM eventually focused on narcotic-related corruption in the PLP ministerial ranks. In 1983 - the year he was knighted - Pindling was accused in a US television programme of involvement in drug trafficking and was forced to launch a royal commission to investigate the claims against himself and the PLP. The commission found against several ministers but Pindling was cleared, although the report noted that his expenditure was eight times his declared income.

Confronted by an angry US government which threatened sanctions against the Bahamas, Pindling had to grant US law enforcement officials diplomatic immunity and free passage through the archipelago, plus access to the criminal secrets of offshore banks.

Gradually, the offshore industry was cleaned up. In 1985 a joint US-Bahamian operation in Bimini netted an incredible 34,000 tonnes of marijuana and 2,500 tonnes of processed cocaine .

Pindling sought political vengeance for his humiliation. The FNM opposition had urged cooperation with Washington. In the 1987 election campaign, he played both nationalist and racial cards to good effect. His opponents, he said, were traitors, concerned only to appease US and white interests and to degrade the black populace. The FNM was trounced and its leadership demoralised. But change was in the air. Former PLP minister Hubert Ingraham emerged as FNM leader and his party's image became more black-orientated.

By the early 1990s, the black population in New Providence in particular was severely affected by recession; then another scandal broke over the state-owned airline, Bahamasair, and the Pindling-headed Bahamas Hotel Corporation. In the 1992 election, the PLP was decisively defeated.

As leader of the opposition, Pindling fought a long rearguard action against inquiries involving his business affairs. Despite his legal difficulties, he gained comfort from the knowledge that the political magic associated with "Black Moses" remained very much alive. His offer to resign after the 1992 election was refused by the PLP rank and file, who revered him to the end.

He is survived by his wife, the former Marguerite McKenzie of Andros, and by his two sons and two daughters.

Sir Lynden Oscar Pindling, politician, born March 22 1930; died August 26 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Bunny Austin, British tennis player

fields.headline: Bunny Austin
fields.standfirst: The most admirable failure in the history of British tennis, and the last British man to reach the Wimbledon finals
fields.trailText: The most admirable failure in the history of British tennis, and the last British man to reach the Wimbledon finals
fields.body:
Henry Wilfred "Bunny" Austin, the most admirable failure in the history of British tennis, has died on his 94th birthday. Though in age he had hoped that Tim Henman might replace him, he still remained the last male British competitor to reach the finals at Wimbledon. Fred Perry won (for the third year running) in 1936; Austin lost in 1932 and 1938. At least he got there, and twice. He was also the man who introduced shorts to the game.

Austin enjoyed an idyllic middle-class childhood before the first world war. He lived with his parents and sister Phyllis in a large house with servants in South Norwood. He was nicknamed Bunny after a rabbit in a comic-strip called Wilfred. So keen was his father (whose own nickname was Wolf), that his son should become a sportsman that he seized the newborn infant from the doctor to check that his limbs were sound. Bunny accommodated these expectations at the earliest possible moment: he practised hitting tennis balls against his nursery wall, and joined Norhurst Tennis Club at the age of six.

At Repton School, he played for the cricket team, but tennis was his passion, and in 1921 he won the under-16 singles in the public schoolboys' tournament at Queen's. The following year he won the junior championships in the singles, doubles and mixed doubles, and in 1923 again won singles and doubles in the public schoolboys' tournament.

He had similar successes in 1924 and 1925: he representing England against America at Eastbourne, winning the Cambridge university singles, and reaching the men's doubles semi-finals in his first year at Wimbledon in 1926, all while still an undergraduate. Altogether, Austin reached the Wimbledon quarter- finals, or beyond, 10 times. Unseeded in 1929, he reached the semi-finals, losing to Jean Borotra of France. He was ranked ninth in the world by the year's end, and was seeded sixth at Wimbledon for the following three years.

In 1932, Austin, aged 25, dropped just three sets en route to his first finals - he was the first Englishman to reach them for a decade - only to be overwhelmed by the American Ellsworth Vines in three sets. Sixty-six years later, as a generous-minded and gracious nonagenarian, he recalled this defeat for the Guardian's Frank Keating in the nursing-home where he spent his last years: "Ellsworth wiped me off the court in 50 minutes. I was annihilated. It was 6-4, 6-2, 6-0 and he won the match with an ace."

Austin bounced back in 1933, was seeded fourth and reached the quarter-final, going out to Japan's Jiro Satoh. As Austin recalled: "It was the year I invented shorts. I found sweat-sodden cricket flannels were weighing me down, so my tailor ran up some prototype shorts." He also had his revenge on Vines, beating him 6-1, 6-1, 6-4 in Paris in the Davis Cup zone final. He and Fred Perry were national heroes, carried shoulder-high by cheering crowds on their return to Victoria Station.

Austin was used to such celebrity. In 1931 he had married actress Phyllis Konstam. She is now remembered only by a few avid Hitchcock film buffs, for roles in his 1928 silent comedy Champagne, his early, stodgy British talkie The Skin Game and his 1930 film, Murder. At the time, Konstam was feted and beautiful, Austin was a pin-up, and theirs was a celebrity wedding of 1931. They had met on a Cunard liner two years earlier as Austin was heading for the US Open at Forest Hills (in which he reached the last eight).

This gilded couple knew a galaxy of famous people; Bunny was a friend of Daphne du Maurier, Ronald Coleman and Michael, King of Romania, and he played tennis socially with Charlie Chaplin and the Queen of Thailand. (He found himself shouting "Run, your Majesty, run!" when they played doubles.) He met Queen Mary and President Roosevelt, and the future President Kennedy told him he had been a fan. The tennis ace Suzanne Lenglen insisted he play doubles with her.

At Wimbledon, Bunny's mixed doubles partners were Betty Nuthall and Joan Lycett, and, in 1934, Dorothy Shepherd Barron, with whom he reached the finals (a 0-6 third set defeat). In the men's doubles he never played again after his second round defeat of 1931, partnered by Charles Kingsley.

In the singles, however, he reached the quarter-finals year after year, peaking in 1935 with a respectable four-set defeat by Donald Budge, one of the game's all-time greats. It would be the longest Wimbledon singles match Budge ever played. That year, Austin was a semi-finalist in the French Championship and defeated Budge and Allison in the challenge round of the Davis Cup, which he and Perry were instrumental in retaining for Britain.

Seeded seventh, Bunny reached the semi-finals once again in 1936, going out to the German von Cramm, and the following year, now the British No 1, he repeated this result against the same opponent. He also reached the finals of the French.

In 1938 he met Budge again, this time in the Wimbledon final. He won only four games. "Donald was unstoppable that afternoon," Austin remembered half a century on - adding, characteristically: "He was a true great. It was an honour just to be on the same court." The following year was Austin's last as a Wimbledon competitor. Seeded No 1, he went out to the American sixth seed Elwood Cooke in straight sets, after beating future champion (and future Briton) Jaroslav Drobny in round three.

It was not the end of the story. Despite their celebrity and famous friends, Bunny and Phyllis had been drawn toward the Oxford Group and Moral Rearmament, and worked for this cause from the early 1930s; during the war, they went to America to promote it. Peter Ustinov, who knew Austin, wrote that he was "disgracefully ostracised by the All-England Club because he was a conscientious objector". Austin had been a Club member since 1925, yet on his return to Britain in 1961, he was told his membership had "been lapsed". They restored it when he was 77 years old; Austin noted: "In 1984, 40 years after getting rid of me, they suddenly let me back in and [were] all very nice to me."

Austin, whose autobiography A Mixed Double was published in 1969, and his wife devoted the rest of their lives to Moral Rearmament, travelling the world to promote the cause. They were particularly involved in the MRA's Westminster Theatre, where a production about their life, Love All, was staged.

Henry Wilfred "Bunny" Austin, tennis player, born August 26, 1906; died August 26 2000
fields.bodyText: Henry Wilfred "Bunny" Austin, the most admirable failure in the history of British tennis, has died on his 94th birthday. Though in age he had hoped that Tim Henman might replace him, he still remained the last male British competitor to reach the finals at Wimbledon. Fred Perry won (for the third year running) in 1936; Austin lost in 1932 and 1938. At least he got there, and twice. He was also the man who introduced shorts to the game. Austin enjoyed an idyllic middle-class childhood before the first world war. He lived with his parents and sister Phyllis in a large house with servants in South Norwood. He was nicknamed Bunny after a rabbit in a comic-strip called Wilfred. So keen was his father (whose own nickname was Wolf), that his son should become a sportsman that he seized the newborn infant from the doctor to check that his limbs were sound. Bunny accommodated these expectations at the earliest possible moment: he practised hitting tennis balls against his nursery wall, and joined Norhurst Tennis Club at the age of six. At Repton School, he played for the cricket team, but tennis was his passion, and in 1921 he won the under-16 singles in the public schoolboys' tournament at Queen's. The following year he won the junior championships in the singles, doubles and mixed doubles, and in 1923 again won singles and doubles in the public schoolboys' tournament. He had similar successes in 1924 and 1925: he representing England against America at Eastbourne, winning the Cambridge university singles, and reaching the men's doubles semi-finals in his first year at Wimbledon in 1926, all while still an undergraduate. Altogether, Austin reached the Wimbledon quarter- finals, or beyond, 10 times. Unseeded in 1929, he reached the semi-finals, losing to Jean Borotra of France. He was ranked ninth in the world by the year's end, and was seeded sixth at Wimbledon for the following three years. In 1932, Austin, aged 25, dropped just three sets en route to his first finals - he was the first Englishman to reach them for a decade - only to be overwhelmed by the American Ellsworth Vines in three sets. Sixty-six years later, as a generous-minded and gracious nonagenarian, he recalled this defeat for the Guardian's Frank Keating in the nursing-home where he spent his last years: "Ellsworth wiped me off the court in 50 minutes. I was annihilated. It was 6-4, 6-2, 6-0 and he won the match with an ace." Austin bounced back in 1933, was seeded fourth and reached the quarter-final, going out to Japan's Jiro Satoh. As Austin recalled: "It was the year I invented shorts. I found sweat-sodden cricket flannels were weighing me down, so my tailor ran up some prototype shorts." He also had his revenge on Vines, beating him 6-1, 6-1, 6-4 in Paris in the Davis Cup zone final. He and Fred Perry were national heroes, carried shoulder-high by cheering crowds on their return to Victoria Station. Austin was used to such celebrity. In 1931 he had married actress Phyllis Konstam. She is now remembered only by a few avid Hitchcock film buffs, for roles in his 1928 silent comedy Champagne, his early, stodgy British talkie The Skin Game and his 1930 film, Murder. At the time, Konstam was feted and beautiful, Austin was a pin-up, and theirs was a celebrity wedding of 1931. They had met on a Cunard liner two years earlier as Austin was heading for the US Open at Forest Hills (in which he reached the last eight). This gilded couple knew a galaxy of famous people; Bunny was a friend of Daphne du Maurier, Ronald Coleman and Michael, King of Romania, and he played tennis socially with Charlie Chaplin and the Queen of Thailand. (He found himself shouting "Run, your Majesty, run!" when they played doubles.) He met Queen Mary and President Roosevelt, and the future President Kennedy told him he had been a fan. The tennis ace Suzanne Lenglen insisted he play doubles with her. At Wimbledon, Bunny's mixed doubles partners were Betty Nuthall and Joan Lycett, and, in 1934, Dorothy Shepherd Barron, with whom he reached the finals (a 0-6 third set defeat). In the men's doubles he never played again after his second round defeat of 1931, partnered by Charles Kingsley. In the singles, however, he reached the quarter-finals year after year, peaking in 1935 with a respectable four-set defeat by Donald Budge, one of the game's all-time greats. It would be the longest Wimbledon singles match Budge ever played. That year, Austin was a semi-finalist in the French Championship and defeated Budge and Allison in the challenge round of the Davis Cup, which he and Perry were instrumental in retaining for Britain. Seeded seventh, Bunny reached the semi-finals once again in 1936, going out to the German von Cramm, and the following year, now the British No 1, he repeated this result against the same opponent. He also reached the finals of the French. In 1938 he met Budge again, this time in the Wimbledon final. He won only four games. "Donald was unstoppable that afternoon," Austin remembered half a century on - adding, characteristically: "He was a true great. It was an honour just to be on the same court." The following year was Austin's last as a Wimbledon competitor. Seeded No 1, he went out to the American sixth seed Elwood Cooke in straight sets, after beating future champion (and future Briton) Jaroslav Drobny in round three. It was not the end of the story. Despite their celebrity and famous friends, Bunny and Phyllis had been drawn toward the Oxford Group and Moral Rearmament, and worked for this cause from the early 1930s; during the war, they went to America to promote it. Peter Ustinov, who knew Austin, wrote that he was "disgracefully ostracised by the All-England Club because he was a conscientious objector". Austin had been a Club member since 1925, yet on his return to Britain in 1961, he was told his membership had "been lapsed". They restored it when he was 77 years old; Austin noted: "In 1984, 40 years after getting rid of me, they suddenly let me back in and [were] all very nice to me." webTitle: Exchange merger vote to be delayed

fields.headline: Exchange merger vote to be delayed
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange will delay next month's vote on its controversial merger with Deutsche Börse, its German rival, amid accusations that it is keeping key information from its shareholders.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange will delay next month's vote on its controversial merger with Deutsche Börse, its German rival, amid accusations that it is keeping key information from its shareholders.

Facing one of the bleakest periods in its 200-year history, the exchange is this week expected to receive a hostile takeover bid worth £800m from OM Gruppen, the Swedish company which owns the Stockholm bourse and which tried to clinch a friendly merger with its London rival last week.

Leading shareholders in the London exchange now intend to use the OM bid to exert pressure on the exchange's beleaguered management to renegotiate the terms of the merger with the Deutsche Börse or call in a white-knight bid from Nasdaq, the US-based exchange for high technology stocks.

The London exchange, which stunned the City by slipping out news of the audacious approach late on Friday, rejected the £27-per-share bid, describing it as "derisory" and a "spoiling tactic" ahead of the September 14 vote of its shareholders on its proposed merger with Deutsche Börse of Frankfurt.

That vote will be delayed, either reluctantly by the stock exchange's management or under the instruction of officials at the takeover panel once the OM offer is formally made.

The delay will placate the exchange's shareholders, particularly the scores of smaller stockbroking firms which have been outraged by the Anglo-German merger plan to move trading in smaller companies' shares and hi-tech stocks to Frankfurt.

Abbey National, one of the largest shareholders in the exchange since its demutualisation earlier this year, last night indicated it was unlikely to support the OM bid but hoped it would improve the terms of any deal for London.

"The German proposals are ill-conceived. I hope it leads to a better deal for the stock exchange, with the Germans or with Nasdaq," said Gareth Jones, chief executive of Abbey National's treasury arm. "I also hope the stock exchange will be more open with its shareholders."

The announcement of the bid by OM prompted calls yesterday for the London exchange to give more details about any other bids it has received, widely believed to have come from a European alliance led by the Paris Borse and also from Nasdaq.

The London exchange would say little yesterday, other than to "welcome" the support it had received from its German partner, the Deutsche Börse. The German exchange indicated over the weekend that it would be prepared to alter the merger terms if it were able to prevent OM taking over the London exchange.

After failing to win agreement for its offer from the London exchange's management last week, OM is expected to approach the exchange's shareholders directly in an attempt to win support for its £27 per share offer, which is also expected to be increased.

 Per Larsson, the 39-year-old chief executive of OM Gruppen, has kept a low profile since launching his audacious bid for the London Stock Exchange.

Other than describing the London exchange's plan to merge with its German rival as "flawed" and expressing his determination to offer a better alternative, Mr Larsson has said nothing.

No doubt gagged by his banking advisers at Lazards ahead of his widely expected approach direct to the London exchange's shareholders this week, Mr Larsson and OM Gruppen have barely registered in the City before now.

Backed by the wealthy Wallenberg family, OM was set up 1985 and has a stock market listing in Stockholm, where it is based, and a market value of £2.5bn. Almost 10 years ago, it set up a derivatives exchange in London, called OMLX, and also trades electicity. It also provides the trading systems used by a number of exchanges around the world, including those in Hong Kong, Australia and the US as well as owning Stockholm's stock exchange.

This year, OM's biggest step into the international arena was made when it set up Jiway, an electronic market, with US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

In the past, Mr Larsson has scorned the idea of mergers and alliances between exchanges to form a pan European stock market like the one intended by the Anglo-German alliance. Instead, he has predicted that technology will be driving force.

This may explain why thrust of OM's approach to the London Stock Exchange is understood to be based on the quality of its technology - an area which has caused repeated problems for London.

fields.headline: Conspicuous by their absence
fields.standfirst:
Work Unlimited
It won't be news to many, but at least it's official - when the PA's away, the office suffers. By Dolly Dhingra
fields.trailText: It won't be news to many, but at least it's official - when the PA's away, the office suffers. By Dolly Dhingra.
fields.body:
If youÍre taking today off, and wondering how colleagues are coping without you, a recent survey, conducted by Parcelforce Worldwide, might confirm certain suspicions. Its findings reveal that the vast majority of UK offices and workers encounter disruptions in the smooth running of day-to-day business when PAs and administrative staff are absent. Whether itÍs a bank holiday, the odd sickie or the secretaryÍs regular two weeksÍ annual leave soaking up the sun, the effects are obvious Ü the office just isnÍt the same without them.

For the 625 people interviewed, the biggest source of office difficulties related to the typing and creation of documents, with 24% of interviewees insisting that things go haywire when their admin assistants are away.

As Rose Bentham, 40, PA to Brian Potiphar, UK sales and marketing director of Masterfil, explains, ñWhen IÍm away, my boss will approach the PC, but he types only with two fingers. His skills are limited and although heÍll open and close documents and work on them, he would rarely venture out to try any packages other than the ones he knows.î

ñMy boss would have problems with presentation of documents when IÍm away,î says Marsha Kemp, team PA to PR company the GCI Group. ñHe relies on me making things look pretty, but when IÍm not around he doesnÍt have a clue as to how itÍs done.î

Surprisingly, perhaps, itÍs not only the old carbon-copying cronies who are having difficulties with new technology: 44% of 16- to 24-year-olds said they would be at a loss around their PCs without the aid of a secretary to act as an intermediary.

To be fair, the mysteries of computer systems have confused us all at some point. But, for 17% of workers, the upkeep of diaries proved just too difficult without secretarial intervention, and a further 10% claimed they had problems with the post. What is going on when those at the top can run multimillion-pound industries yet lack the nous to lick a stamp?

Kemp feels she has an answer. She believes that bosses often develop a dependency on their staff Ü which doesnÍt mean that they canÍt fulfil straightforward tasks, but rather that they prefer not to. ñThey act a bit thick sometimes because they consider secretarial duties to be menial tasks and because they are paid to do more important things,î she says. ñThey donÍt want to waste their time sending out faxes or spending hours on end in the photocopying room like I do.î

Knowing how much you are needed in the workplace is always good for the ego Ü but make sure that what seems like a confidence boost does not backfire. This kind of dependency can result in PAs worrying incessantly about the office while they are supposed to be a world away from such routine cares. Setting boundaries Ü and keeping to them Ü is increasingly important in a society where work can too easily infiltrate every area of our lives.

Karen Haddon, who has worked as a PA for a number of high flying bosses for over 15 years, currently works for the managing director of Aggregate Industries UK, manufacturers of quarrying products. She knows the dangers of not feeling able to hand over responsibility during her time off. ñIn the early days I used to get little panic attacks while I was on holiday, worrying that I hadnÍt done one thing or another,î she explains.

ñBut now IÍm a lot better, and my method of coping is simple. I run through every eventuality in my mind and make sure I leave notes for both the boss and the girls in the office. I always leave a contact number in case of a dire emergency but I expect a boss to respect my privacy so I wouldnÍt expect him to call me unless it was really serious. If you want a relaxing holiday it is necessary to forward plan and be organised,î she says.

Interestingly, 82% of female bosses admitted to feeling lost without their assistants, compared with 75% of male bosses Ü but it would be sensible to bear in mind that women are perhaps more likely to admit to problems, and also that they are better at delegating.

As Haddon explains, ñI worked for one female boss who was incredibly high powered Ü and she was a great deal tougher than many of the male bosses that I had worked for Ü but she was able to ask me to do things that the men didnÍt. She had absolutely no problem saying something like, ïIÍve got a meeting this evening and I havenÍt got the right dress to wear, could you help me out?Í It wasnÍt that we were girlies together, it was just that she was able to be less formal with me.î

It would be comforting, then, to assume that bosses miss their PAs for their company, advice and general capability around the office. Alas, no. An alarming 1% of the surveyÍs respondents said they missed their secretaries making them cups of tea Ü proving that there are still traces of the Neanderthal in the workplace. Reason enough for any PA to switch off completely and enjoy the rest of the bank holiday.

fields.headline: Hardcore's nasty glory
fields.standfirst:
Pulp
The Corn Exchange, Edinburgh ****
fields.trailText:
Pulp
The Corn Exchange, Edinburgh ****
fields.body:
You expect the unexpected with Pulp. Just when we'd all finally grown to love those bittersweet, poppy songs, they turned hardcore on us with that dark last album of existential brooding. At the Corn Exchange, things were stranger still. There was a sheep pen outside, with sheep in it, for starters. The venue itself, tiny and odd like a 1940s dancehall, had what appeared to be a toiletries tombola stall at the entrance. In fact, they were confiscating aerosols and sticking raffle tickets on them. It's amazing how many people carry deodorant with them to a Pulp gig.

Then there was the shortish set, two thirds taken from This is Hardcore, the remainder peppered with the ones the crowd really wanted to hear like Babies, Sorted for Es and Wizz, and Do You Remember the First Time.

And some of it sounded rather marvellous. This is Hardcore was all twisted, nasty glory; Party Hard was lifted by the live performance into something much stronger than the album track. The Day After the Revolution, with Jarvis against a backdrop of an open sky, felt a bit like that. For a second or two. While the crowd tried to work out how to dance to all these tunes that lend themselves more to being listened to, prone, in a room with the curtains drawn on a sunny day, there was no stopping Jarvis. Gone are the small, quirky dance moves; he scrabbles wildly like he's running up an invisible ladder.

It's brave not to rely on Common People any more. It's braver still to have felt The Fear, done it anyway, and to play it instead of Something Changed. Something did, and live at least, the results still enthral.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival theatre review:  War of the Worlds

fields.headline: Poisoned Welles
fields.standfirst:
War of the Worlds
Edinburgh Lyceum *

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
War of the Worlds
Edinburgh Lyceum *
fields.body:
So Orson Welles was a showman who could never stop acting out the myth he had created, and whose career strangely resembled the plot of his own Citizen Kane. There is nothing new, then, that New York's SITI company can tell us in this awkward biopic.

Written by Naomi Iizuka, War of the Worlds is a whistle-stop review of Welles's career. Conceived and directed by Anne Bogart, the production also contemplates the parallels and differences between theatre and cinema, and between performance and life. But the show clumsily spoon-feeds us its insights. It starts out with the creakingly facile device of having Welles investigated post-mortem by a group of reporters who have just watched the newsreel of his life - just like Charlie Kane all over again.

Hammering the point home repeatedly, Stephen Webber's Welles announces, "I'm a kind of theatre unto myself - always playing a character." The tricks of staging are not so bravura as simplistic and irritating, and the bustling "hooray for Hollywood" routines would look hackneyed in a West End musical. Webber is jowly and basso-voiced enough for Welles, but there is none of the self-mocking farceur's gravitas, and he comes across more as a swaggering matinee idol.

As a self-conscious commentary on art and illusion, the production feels like a nasty case of theatre folk condescending towards that rather primitive medium, cinema, and finding it quite interesting after all.

fields.trailText: If football took a leaf out of cricket's book and promoted and relegated a third of its division, it would be a different game, imagines Will Buckley.
fields.body:
We should expect the unexpected. Snow in August; Tiger Woods's caddie in line to be New Zealand's sportsman of the year - well, he has earned more money than the rest; Craig the Scouser being voted the most popular inhabitant of the Big Brother house - well, no, there is no explanation

What is surprising is the expected. For instance, the fact that the football season is two Saturdays old and already the bulimic game is threatening to overshadow all else. There has been more written on Wenger, Vieira and Poll than the entire County Championship. And this at a time when the cricket season is reaching a thrilling conclusion.

One made all the more exciting by the three-up, three-down system in operation. Such a system is fine if you have 20 or so clubs in a league, but really comes into its own when it is applied to a nine-team competition. Somerset are currently top of the one-day competition and could still be relegated. That's pressure.

To explain this to those that only football know, if applied to their game it would involve a seven-up, seven-down system. (I realise that strictly it should be six and two-thirds, and I realise that some time in the future Sky will probably demand that two-thirds of a team be relegated and then ask their viewers to call a premium-rate phone-line to vote out the defence, midfield or attack, but let's settle for seven.)

If this had been in use since the Premiership began it would have led to some fine results. In 1992-93, defending champions Leeds would have been relegated and Portsmouth, Swindon and Millwall among those promoted. Next year Everton would have gone down and Notts County would have gone up. 'Two founder members of the Football League exchange places in the most thrilling denouement football has ever seen' is how Richard Keys might understate it.

And so it would go on. Reading for Villa in 1995. Crystal Palace and Stoke City promoted in 1996. Even Wolves would have gone up. What's more, those perennial relegation suspects - Coventry and Southampton - would have been demoted years ago.

All this action would add greatly to the merriment of football fans. Pretty much every Premiership match could be billed as a battle for Europe or a struggle against the drop.

There would be 760 six-pointers every season, which should be sufficient for even the most addicted thrill-seeker. Keys might, after a season or two at such a rate, run out of hyperbole.

Naturally, the managers would complain. But they always do. And I'd much rather listen to Wenger fretting about being in the relegation zone than moaning 'after this week, you would have thought I killed three people'.

fields.headline: Tales from the Tabs
fields.trailText: VIEIRA: JUVE UP BID Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein has admitted that Patrick Vieira could quit Highbury for Italy after Juventus strengthened their interest. 'Patrick is very, very distraught at his treatment by referees,' says Dein. 'And this is a player who everybody would like in their side. We want him to stay, but he's only human.'
fields.body:
VIEIRA: JUVE UP BID Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein has admitted that Patrick Vieira could quit Highbury for Italy after Juventus strengthened their interest. 'Patrick is very, very distraught at his treatment by referees,' says Dein. 'And this is a player who everybody would like in their side. We want him to stay, but he's only human.'

YOU'RE DESTROYING HIM John Gregory last night accused Chelsea of destroying Gareth Southgate by failing to make a firm bid to sign him. 'This has been going on for nearly four months, and it's wearing Gareth down mentally,' says Gregory. 'They've put us and him under siege. Ken Bates and Gianluca Vialli should put up or shut up.'

BENT'S BIG BUST-UP Marcus Bent has told Sheffield United he wants out after the club withdrew a new contract offer. 'It's only fair the supporters know what's going on,' says Bent. The news has alerted a host of Premiership and Division One clubs: Wimbledon, Derby, Manchester City, Crystal Palace and Sunderland lead the chase.

Sylvain Wiltord arrived in London last night to complete his Arsenal medical: a £13m fee was agreed on Friday, personal terms are being discussed

Sunderland and Middlesbrough have made new moves for Aston Villa's Ugo Ehiogu - Peter Reid enquired again after Stanislav Varga picked up a knee injury

Bradford are leafing through offers for Isiah Rankin and Robbie Blake after clubs reacted quickly to the pair's transfer-listing. 'We've named our price of £1.5m for Blake and £1.3m for Rankin,' says chairman Geoffrey Richmond. 'That's what they'll go for'

Charlton are close to finalising a £1m deal with Tivoli Gardens for long-time target Ricardo Fuller

Gianluca Vialli has laughed off reports of a late Chelsea bid to scupper Steve McManaman's move to Middlesbrough - 'He is an excellent player, but we have enough of those'

Colin Hendry is set to quit Coventry after being told he no longer has a guaranteed first-team spot

Birmingham's move for Derby's Dean Sturridge has stalled after Trevor Francis decided to eye up some other targets. 'I know what we want,' says Francis. 'but you cannot sign players on their name alone'

Everton could move again for Italian icon Roberto Baggio - Walter Smith still wants cover up front despite landing Duncan Ferguson. Gazza, meanwhile, has tipped himself for an England recall

Ipswich could spend again - George Burley's still chasing Southampton's Hassan Kachloul

Peter Risdale says Leeds fans won't stop emailing him: 'I've had lots of emails from fans urging me to spend money'

Leicester have offered wantaway Tony Cottee to QPR; Liverpool could beat Leicester to sign Wigan keeper Roy Carroll

Man City are ready to pay £1m for Ecuadorian trialist Ulises de la Cruz

Teddy Sheringham could stay even longer at Manchester United after Alex Ferguson offered him a new one-year deal - 'Teddy is one of those rare players who can continue long after others have retired,' says Fergie

Middlesbrough's Brian Deane is a target for Celtic - Martin O'Neill has £3m to spend on a striker

Newcastle have blocked another Arsenal move for Kieron Dyer - Arsène Wenger had offered an £8m package

Southampton are ready to sell striker James Beattie to Crystal Palace for £2m, but David Howells has been forced to quit through injury

Sunderland could sell Jody Craddock to Portsmouth after all - Peter Reid has reduced his £1.8m asking price

Spurs could make a late bid for Steve McManaman - Ernesto Bronchetti claims the England man 'has important offers from almost all of English soccer'

West Ham's Harry Redknapp says his summer transfer spending has finished: 'We can't buy until we sell, and I'm not going to sell.'

fields.headline: The Journalist
fields.trailText: English football is going backwards through standing still, believes Christophe Larcher
fields.body:
English football is going backwards. This summer no great player has signed for an English club and there are no new big stars. Where is the new Eric Cantona, Dennis Bergkamp, Gianfranco Zola or David Ginola? Thanks to them, English football improved, but now Cantona is gone and the others - who remain the big attractions in England - are old. If English football wants to improve again it needs players of quality at their peak. A young Bergkamp, not a thirtysomething Boksic.

Redondo and Veron prefer to play in the South of Europe not only because the food and the weather are more appealing. The Premiership has become less attractive than before because it is standing still. What is more, if you want to attract young technical players you must protect them.

To focus on Patrick Vieira is to avoid talking about the real problems of refereeing in England. In my opinion, it is the poorest in Europe because it is so inconsistent. I've watched some games where the referee is in control and talks a lot to the players, and others where there is no sensitivity and a lot of rash bookings. You can understand the players' frustration when somebody is punished for an innocuous challenge and the next day on television you see a dangerous tackle and the referee waves play on. Roy Keane was sent off in the Charity Shield for a terrible tackle, but I have seen that kind of thing go unpunished before in English football. I remember when Ian Wright could have broken Peter Schmeichel's leg with a moment of pure aggression but stayed on the field.

Sometimes I'm horrified when I see the brutal tackles that litter the Premiership. They are impossible in France, Spain or Italy. Football is too violent in England, but it is part of the culture. The crowd like men who fight, who try to win the ball with physical intensity, and fans applaud a great tackle - a reaction that doesn't exist in Mediterranean leagues. But the problem is that when it is done by a British player it is a fantastic challenge, yet when it is Vieira or Hamann it is a reckless foul.

Feeling victimised by referees was not the only reason Emmanuel Petit left the Premiership, but when you watch matches in Spain you see players can actually play football. They can pass, move, run, dribble. Look at Valencia, Barcelona and Real Madrid in last season's Champions League. Technicians like Raul, Redondo, Mendieta and Figo are fantastic players who have the space and atmosphere to play football without a fight. David Beckham would improve if he played in Spain because he would have more freedom.

Sometimes players get tired of fighting. Vieira is a great player and it's normal for lesser players to provoke him, but in fairness he has to learn to stop using his elbows. He can avoid that. Raul, for example, has his shirt pulled regularly but he manages to wait for the free-kick rather than react. Vieira is not a perfect French angel, but he is not a hooligan. If you know him he is a well-balanced, kind man. The shame is that he really loves English football - but six red cards in four years?

I expect he will stay this season because he won't abandon Arsène Wenger, but in the summer he might feel the time is right to leave. Every big club in Italy wants him. It would be detrimental to English football if he left. You would end up with games contested by British players and bad Europeans. A drain of premium talent, coupled with the unimpressive state of the national team, means England is at least five years behind the top echelons of European football.

fields.headline: World Cup gamble
fields.trailText: Football fans may, after all, have to find a pay-per-view fee to watch live TV coverage of another of England's World Cup qualifiers, reports Jon Henderson.
fields.body:
Football fans may, after all, have to find a pay-per-view fee to watch live TV coverage of another of England's World Cup qualifiers.

Facts emerging from negotiations to screen the match in Greece next June make it increasingly likely that it will join the Finland game in Helsinki on 11 October as the property of u>direct, the independent pay-per-view company who have dramatically raised the rights-buying stakes.

U>direct's £3 million splurge to secure the game in Finland - it will be shown on Sky Digital for a fee to viewers expected to be in the region of £10 - alerted agents to the possibility of the higher profits to be made trading England's World Cup qualifiers in the UK market.

Accordingly, CSI Octagon went 'very, very high' to outbid rival agents Ufa and Global Sportnet for the rights to the Greece-England game, which means that Sky and u>direct are probably the only outlets that will be interested in meeting what is certain to be a steep asking price. 'We retain an interest in acquiring the match,' a u>direct spokesman confirmed.

Both are likely to wait, though, to see how England start their World Cup campaign. A few poor results and CSI Octagon may wonder about the wisdom of their investment.

fields.headline: Said and Done
fields.trailText: Trainor taps talent
fields.body:
Trainor taps talent

Is this football's first agent/manager? Will he unsettle his own players? Shay Trainor, part of Mel Stein's iron-grip on the North-West, has been appointed boss of Timperley Bigshorts, a Manchester Amateur League side founded by comic Frank Sidebottom (right). 'Shay started with us as a player a couple of seasons ago,' says club secretary Simon Heywood. 'We promoted him from within. Being an agent, he's brought us loads of perks: a free Italian-made team strip via George Weah's agent, an under-16 Georgian international - Busco Cardone - who's now in Holland after playing a couple of times for us, Nike kit at cost price and hopefully he'll get some of his clients down here to take training soon. Jonathan Greening's quite keen.' Timperley's season begins next Sunday. Before then, Trainor's also planning visits from Wes Brown and Nicky Weaver, plus a fund-raising bash at a local pub with - he hopes - Weah as compere. And Trainor has already identified the first Timperley player who could make it into the big time. 'We've got the world kick-boxing champion here, Johnny Roye, who Shay reckons could play Third Division football if he put his mind to it. But he'll be here for a while - we only finished sixth last year, but this year we're going for it.' Bigshorts' crowds rarely pass 60: get down to a public park near you.

Drunk ref: they all hate me

The Russian referee sent home in disgrace last year after arriving from a Uefa Cup tie in Israel drunk and incapable has told the country's press to leave him alone. Sergei Khusainov, deported with three colleagues after landing at Tel Aviv's Ben-Gurion airport in a stupor the day before he was due to officiate Haifa v Club Bruges, initially claimed he had been set up by Russian enemies, 'who couldn't wait to see me sacked'. Now, though, a year on, he's keen to let it drop - particularly given recurring allegations that he molested a female police officer in the same incident before being hauled away after starting a song-and-dance routine . 'Please, don't think of me as such a big drinker,' he told the Sport-Express newspaper last week. 'Yes, I drank just like everybody else. I could drink a lot and after that I could get behind the wheel and easily drive home past all the police checkpoints. But this incident has hit me very hard. Now that's it. I won't drink a single drop, ever again.' He's still sure, though, that someone spiked his drinks. All of them. 'I still know who did this,' he said. 'It was a planned action, led from Moscow. I still cannot believe it happened. This would have been my last year because of the age limit,' he said. 'To finish like this , it really hurts.'

Fan power goes glossy

The National Federation of Football Supporters' Clubs have launched a new glossy magazine to strengthen their 'Fans Charter' campaign, and are giving it away free to fans at grounds across the country. 'The more money that goes into football, the less fans get out,' says MD Martin Feeley. 'This is about giving fans a voice.'

Transfer of the week

Milan Fukal, the divertingly named Czech defender, moving from Sparta Prague to Hamburg SV, as reported on the Reuters news wires.

Germany's Bild newspaper reported on Thursday that Hamburg, who have qualified for Europe's top club competition for the first time in 17 years, are ready to pay a club record fee of £2.2m for Fukal.

webTitle: O'Neill settles in for long haul

fields.headline: O'Neill settles in for long haul
fields.standfirst: The new Celtic manager will stay for the term of his contract - and maybe years beyond
fields.trailText: The new Celtic manager will stay for the term of his contract - and maybe years beyond, reports Glenn Gibbons
fields.body:
The certainty of Scotland having two clubs in the Champions League from the start of next season and the projected northern European League - in which Celtic and Rangers would be participants - should, in theory, be sufficient to dilute the significance and the passion that have attached to matches between the two for more than a century.

But, on those days when the Glasgow giants are due to collide, Old Firm fans would not be deflected from their purpose by the kind of cataclysm that extinguished the dinosaurs.

The first ritual of this new season is staged early this afternoon, the 1pm kick-off at Celtic Park (prompted by previous delinquent behaviour) is an attempt at limiting the amount of time supporters can spend in pubs attaining the headiness that immunises them against inhibition.

If the deep-rooted anxiety and apprehension, which the respective followers try to camouflage with forced bravado, are more intense among those who wear the green and white, it is because they are being invited to scrutinise the potential of yet another debutant manager, virtually aching with the hope that, this time, the long-awaited revolution will be set in motion.

Martin O'Neill is the latest to assume the role of redeemer, a post that has fallen vacant on an annual basis since the departure of Tommy Burns in 1997. Of the three appointees before the Irishman, Wim Jansen, Jozef Venglos and John Barnes, only the first named wrested the championship from Rangers.

O'Neill has already promised that, successful or not in this first season, he will be in the job for at least the duration of his three-year contract. He has even hinted that, if the good times roll, he could see himself on the bridge at the club he has idolised since childhood for years beyond.

As O'Neill said on Friday, the power of the emotive element in this fixture cannot be overstated. 'If we lose,' he said, 'many people will say we have made no progress. If we win, they will take it as a sign that the championship is just around the corner. What we need is a bit of realism.'

O'Neill has already exhibited encouraging qualities in his short time at Parkhead, including an unusually quick appreciation and even more impressive adroitness in handling the virtually intolerable demands made of Celtic managers. Those non-Scottish predecessors with no previous emotional attachment to the club have been largely impervious to this problem, but O'Neill's credentials are almost identical to those of Liam Brady, who admitted to being crushed by the burden of expectation.

Billy McNeill had predicted Brady's difficulties, pointing out that an Irish Celtic supporter could quite justifiably claim unbreakable allegiance to the club, but that never having been in Glasgow to experience the punishing reality of the pressures would probably prove to be an insurmountable handicap.

O'Neill, of course, has over Brady the significant advantage of having been in management for 10 years, several of them in the hurly-burly of the English Premiership. His insistence that the rigours of taking charge of Celtic are no more taxing than he had imagined and had prepared for is entirely convincing.

There is little doubt, either, that he has renewed the vigour of a team whose morale, in the later stages of last season, seemed to be disintegrating. The acquisition of the Belgian central defender Joos Valgaeren and the English striker Chris Sutton has renewed the strength of those departments, although there remain alarming weaknesses, most notably a lack of wide players who can be relied on to deliver the kind of crosses that terrorise defences and provide a player like Sutton with live ammo.

Celtic should draw further encouragement from the probability that Rangers have not improved since last season, when their 21-point victory in the championship made them seem invincible. But Dick Advocaat himself considers that an artificially wide margin, repeating the other day his opinion that, in the two games Rangers played at Celtic Park, they enjoyed good fortune.

Advocaat never exudes anything but confidence that his team will maintain their superiority, even dismissing the injury-enforced absence of one of his most formidable players, Jorg Albertz, as nothing more than a mild irritation.

'Celtic are obviously playing with more confidence at the moment,' he said, 'but it's much too early to say how things will unfold. This time last season, people were writing about Celtic's brilliant start and how they were playing Brazilian-style football and look how it finished.

'I don't think they're all that different. Valgaeren is a good player. In fact, he was on my list of central defenders I was interested in, along with Bert Konterman. I took Konterman because I knew him better, being Dutch and playing with Feyenoord. Whether Sutton is better than [Mark] Viduka, we don't know.

'Sutton is more of a penalty-box player, whereas Viduka could do things for himself and set up other people. Sutton will need good service, but he is stronger, more physical than Viduka, so it's going to be very interesting.'

The Old Firm match will be long enough in the past to allow the country to turn its attention to the opening World Cup qualifier, Scotland's meeting with Latvia in Riga on Saturday. It is the kind of fixture Craig Brown favours at the start of a series, away to potentially dangerous opponents.

'It's a good time of year for us, with players fit and fresh,' said the manager. 'I really believe Latvia will do damage to others, hopefully Croatia and Belgium, as the qualifying progresses. If we can open with a victory there - and it's the kind of result we've had often enough in the past - it would be a terrific boost to our chances.'

webTitle: Fulham a class above the rest

fields.headline: Fulham a class above the rest
fields.trailText: Nationwide League review Tigana's side give a dominant performance while Chesterfield and Walsall also remain unbeaten.
fields.body:
Only three of eight teams who went into action yesterday with 100 per cent records managed to hold on to them - Fulham, Walsall and Chesterfield.

Fulham beat Stockport 4-1, with the latter experiencing further gloom with two players - Tony Dinning and Mike Flynn - being sent off. Things had looked much brighter for them after five minutes, when a third-minute Barry Hayles goal was cancelled out by Kevin Cooper. However, Fulham created a number of chances, and the eventual scoreline created by John Collins, Hayles and Luis Boa Morte, did not flatter them.

The point was readily acknowledged by Stockport's manager, Andy Kilner. 'They are a quality side,' he said. 'I've never seen a team play like them - we tried to restrict them but they've got fantastic individual players. I admire the way they stick to their beliefs.'

Walsall and Chesterfield also kept their records going with a three-goal margin; Walsall won 4-1 at Swindon, while Chesterfield beat Shrewsbury 3-0. Of the teams who faltered, the most surprising collapse was that of Millwall, who fell 2-1 at home to Wycombe after being ahead. They were another team who had two men sent off - David Livermore and Steven Reid.

At the other end end of the scale are West Bromwich Albion and Oxford, the only Nationwide teams with no points. West Brom, at Barnsley, had the early boost of a goal by Lee Hughes. But they eventually lost 4-1.

'We were found sadly wanting in desire and tempo,' said their manager, Gary Megson. 'If you don't have them you can't win football matches. It is essential that we get stronger, both physically and mentally.'

One striker to keep an eye on this season is clearly Sheffield United's Marcus Bent. The scorer of 16 goals in 34 matches last season - his first at Bramall Lane following his transfer for just £290,000 from Port Vale - he brought his total to five in two matches by netting twice in the 2-0 win over Tranmere.

In terms of his development, the England under-21 striker feels that he can only benefit from playing alongside the 34-year-old Irish Republic international David Kelly. He says: 'David knows what he is doing and helps me along.'

In addition to Kelly, other strikers catching the eye in new set-ups included QPR's Paul Furlong, who is on loan from Birmingham. Furlong could have had a hat-trick on his home debut against Crewe, which is probably why he did not feel too embarrassed about the freak nature of the goal he did get to earn his team a 1-0 win.

The chance came as Crewe's keeper, Jason Kearton, tried to clear a back-pass from David Wright. But the ball struck the onrushing Furlong and rebounded into the net.

There was also a contender for fluke goal of the season from Huddersfield's captain, Chris Lucketti, who picked up the ball 30 yards out against Crystal Palace, and hit it towards Clyde Wijnhard. The striker completely missed it - as did the Palace keeper, Stuart Taylor, who was rooted to the near post as it went in at the far one. Still, Palace recovered from the shock to win 2-1.

fields.headline: Crawford cracker seals victory
fields.trailText: Dundee United, anchored at the bottom of the Premier League, are still looking for their first league win of the season.
fields.body:
Dundee United, anchored at the bottom of the Premier League, are still looking for their first league win of the season.

Despite the fact that they produced a lot of good football, even a point was denied them at Dunfermline, where they fell to a 1-0 defeat through an outstanding goal by Steve Crawford.

The goal came three minutes before half-time. Barry Nicholson, who had been one of the home team's best players, linked up with Mendes in the United box, and Crawford turned superbly on the latter's pass to get in his decisive finish.

Such was the quality of the goal that the crowd were still buzzing about it at the start of the second half.

How United could have done with finishing like that. One good chance for an equaliser came after 49 minutes, when a Steven McConalogue header was pushed on to the bar by the Dunfermline keeper, Marco Ruitenbeek.

This was followed by the miss of the match, from David Hannah. The midfielder looked certain to score when he raced in unmarked to connect with a McConalogue cross.

But, despite being only four yards out, he made a hash of his header and the ball went wide.

Among other particularly exciting goals yesterday were the two in St Johnstone's 1-1 draw against Kilmarnock.

A match which had resembled a game of chess was brought to life in the first half when Tommy Lovenkrands gave St Johnstone the lead with an explosive long-range strike - with Andy McLaren equalising with a similar effort just 40 seconds later.

Kilmarnock should have gone on to win in the second half. Alan Mahlood hit the woodwork with a diving header, and that irrepressible veteran Ally McCoist did likewise with a cheeky curling shot from 50 yards out.

fields.headline: Can Irish fortunes change?
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Harling on why Mick McCarthy believes his team are due some good luck
fields.trailText: Nicholas Harling on why Mick McCarthy believes his team are due some good luck.
fields.body:
It could be a quiz question tricky enough to test the knowledge of the dullest football anorak. What do Holland, Belgium and Turkey have in common apart from the fact that the first two staged Euro 2000 jointly in cities largely occupied by Turks? Answer: all three won play-offs to prevent the Republic of Ireland from reaching the finals of the last three major tournaments.

Holland, Ireland's hosts in the Amsterdam Arena next Saturday, triumphed in a play-off for Euro 96 at Anfield to end Jack Charlton's reign on a sad note. Luc Nilis hammered in the Belgian goals that prevented Mick McCarthy's side from making a third successive appearance in the World Cup finals and then, amid much controversy in Bersa last November, it was Turkey's turn to discredit the myth of the leprechaun.

So much so then for the luck of the Irish. McCarthy, who had a tough enough job winning over Irish hearts in Charlton's wake, will not have a simple task placating his critics in the months ahead.

One look at the formidable list of opponents lining up in the second qualifying group for the 2002 World Club was enough to convince McCarthy that the target of qualification this time will, if anything be even more strewn with obstacles. But if Ireland will do anything to avoid another play-off, Holland have a particular aversion themselves to shoot-outs, habitually losing on penalties.

McCarthy knows it will be no picnic. Not only must his side start with ties against the two Euro 2000 beaten semi-finalists who have much to prove, but the games against Holland and Portugal are both away. Talk about getting the tough ones out of the way first.

It should be considerably easier for Ireland after fixtures against that gruesome twosome, but the question remains as to whether Ireland will have lost too much ground by the time they prepare for the simpler looking matches against Estonia, Cyprus and Andorra.

Publicly, at least, McCarthy is content with the way the schedule has been arranged: 'I'm quite happy,' he said 'We've got to play these games at some stage. I think it would be a false economy if, for instance, we played Andorra away, Cyprus and Estonia at home, put nine points on the board and started feeling great about ourselves. In my mind we have to play these games at some time so why not now?

'Potentially, of course, we could lose both of them and people will start screaming but I don't subscribe to all that nonsense.'

McCarthy who has yet to see his side lose a competitive game at Lansdowne Road, added: 'When you consider our home form , it would be brilliant if we could nick something from these games.'

Like Holland, Ireland opted not to take advantage of the date set aside for friendly internationals the Wednesday before last.

'It would have put a lot of demands on the players,' explained McCarthy who had resisted numerous complaints from the clubs to take his squad to the US Cup in June when, after draws with the USA and Mexico and a 2-1 win over South Africa, they finished runners up to the hosts. If the players were supposedly exhausted after their domestic campaigns, many of them did not show it.

McCarthy returned home extolling the virtues of, among others, Mattie Holland (a doubtful starter for the Dutch trip), Gary Breen, Richard Dunne, goalkeeper Dean Kiely and Stephen Carr.

The summer was far from over for McCarthy. Continuing in an easterly direction, he fetched up in Holland to run the rule over his next opponents and to marvel at the venue, the Amsterdam Arena which would surely have been a far more appropriate choice than Rotterdam for the Euro 2000 final.

McCarthy dismisses suggestions that some of his younger, less experienced players will 'freeze' in that spectacular setting. 'There's not a chance of that happening,' he insisted.

'People want to play in the big games. They'd far rather play Holland away than Liechtenstein or Moldova away because they will raise their game for this one.'

The Arena will therefore present no fears. But what of Holland themselves under the care now of Louis Van Gall? With no warm-up game the home coach is certain to pin his faith in tried and trusted players, the nucleus of the side he had with him at Barcelona or, in the case of Marc Overmars, players who have since jointed the Catalans.

But what of the tactics. McCarthy can be sure of one thing. Holland will provide fiercer resistance than the night they went out of Euro 2000 when Van Gall's predecessor Frank Rijkaard curiously elected not to put on an extra striker after Italy had been reduced to 10 men.

Rijkaard jumped before he was pushed. If there is any apprehension still lurking within Dutch minds, McCarthy must feel that he has just the players in the Keanes, Roy and Robbie to exploit the weaknesses.
