fields.headline: Sudden collapse stuns Smith
fields.trailText: Everton let it slip after dominating in the first half.
fields.body:
New season, new optimism. But it seems the same old story is never far away at Goodison Park. Two goals to the good after a first half of outstanding skill and creativity, Walter Smith's Everton let it slip in dismal fashion as defensive lapses and sloppy passing allowed Derby County the draw they scarcely deserved.

It looked so good for Everton at half time, as Smith's new signings - Niclas Alexandersson, Alex Nyarko and most notably, Thomas Gravesen - led the visitors a merry dance.

Maybe the prospect of winning successive home games at a canter, following Wednesday night's 3-0 demolition of Charlton, injected a dose of nerves into Everton's play, but the result was the sort of collapse that has been all too common with the Blues in recent seasons.

The rot kicked in after 51 minutes when substitutes Stefan Schnoor and Dean Sturridge combined to unlock Everton's defence. Full-back Steve Watson mistimed his challenge on Schnoor and, when the ball was played into the box, Sturridge gratefully accepted the chance.

The fightback was complete 15 minutes later when Derby's Belgian international striker Branco Strupar showed himself for the first time in the afternoon with a free-kick outside the box.

Everton defender David Unsworth conceded the foul with a poor challenge on Deon Burton, and Strupar stepped up to deliver a shot from the free-kick that blazed a trail through Everton's defence and left goalkeeper Paul Gerrard little chance.

Afterwards Smith was understandably disappointed. 'We handed the initiative to Derby in the second half, which was a real shame because we were in control up until half time,' he said. 'Derby fought back well and they deserved to come back into the game because of the amount of commitment they showed. They were the better side in the second half.'

Smith had started without Wednesday's two-goal hero, Duncan Ferguson, out with yet another injury, while fellow new boy Paul Gascoigne was relegated to the bench in a bid to taper his reintroduction to the harsh realities of Premiership football.

But the first half proved life without the pair is not all that bad. Not bad at all. Everton sprang to life after a quarter of an hour with four chances in less than five minutes.

Mark Hughes fired narrowly wide after Alexandersson had ripped apart Derby's marking on the right wing to deliver a dangerous, low cross. American striker Joe-Max Moore was equally effective cutting a swathe through the visiting side's back line, but goalkeeper Mart Poom turned the ball around the post.

Everton kept up the pressure and were dominant in midfield. The reward for their effort was spectacular, with two goals inside as many minutes at the game ticked towards half time. First, young striker Francis Jeffers side-footed home with great aplomb after Moore slipped the ball into his path at the second attempt.

Goodison was still celebrating when Danish midfielder Gravesen broke through Derby's static defence to latch on to Stephen Hughes's intelligent through ball. Poom got a finger to Gravesen's shot but it was insufficient to divert it from the bottom right hand corner of his goal.

fields.headline: Tide turns on Reds
fields.trailText: Southampton seem dead and buried at 3-0 down, but Marian Pahars leads the fightback to earn Saints an unlikely point.
fields.body:
You second-gear your way through all that Bank Holiday traffic and motorway spray just to see the man perform and what happens? He strolls and smiles his way through the game, offering little but experience and authority, failing to make any real impact. So instead of a game littered with Jeff Winter's yellow and red cards, we saw one full of goals and entertainment. Typical.

It was a stunning collapse by Liverpool, a rousing comeback by Southampton. The visitors were 3-0 up with just 17 minutes to go thanks largely to two neat pieces of finishing by Michael Owen, who on this evidence looks ready to relish next Saturday's England game against France in Paris, his poached pair sandwiching Sami Hyypia's captain's goal that seemed to have settled his side and the game.

Then a combination of Matthew Le Tissier rolling back the years, Marian Pahars - scoring twice himself - finally being moved from the right wing into the penalty box, and Liverpool losing their discipline, gleaned Southampton a point that The Dell could hardly have expected from such adversity.

Gérard Houllier could barely contain his anger. 'It was the sort of game which makes a manager throw tea cups in the dressing room,' said the Liverpool manager. 'We threw it away. I don't know how we conceded three goals in the air.

'With our size at the back, it's a joke. But then we didn't close down the crosses. We lost a bit of concentration and paid dearly.'

It was curious, however, that although Liverpool frequently played the more composed and incisive football, with Vladimir Smicer, creator of all three goals, at last beginning to turn his talent into productive performances, they also allowed Southampton a glut of glimpses at goal; the home side also twice hit the woodwork. This from the Premiership's best defence of last season.

'The difference was Michael Owen with his cutting edge,' said the Southampton manager, Glenn Hoddle, the man who gave Owen his England debut. 'His movement and sharpness were there. He played as if he was free. His movement was the only thing on his mind, not his hamstring.

'But we got a break and the crowd lifted us. Things like that can happen at The Dell.' Indeed. While few except incorrigible nostalgists will miss its claustrophobia when the club moves to a new stadium next season, it does pose an intriguing test for the the bigger clubs used to grandeur and breathing space.

Not that Liverpool initially seemed intimidated. 'After all that happened at Arsenal, we showed a lot of character,' said Houllier, who responded with 'they have done a good job' to the news that an FA video panel was recommending that the red for Gary McAllister - omitted yesterday - from that match be downgraded to yellow.

Without Emile Heskey, whose knee injury will keep him out of the England squad, they played a clever triangle up front of Owen with Smicer and Nick Barmby behind him and it came as no surprise when they took the lead after 24 minutes. Smicer set Owen clear of Claus Lundekvam and he tucked the ball neatly away with his left foot.

It seemed that Liverpool had heeded the warning signs of Hassan Kachloul's half-volley that grazed the bar, and Uwe Rosler's rounding of Sander Westerveld only to take the ball too wide and waste the chance, when Hyypia headed home Smicer's corner. And when Owen again tucked home a Smicer through ball, this time Dean Richards the outpaced defender, it seemed like game over.

Then the attention switched from fleet-footed colt to old warhorse. On came Le Tissier to inspire, first with a shot across the face of goal, then with one which Westerveld turned aside, followed by a cross that Richards headed against the bar. The Dell's wooden main stand rocked at last.

So too Liverpool. Pahars headed home Jo Tessem's cross, but as consolation we thought; Tahar El Khalej did similarly from James Beattie's flick at Mark Draper's cross, surely a token gesture. But finally the hapless Djimi Traore headed Le Tissier's cross into Pahars's path and the Latvian stabbed home. It was a finale and a game - unbelievable as it may sound - to eclipse the referee.

fields.headline: Hammers earn late reward
fields.trailText: Hammers late show from Di Canio and Suker floors the champions.
fields.body:
Just as it seemed Harry Redknapp would again be left exasperated by his team's worrying tendency to lose games when they have created the lion's share of the chances, a late salvo turned a fascinating tussle - and West Ham's season - on its head.

It was an astonishing recovery, with that enigmatic double act of Paolo Di Canio and Davor Suker summoning those scoring instincts which had proved elusive for 85 minutes. Even the legendary clockwatcher Sir Alex Ferguson, naturally disappointed to see a two-goal lead slip so late, admitted it was no less than West Ham deserved.

Redknapp is genuinely excited about his team's chances now they have finally kick-started their season, remarking: 'This is the best team we've had since I've been manager here.' He is convinced the blend of experienced heads - and he was purring about the relentless enthusiasm of Nigel Winterburn and Stuart Pearce - coupled with a crop of prodigious youngsters will bear fruit.

Taking on the Premiership Champions was a test Joe Cole answered with relish. His positive run into the box earned the penalty that began the comeback. 'It was a bit like watching Gazza in his prime,' cooed Redknapp. 'When he gets the ball and runs straight at people, it frightens them to death.'

Equally frightening, the West Ham manager agreed, is the sight of David Beckham hovering over a dead ball. This was the game's overture, after Igor Stimac floored Teddy Sheringham. No booking from Dermot Gallagher, but Beckham administered punishment of a more damning nature, floating the ball into the top corner with typical undefendable accuracy. Ferguson later praised his midfielder as the best striker of a free-kick he has ever worked with.

It knocked West Ham out of their stride and, without the useful outlet of hamstrung striker Frederic Kanoute, they searched for some other way to hurdle a reshuffled United defence.

Enter the kids, who took up the baton through enthusiasm and exuberance. First a shimmy and shot from Rio Ferdinand, who later limped off with his recurring hip problem which will keep him from England duty, and then the teenagers surged forward: a driving run from Joe Cole carved an opening for Michael Carrick, who wallopped goalwards and forced a smart save from Fabien Barthez.

Suddenly West Ham had United's measure. Mikael Silvestre, at left-back, looked a weak link and Di Canio went for the jugular. Capitalising on a mix-up between Silvestre and compatriot Barthez, the Italian tried a lob into the empty net - it fell fractionally wide. Suker, Cole and Steve Lomas were all denied in a first half which was a familiar story of frustrated attacking for Redknapp's men. In contrast United played the patience game, soaking up the pressure and waiting for the opportune moment to pounce.

The effectiveness of these contrasting styles was confirmed immediately after the break. Stimac's glancing header fizzed past an upright, and in an instant, with breathtaking efficiency, United were two to the good. A perfect lofted pass from Beckham landed on Ryan Giggs's toe. He killed it, flipped it unselfishly to Andrew Cole, and the international wannabe clipped the ball in via Hislop's hand. 'I hope he gets his chance with England,' noted Ferguson.

West Ham's relentless spirit paid off when Henning Berg, who replaced hamstring victim Jaap Stam at half-time, upended Joe Cole and Di Canio belted the spot-kick past Barthez. Having finally discovered their touch in front of goal, they swarmed forward to equalise in dramatic fashion. Di Canio whipped in a cross which Silvestre could only slice into the inviting path of Davor Suker. His glanced header bounced along the line and in, and Steve Lomas rammed it home to make sure. There was still time for United to strike the woodwork twice. But West Ham survived, and east London rejoiced.

fields.headline: Sedgley taps in first win
fields.trailText: Sedgley's deflected goal helps Wolves strike it lucky against the Division One new boys.
fields.body:
Some thirty years ago, a meeting of these two sides would have been on Match of the Day. These clubs' great traditions may count for naught in the 21st century but there appeared to be a moment, as the teams warmed up, when Burnley and their support looked awe-struck in the old gold grandeur of this splendid stadium. But once the game was underway, newly promoted Burnley showed themselves well-equipped for the contest.

Their vastly experienced manager, Stan Ternent, has packed his squad with veterans. Players like Kevin Ball, the former Sunderland skipper, Mitchell Thomas, Paul Cook (one a Wolves player) and the Northern Ireland international, Phil Gray. But, eclipsing them all in tireless effort and guile was Glen Little whom they signed from humble Darlington.

Wolves were running the game when a comedy of errors in an otherwise sound Burnley defence led to a playground goal. The substitute George Ndah met a far-post cross with a header which hit the foot of a post. The ball came back into play off a defender's leg and landed at the feet of Steve Sedgley whose half-hit shot reached the net after yet another deflection.

So the Wanderers can count themselves lucky to take the points as their manager Colin Lee conceded: 'We're just pleased to get our first win under our belts.' And with two draws already secured, that precious goal has turned what might have been considered a poor start to the season into a good one.

Yesterday though, Burnley tactically looked the better side. Playing Ian Cox, Steve Davis and Mitchell Thomas at the back they comfortably snuffed out the predictable aerial threat of Wolves' new striker Robert Taylor.

While Lee 'knew it would be competitive in midfield', actually it wasn't. Burnley had a midfield via Little and Cook, Wolves were untidy with Neil Emblen and Temuri Ketsbaia swapping positions throughout the game in an effort to find some rhythm.

Afterwards, a smiling Ternent knew his side had at least deserved a point, but conceded: 'In football you don't always get what you deserve. We'll take it on the chin. It was just one of those days.'

Ternent's agenda, limited presumably by the club's financial clout, is to establish Burnley in the First Division. On the evidence of this game, he has the defence and midfield for the task but lacks a truly menacing strike force.

A bright spot for Wolves was the performance of their left-back Lee Naylor. Confirmed in Howard Wilkinson's England under-21 squad, he looks mature beyond his years and will surely attract the attention of a Premiership buyer. Talking of which, Robbie Keane, late of Wolves and Coventry City, now of Inter, made a pre-match touchline appearance.

fields.headline: Earnshaw earns Cardiff reprieve
fields.trailText: Sam Hammam's sleeping giants grab two late goals to earn a point at Underhill.
fields.body:
Whatever the outcome of Sam Hammam's dream of delivering another rags-to-riches story, Cardiff City fans have fast become aware that it will not be pursued on the back of convention or compromise. Making waves and ruffling feathers were part and parcel of his Wimbledon reign and he clearly sees no reason to change tack for life in the Third Division.

Hammam has already annoyed Wales's finest player, John Charles, by declaring that rivals Swansea City are a second-rate club, irritated referees by distributing red and yellow cards to supporters at the first home game of the season, and suggested that Cardiff's Bluebird emblem be replaced by a Welsh dragon.

He will also operate without a chairman. Steve Borley is stepping down after the £3.1million takeover is officially completed this week. Borley said: 'Sam is like a whirlwind. He has given the whole area a new buzz. With his enthusiasm, he can do more with £3m than others could do with £10m.'

'I'm not a chairman and I never will be,' Hammam said. 'Chairmen are supposed to be wise, speak pearls of wisdom and drive Rolls-Royces. I'm not into that.

'Wimbledon was, is, and always will be my baby. But the baby has grown up. I like to think of Cardiff as my new family. The potential here is huge. I want to give Wales the club it deserves, so that the fans don't have to wear Liverpool and Manchester United shirts. I'm not making any predictions, just to say it is up to us to make it happen.'

An 11,000 crowd for their first home match, against Blackpool, after Cardiff were relegated last season underlined the potential available to Bobby Gould, who will now take over as manager.

Then their team conceded a last-minute equaliser to Blackpool. This time it was Cardiff who rescued a match after looking dead and buried at 2-0 down with seven minutes left.

Paying the price for a host of missed chances, they went behind to Scott McGleish's fourth goal in four games and conceded another to substitute Ken Charlery after excellent work by Darren Currie. Hammam, prowling the terracing next to his team's dugout, looked resigned until Josh Low fired one in off an upright, and he was positively beaming when substitute Robert Earnshaw volleyed the equaliser.

Billy Ayre, who now steps down to become Gould's assistant, said: 'One or two things were said at half-time and we looked a different proposition after that.'

While Cardiff aim for the stars, Barnet have to cope with poor crowds and the thought that if they don't find a new ground quickly then permission to continue operating below the minimum requirements for a Third Division ground could be withdrawn.

Manager John Still reflected on the late collapse by admitting: 'We don't know how to kill teams off. It happened the week before and the only way to do it is to kick it long and hard.'

webTitle: Shearer still waiting despite Spurs' collapse

fields.headline: Shearer still waiting despite Spurs' collapse
fields.trailText: Ordinary Spurs no match for determined Newcastle, though Shearer stays on 199 league goals.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at St James' Park
fields.body:
Still the waiting goes on for Alan Shearer, yet to score this season and marooned one strike short of a double century of League goals.

Newcastle still had more than enough firepower to overwhelm an ordinary looking Spurs side in which Sergei Rebrov gave a passable imitation of the invisible man, but Shearer's inability to get on the end of his colleagues' best efforts to set him up provided the afternoon with an almost comical sub-plot.

There was not much else to chuckle about on a thoroughly damp August day. If it had just been a matter of choosing a winner of the midfield hackabout on a slippery pitch, which took up most of the 90 minutes, a draw would have been the fairest result.

Newcastle showed a greater self-belief and determination to get forward and by the end deserved their victory, but the only reason they were ahead at half time was a lapse of concentration in the Tottenham back four.

There had been no concerted attacks or attempts on goal worthy of the name from either side until the 10th minute, when a speculative ball forward by Aaron Hughes was turned into a defence splitting pass by Sol Campbell and Co mistiming their offside trap.

Even Gary Speed must have been expecting to hear a whistle as he gathered the ball with the Spurs half virtually to himself, but the flag stayed down and the Welshman ran on to beat the advancing Neil Sullivan with a delicate chip.

George Graham was not pleased. 'I don't know if it was offside or not, but it was close and we shouldn't have been playing for offsides so early in the game,' the Spurs manager said. 'You can't come up here and give them a goal start.'

Perhaps unnerved by the prospect of a tongue-lashing at half time, the Spurs defence promptly went to pieces. Speed could have had a second within minutes when Warren Barton's pass down the right again found space behind the back four, but sliced his shot from Daniel Cordone's into the crowd.

Spurs found the home defence more difficult to catch out, although Darren Anderton had Shay Given worried with a deep cross, which the goalkeeper was grateful to see rebound from a post.

In terms of chances created in front of goal in the first half, the visitors could point only to a Steffen Iversen volley, which flew too high. Newcastle did not create many more, but hardly needed to. Another defensive slip, this time from Chris Perry, let in Shearer for what looked a certain 200th goal.

The former England captain did everything right, taking the ball wide of Sullivan then clipping back a goalbound shot over the goalkeeper's head, but Campbell arrived to head out from under the crossbar and keep Shearer waiting for his landmark.

Spurs put in the usual bright 10 minutes immediately after the interval, and in fairness were unlucky to see shots in quick succession by Oyvind Leonhardsen and Steffen Freund cleared off the line by Barton and Hughes respectively, but faded all too predictably once Newcastle regathered their forward momentum.

Shearer's moment almost came on 56 minutes when Perry fouled Cordone on the edge of his area, but though his firmly struck free kick beat the wall and had Sullivan stretching, it curled just the wrong side of the upright. Sullivan was obliged to save from Keiron Dyer just after an hour, then managed to thwart Shearer again by intercepting a Nolberto Solano cross as the striker waited for a far post tap-in.

At least Shearer had the satisfaction of seeing Cordone swoop on the rebound for the goal that settled the game, but he was less delighted four minutes later when, with Sullivan out of his area, Solano wastefully went for glory from 40 yards out with his captain again unmarked in the area.

'If you play well at home you should collect the points,' a satisfied Bobby Robson remarked. 'I was delighted with our back four.' He must have been quite pleased with the Spurs back four as well.

fields.headline: Coventry's away delight
fields.trailText: After their season-long drought Coventry bag their second away win in four days as poor Richard Edghill has a match to forget.
fields.body:
On Wednesday the coach driver, yesterday Manchester City captain Richard Edghill. When successive away victories have been a long-time coming Gordon Strachan will accept any assistance, however unexpected the source.

After ending 16 months without an away success at Southampton on Wednesday, Strachan credited a change in bus driver. Yesterday, the win came courtesy of an error-riddled first half performance from the unfortunate Edghill.

His performance included a headed own goal, being soundly beaten for a second and laying on a back pass that could have brought a third. At the interval, his manager Joe Royle took the humane option and substituted the tearful full-back.

'I took him off for his own good, you could see the lad was distraught,' explained Royle. 'He hadn't had a good half and was upset at himself for the goal he had given away. There's nobody out there who has given more for this club than him.

'He will hold his hands up and say he didn't have a good half but the crowd reaction made it impossible for him to stay out there.'

Edghill is the lone survivor from the club's last, disastrous, Premiership campaign four years ago. A hard-working professional who has overcome injury and the misgivings of his own supporters, he deserved better than this very public crisis in confidence.

The nadir had come in the 24th minute when he headed John Eustace's lobbed pass into the area he expected his goalkeeper to occupy. But Nicky Weaver had stepped forward, resulting in one of the those own goals that seem to occur in slow motion.

Worse was to follow. When a perceptive Eustace pass isolated the dangerous Craig Bellamy against Edghill, even the staunchest City fan feared the worst, which duly followed as the Coventry man beat the hapless defender and Weaver from a wide angle.

If the first week of the new campaign has unearthed anything about Manchester City, it is that their fortunes will be dictated by George Weah and Paulo Wanchope's ability to produce more goals than their defensive colleagues allow.

In contrast to the 4-2 midweek victory over Sunderland, they could not do so. Wanchope had a goal ruled out for offside, set up his Liberian partner for a 15-yard shot that drew a magnificent block from Magnus Hedman, leading to a corner headed against the bar by Steve Howey. There were isolated chances for both sides until a suspiciously offside Kevin Horlock converted in the 78th minute following a blocked Wanchope shot and Paul Dickov deflection, the goal ensuring a frantic finale but ultimate frustration for Royle's team.

For the Coventry manger there was satisfaction at a job well done and the opportunity for a trademark pay-off. 'At least the bus driver is a celebrity,' said Strachan. 'He's out there signing autographs!'

fields.headline: Vieira signs off with style
fields.trailText: Vieira bounces back to score twice as Arsenal edge out Charlton in Highbury thriller.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira twice went into the referee's notebook, both times as a goalscorer, as Arsenal won a hugely entertaining derby. Eight times as many goals as yellow cards. Perhaps we can stop talking about referees and start talking about the new football being used, which is turning the Premiership into a goal-fest. It curves, it swerves, it goes in the net.

A hectic afternoon saw four goals from French internationals and three goals conceded by English internationals. I know how I'd bet on the forthcoming friendly. Sylvain Wiltord watched from the stands and must wonder how he will get into the French and Arsenal teams.

Others were left to wonder whether Wenger might have been wiser to have spent the £13 million on a defender or a goalkeeper (John Lukic was on the bench yesterday). Wenger said afterwards that he had bought Wiltord in an attempt 'to play a game based on mobility and technique'. In attack Arsenal have these qualities in abundance, in defence less so. In midfield, they have Vieira.

Charlton started the game hesitantly, making basic errors on a glassy pitch. And Arsenal should have taken advantage. Nwankwo Kanu and Robert Pires both had a pair of chances in the opening 15 minutes but failed to take them. Even on the rare occasions Charlton attacked, Arsenal looked the more likely to score on the break.

They made spectacular amends for their profligacy. Kanu picked the ball up 35 yards out, skipped past a defender, passed the ball through to... guess who?... Vieira and, cool as you like, he did a little shimmy before chipping the ball into the net. A wonderful goal. Highbury got quite carried away with the symbolism of it. Vieira had scored before he had been booked. Before anyone had been booked.

Game over, one thought. Then, an innocuous cross by Radistan Kishishev eluded Martin Keown and Tony Adams and Andy Hunt scored from close range.

Charlton, thanks to the diligent efforts of Mark Kinsella and Claus Jensen in the centre of midfield, edged themselves back into the game. On the half-hour, they took the lead. John Robinson's hopeful cross from mid-way down the left hung in the air long enough for Hunt to shrug off a feeble challenge from Silvinho and loop a very slow header past David Seaman. It was Andy Hunt 2, Arsenal 1. And not a referee or linesman or fourth official to blame.

Perhaps Seaman must shoulder some of it. He wasn't directly responsible, but his marked unwillingness to come off his line seems to have rendered his defence suddenly very dodgy on the six-yard line. At the very end, he didn't even come for a ball three yards out.

Arsenal needed a goal early in the second half. It took less than a minute. Thierry Henry received the ball towards the edge of the Arsenal area, teed it up and casually volleyed it into the net. Back came Charlton. Kevin Lisbie ran down the left, crossed towards that six-yard line and Graham Stuart snuck in front of Adams to clip the ball into the net.

And back came Arsenal. Kanu passed the ball across to Vieira who caroomed the ball into the net from 20 yards. Two red cards, two goals. If he keeps this up he'll be very useful in short bursts.

At 3-3, there was everything to play for. The kind of pressure situation when someone might get booked. They were. The impressive Kinsella for a foul on...Vieira. A minute later, Arsenal were ahead when Henry skipped through and beat Dean Kiely from a tight angle. Seven goals, 25 minutes to go. 5-5, anyone?

Not quite but a minute from time there was another cracker. Silvinho streaming through on the left and stroking the ball into the net.

Afterwards, Alan Curbishley talked about his players feeling knackered. He took Kinsella off because he 'was so tired'. His parting words to the press were: 'We've just been beat 5-3 and you're gentle.' Eight goals and a gentle press. Arsène Wenger's 'crazy week' had come to the most surprising of ends.

webTitle: Home at last, with a lump in my throat

fields.headline: Home at last, with a lump in my throat
fields.standfirst: After three years, MI6 man comes in from the cold to the reassuring mediocrity of his beloved Boro
fields.trailText: To give you an idea of how long it is since I saw the Boro live, the last player I witnessed scoring for us was Fabrizio Ravanelli. The Boro have come a long way since then. We've been promoted. We've been to another Wembley final. And we've restored ourselves to mid-table mediocrity. Before the season, I had managed to convince myself that Bryan Robson had finally succeeded in assembling a squad capable of qualifying for Europe. After a quarter of an hour of the game, that dream was in tatters.
fields.body:
To give you an idea of how long it is since I saw the Boro live, the last player I witnessed scoring for us was Fabrizio Ravanelli. The Boro have come a long way since then. We've been promoted. We've been to another Wembley final. And we've restored ourselves to mid-table mediocrity. Before the season, I had managed to convince myself that Bryan Robson had finally succeeded in assembling a squad capable of qualifying for Europe. After a quarter of an hour of the game, that dream was in tatters.

But let's leave the Boro's prospects aside. For me, yesterday represented the real end of my exile because I finally managed to sit in the seat I have been paying for for the past three years. I couldn't give it up because that would have meant being on the waiting list until another season ticket became available. And the last thing I wanted was to return from France and not be able to see the Boro.

In the Cleveland Trade Union Centre before the game, I felt the same strange lump in my throat that I felt when I saw the white cliffs of Dover last Monday. I just hoped I wouldn't break down in tears. In some ways it was a more emotional experience than seeing England again. After all, friends and family came to see me in Paris. They brought over those peculiarities of English culture that cannot be obtained in France like brown sauce, cheddar cheese and Branston Pickle. The only thing I really couldn't simulate in Paris was the Riverside experience.

But it was also important because Middlesbrough Football Club defines me in a way that nothing else does. I left the town when I was ten and the only connection I have with my roots is the football team who somehow captured my heart when I was eight and have never given it back since.

Of course, the Teesside weather came in on cue. When I arrived on Friday night, the sun had been blazing. By yesterday lunchtime it was pissing down. But no matter how wet and bedraggled I became in my Albert Camus Philosophy Football shirt, I still had a bounce in my step.

As I neared the ground, Boro fans came up and shook me by the hand. Lynn, the woman who sits behind us, had even bought me a 'Welcome Back' card. Everyone was supportive. I think nearly a hundred people must have approached me not just to wish me luck but to impart to me their fervent wish that I gave the intelligence services what for, because it was about time someone did.

It had been the same in London during the week. But somehow this meant more to me, because no one could accuse Boro fans of being Hampstead intellectuals or Islington socialists. It meant more because these people are the traditional Labour voters that were first ignored by the Conservatives and then by New Labour. I was particularly touched as a group of Boro fans came up to me and started singing: 'There's only one David Shayler.' I nearly cried. I hadn't really recovered before I finally pushed through the turnstile.

I thought the Boro might for once come good and beat Leeds just for me. But the football fan's relationship with his team is seldom requited. By half-time I was, as they say, gutted. Ricard (Hamilton, not the pastis) was as bad as he had been when I left three years earlier.

One line from earlier in the day summed up for me the warmth and cleverness of the Teesside wit. Just before I went in, one wag jokingly accused me of being a fair weather fan. 'Typical of some people,' he said. 'They only turn up when we're top of the league.'

fields.headline: Close shave for toiling Bradford
fields.trailText: Rodney Marsh had his head shaved before kick-off, after saying Bradford had been 'the worst team he had ever seen in the Premiership' last season and would never stay up. He told the crowd he would keep his predictions to himself in future, but after watching a game in which Leicester somehow didn't run away with it, privately he must be tempted to make the same bet over again.
fields.body:
Rodney Marsh had his head shaved before kick-off, after saying Bradford had been 'the worst team he had ever seen in the Premiership' last season and would never stay up. He told the crowd he would keep his predictions to himself in future, but after watching a game in which Leicester somehow didn't run away with it, privately he must be tempted to make the same bet over again.

Only Matt Clarke stood in the way of the Foxes and victory, the home goalkeeper making eight great saves. He left his best until last, an astounding reaction parry from Ade Akinbiyi's close-range effort in the last minute.

'He kept us in it, and given the amount of chances they had, this was an excellent point for us,' said manager Chris Hutchings afterwards. Hutchings revealed defender Andy O'Brien had suffered a suspected fractured collar bone after being carried off following an early collision with Akinbiyi.

The talk after Tuesday's defeat of Chelsea was that Bradford had somehow acquired a new-found solidity. It wasn't much in evidence here. Granted, new signings such as Peter Atherton, David Hopkin, Ian Nolan and Dan Petrescu, have added confidence to the midfield, but Leicester still penetrated them far too easily. Darren Eadie and Akinbiyi in particular could both have had hat-tricks.

With the impish genius of Benito Carbone, Bradford do have a world-class performer, but he often looked isolated here, an artist among artisans. His free role acted as something of a double-edged-sword. He created some marvellous openings in midfield and on the flanks, but when he did there was no one in the middle able to capitalise.

Carbone did engineer one effort late on, a stinging shot which Tim Flowers just managed to parry away, but a frustrating season could lie ahead.

Leicester are unbeaten and have still not conceded a goal under new manager Peter Taylor. He was disappointed the team had not taken some of the chances but said: 'This was still our best performance of the season, we played well in all positions and all in all, it has been an excellent start to the season.'

webTitle: Bramble's star rises high over the Town

fields.headline: Bramble's star rises high over the Town
fields.trailText: Ipswich deserve their victory in a cracking match and their scorer Titus Bramble has the potential to become a big star.
fields.body:
The Premiership a new star and his name is Titus Bramble. This may not be earth-shattering news to some, as the born-and-bred Ipswich defender has already had more than a few column inches dedicated to him. And it is unlikely this will be the last report in which the 19-year-old central defender features. He missed most of Ipswich's promotion season through injury, and after impressing against the full force of Manchester United in midweek, he did it all over again against Sunderland, playing with the poise and assurity of a seasoned professional. And he scored, too.

There was more to this fixture than Bramble, of course. It was a cracking match with both teams playing with passion and endeavour. But Ipswich finished the stronger side and could have won by more as David Johnson went close time after time.

The Ipswich manager, George Burley, said: 'We're proud of the young players we have brought through the ranks. Titus made his debut two years ago but he has worked so hard to come back from injuries and he has been outstanding in all three games so far. He can play as a centre-forward, too, so I encourage him and all the players to get in attack. We don't have robots here.'

Sunderland started the game as if they were the home team, launching a series of early attacks with Niall Quinn ever the focal point. But they struggled to create clear chances and Ipswich soon gained their composure to make a game of it. It was end-to-end stuff and the deadlock was nearly broken when Richard Wright, left out of the latest England squad in favour of Aston Villa's David James, tried to punch clear a Kevin Kilbane corner only to skim the ball off his knuckles. Fortunately for Wright, Jamie Clapham was standing behind on the goal line to block the ball back into his keeper's hands.

Wright recovered to launch an immediate counter-attack and Bramble was putting Marcus Stewart clear on goal before Sunderland had woken to the danger, although their goalkeeper, Jurgen Macho, was alert and dashed off his line to deny Stewart with his feet.

The chances continued to flow and the referee, Graham Poll, who started his season with a hat-trick of red cards at Highbury last Monday, took until the 49th minute to book anyone. But he had no option when Darren Holloway hacked down Fabian Wilnis from behind. The Sunderland manager, Peter Reid, who admitted his team did not deserve anything and criticised their passing, praised Poll, as did Burley. 'I'm the losing manager and I'm praising the referee, I must be going soft,' said Reid.

But the game needed a goal and it was a defender who showed the strikers how to finish. Bramble started his run just inside the Ipswich half and received the ball, from a well-weighted Marcus Stewart pass, just outside the penalty area before holding off a Paul Butler challenge to score with a low shot. It was a goal worthy of being a match winner from a player who is going to be the talk of the Town for years to come.

webTitle: Four in a row for the lords of Lord's

fields.headline: Four in a row for the lords of Lord's
fields.standfirst:
Warwickshire 205-7
Gloucestershire 122-3
Gloucestershire win by 22 runs on Duckworth/Lewis method
fields.trailText:
Warwickshire 205-7

Gloucestershire 122-3

Gloucestershire win by 22 runs on Duckworth/Lewis method
fields.body:
The bank closed early here yesterday but it did not stop Gloucestershire winning their fourth successive Lord's final. They also became the first team to retain the NatWest Trophy.In the 20th and final NatWest final, they defeated Warwickshire by 22 runs under the Duckworth/Lewis method for calculating the result of interrupted matches.

It was something of a carry-over carry-on and, with the ground less than half full, this was hardly a fitting climax for the most popular of the domestic one-day competitions. It was, however, substantially better than the bowl-out bow-out that had been predicted after rain washed out Saturday.

Warwickshire, who had been put in, scored 205 for seven from their 50 overs. In reply Gloucestershire had made 122 for three from 29.4 overs when heavy rain fell like a damp curtain on the competition that succeeded the Gillette Cup in 1981; this was the first Lord's final to be decided by Frank Duckworth and Tony Lewis.

The result, however, was no anomaly. Gloucestershire were once again the better side. Theirs is an astonishing accomplishment for it is most difficult to establish such consistency in the one-day game.

They have done so not by outstanding batting, which so often decides limited-overs matches, but by their expertise in the field and by the thoroughness of their method, even though were times yesterday when their efficiency betrayed them.

"It was disappointing for it to finish this way," said their captain Mark Alleyne. "But we came here to win the NatWest Trophy and that's what we have done."

All this is of little consolation to Warwickshire, for whom victory would have been some comfort in their general malaise. They are playing indifferent cricket and Bob Woolmer, their once-messianic coach, is now under some pressure.

So is the captain Neil Smith, who is far from fireproof even though the club chairman happens to be his father. Allan Donald, who was the beneficiary of one of the more eccentric man-of-the-match judgments yesterday, is off at the end of the season and so, it is expected, is Ed Giddins. The smile has been wiped from the county's countenance. Gloucestershire were required to jog but never sprint in pursuit of their modest target. Only Donald, in his brief thoroughbred gallop, looked capable of undoing them.

Donald, who comes on first change in these matches, appeared for the 10th over and with his sixth ball he bowled Tim Hancock. He beat Kim Barnett for pace to claim his second wicket with the second ball of his second spell, but only after Barnett had put on 53 with Ian Harvey, the match's only half-century stand.

Gloucestershire had plenty of time to increase their run-rate as the skies darkened. But it was strange that with the side already in a winning position Harvey, with the last ball of the match, should complicate the calculations by throwing his wicket away, Michael Powell taking the catch on the deep square-leg boundary.

Warwickshire had appeared capable of setting something more challenging, even though their most important batsman, Nick Knight, was caught behind in the second over.

Gloucestershire, unusually, did not bowl well early on when the ball did plenty. The first ball of the match, bowled by Harvey, went for four wides. His third and fourth deliveries were also wide.

Mike Smith, with 10-3-18-3, maintained Gloucestershire's traditional parsimony, but James Averis was also profligate. Alleyne himself went for 28 in six, which was expensive by his miserly standards.

Ashley Giles, in good spirits after his England Test call-up in the morning, exploited this waywardness better than any of the specialist batsmen. He scored 60, driving with power and confidence, and hit five fours in his 104-ball innings.

fields.headline: Vialli draws little comfort
fields.trailText: Neither Aston Villa nor Chelsea were entitled to take anything more than muted satisfaction from yesterday's draw at Villa Park. While Villa preserved their unbeaten Premiership record and Chelsea avoided a second defeat after losing dully at Bradford City last Tuesday the poverty of the football said little about the chances of these teams making a serious championship challenge this time.
fields.body:
Neither Aston Villa nor Chelsea were entitled to take anything more than muted satisfaction from yesterday's draw at Villa Park. While Villa preserved their unbeaten Premiership record and Chelsea avoided a second defeat after losing dully at Bradford City last Tuesday the poverty of the football said little about the chances of these teams making a serious championship challenge this time.

An outstanding early goal from Luc Nilis, the Belgian striker making his first league appearance for Villa since joining them on a free transfer from PSV Eindhoven, promised Villa Park a treat that never ensued. By half-time a header from Marcel Desailly, helped by another of David James's flat spots, had brought the scores level and there they were always likely to remain.

Since Aston Villa had not beaten or scored against Chelsea at home in a league fixture since Christmas 1994, they were perhaps entitled to feel a little happier with the result. Yet the readiness of the home supporters to boo two of the players who have expressed a desire to leave, Gareth Southgate at the start and Julian Joachim when he came on for the last 20 minutes, suggested that Villa are going to have to work a little harder to please their followers.

More is expected of Chelsea this season, given the addition of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink to their attack and Christian Panucci and Mario Stanic to the defence and midfield. But yesterday their football functioned only in fits and starts and in any case Stanic went off after 25 minutes with the recurrence of a knee injury.

Normally the most consistently accurate passers in the Premiership, Chelsea kept wasting the ball through casual distribution and showed a depressing tendency to lump it high towards goal, which is not their style. Yet they could and should have won the match in the penultimate minute when Eidur Gudjohnsen, the Icelander signed from Bolton, cleverly set up a chance for Tor Andre Flo, whose chip beat James but floated wide.

While a win for Chelsea would have been hard on Villa, whose all-round effort could not have been faulted, it might have spared Gianluca Vialli some breast-beating after the game. Under pressure after the defeat at Valley Parade, the Chelsea manager complained that, according to some people, that is the media, "unless we win the league by 25 points we are shit''.

"I can take criticism," Vialli continued, "but for the players it is difficult sometimes because we think people keep picking on Chelsea for some reason.

"Maybe it is because we have a lot of foreigners and people think they are just here for easy money and don't care about the club. Maybe it's because I am a foreign manager. "We are here to do our best and give something to the English game, which is fantastic. But we've got no friends and that's the way it is.''

This is remarkably early in the season for any manager to be suffering from press paranoia. A lot of the criticism of Chelsea has concerned their inconsistency and seeming inability to produce the quality of football for the bread-and-butter fixtures, Bradford away for example, that they have shown in the big games.

After losing at Valley Parade Vialli's peace of mind could ill-afford another setback. The way Aston Villa began, however, suggested that Chelsea would struggle again. With Lee Hendrie and Paul Merson taking on opponents with the ball and establishing early links with Nilis and Dion Dublin, Chelsea found it difficult to get into the match, let alone achieve a rhythm of their own.

After 10 minutes Dublin nodded the ball out to Alan Wright whose centre from the left found Nilis nipping across Frank Leboeuf to gain possession before beating Carlo Cudicini with a superb left-footed shot on the turn.

Cudicini had come into the Chelsea goal at the last minute after the first choice, Ed de Goey, had strained a muscle during the kick-in.

Early in the second half Cudicini did exceptionally well to push away a shot from Hendrie aimed towards the top far corner of the goal, by which time Villa were rueing a lapse by James similar to the error which had led to Chelsea's winning goal in the FA Cup final.

As Dennis Wise swung over a corner a minute before the half-hour James failed to get to the ball and Desailly, just as he had done at Wembley, headed hard towards the net. This time, however, a finishing touch from Roberto Di Matteo was not needed.

Far from blaming James, John Gregory, the Aston Villa manager, said his defenders had lost concentration in allowing Desailly a free header. James, he claimed, had been obstructed by Flo but Villa had not been awarded a free-kick because Paul Durkin, the referee, felt the goalkeeper was not going to reach the ball. If that was the case Durkin is not a bad judge.

fields.headline: Finding the White balance
fields.trailText: The summer's most overlooked success has been Craig White, believes Vic Marks
fields.body:
This summer England cricketers have been grabbing the headlines and - glory be - it's often been for the right reasons. There has been Dominic Cork's match at Lord's; a couple of purple spells from Andrew Caddick; Darren Gough, now canny as well as impish, alarming overseas left-handers with the new ball; Stewart's hundred in his 100th Test and Marcus Trescothick's encouraging arrival in international cricket.

So it's not so strange that one of the more significant advances by any English cricketer this summer has passed almost unnoticed. Perhaps it is appropriate that Craig White should now find himself a regular in the England squad without any fanfare. For White does not crave the spotlight; and he concedes that he's not the most confident man in the world, that he has a tendency for introspection, for agonising over past failures on the cricket field.

In a way this is remarkable. You'd think anyone born in Yorkshire and brought up in Victoria, Australia, would, at best, be full of himself; at worst intolerably brash and insensitive; a talker not a listener. So much for our stereotypes. White is quietly spoken, unassuming and a little diffident; far closer to Graham Thorpe, say, than his fellow Yorkshireman, Gough.

He's had an astonishing eight months. Last winter he was in New Zealand, in the middle of an undertaking to play one-day cricket for Central Districts when the SOS from South Africa arrived. This surprised him since he was not one of the reserves alerted to be on standby for the tour. He replaced the injured Andrew Flintoff and his one-day performances soon impressed coach, Duncan Fletcher, something White learnt at first hand on another rain-soaked afternoon in South Africa.

'I remember being in my room and I got a call from Duncan to come and see him. He told me he'd seen something he liked not just for one-day cricket but for Test cricket as well. Somehow he knows how to say the right thing at the right time. He lets you know that he rates you. And I came out of his room ten feet tall, feeling a world-beater.'

The central contract, offered White at the start of this season, soon confirmed that Fletcher wasn't blathering; he put the ECB's money where his mouth was. The pundits were surprised but now most of us nod sagely. Yet it has not been straightforward for White this summer.

He was omitted from the team to play against Zimbabwe at Lord's in May and tore a hamstring while on a training run. The hamstring tear was to become the least of his worries as he recalls: 'I went back to Yorkshire and on the Sunday I was going to Headingley on my motorbike for some treatment and I could hardly see. On the Monday my vision failed again. On the Tuesday when I was in Scarborough I had a pain in my chest and blacked out. I ended up in the gutter with blood pouring from my chin. Apparently I'd been unconscious for about 20 seconds'.

After a night in hospital under observation there was a desperately anxious ten days for White awaiting the results of a variety of tests. No definite answers were produced but at least blood clots or brain tumours were ruled out. During that period White contemplated life without cricket and certainly began to view things in a different light: cricket was suddenly a game again.

It may be fanciful to suggest that White's improved performances in an England shirt are a direct consequence of this frightening experience, but there is no doubt that he's looked far more relaxed in international cricket this summer, especially when he's tossing down 88 mph reverse swingers from around the wicket to the West Indian left-handers.

However there was good reason for him to feel a bit awkward in his first spell as an England player. Back in 1994 he was mischievously plucked out of the hat by that Yorkshire magician, Raymond Illingworth, and suddenly plunged into the England side at number six. 'I could sense the conflict between Athers and Illy over selection and that played on my mind. I was thrilled to play and I wouldn't change that but I think I would have played more for England if I'd started a couple of years later,' he says.

For White the pace bowler was incredibly raw in 1994. He came over to England from the Australian Academy in 1990. 'I arrived as an opening batsman, who also bowled off-spin and was a reserve wicketkeeper,' he recalls. Like Fred Trueman he played for the Yorkshire first team before playing in the second XI and actually took five wickets in an innings against Surrey at Harrogate in that season bowling off-spinners.

But he cemented his place in the team as a batsman. In the nets he bowled some seamers and Martyn Moxon was impressed by his surprising pace from such a gentle, ambling approach and started giving him a few overs in this vein in Championship cricket in 1993. In 1994 he was in the Test team; it was, as they say in Bendigo, where White was raised, 'a big ask'.

Now at the age of 30 he's learnt his trade. He offers the batsman an unusual threat especially with the old ball. He has become a reverse-swing specialist. When the ball stops swinging in the orthodox manner for Gough and Caddick it's time to toss the ball to White to see if reverse swing can come into play. He attacks the left-handers, predominantly from around the wicket and the slip cordon are on the alert. He's content in a role that has changed significantly since his arrival in England a decade ago. Now he's a bowler, who bats as low as number eight for England. He's yet to score many runs at Test level but he should do. On a broader scale he's happy - after his experience in Scarborough - just to be playing.

He's yet to score many runs at Test level but he should do. On a broader scale he's happy - after his experience in Scarborough - just to be playing.

webTitle: Coping with Saqlain is the key

fields.headline: Coping with Saqlain is the key
fields.trailText: The touring squad will bond strongly in Pakistan, but beware the spinning fingers of Saqlain Mushtaq, warns Ed Giddins.
fields.body:
England's winter tour to Pakistan will be the first time that the senior side has ventured to that country since the infamous tour in 1987. Back in 1995 I travelled there on an England A trip under the leadership of Nasser Hussain but most of the boys won't have played out there before and are in for something different.

Pakistan is one of those places where the squad will tend to stick together. This is fantastic for team spirit but is brought about by the lack of the usual diversions encountered in the Caribbean, South Africa or Australia.

When we were out there we seemed to spend an awful lot of time in the markets, particularly in Lahore, where we became very adept at avoiding buying carpets and other furnishings. Not everybody found it easy to say no, John Emburey, who acted as the cricket manager on the trip, came a real cropper. Having spent something like £2,000 on carpets he got them back to England and had them valued. The estimate came to about £50.

There are other hazards like the food but a little common sense should avoid any serious mishaps. It is sensible to eat as much rice as possible and spaghetti bolognese is a safe choice for the cautious tourist. Jason Pooley took caution to extremes as he ate 'spag-bol' for breakfast, lunch and dinner, every day of the tour. It's a shame really as the hotel staff were delightful and couldn't have been more helpful.

On the whole Pakistan is very social and I guarantee the England party will be very well looked after. The British High Commission in Rawalpindi are fantastic hosts and will provide the players with the chance of a relaxing beer and a game of darts.

The most important aspect of the tour is what happens out in the middle and I think England have a very good chance. The key to the whole trip is how they deal with Saqlain Mushtaq, who is a wizard. If the pitches turn - and you have to guess that they will - then seeing off Saqlain is essential. It might be prudent to take John Crawley as he is a good player of spin and seems to be coming into form at the right time.

England's current strength lies in their pace attack and the key men will be Darren Gough and Craig White, who was there in 1995. They are vital due to their ability to reverse-swing the ball.

I discovered when I was out there that during the first 10 to 12 overs of an innings the ball will swing a lot but then it suddenly stops. This is because the surfaces in Pakistan are very abrasive and take the shine off the ball. Often a side is reduced to something like 20 for three but will then build a partnership as the ball stops swinging. In years gone by the Pakistanis have been the masters of reverse swing but in Gough and White we have two of the best in the business and they will see a lot of work in the three Tests.

Andy Caddick's effectiveness might be dulled as the bounce tends to be of the skiddy variety so his height won't help him that much.

I doubt that there will be too many surprises when the party is announced as England now look to be a settled outfit. But they pick must players who can deal with Saqlain.

webTitle: Striking it rich with a squad

fields.headline: Striking it rich with a squad
fields.trailText: England announce their squad for the fifth Test today and their party for the winter tours tomorrow. Vic Marks on England's likely lads.
fields.body:
Today the England selectors announce their squad for the final Test of the summer at The Oval; tomorrow it is their intention to reveal those chosen for the winter tours, which will take the team to Kenya, Pakistan and Sri Lanka for one-day internationals and six Test matches. They set off on 29 September.

The composition of the Test squad may have caused much agonising but it will only have been about one place. The Oval demands the inclusion of a spinner in the 12, but which one? Robert Croft toiled at Old Trafford for just one wicket and the notion that an off-spinner is the best way forward against a battery of left-handers is losing favour. Chris Schofield is contracted but cannot even demand a regular place in the Lancashire first team. He's too raw and unreliable for such a crucial game.

So the final choice will probably have rested between two left-arm spinners, Ashley Giles and a cricketer who is perennially summoned back for the final Test of an English summer, before embarking on yet another tour, Phil Tufnell. Both have enjoyed reasonably productive summers in the second division of the Championship. Tufnell is the superior spinner; Giles offers the prospect of a few runs.

Given that England have taken the lead in the series partly because their lower order has been far less brittle than that of the West Indians, who are capable of disappearing in the time it takes for Channel 4 to pop off to Newmarket for the 3.10, the selectors may well opt for the 'two-dimensional' cricketer, Giles, rather than the out-and-out specialist, Tufnell.

They would prefer to see a surface at The Oval that does not demand a spinner in the final XI but this is unlikely. In which case there will be more agonising on Thursday morning as they decide who to omit from the victorious Headingley team. There is no easy solution. There has been the fanciful suggestion that it should be Mike Atherton, a little short of Test runs, but this would be ridiculous. What about Cork? Two problems here; so far he has taken 15 wickets at 11 apiece in the series and he's just struck a double century for Derbyshire. I think not.

A month ago Craig White would have been the obvious candidate, but his brand of pace bowling , delivered from around the wicket at the left-handers, has been a revelation. My inclination would be to leave out Hick if a specialist spinner is required. There would be much mumbling about his key contribution at Headingley and the fact that this would be the eleventh time that he's been dropped from the Test team. This would have to be countered by selectorial protestations that England now operate a squad system and the sort of 'horses for courses' policy now favoured by the Australians.

At least England's problem is who to omit; the West Indies don't know who to pick. Their support bowling is in disarray. Reon King, whose confidence was shattered at Leeds, is now lame anyway. Nor was Franklyn Rose fit enough to play at Taunton on a pitch that must have surprised the tourists; the ball bounced predictably and then kept going in the same direction. By a process of elimination they will probably have to play Nixon McLean and the leg spinner, Mahendra Nagamootoo, even though neither of them has looked particularly threatening on the tour. Provided Shivnarine Chanderpaul has recovered fitness they must be tempted to open up with Wavell Hinds rather than Adrian Griffiths. England, peculiarly, enter the Test as firm favourites, though nothing can be taken for granted against a side that possesses three world-class players as well as a few duds.

The list of potential England tourists will not be as extensive as usual. For the Tests in Pakistan and Sri Lanka we can take as a base the Headingley Test team and add five. This will include two spinners, who could well be Giles and Tufnell. Again, I would not flirt with Schofield. England's improvement stems partly from the fact that they are grudging in the field, offering fewer cheap runs than in the past. The spinner must at least support the seamers by being mean even if he is not going to run through the opposition. (An extra one may be considered for the Sri Lankan tour.)

Moreover the notion that youngsters can learn on the senior tour should be discarded; nowadays there is neither the time nor the fixture list to do that as Graeme Swann and Alex Tudor discovered in South Africa last winter. But with Alan Mullally unavailable for Test cricket this winter young Matthew Hoggard has the chance to embark on his first England tour. I would also stick with Andrew Flintoff and a second wicketkeeper is essential since it's always possible that Stewart may encounter a dodgy boiled egg on the morning of the match.

The one-day squad has converged with the Test team over the past six months, which is a good sign. It's quality that counts. So the only tourist additions should be Nick Knight, provided he recovers from a knee operation which is scheduled for Tuesday, and Mark Ealham. There is a case for resting Stewart, since he's so indispensable, from the tournament in Kenya, but he would be appalled by the idea.

fields.headline: One-day final a damp squib
fields.standfirst: Lord's showpiece moved to today
fields.trailText: Vic Marks at Lord's believes cricket's premier one-day competition is losing its lustre.
fields.body:
The NatWest final is often regarded as cricket's FA Cup. The ECB's chief executive, Tim Lamb, made that comparison again yesterday while Lord's was enveloped by rain, which means that the game takes place today. The parallel may be valid, but it is not such a cheery thought as it once was. In recent times the FA Cup has become devalued; it is no longer regarded as the pinnacle of the football season and judging by the ticket sales for the game between Gloucestershire and Warwickshire, cricket's one-day final is also losing its appeal.

17,000 tickets had been sold for the match, so even if the sun had shone there would have been some embarrassing empty spaces in a stadium that now holds 28,000. There was a time when a final ticket was a rare and valuable item. When Warwickshire played their semi-final against Hampshire at Edgbaston the ground was barely a third full. The ECB must surely reconsider their pricing policy. Better to fill the ground rather than charge up to £50 for a ticket.

There was also a time when victory in the one-day final constituted a fine season for a county side. There is no guarantee of that now. Warwickshire, even if they win the final today, have a few problems to sort out. The advent of two divisions has changed the emphasis of the season. Narrowly - and controversially - consigned to the second division in both competitions last year, Warwickshire are not guaranteed to escape in either form of the game. They are seventh in the Championship table and third in the one-day league.

So even if they win this final they can't put their feet up for the rest of the season. Their coach, Bob Woolmer, has openly mused whether their current captain, Neil Smith, should demand a regular place in the team; one or two of their prominent players want away and Allan Donald won't be returning next summer.

Not that anything can be taken for granted against Gloucestershire, who contest their fourth consecutive Lord's final; they have won their previous three. In Worcester they grumpily aver that their name must already be written on the trophy; remember how Worcestershire defeated Gloucestershire in the first round of the NatWest this summer but were forced to replay the game because they fielded an ineligible player.

Gloucestershire make their own luck as well. They have a superbly complimentary duo in charge; the softly-spoken, self-effacing Mark Alleyne and the Kiwi, John Bracewell, forthright and innovative. Together they have forged a magnificent one-day side, which bats and fields aggressively and whose bowlers make a virtue of their lack of pace. The names on the Gloucestershire scorecard terrify no one but the team is formidable, which is a reflection on the achievements of Alleyne and Bracewell.

Another leadership duo to be much lauded in recent days is England's Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain. Hussain was there yesterday as part of Channel 4's commentary team and as the rain persisted he was prevailed upon to look forward to the final Test at The Oval. He was, as usual, cooperative, but wary since he could not reveal the decisions of the selectors about the team for the final Test, which will be announced today or the composition of the touring parties (announced tomorrow).

In a way Fletcher and Hussain are seeking to ape the achievements of Alleyne and Bracewell, to create an England team that is as tight-knit and committed to one another as the best of county sides. Hussain reinforced the notion that his players are starting to believe they are England cricketers, first and foremost. Their county allegiances are becoming increasingly peripheral and their appearances strictly controlled by Fletcher.

He is peculiarly suited to this role. It actually helps that Fletcher is from overseas. This means that he has no axes to grind. Admittedly he had two years as a coach at Glamorgan but he can be dispassionate in his judgment of who can play when, without the pull of old mates from his old county.

Hussain said that England would not be looking to protect their 2-1 lead in the series by playing for a draw at The Oval. Five days is a long time for both of these teams, he said. But he also pined for a longer match. It will be good for the game if the Test goes five days like Old Trafford. It would also be good for the ECB coffers that cannot afford many more truncated Tests or damp, sparsely- attended one-day finals.

There was also a time when victory in the one-day final constituted a fine season for a county side. There is no guarantee of that now. Warwickshire, even if they win the final today, have a few problems to sort out. The advent of two divisions has changed the emphasis of the season. Narrowly - and controversially - consigned to the second division in both competitions last year, Warwickshire are not guaranteed to escape in either form of the game. They are seventh in the Championship table and third in the one-day league. So even if they win this final they can't put their feet up for the rest of the season. Their coach, Bob Woolmer, has openly mused whether their current captain, Neil Smith, should demand a regular place in the team; one or two of their prominent players want away and Allan Donald won't be returning next summer. Not that anything can be taken for granted against Gloucestershire, who contest their fourth consecutive Lord's final; they have won their previous three. In Worcester they grumpily aver that their name must already be written on the trophy; remember how Worcestershire defeated Gloucestershire in the first round of the NatWest this summer but were forced to replay the game because they fielded an ineligible player. Gloucestershire make their own luck as well. They have a superbly complimentary duo in charge; the softly-spoken, self-effacing Mark Alleyne and the Kiwi, John Bracewell, forthright and innovative. Together they have forged a magnificent one-day side, which bats and fields aggressively and whose bowlers make a virtue of their lack of pace. The names on the Gloucestershire scorecard terrify no one but the team is formidable, which is a reflection on the achievements of Alleyne and Bracewell. Another leadership duo to be much lauded in recent days is England's Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain. Hussain was there yesterday as part of Channel 4's commentary team and as the rain persisted he was prevailed upon to look forward to the final Test at The Oval. He was, as usual, cooperative, but wary since he could not reveal the decisions of the selectors about the team for the final Test, which will be announced today or the composition of the touring parties (announced tomorrow). In a way Fletcher and Hussain are seeking to ape the achievements of Alleyne and Bracewell, to create an England team that is as tight-knit and committed to one another as the best of county sides. Hussain reinforced the notion that his players are starting to believe they are England cricketers, first and foremost. Their county allegiances are becoming increasingly peripheral and their appearances strictly controlled by Fletcher. He is peculiarly suited to this role. It actually helps that Fletcher is from overseas. This means that he has no axes to grind. Admittedly he had two years as a coach at Glamorgan but he can be dispassionate in his judgment of who can play when, without the pull of old mates from his old county. Hussain said that England would not be looking to protect their 2-1 lead in the series by playing for a draw at The Oval. Five days is a long time for both of these teams, he said. But he also pined for a longer match. It will be good for the game if the Test goes five days like Old Trafford. It would also be good for the ECB coffers that cannot afford many more truncated Tests or damp, sparsely- attended one-day finals.

fields.headline: Overstep costs five grand
fields.trailText: Cricket is hardly the most lucrative of sports, and individual rewards traditionally go into a team 'pool'. But yesterday at Lord's a young bowler had the chance to pocket £5,000 - and blew it.
fields.body:
Cricket is hardly the most lucrative of sports, and individual rewards traditionally go into a team 'pool'. But yesterday at Lord's a young bowler had the chance to pocket £5,000 - and blew it.

Matthew Whiley, a 20-year-old whose Nottinghamshire appearances have been mostly for the second XI, was one of a group of young fast bowlers competing for the money put up by Freeserve, the sponsors of the speed gun used at all major matches. With rain dominating outside, the young tearaways stretched themselves to the limit on the smooth surface of the indoor cricket school.

One of those competing was Yorkshire's Matthew Hoggard, who made his Test debut here, but at the end of the preliminary round the best reading was 84.1mph by the little-known Whiley, a heftily-built left-armer. After a rest, the best six bowlers delivered the decisive three balls. Hoggard now went ahead with 86.2mph. Then, with a drama that echoed an Olympic long-jump final, Whiley's last delivery registered 86.5 - but he was no-balled. It was agonisingly close. A mere half-inch beyond the line had deprived him of £5,000.

In the best traditions of the Big Loser, Whiley said: 'I came here with nothing so I've lost nothing.'

Hoggard received his big cheque from team-mate Darren Gough, who stands to win an even bigger sum - £10,000 - for the fastest ball of the summer. There has been no serious challenge to the 93.2mph he recorded in the summer's first Test, against Zimbabwe.

*****

Being hand-made, cricket balls vary more than balls in any other sport. And unlike, say, tennis or football, it's not the same for both sides: the variability can dramatically benefit one team at the other's expense. It seems astonishing, then, that professional cricket has been so lax in checking and monitoring balls - though that could be about to change.

The catalyst may be the recent discovery that many Dukes balls were lighter than the permitted weight tolerances - arguably making them swing more - while some Readers balls were overweight. Clearly, the twice-a-year checks by the British Standards Institution are inadequate for this type of product. Surely that is where the umpires should come in. At present, the most they will do is check for size with two ring gauges.

Many counties select their season's supply at the maker's factory, and the whim of bowlers seems to dictate. It is from that selection that, before each innings of a county match, the fielding side choose their ball. At long last, all this is starting to worry the England Cricket Board, who recognise that 'manufacturers are encouraged to produce a ball that bowlers like'.

John Carr, of the ECB, says: 'We have a problem that we must address. It may well be that all balls for county cricket will have to come through the ECB offices and be checked by us.' That would certainly be a professional move.

'Do Channel 4 producers ever read this stuff?' So asks a plaintive message, one of many placed on the cricket4.com website. Probably not, is the answer. Channel 4's cricket is delivered by a production company, Sunset+Vine, whose boss was last week unaware of a stream of messages supporting a 'Bring Back Sensible Cricket Highlights Campaign'.

The accessible channel deserves credit for displaying viewers' opinions, many of which are supportive. But no topic, not even the switches from cricket to racing has generated such concerted criticism as the highlights programme.

Viewers say that a 30-minute slot at 7.30pm is too short and too early, and they're particularly irked by time being taken up by this summer's 'arty', mannered introductions to the programme. Trying to catch up on the day's play, the campaigners say they just want lots of great shots and wickets - the 'People's Highlights' as one of them says.

When contacted last week, Sunset+Vine's managing director, Jeff Foulser, was unaware of the comments on cricket4 and rather scornful of the term 'campaign'. He concedes that 'maybe we have been a bit ambitious', but argues that the highlights have to be more entertaining to draw an audience that will justify the early evening slot. 'Last year the highlights didn't rate very high. This year they've gone up a bit.' As for the ECB, their marketing director, Terry Blake, says this year the highlights have been 'really amazing - the old format was not the way forward'.

*****

There is no doubt that Colwyn Bay is a small ground. There were 20 sixes there last week as the Glamorgan v Sussex game generated 1,376 runs. However, the 1,354 runs at Leicester included only five sixes. Such statistics should make it clear that it is difficult to defend such small boundaries as Colwyn Bay's. Yet the game continues to sustain the perverse notion that big grounds like the Oval and Bristol are 'hard to defend'. Nonsense. They may see many twos and threes, but that just means fewer fours and sixes.

fields.headline: Third division roundup
fields.trailText: Chesterfield made it nine points out of nine for the season with their 3-0 win over the bottom club Shrewsbury. David Reeves scored either side of a 40-yard chip from Sean Parrish to keep the Spireites two points ahead of Cheltenham and Leyton Orient at the top.
fields.body:
Chesterfield made it nine points out of nine for the season with their 3-0 win over the bottom club Shrewsbury. David Reeves scored either side of a 40-yard chip from Sean Parrish to keep the Spireites two points ahead of Cheltenham and Leyton Orient at the top.

Richard Garcia scored two for the Os, but in between them Paul Simpson had equalised for Blackpool and late in the game Danny Coid claimed a point for Steve McMahon's team.

Cheltenham had Julian Alsop sent off and Bob Bloomer dismissed from the dugout in their home game with Torquay but still won 2-0. Jamie Victory scored before the interval and Neil Howarth during a second half which saw United's Steve Tully also sent to the dressing room for a second bookable offence.

Scunthorpe slipped to fourth after losing at Rochdale, where Tony Ellis became the first player to score against them this season. Gary Sheldon and Lee Hodges, from the spot, soon rectified that but Clive Platt and Paul Ware secured the points for Steve Parkin's side.

Barnet, with Eddie Newton making his debut, allowed Cardiff to come from two down to secure a point, Josh Low and Rob Earnshaw getting the goals.
