webTitle: Battle over Gulf War hero's missing brain

fields.headline: Battle over hero's missing brain
fields.standfirst: MoD charged with illegally removing brain of Gulf War veteran for secret scientific tests
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence was last night at the centre of extraordinary allegations that it was behind a programme to remove body parts from Gulf War veterans illegally and send them for secret research experiments.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence was last night at the centre of extraordinary allegations that it was behind a programme to remove body parts from Gulf War veterans illegally and send them for secret research experiments.

Mark McGhee, a lawyer, has launched legal action for the mother of one soldier, 24-year-old Andrew Mullineux, amid allegations that his brain was removed after he died mysteriously in 1993. It is alleged that the brain and other organs were sent to Porton Down, a military research centre in Wiltshire.

Margaret Mullineux only found out the fate of her son's organs last February in a letter from a consultant pathologist at the Royal Military Hospital in Gosport. It informed her Andrew's brain was removed six years earlier after a post-mortem at Southampton General Hospital.

The letter, which has been seen by The Observer, says parts of it were sent 'to Porton Down because of the potential risk of infection'. Tissue samples of skin, liver, kidney and spleen were also sent.

Mrs Mullineux said: 'I was shattered. I believed I had buried my son whole and I now have found out his brain was removed without my permission and parts of his body are now in jars at Porton Down. I remember at the time of his funeral the undertaker advising me to keep the coffin lid closed. At the time, I didn't know why, but I do now.'

She added: 'When he died Andrew was a civilian and died at a civilian hospital. I want to know why a doctor at a military hospital was telling me six years later that his brain was sent to Porton Down.'

McGhee, who also represents more than 120 veterans suffering from Gulf War syndrome, says he has received inquiries from several families who believe the MoD has removed organs and tissues from their relatives without their knowledge.

He said: 'The Human Tissues Act requires permission from next of kin before body parts are removed, and it appears in the case of Andrew this hasn't happened. I believe there are other similar cases and we need to know what went on and why these body tissues were removed and retained.'

The veterans believe their illness stems from injections they were given to help protect them against chemical gas attacks, or from radiation poisoning from depleted uranium shells used in the war.

Larry Cammock, chairman of the Gulf Veterans' Association, said: 'We know of a number of cases where body parts have been removed from veterans under mysterious circumstances. What are the MoD trying to hide?'

A Ministry spokesman said: 'There is absolutely no truth in the suggestion we are taking body parts of Gulf War veterans and sending them to Porton Down or anywhere else.'

The allegations, which first surfaced in Esquire magazine, were a matter for the hospital, he said. But the pathologist might have confused Andrew's mother by mentioning Porton Down. Although it is best known for secret military research, the site also houses the Department of Health's Centre for Applied Microbiological Research (CAMR). Perhaps the body tissues were sent to this centre, the MoD suggested.

But a CAMR official said: 'We have absolutely no record of receiving a sample from a patient of the name Mullineux. Our records are very comprehensive and I am confident we would know if we had received such samples in the time period suggested.'

A spokeswoman for the Southampton hospital said: 'If anything was sent to Porton Down it's a question for the Ministry of Defence, not us.'

The Government is reviewing the rules governing organ removal after the scandal at Alder Hey Children's Hospital in Liverpool, where it emerged that parts from the bodies of 146 children were retained without their parents' knowledge.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Terrorist fear as bomb cache is found hidden in woods
fields.body:
Terrorist fear as bomb cache is found hidden in woods

Bomb disposal experts were yesterday working to defuse a series of sophisticated explosive devices found in a copse near Witney, Oxon, on Friday. There are fears they may have been placed by dissident Irish republican terrorists.

Driver held over immigrants

Belgian lorry driver Muzafer Prekopuca, 33, appeared at Dover accused of illegally bringing 25 Indian and Afghan men into Britain. He was remanded in custody.

Storm family strike it lucky

A family struck by lightning during an open-air concert at Blenheim Palace, Oxfordshire, had a lucky escape, said emergency workers. A tree they were standing under was split in half.

Army billets for bats

Rare bats are to be given protected homes in Second World War pill boxes in Thundery Meadows, Surrey, under a conservancy scheme by the National History Museum.

Fire of London

Crowds gathered to see a replica of 17th century London go up in flames last night at Torrington, Devon. The recreation of the Great Fire of 1666 raised money for charity.

Vodafone price cut claim

Vodafone announced new tariffs which, it claimed, would mean the cost of using a mobile phone had dropped by 6 per cent in the last five years. It was the latest operator to announce cuts.

One dead, 20 hurt in crash

Twenty holidaymakers were treated in hospital after their coach left the A1 near Harrogate, crashing into a field. The driver died. Those aboard were returning from a holiday to the north-east of England. In other parts of the country bad weather contributed to bank holiday motorway traffic jams yesterday.

Lottery winners

The winning numbers are 4 11 16 29 34 35, bonus 13. Thunderball numbers are 2 8 10 30 33, Thunderball 9.

War victims to be buried

Four Second World War airmen whose bomber crashed in Iceland in 1941 are today to be buried with full military honours at the Commonwealth Graves Commission cemetery in Reykjavik.

Their Fairey Battle bomber was entombed in a glacier. Last week a team from RAF Kinloss, Morayshire, retrieved the bodies when exceptionally warm weather softened the ice.

webTitle: Last of the Krays freed to die after 32 years in jail

fields.headline: Last of the Krays freed to die after 32 years in jail
fields.standfirst: His brothers are gone, and his illness is terminal, but he has won his last wish
fields.trailText: Reggie Kray, the last surviving member of Britain's most infamous gangland family, is finally to leave prison this week after Home Secretary Jack Straw ruled yesterday that he should be allowed home to die.
fields.body:
Reggie Kray, the last surviving member of Britain's most infamous gangland family, is finally to leave prison this week after Home Secretary Jack Straw ruled yesterday that he should be allowed home to die.

Kray, 66, is terminally ill with cancer of the bladder and has a life expectancy of only a few weeks. Having spent 32 years behind bars, he faces a world changed beyond all recognition from the one he left behind, but friends and family say knowing that he will not die in prison will be a great comfort to him.

He was said to have been overcome with emotion after being given the news by his prison governor. Although Kray is currently too ill to be moved, his solicitor, Trevor Linn, said yesterday he hoped to be at home with his wife, Roberta, by the end of the week.

Rather than returning to London's East End, Reggie is likely to live out his last days at his wife's home a few miles from his Norfolk prison, where she moved two years ago to be closer to him. Insiders at the hospital say Kray is unlikely to leave his bed, let alone take part in any welcome home parties.

Anne Osborn, acting chief executive at the Norfolk and Norwich hospital said: 'Mr Kray will not be leaving in the foreseeable future. 'He hasn't recovered sufficiently to be fit to go.'

Reggie and his twin, Ronnie, led Britain's most notorious criminal clan. Their gang, The Firm, established a Mafia-style grip on London's criminal underworld in the Sixties, specialising in protection and extortion rackets. The Twins, as Ronnie and Reggie were universally known, were born in Bethnal Green, east London, in 1933, with Reggie the younger by 45 minutes. The family was part Irish, Jewish, Gypsy and Austrian. Their father was a second-hand clothes dealer. Their mother, Violet, made them the centre of her world and they worshipped her.

By the time they were 17, both were accomplished amateur boxers but decided against turning professional for fear of losing their looks.

Both were dishonourably discharged from National Service in 1954 after spending much of their time in military prisons, and within two years they established the biggest criminal racket in London's East End. The turning point for them came when they bought a seedy snooker club in Bethnal Green which was the scene of almost constant fights. webTitle: Leader: The cover-up of the meningitis vaccine

fields.headline: A fatal cover-up?
fields.standfirst: Life, death and the meningitis vaccine
fields.trailText: Few things are more emotionally charged than the decisions parents must make in the care of their children. With mass vaccination programmes, those decisions - each one possibly the difference between life and death - are being made by millions of parents. That rich recipe can cause panic that can itself cost lives. Fears that whooping cough vaccination could cause brain damage led to a mass boycott in 1974. Hundreds of thousands of infants contracted the disease. Only in 1985, with parents reassured by new evidence, was whooping cough nearly eliminated.
fields.body:
Few things are more emotionally charged than the decisions parents must make in the care of their children. With mass vaccination programmes, those decisions - each one possibly the difference between life and death - are being made by millions of parents. That rich recipe can cause panic that can itself cost lives. Fears that whooping cough vaccination could cause brain damage led to a mass boycott in 1974. Hundreds of thousands of infants contracted the disease. Only in 1985, with parents reassured by new evidence, was whooping cough nearly eliminated.

The Department of Health believes that reactions to the new meningitis C vaccination could have killed 11 schoolchildren, but has decided on a cover-up. This will undermine confidence in a vaccination scheme that could save hundreds of lives. Doctors and parents must be told what effects the vaccination could have, so that they can cope with the few bad reactions. Parents, if they are exposing their child to a risk, have an absolute right to know what that risk is.

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: South Africa is fighting Aids

fields.headline: South Africa is fighting Aids
fields.trailText: The suggestion by David Beresford (World, last week) that South Africa is 'in denial over Aids' is an affront.  President Mbeki takes the HIV/Aids pandemic extremely seriously and campaigns vigorously to promote awareness and   prevention, focusing on abstinence, safe sex and condom use.
fields.body:
The suggestion by David Beresford (World, last week) that South Africa is 'in denial over Aids' is an affront. President Mbeki takes the HIV/Aids pandemic extremely seriously and campaigns vigorously to promote awareness and prevention, focusing on abstinence, safe sex and condom use.

We have a five-year strategic plan focusing on key areas of prevention, education and social mobilisation, including treatment, care and support, with strategies to reduce transmission of HIV from mother to child. Our focus remains the improvement of access to all drugs, including anti-retrovirals.

At current prices, anti-retrovirals are beyond the reach of developing countries. Their introduction into the health service will require substantial investment in infrastructure, training and support. We also need time to evaluate the drug Nevirapine. Studies from Uganda suggest it can reduce HIV/Aids transmission from mothers to babies, but other findings show a reversal where women continue to breastfeed.

The epidemic will be with us for many years. We remain committed to positive and decisive action and are determined to meet our constitutional obligations to provide safe, affordable and accessible health care to all South Africans.

Cheryl Carolus
South African High Commissioner
London WC2

webTitle: The secret's out - today's mistress is really the master

fields.headline: The secret's out - today's mistress is really the master
fields.standfirst: A new book explains how the once pitied 'other woman' is coming into her own
fields.trailText: Ally McBeal may complain that all the best men are married, but a new breed of self-confessed serial mistresses say women in the know would not want it any other way.
fields.body:
Ally McBeal may complain that all the best men are married, but a new breed of self-confessed serial mistresses say women in the know would not want it any other way.

Today's mistresses are a different species from the old-school Other Woman, whose lonely days revolved around the phone call that never came. The modern mistress is in control and in demand. Her position empowers her and, best of all, she never has to watch football in bed.

Victoria Griffin - author of a new book, The Mistress: Histories, Myths and Interpretations of the 'Other Woman', and a mistress herself - believes the modern mistress has discovered what men have long known: sex without commitment is fun and empowering.

Griffin believes that, while marriage forces women to cede control over their lives, illicit love affairs allow them to protect their autonomy while enjoying loving relationships.

'I value my independence and have a horror of domesticity and family life,' said Griffin, a serial mistress for 15 years and in her current illicit relationship for three years. 'At the same time, I thrive on having an intimate relationship in the background - stable, but not obvious. Thus, someone who is unable to be with me all the time but who, when he is with me, is fully with me, is ideal.'

Griffin believes that, although society likes to pretend women are free to co-exist in equal relationships with men, the reality is different. 'It's getting more difficult to admit to being a serial mistress because marriage isn't the oppressive and coercive institution it once was,' she said. 'People don't have to get married so they're expected to remain faithful when they finally do.

'But we're deluding ourselves. Society still conditions women into taking a second seat in relationships and teaches them to compromise their lives for the benefit of their male partner,' she added.

'I know myself well enough to know I simply don't have the internal boundaries to resist putting myself in second place in a relationship. I know the sort of life I want to lead and I know the characteristics in me that could endanger it. I've chosen my life carefully to get what I want: the best of both worlds.'

Griffin believes the empowered mistress relishes her anarchic, secret life and thrives on the excitement of falling in love and living for the moment. 'You can end up with no power at all as a mistress or you can end up holding the full deck of cards. It's completely up to you,' she said.

Phyllis Rose, author of a book on Victorian marriages, Parallel Lives, maintains that modern mistresses get their power from questioning society's definition of a successful relationship. 'The plots we choose to impose on our own lives are limited and limiting,' she said. 'And in no area are they so banal and sterile as in love and marriage, where we filter out experience through the romantic clichés of popular culture.'

Margaret Emsley, a 45-year-old antiques dealer from Eastbourne, East Sussex, has been a mistress to three men for the past nine years and says she's never been happier or more in control of her own life.

'I have a thriving business, my own house and a comfortable lifestyle. But as a mistress, I get the best of a man while being able to ignore the worst,' she said. 'After three failed marriages, I've found my recipe for happiness.'

'I don't have to wash his socks, clean his kitchen floor or do the countless chores a wife has to, and instead I get taken to the best restaurants, given expensive presents and get treated like a queen.

'I wouldn't marry any of my lovers for the world. I'm never going to give any man the power to have a say in how I live my life or be unfaithful to me. I'm holding the pack and I'm not giving away a single card.'

webTitle: Observer alert starts engine fumes inquiry

fields.headline: Observer alert starts engine fumes inquiry
fields.trailText: The government is to carry out an urgent investigation into the risk of an air disaster after warnings that lives are at risk from toxic fumes leaking into the cabin during flights.
fields.body:
The government is to carry out an urgent investigation into the risk of an air disaster after warnings that lives are at risk from toxic fumes leaking into the cabin during flights.

In December, The Observer revealed that a British Aerospace jet in Sweden nearly crashed after poisonous fumes seeped into the cabin, knocking out the pilots and turning the passengers 'into zombies'.

This was only one of dozens of similar incidents affecting the jet, a BAe 146, which is used by thousands of holidaymakers each year.

The problem appears to be caused by lubricant oils that contain a chemical compound called Tricesylphosphate (TCP), which is believed to cause nervous system disorders. Faulty seals in the engines allow the fumes to enter the cabins through the air-conditioning.

Six pilots who have been unable to work since inhaling toxic fumes while flying have had their cases taken up by the British pilot's union. Hundreds of cabin staff in America, Canada and Australia have complained of feeling disorientated, blurred vision and breathing difficulties. The Australian Senate has already launched an inquiry after a series of leaks on the BAe 146.

Now, Environment Minister Michael Meacher has 'asked the Civil Aviation Authority to review the report of the investigation as soon as it is available and advise me of its contents'.

Since The Observer's revelations, it has emerged that many of the world's largest airlines have the same problem, including British Airways. There have been more than 90 incidents reported to the CAA of fumes escaping into the cabin over the past 10 years. Although 17 of these involved BAe 146s, 33 have been reported on Boeing 737s, 21 in Boeing 757s and 20 in Airbus A320s.

A study by Dr Jean Balouet, of the international Aerospace medical Association, estimated that 300 flights a year suffer fluid leaks or cabin smoke.

In March, an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 aborted its fight to Anchorage after passengers complained about a chemical mist. One passenger had an asthma attack and others vomited. The airline admitted that oil had leaked into the air supply.

Paul Tyler, Liberal Democrat MP for North Cornwall and chair of the all-party organophosphate group, said: 'The implications for air safety are mind-boggling. Of the 1,000 deaths that take place in flight each year worldwide, more are due to heart attacks than to crashes. Passengers are in an environment where there may be 20 to 25 per cent less oxygen, equivalent to being at the top of a mountain. When you add this to the gathering evidence of neurological damage from leaks of dangerous lubricant fumes, it is obvious that there is real cause for concern.'

Some of the pilots affected by this gas have reported similar symptoms to farmers who believe organophosphates used in sheep dip have made them unwell. One British pilot, who does not wish to be named, says that at first he felt like he had a bad flu. He has been off work for several months with suspected organophosphate poisoning.

The Swedish pilot involved in the near-disaster last year said: 'From the onset of the feeling of sickness, I very rapidly became worse, feeling dizzy and groggy.'

Tyler said: 'Every single passenger travelling by air this summer, let alone the pilots and cabin staff, will be reassured that, at long last, the Government is taking this problem seriously.'

webTitle: Life of learning wards off death from coronary

fields.headline: Life of learning wards off death from coronary
fields.trailText: Learning is the key to success in this world - and it can help delay your departure to the next.
fields.body:
Learning is the key to success in this world - and it can help delay your departure to the next.

Scientists have discovered that those who have gone to university or college are five times less likely to die after a heart attack than people with a basic education and menial job.

An international study, the biggest of its kind, showed the heart disease lottery is particularly loaded in Britain. Socio-economic factors have long been known to influence the likelihood of getting heart disease in the first place. Manual workers are three times more likely to suffer than managerial workers, but this is the first major study to look at survival rates among people afflicted.

Some 300,000 people suffer a heart attack every year. Of these, 110,000 will die. Dr Bob Wilcox of the Queen's Medical Centre at Nottingham University and Alan Skeen at Nottingham Clinical Trial Group have collated figures which show a wider socio-economic gap in survival rates than in other nations. They found that 15 per cent of people who left school during or before fifth year will die within a year of suffering a heart attack, compared with 3 per cent of people who stayed on and then completed more than 12 years of learning.

Of the nine countries in the survey - the US, Canada, UK, Germany, Australia, Sweden, Poland, New Zealand and Italy - only the Italians and Swedes had a bigger gap than the British.

Taking all the countries' figures together, the investigators found that, within a year of hospital treatment, the death rate for patients with fewer than eight years of education was 19.8 per cent, compared with 3.5 per cent for those who had more than 16 years of education. Internationally some 15,059 people were monitored and the results were collated by a team led by Dr Conor O'Shea, an Irish scientist working at at Duke University Medical Centre in Durham, North Carolina.

He found that living alone, shown by previous, smaller studies to have a dire impact on heart attack survival rates, had little relevance. 'That was a surprise,' he said. 'People living alone do worse on first glance, but when you factor out that many will be older and therefore likely to have an increased mortality rate anyway, or perhaps suffering from contributory factors like diabetes, then the difference disappears.

'It was less of a surprise to find a patient's level of education and occupational status does significantly predict whether he or she will survive a heart attack, although the difference in the socio-enomic gaps between countries was surprising.

'Of course, the length of time someone spends in education tends to mark out their socio-economic class. It could be that people from lower socio-economic classes are simply not complying with the advice given to them by their health professionals after they have had their heart attack. If they cannot afford to improve their diet, or perhaps continue to smoke, that may explain the dramatic difference in survival rates.

'This needs to be further researched, as does the type of healthcare they are getting. Most importantly, this is a call to arms to see what we can do to reduce this gap.'

It may also have to be taken on board by the Government, which has embarked on a huge £230 million a year programme to cut heart disease deaths.

Doctors need also be aware that education and job are things to be taken into account as risk factors for early deaths, and perhaps treatments for stress offered, O'Shea suggests.

Dr Bob Wilcox of the Queen's Medical Centre at Nottingham University and Alan Skeen at Nottingham Clinical Trial Group have collated figures which show a wider socio-economic gap in survival rates than in other nations. They found that 15 per cent of people who left school during or before fifth year will die within a year of suffering a heart attack, compared with 3 per cent of people who stayed on and then completed more than 12 years of learning. Of the nine countries in the survey - the US, Canada, UK, Germany, Australia, Sweden, Poland, New Zealand and Italy - only the Italians and Swedes had a bigger gap than the British. Taking all the countries' figures together, the investigators found that, within a year of hospital treatment, the death rate for patients with fewer than eight years of education was 19.8 per cent, compared with 3.5 per cent for those who had more than 16 years of education. Internationally some 15,059 people were monitored and the results were collated by a team led by Dr Conor O'Shea, an Irish scientist working at at Duke University Medical Centre in Durham, North Carolina. He found that living alone, shown by previous, smaller studies to have a dire impact on heart attack survival rates, had little relevance. 'That was a surprise,' he said. 'People living alone do worse on first glance, but when you factor out that many will be older and therefore likely to have an increased mortality rate anyway, or perhaps suffering from contributory factors like diabetes, then the difference disappears. 'It was less of a surprise to find a patient's level of education and occupational status does significantly predict whether he or she will survive a heart attack, although the difference in the socio-enomic gaps between countries was surprising. 'Of course, the length of time someone spends in education tends to mark out their socio-economic class. It could be that people from lower socio-economic classes are simply not complying with the advice given to them by their health professionals after they have had their heart attack. If they cannot afford to improve their diet, or perhaps continue to smoke, that may explain the dramatic difference in survival rates. 'This needs to be further researched, as does the type of healthcare they are getting. Most importantly, this is a call to arms to see what we can do to reduce this gap.' It may also have to be taken on board by the Government, which has embarked on a huge £230 million a year programme to cut heart disease deaths. Doctors need also be aware that education and job are things to be taken into account as risk factors for early deaths, and perhaps treatments for stress offered, O'Shea suggests.

webTitle: New meningitis vaccine has saved 100 lives

fields.headline: New vaccine has saved 100 lives
fields.trailText: Meningitis remains one of the most feared killers in this country. It stalks children and adults in the 15-25 age group, causing inflammation of the membrane of brains and spinal columns, as well as blood poisoning.
fields.body:
Meningitis remains one of the most feared killers in this country. It stalks children and adults in the 15-25 age group, causing inflammation of the membrane of brains and spinal columns, as well as blood poisoning.

Scientists believe babies are at particular risk because they have immature immune systems. Teenagers are vulnerable because they have reached an age where they leave home and come into contact with new microbes.

Meningitis bacteria live in the noses and throats of millions of adults and adolescents and are spread by coughing, sneezing and kissing. Just why it affects some individuals but not others is a mystery.

Early symptoms include headaches, vomiting and fevers. Patients often display purple blotches, a sign of blood poisoning.

These blotches do not disappear when pressed with a glass, providing parents with away of detecting the disease. When it has been diagnosed, only rapid administration of antibiotics can save victims.

Two principle classes of bacteria are responsible for these cases: meningitis B and C. The C-strain used to account for about 40 per cent of all reported outbreaks, affecting about 1,500 people of whom 150 were killed. Another 150 were left with severe disabilities.

The development of a vaccine to counter meningitis C (one for meningitis B is still being developed) was therefore hailed as a major breakthrough in the battle against the disease. Several versions are being developed, though only one is currently used in Britain. Unlike many other vaccines, meningitis C inoculations rely on using disabled, not live, versions of microbes to stimulate immune responses that arm the body in advance of a bacterial attack. Instead, the meningitis C bacterium is broken up and a sugar molecule from its outer coat is attached to a protein, which together form the basis of the vaccine.

'In the past, people visiting sub-Saharan countries where meningitis strains are prevalent were given a vaccine based on this sugar molecule,' said Dr Nigel Klein, a consultant in infectious diseases at London's Great Ormond Street Hospital.

'However, protection only lasts a few months.The addition of the protein molecule, from another microbe species provides the body with a longer-lasting ability to fight the disease and it is this scientific development that has allowed doctors to develop the new vaccine.'

Since its introduction last year, 13 million samples of the vaccine have been administered, resulting in a 75 per cent drop in cases of Meningitis C throughout the country. By inference, that translates as the saving of more than 100 lives, children and young people who would otherwise have died had a meningitis vaccine not been introduced in this country.

webTitle: Hell of families hit by meningitis vaccination 'cover-up'

fields.headline: Hell of families hit by 'cover-up'
fields.standfirst: One boy died and the life of another lay in ruins after meningitis C vaccinations, but medical and schools chiefs defend current policy
fields.trailText: One boy died and the life of another lay in ruins after meningitis C vaccinations, but medical and schools chiefs defend current policy.
fields.body:
When Christopher Robb collapsed on the stairs of Dunfermline High School at 1.30pm on 17 December 1999, his world collapsed with him. He had been feeling strange for two hours since being given the vaccine for the meningitis C virus.

'The next thing I remember was waking up in hospital later that afternoon with needles and equipment sticking out of me,' says Robb, now 17.

Staff at Queen Margaret Hospital in the Fife town, suspecting meningitis itself, gave Robb a brain scan and attempted a lumbar puncture for diagnostic purposes. He was discharged the next day, but collapsed again and was readmitted to be kept under observation for three days. His life has not been the same since. He made a slow recovery and his schoolwork suffered as a result. After Christmas he fell into a suicidal depression that his family is convinced was caused by the trauma of the reaction to the vaccine.

Robb has just heard that he did not get the exam grades he needed to get to the university of his choice.

His mother Una said: 'We have no idea what went on in his brain that day. We just feel there must be a connection to the jab. He was a young man with everything to look forward to. This has affected his whole life.'

Robb has now recovered from the effects of the vaccine and will soon come off medication he has been taking for depression. He hopes to retake his Scottish Higher exams next year and study sports science at Edinburgh or Stirling universities. But it remains mystifying that a fit young man with no history of fits or fainting, who played rugby and football for his school, should have been affected in such a devastating way by a simple vaccine.

Robb's is one of 11,000 cases reported by GPs across the country in which the new meningitis vaccine has caused adverse reactions. The vast majority are relatively minor, involving the usual headaches, rashes and dizziness associated with vaccination jabs. But some are far more serious, and have resulted in hospital treatment and even death, say doctors.

Una Robb was told that there were no other cases similar to Christopher's. She was instructed not to talk to the media when she rang the Meningitis Trust's helpline for advice. 'It has never been disputed that this was a reaction to the vaccine, but the school doctor insisted it was an isolated case,' she told The Observer.

The family kept quiet until they heard about the case of another Scottish boy, 14-year-old Keith MacGregor, who died last March five days after a menigitis C jab at Inverurie Academy in Aberdeenshire. MacGregor was taken ill while playing a Saturday football match. He died the following morning.

'The whole thing has been covered up,' says Mrs Robb. 'That's what really annoys me. I read about the boy from Inverurie and thought "that could have been me".'

She is now furious that she was told to keep quiet about his case: 'We kept asking them to make it public, to make sure people were careful. But they kept telling us not to talk to the media.'

The small northern Scottish town of Inverurie has been devastated by Keith MacGregor's death, although health officials immediately reassured the family that the death was not connected to the inoculation. A letter sent by Dr Jon Cresswell, consultant in public health medicine at Grampian Health Board, to all parents at the time said: 'Although your child may have had menC vaccine recently, I want to reassure you that [Keith MacGregor's death] is not related to the vaccine, which is very effective in preventing meningitis C.'

MacGregor's father was told his son's life might have been saved if he had had the injection earlier.

Graham Richie, acting head of the academy at the time the boy died, said the letter had reassured parents and teachers, who had felt responsible. The school will make a statement about the possible link to the vaccine this week, after talks with the MacGregor family.

There are also serious concerns for young babies who are now vaccinated against meningitis C, when they receive their other jabs at the ages of two, three and four months. Of the 11 deaths reported to the Medicines Control Agency, six involved sudden infant death syndrome, and GPs are reporting thousands of cases of reactions among babies.

One north London couple said they wanted The Observer to tell the story of their son, who nearly died after a meningitis jab earlier this month. They have chosen to remain anonymous because of their need to maintain good relations with their hospital and GP.

The baby, 'Ralph', developed a high temperature and started vomiting after his third meningitis jab. He was taken to the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead. As happened in the case of Christopher Robb, staff immediately treated it as a case of meningitis, although they said 'Ralph' couldn't have developed this from the drug. His parents were told he could die if doctors couldn't get his temperature down.

Eventually, after administering heavy doses of antibiotics overnight, his temperature returned to normal. Again the family were told this was an isolated case. Their GP told them Ralph had 'a slight reaction'.

'We kept asking for information,' the mother said last night. 'But they wouldn't tell us what was happening. We were told the vaccine was safe, but I couldn't believe the seriousness of it.'

Her husband is now convinced babies are given too many vaccinations at the same time. 'It would be extremely unlikely that our son developed meningitis on exactly the same day as the injection,' he said. 'I am a great believer in vaccination programmes, but there must be better ways of doing it. It is devastating to watch your child dying.'

fields.headline: Cast out from the home they love
fields.standfirst: Crisis in provision for old people as councils abandon costly residential care
fields.trailText: Stanley Smith  and Peggy Rousell sit in their purpose-built residential care home in Bognor Regis watching the furniture being taken out piece by piece. The fish tank went weeks ago. But Smith and Rousell refused to budge.
fields.body:
Stanley Smith and Peggy Rousell sit in their purpose-built residential care home in Bognor Regis watching the furniture being taken out piece by piece. The fish tank went weeks ago. But Smith and Rousell refused to budge.

They are the last two residents of Nyewood House, one of four county council homes in West Sussex picked for closure. In less than a week the remaining staff will be moved to other jobs. Only one - a maintenance man the council claims is also a care assistant - is on duty when The Observer visits.

But, despite fierce local opposition, Nyewood will close on 1 September and Rousell, aged 83, and Smith, aged 79, will probably receive eviction notices. Peggy Rousell, an agoraphobic, has lived at Nyewood for five years, and says she will superglue herself to her chair.

'I like it here and I'm not being stubborn but I don't want to move. It took me a while to settle but now this is my home. My best friend didn't want to move either, but her relatives were so worried she'd end up with nowhere to go that they talked her into it. She'd come back here like a shot if she could.'

Smith, a wartime 'Bevin boy' drafted to work in the coal mines for the war effort, has lived at Nyewood for 13 years. His room has a single bed, a few chairs, wardrobe, dressing table and a television. He loves it and happily chain-smokes his way through a day interspersed with walks round the once well-tended gardens.

'They think we're all weak-minded, but we just want to stay in our home. I don't want to go to some private home with masses of rules and regulations. I'm not interested in en-suite peach bathrooms. I want the independence I have here, and I want this facility to remain for other local people,' he said.

One such local woman was Jessie Langley. For the first time in her life she was genuinely content. After a tough, hard-working life in which she had been twice widowed, she finally had a secure home and friends around her.

She was devastated when she learnt that Nyewood was to close. The upheaval of a move to a strange home at the age of 86, without the friends and carers she had grown to love, was too much. Her health deteriorated rapidly and within months she was dead. According to her GP, Dr Chris Furlepa, her death was directly linked to the stress of losing her home.

Langley's daughter, Joan Cresswell, and Smith's brother, Clifford, both support the Nyewood Action Group along with local councillor Martin Lury. 'This is about human rights,' said Lury. 'None of the Nyewood residents wanted to move, they were intimidated out. The local hospital has a massive problem with bed blocking, yet the respite care beds here are not used, it is a terrible waste of resources, with finance-led instead of care-led decisions.'

Hundreds of homes have been closed this summer by authorities out to save money. The closures provoke angry opposition from residents, relatives, locals and town and district councils.

Langley is one of hundreds of frail and vulnerable elderly who will have died because of the closures. At Nyewood alone, of 39 residents who were moved, nine have died.

'It is well recognised that a greatly increased mortality rate can result from moving elderly people from where they feel secure. Closure of local authority homes has been going on all over the country, so one shudders at how many lives are being lost,' said Stephen Lowe of Age Concern, who believes the value of the land is often the main motivation.

Some 600,000 people live in residential care homes. An estimated one in six of men and one in four of women retiring today will need such a home, but provision of places is a difficult area.

'Anyone being moved from the public sector into the private is more than likely to see yet another move - private homes can shut at very short notice; one closed literally overnight,' said Lowe.

The Government cannot interfere in local authority care provision. None the less, the Department of Health recommends: 'Whatever decisions an individual authority makes when considering changes to the extent of their provision of residential care, welfare and wishes of residents and staff of the homes concerned must be taken fully into account.'

Barry Mack, West Sussex County Council's social and care committee chairman, blamed new regulations brought in by the Government, although the council need not comply with them until 2007. 'The costs of running these homes are horrendous, our budgets are being cut all the time,' he said.

The cost of operating Nyewood with about 40 residents is around £350,000 a year, he explains. The same 40 could all be housed in private homes for about £240,000. In addition, a further £100,000 may be needed to bring Nyewood up to scratch with the new regulations.

'This is an absolute nightmare for us, a terrible experience for staff,' said Mack. 'Opposition at Nyewood is politically driven. This is the only home where people are causing problems. Having a huge building with just two residents is unsatisfactory and not fair on the needs of other people in this county. It will eventually be sold for the best price we can get. We have leaned over backwards for these people, the fact that two residents are still there after a year shows that.'

Angela Alderslade, a worker at another West Sussex home, Greenfield in Middleton, described the atmosphere when its closure was announced. 'Lights on into the night, bells ringing and people wanting to talk, worrying about what is going to happen to them and where are they going to go. What is going to happen to us staff?

'These people have fought in wars, they have brought up families, worked hard all their lives, and now they deserve a quiet life with people they have come to love and trust.'

Three of Greenfield's residents faced a double blow - they were moved to a new home also on the closure list.

webTitle: Letters to the Editor:   Love has no limit

fields.headline: Love has no limit
fields.trailText: As a woman of 72, wrinkles have become less important than the knowledge that there is neither mercy nor justice in most lives (Review, last week). Only - for the lucky ones - love.
fields.body:
As a woman of 72, wrinkles have become less important than the knowledge that there is neither mercy nor justice in most lives (Review, last week). Only - for the lucky ones - love.

Human love: our consolation, joy and hope, our only valid faith, our proper pride, our reason why, our redemption and our splendour. And always, dependent less on the way we look than the way we are. Now I am old, I find amusement and delight where I can. There's still a lot. But my years are replete with many varied lives, and I have not the least desire to prolong them. Death seems a kind and peaceful destination, and I await it with interest.

Pam Hutcheson
London SE19

webTitle: Last dolphins drown slowly in man's filth

fields.headline: Last dolphins drown slowly in man's filth
fields.standfirst: Killing them softly: extinction draws near for a group of bottlenoses on Scotland's Moray Firth
fields.trailText: Killing them softly: extinction draws near for a group of bottlenoses on Scotland's Moray Firth
fields.byline: Anthony Browne on the Moray Firth
fields.body:
The cold, murky sea erupted with life as a dozen dolphins leapt out of the water, glistening forms in the August sunlight, delighting the tourists on the old fishing boat Benbola.

Time and again the dolphins - among the most intelligent, playful and social of all animals - frolicked near the boat, surfing in front of the bow wave. 'They are just amazing,' said Jackie, who had come from the south of England to see them. 'I'd definitely come to watch them again.'

But soon there may be no dolphins left to watch. The 130 bottlenose dolphins of Moray Firth, the last remnant of a population that once stretched across the entire North Sea coast of Britain, are the largest in the world. They are also the only dolphins to live so far north. To protect themselves against the cold, they have evolved to as long as 12 feet, a third longer than their tropical cousins, and weigh up to half a tonne. Local people have given each dolphin a name such as Sundance, Splash and Bubbles.

But Sundance and his friends are steadily falling victim to illegal fishing, pollution, starvation and harassment from jet skis and pleasure boats. More than 23 dolphins - almost a fifth of the population - have died in recent years. Almost all of them have skin disease and wounds. A recent study by the University of Aberdeen predicted that in 50 years there will be none left.

At the Moray Firth Wildlife Centre, a shrine to the dolphins in an old salmon fishery at Spey Bay, owner Tony Archer has compiled a harrowing photograph album. One dolphin, just a few hours old, has fetid tumours that have turned his back into a molten mass. 'The dolphins have real, real problems,' said Archer. 'It's frightening.'

At the Scottish Agricultural College in Inverness, marine biologist Bob Reid has been conducting post-mortems on the dolphins that are found.

'We've had chronic wasting disease, hepatitis, deformed spines, drowning as a result of entanglement in fishing nets, starvation,' said Reid.

He added: 'There is chemical pollution in these animals.'

A study has shown that 95 per cent of the dolphins have skin lesions, marked by black, white or pink scars. Some have open, bleeding sores.

'They are very good at collecting pollution in their bodies, and the mothers pass it on to their young,' said Mark Simmonds, director of science at the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, citing pesticides and organotins as the worst culprits. 'They have more skin disease than any other dolphins in the world.'

Graceful, friendly and sophisticated, they draw crowds from across the world. Bill Fraser became the first person in Scotland to offer dolphin-watching tours when he set up Dolphin Ecosse in Cromerty on the Black Isle 11 years ago. He now has 15 employees, taking 1,500 people out to see them each month, and has 16 rival companies.

Overall, he says they bring in a total of £15 million a year to the local economy. 'People love dolphins because they have this image of cuddly teddy bears. They seem to have this perpetual smile,' said Fraser. But Simmonds warns that too many tour boats can disturb them. 'They need to be controlled,' he said.

The dolphins may also be disrupted by the hulking oil rigs that are towed in to Cromerty Firth for repairs. It is the pleasure craft that pose a more malicious threat. 'People on jet skis and speed boats harass the dolphins - they'll just aim at them,' said Archer.

In a recent incident, people in fast boats corralled a number of dolphins and trapped them in a small bay.

Over-fishing means there are fewer large, energy-rich fish for the dolphins to eat. Recently the dolphins have been spotted heading further south down the coast.

'Starvation is a potential threat,' said Kate Grellier of the University of Aberdeen, who has been studying the cetaceans for six years.

While legal fishing may be starving them, illegal fishing is killing them. Locals have been catching salmon using monofilament gil nets within the legal one-mile limit of the shore - the dolphins' main territory. They leave a nylon filament in the sea which is impossible for the dolphins to spot by sight or echo-location. The dolphins get entangled, and within 15 minutes, drown.

Last year, the boat belonging to the Friends of the Moray Firth Dolphins, the Delphis went missing. It was discovered at sea, having been holed and left to sink. 'We have our suspicion about who did this,' said the Friends.

Overall, the university researchers reckon that the number of dolphins, just 130, is set to decline by 6 per cent a year, with the last one dying before 2050. Simmonds said: 'They are on the knife-edge of survival and they are being pushed over the edge.'

'Once they've gone, they won't come back,' said Archer, looking for dolphins from the deck of the Benbola. 'To lose a key species on our doorstep is unthinkable, but that's what's happening.'

Why we all love Flipper

 The Scottish bottlenose dolphin is the largest in the world, reaching over 4 metres in length.

 Dolphins are among the most intelligent of all animals, with larger brains than man.

 They are a highly social species, and live to over 50 years old, with females living longer than males.

 Calves learn from their mothers to make 'signature whistles' so they can identify each other even in a large pod of dolphins.

 Dolphins make clicking sounds for echo-location underwater.

 They can stun their prey by hitting them with intense waves of sound.

 They are the only mammal born backwards - tail first, head last - and the mothers produce the fattiest milk in the animal kingdom: 14 per cent fat.

 They are thought to bow-ride in front of boats - a form of surfing - to show off to each other.

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Big Brother Nick was programmed

fields.headline: Big Brother Nick was programmed
fields.trailText: Despite the acres of newsprint devoted to Nick's exit from the  Big Brother house (Focus, last week), I think we are missing an opportunity to learn a valuable lesson about the nature of Britain.
fields.body:
Despite the acres of newsprint devoted to Nick's exit from the Big Brother house (Focus, last week), I think we are missing an opportunity to learn a valuable lesson about the nature of Britain.

In his treatment of his fellow contestants, befriending them in order to exploit them, and in his response to his unmasking, simultaneously blaming others, feigning remorse and denying any wrong doing, we saw every disgraced MP, company director and civil servant that has ever been exposed.

Like them he will find some sympathy, not least from the Channel 4 doctor, who said: 'He's programmed to behave like this... he is a pike among minnows.' He is no pike but he is programmed to behave like he did because that is what the public schools do - train, generation after generation, a group of people who will live in society like an occupying army and treat the rest of the population as resource to cajoled and divided in order to exploit it. This group dominates all public life and this attitude is the root cause of the appalling negligence of our institutions in the regulation of our society.

Richard Warwick
Isle of Mull Argyll

webTitle: Letters to the Editor:   Not enlightened

fields.headline: Not enlightened
fields.trailText: Mary Riddell (Comment, last week) is correct: Tony Blair is no more of a Philistine than most of his predecessors. It's just that we expected him to be a little more enlightened.
fields.body:
Mary Riddell (Comment, last week) is correct: Tony Blair is no more of a Philistine than most of his predecessors. It's just that we expected him to be a little more enlightened.

She is a touch unfair when she accuses Sir John Drummond of not doing enough to broaden the appeal of the arts. Sir John ran the Proms for a number of years. Can you name anywhere in the UK, other than the Proms, where world-class performances can be enjoyed for £3?

Mark Hebert
Needingworth Cambs

webTitle: Letters to the Editor: Rational religion?

fields.headline: Rational religion?
fields.trailText: Will Hutton is quite right (Comment, last week) - religion has lost its centuries-old battle against reason and science. But he is wrong to say that we are 'damned by our knowledge'.
fields.body:
Will Hutton is quite right (Comment, last week) - religion has lost its centuries-old battle against reason and science. But he is wrong to say that we are 'damned by our knowledge'.

We should not be afraid to make difficult decisions about the moral desirability of any particular scientific advance, after assessing them according to knowledge, logic and evidence. Priests should have no say in it. They have a vested interest in keeping us in the dark. The more we know about how the world works, the less likely we are to believe their fairy tales.

Terry Sanderson
London W5

If the moral imperative in this humanist, rational age is to improve the human condition in the here and now, without reference to longer-term considerations, I, for one, welcome the more rational strategic view of the church. Why Will Hutton assumes that religious people are incapable of rational thought escapes me. Has he not heard of St Thomas Aquinas or Erasmus, great Christian theologians and impeccably rational simultaneously?

Robert Ganley
Manchester

webTitle: High on a cliff the radio crackled... and a climber's triumph turned to tragedy

fields.headline: High on a cliff the radio crackled... and a climber's triumph turned to tragedy
fields.trailText: Britain's most brilliant young climber spoke for the first time yesterday about the greatest ascent of his career - and of his father who fell to his death while watching it.
fields.body:
Britain's most brilliant young climber spoke for the first time yesterday about the greatest ascent of his career - and of his father who fell to his death while watching it.

Ben Bransby, 20, from Cirencester in Gloucestershire, described how, just over three weeks ago, he heard the news of the tragedy while resting on a ledge 2,000ft from the ground. He had completed the first ascent of The Thumbnail - a 4,500ft sheer spike of rock above a remote fjord in Greenland. His father, Matthew, had watched the ascent through binoculars from the summit of another peak, but was killed while descending to congratulate the team.

'I was lying in the tent when we heard,' Bransby said. 'I just thought that there were so many things still to do together. We all had a bit of a cry. Then we went on to automatic to get ourselves off the mountain and to safety.'

The team had been climbing for five days and still had a difficult descent ahead of them. For nearly a week they had been living in a vertical world, sleeping on ledges or in miniature tents slung from the bare granite.

Though danger had been with them throughout the climb, no one dreamed of the tragedy to come. 'We thought about accidents of course,' said 27-year-old Gareth Parry, another climber in the team.'But we thought it would be us, not our support team.'

Bransby remembered how, after hours spent clinging to tiny ledges, wedging themselves into overhanging cracks and delicately padding across bare slabs, the team finally reached the top. One by one the four pulled themselves up the final 150ft rope length and on to the knife-edge summit. Bransby, the youngest of the team, described standing up and waving his arms in the air. Across the fjord, on top of another, easier mountain, his father and a friend had been watching the ascent through binoculars.

Twice daily radio calls had kept them informed of developments on the climb. Now he could see the tiny figure of his son on top of one of the most audacious climbs in the world. 'I stood and waved and the others told Dad on the radio that it was me,' Bransby said last week.

'We were running around like idiots,' said Parry. 'It was an amazing climb - fantastic, unbelievably enjoyable.'

The moment was the culmination of 18 months of planning and hard work. Even reaching the base of the crag was not easy. The team took a helicopter and then a fishing trawler to their base camp. Then a small inflatable dinghy was used get to the base of the cliff.

At one point during the climb a huge flake of rock came loose in the hands of the leader of the expedition, 31-year-old Ian Parnell. Unable to climb around it safely, Parnell pulled it off and sent it crashing to the fjord 2,000ft below.

The hardest sections were left to Bransby, a former British junior champion known for completing some of the most technically challenging ascents in Britain.

Bransby was modest about his achievements last week. 'It was fairly safe... not too hard,' he said. The other team members are less phlegmatic. 'It was amazing,' said Parnell.

Conditions were tough. The team had to haul 170lb bags of equipment and supplies with them and rations were thin. When water ran out they were lucky to find a patch of snow to melt. At one point they ended up gambling for their few remaining chocolates.

But Bransby was happy, and so was his father. The 54-year-old engineer's diary - which his son has been reading since returning to the UK - reveals that he was having the best holiday he could remember.

The two had spent many holidays climbing together. It was part of family life. Matthew Bransby's widow, Jean, was a climber and is still a keen fell walker.

The son had learnt to walk while his father climbed above him on cliffs in Britain and was taken up his first routes - including a 450ft climb in Snowdonia - at the age of five. By 11, Bransby was successfully completing 'extreme' grade rockclimbs. 'We did a lot of great stuff together. He taught me to be careful, to be aware of the risks,' Bransby said.

'I was looking forward to doing a few easier [climbs] with him in the days after finishing our route.'

It wasn't to be. Hours after proudly watching his son on the summit of The Thumbnail, Matthew Bransby and his climbing partner, an old friend called Sandy Ogilvie, started the descent from their vantage point high on the other side of the fjord.

The pair started to abseil down, but after only one rope length things went terribly wrong. They had hooked the rope over a seemingly secure spike of rock and Ogilvie had slid down it safely. But when Bransby's turn came the cord slipped off its anchor. Ogilvie heard a shout and watched as his friend plummeted 1,000ft.

The team on The Thumbnail had descended from the summit to spent the night on a ledge in the middle of the face. In the morning Ogilvie radioed them and broke the news.

Matthew Bransby's funeral was last Thursday. Ben consoles himself with the thought that his father died doing what he loved.

'We were having a brilliant time, and he would have hated our achievement to have been overshadowed. Of course, now I wish we'd never gone. But you can't know, can you?'

For all the members of the team, the climbing will go on - they say it is what Matthew Bransby would have wanted. Ben Bransby was yesterday watching the weather forecast for Bank Holiday Monday. The other members of the team are already planning more ascents

'Not everyone can understand it,' said Parry last week. 'The enjoyment you can get is indescribable. You can never imagine life without climbing. Whatever would you do with yourself instead?'

fields.headline: Ships vanish as piracy rules
fields.standfirst: John Sweeney reports on a new wave of brutal buccaneers plundering cargo lanes
fields.trailText: John Sweeney reports on a new wave of brutal buccaneers plundering cargo lanes.
fields.body:
It would be hard in the modern age for a 12,000-tonne cargo ship, loaded to the gunnels with furnace slag, to disappear from the face of the earth. But that is exactly what happened to the MV Cheung Son, a Panama-flagged bulk carrier, as it ploughed through a slow swell in the South China Sea about 200 miles east of Hong Kong in November 1998.

It didn't vanish, of course. It was 'shipjacked' by pirates. The modern-day Long John Silvers gathered the crew of 23 together on the deck and shot them. Their bodies were weighted, bound and gagged, and dumped overboard. Later, six bodies were recovered in fishing nets off the southern Chinese port of Shantou. Of the ship and its cargo, there is no trace. The suspicion is that it has been given a new identity, with the collusion of corrupt officials.

The shipjacking of the Cheung Son was one of nine in the past two years. The rising problem of piracy on the high seas has led Foreign Officer Minister Peter Hain to call for global action. 'Piracy is deadly,' Hain told The Observer. 'Attacks on sailors, ships and their cargoes are increasing, by both opportunists and organised crime groups. They also steal huge vessels such as oil tankers, worth millions of pounds, and whose cargo if not protected poses a dreadful threat to the environment.'

Pirates work mainly from wretched places of the earth - Somalia in the Horn of Africa, west Africa, Bangladesh, and Indonesia - using speed boats capable of 30 knots to overtake ships going half as fast. The choke-zones of the high seas are favoured places to strike: the Malacca Straits between Malaysia and Indonesia and the lawless waters where the Red Sea enters the Gulf of Aden, a short boat ride from Somalia.

The Piracy Reporting Centre of the International Maritime Bureau (IMB) has a standard instruction that the coast off Somalia is a no-go area. The advice is to sail 50 or 100 miles off shore and keep radio use to a minimum.

Recently, pirates in small fast boats have tried to board ships off Bab el Mandeb in the Red Sea's southern tip. Masters report that small boats wait at the northern end of the traffic lane where ships slow down to turn towards the Indian Ocean.

The Indonesian archipelago and the Straits of Malacca - the world's busiest sea lane after the English Channel - have seen increased attacks. 'Piracy is increasingly concentrated in South-east Asia and the Indian Ocean,' said Hain. 'The number of pirate attacks worldwide in the first six months of this year was 161, an increase (of 56) on the same period last year.'

Captain Jayant Abhyankar of the IMB said: 'Most ships that are targeted are going eastbound through the Straits of Malacca, loaded, fairly low in the water and because the way the traffic system works, close to the Indonesian shore.'

Incidents logged in the past week by the IMB give a picture of modern piracy.

 In the Malacca Straits two speedboats showing no lights approached a bulk carrier from the stern at night. The ship directed an Aldis lamp at the boats, which sped off.

 Off Chittagong in Bangladesh, four pirates in a small wooden boat tried to steal zinc anodes - worth around $200 each - from the rudderpost of an anchored chemical tanker. Crew spotted the sea-thieves, who fled.

 A would-be pirate was spotted on the forecastle of a tanker anchored off Vietnam, attempting to lower a rope to fellow raiders. When crew raised an alarm, he climbed down and escaped in a motorboat.

 Off the coast of Conakry, Guinea, nine men armed with shotguns attempted to board a bulk carrier. The ship's crew fired flares at their wooden boat, and they fled.

Modern-day piracy - like that of old - requires organisation and funds. Impoverished fishermen cannot afford speedboats. The Foreign Office believes five or six gangs, some linked to Chinese triads, are behind some attacks. One gang operated from a mother-ship, where Indonesian police found handcuffs, masks, knives, immigration and ship stamps, and paint. Rogue regulators from flag-of-convenience states sell ship's papers for as little as $6,000.

And the IMB points to evidence that rogue Chinese military units have, in the past, colluded with pirates.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: EU in Burma protest
fields.body:
EU in Burma protest

Amid rising world protests, the European Union urged Burma to restore freedom of movement for opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner Aung San Suu Kyi. She was spending a third night in her car after it was stopped by the military in Rangoon.

Algerian PM resigns

Algerian Prime Minister Ahmed Benbitour has resigned and President Abdel-aziz Bouteflika has invited Ali Benflis, a close aide, to form a new cabinet. The decision follows an administrative up-heaval and the dismissal of discredited officials.

Crime soars in Iran

Crime rates in Iran rose sharply last year, with a 16 per cent increase in murders. An official blamed unemployment and inflation.

Detained poet freed

China has freed a detained poet, Huang Beiling, and deported him to the US. He was held after publishing work by dissident writers.

Four die in stampede

Four people died in a stampede at a crowded market in Khasavyurt, Dagestan. It was started by a rumour that a bomb had been found.

Fond farewell to spies

In another sign of the Korean thaw, thousands of students gathered in Seoul to bid a fond farewell to 63 former North Korean spies returning home after decades in prison.

Milosevic critic missing

Ivan Stambolic, a former Serbian President and critic of Slobodan Milosevic, has not been seen since he went jogging in Belgrade on Friday.

Immigrants drowned

A Turkish boat with 32 illegal immigrants capsized off the Greek island of Kos, authorities said. At least five drowned and 22 were missing.

webTitle: Clinton puts pressure on Nigeria over drugs and oil

fields.headline: Clinton puts pressure on Nigeria over drugs and oil
fields.standfirst: Chris McGreal reports on the arrival of the US President in Abuja to back leader who has fallen from public favour
fields.trailText: Chris McGreal reports on the arrival of the US President in Abuja to back leader who has fallen from public favour
fields.body:
Bill Clinton arrived in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, yesterday after its streets had been cleansed of beggars in favour of dancing midgets. The American President began a two-day visit to the turbulent West African state to plant Washington's flag firmly with Nigeria's beleaguered leader, Olusegun Obasanjo.

A girl introduced as 'Little Miss Jennifer' presented Clinton with a gourd before he drifted past the guard of honour, stripped of its swords at the insistence of the US Secret Service. Then came the traditional drums and pipes, and two midgets in purple.

Nigerians only got to see part of this after national television announced it would not be able to show all of Clinton's arrival because 'at the last minute our equipment was removed by American security'.

When Abuja's streets were rid of beggars and hawkers, the wares of many were burnt before their eyes. Among those driven to the nearby city of Jos was Adamu Sadau, a blind beggar.

'We were told a very important guest - the American President - was expected in Abuja soon and the government does not want to see us around, because it feels that we can be an embarrassment,' he stated.

Obasanjo will be pressing Clinton to help ease Nigeria's £2.5 billion annual debt servicing bill. The US has already said it will work to get it reduced to £1bn a year, but Obasanjo wants a complete freeze on payments ahead of a total write-off.

The US has already moved Nigeria from near bottom to top of its aid list for sub-Saharan Africa since Obasanjo came to power 15 months ago.

This year it is to receive £112m from Washington, almost one-third of which is dedicated to training and equipping Nigerian troops for peacekeeping in Sierra Leone. But the US Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Susan Rice, warned against 'exaggerated expectations' from the visit.

Obasanjo will also raise the 'maltreatment' of Nigerians applying for US visas. The US embassy is often accused of treating all Nigerians as potential gangsters and drug-traffickers, and refusing legitimate businessmen visas on spurious grounds.

The Americans are keen to talk about drugs. They believe the Nigerians could do more to stop the transshipment of heroin and other narcotics to the US. Clinton also wants the Nigerian leader to boost oil exports and to persuade other producers to reduce fuel prices to avoid a recession in the industrialised world. But the visit is primarily an attempt by Washington to bolster Obasanjo's leadership.

The US is concerned that many Nigerians have swiftly become disillusioned with his rule because it has failed to ease the hardships of everyday life and because political corruption is still rife, particularly in parliament. Before his arrival, Clinton said he saw the success of Nigeria's democracy as key to stable government throughout West Africa.

It is the second time Obasanjo has welcomed an American President to Nigeria. Jimmy Carter visited in 1978 when the then General Obasanjo was the country's military ruler. He proved to be a different kind of general by voluntarily giving up power to an elected President.

Times have changed greatly. Twenty-two years ago, Nigeria was awash in oil money and Obasanjo oversaw massive government spending on grand construction projects.

Today, Nigeria is deep in debt, its infrastructure is collapsing and the country is more fractured than at any time since Biafra's bloody attempt at independence in the Sixties. But at least Africa's most populous country is no longer the untouchable it was two years ago under the brutal rule of General Sani Abacha, who outraged international opinion by hanging the Ogoni rights leader, Ken Saro-Wiwa.

Relations with the US were so bad that Clinton bypassed Nigeria on his first tour of Africa in 1998. In one fit of pique, Abacha renamed the road outside the US embassy after Louis Farrakhan, the black leader of the radical Nation of Islam.

Abacha's suspicious death - it is widely believed in Nigeria that he was poisoned by two prostitutes at the behest of army officers who feared that he was destroying the country - opened the way for Obasanjo's election to the presidency.

But the Americans, like the British, are disappointed Nigeria's leader is moving so slowly to implement reforms, failing to embrace privatisation programmes vigorously enough and still applying an authoritarian, centralised style of rule.

And while Obasanjo seems personally committed to combating corruption, that has not stopped some of his aides continuing to profit from graft and the government from continuing to buy political support in the National Assembly.

The two Presidents gave a press conference in which Clinton urged Obasanjo to use his influence in Opec to encourage increased oil output. Nigeria is already at full capacity. Obasanjo acknowledged that high world prices were in the interests of neither producers nor consumers.

Clinton leaves Nigeria tomorrow for Tanzania where he will add his weight to efforts to secure peace in neighbouring Burundi. He visits Cairo on Tuesday for Middle East talks.

webTitle: Gulf Air mystery of 60 lost seconds

fields.headline: Gulf Air mystery of 60 lost seconds
fields.trailText: Coffins wrapped in blue plaid cloth topped by plastic carried the remains of victims of last week's Gulf Air disaster on a flight to Cairo yesterday as a formal inquiry opened into the crash.
fields.body:
Coffins wrapped in blue plaid cloth topped by plastic carried the remains of victims of last week's Gulf Air disaster on a flight to Cairo yesterday as a formal inquiry opened into the crash.

Sixty-four Egyptians were among the 143 people who died when the Airbus A320 nose-dived into the sea off Bahrain. Nobody on board survived. The dead included 30 children aged under 12.

More than 150 relatives met the plane carrying the coffins in Cairo. Grieving women dressed in black wailed as an official called out the victims' names. Attempts to identify the passengers and crew went on in Bahrain, hampered because many of the bodies had been torn apart by the impact, as an international investigation team began the inquiry.

The investigators are seeking an explanation for a puzzling sequence of events between an aborted landing by pilot Ihsan Shakeeb at 19.29 (GMT) last Wednesday and the crash only a minute later.

Gulf Air's chief pilot, Hameed Ali, said that the inquiry would examine the speed and altitude of the attempted landing by the twin-engined aircraft.

'It is very important, and intra-cockpit communication is even more important. We have not listened to that yet,' Ali told a packed press conference.

But he stressed: 'We have spotted no error in [Shakeeb's] approach.' Shakeeb was an experienced crew member, with 6,856 hours' flying time spanning eight years. The minimum qualifying time for a Gulf Air pilot was 4,000 hours.

He had calmly requested a 'go around' from air traffic controllers on his first approach to Bahrain International Airport, according to Gulf Air. After circling once, he aborted his landing attempt without explanation. The pilot's remains were buried last Friday.

The airline says 135 passengers and eight crew members were on board Flight 072. The biggest group of victims were Egyptians, but the passengers and crew included two Britons as well as people from Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, the Palestinian Authority area, the United Arab Emirates, China, the United States, Australia and Canada and Poland.

Gulf Air has offered counselling to the bereaved, and pledged £25,000 to each family that lost an adult relative. It said that it would consider increasing that amount, once the investigation had been completed.
