fields.headline: Struggling Kenya voices its fury
fields.standfirst: Jesuit's murder adds to crisis in corruption-ridden nation
fields.trailText: Jesuit's murder adds to crisis in corruption-ridden nation.
fields.body:
The Rev John Anthony Kaiser, 67, a fearless critic of the Kenyan government, had seemed unusually agitated for several days. The American priest had apparently told friends he feared for his life.

On Wednesday night he dined with the Bishop of Ngong, about 25 miles from Nairobi, and left about 7pm to drive to his parish - about 150 miles to the west.

Next day his body was found on a country road near his pickup truck. He had been killed by a shotgun bullet which almost decapitated him. There was a live round of its ammunition in his shirt pocket. Police suspect murder and the United States ambassador has urged Kenya to accept FBI help.

The death is the latest episode in Kenya's descent into chaos, incompetence and corruption. Once it was the hope of Africa; now there is universal disillusion.

Kaiser, a Jesuit from Minnesota who had lived in Kenya for most of the last 36 years, had been a frequent critic of the government, notably defending victims of land disputes. He was briefly held under house arrest in 1994 after criticising two government Ministers.

His most recent run-in was with a Kenyan Minister of State, Julius Ole Sunkuli, over allegations that the official had sexually violated a minor. On the bishop's advice she went to lawyers who pursued a case against Sunkuli.

The Minister was charged with statutory rape in June. He has denied the charges.

After the allegations became public, Kaiser was refused renewal of his work permit, which was granted late last year only after strong protests from the US Embassy.

The crisis of confidence in Kenya has been fed by power shortages, inflation, water rationing, corruption and the steady slide of the currency. The President - the autocratic Daniel arap Moi - recently admitted that the country was 'facing its worst crisis'. A disastrous two-year drought has left more than three million Kenyans at risk of starvation. Thousands of pastoralists have brought their cattle to Nairobi in a desperate search for grazing.

More than 75 per cent of the country has been hit by the drought, including areas that have not known hunger in living memory, prompting the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) to launch an emergency appeal for more than £50 million of food. 'We don't have enough food and we don't have enough money,' said Lindsay Davies, a WFP spokesperson. 'If we don't get help soon, we won't be asking for food, we'll be asking for intravenous drips.'

And while drought is the main cause of the shortages, corruption and mismanagement in Kenya's once mighty agricultural sector have a lot to answer for. The previously vibrant tea and coffee sectors have been ruined by corruption, and the tourist industry, once Kenya's chief foreign exchange earner, has been destroyed by a decaying infrastructure and an increasingly violent society.

The International Monetary Fund reopened the aid pipeline this month - suspended since 1997 because of government-sponsored corruption - but the economic crisis continues to deepen. In the last six months the price of corn flour, Kenya's staple food, has increased 50 per cent. A two-kilo bag of sugar which two months ago cost 70p now fetches double that.

Until now the government has shown itself to be a master at shirking responsibility for Kenya's woes, and the people have obliged it by suffering their lot in silence.

But Father Kaiser was not the only cleric to speak out. Last week, at a memorial service to commemorate the 22nd anniversary of Kenya's first President and founding father, Jomo Kenyatta, President Moi had to listen to stinging criticism from the Catholic priest leading the service.

Father Dominic Wamugunda voiced the views of many citizens when he said Kenya had declined so much since Kenyatta died that the former President would be ashamed to be associated with it. 'We pray for this country, but we must also ask questions,' said the priest.

When Kenyatta died in 1978, Kenya enjoyed growth rates among the best in Africa, and a development programme that had the country growing faster than some of the countries which later became known as the Asian tigers.

'To think that we were so far ahead then and so far behind now beggars belief,' said Smokin Wanjala, a corruption analyst. 'We had a lot going for us then. Now we have very little.'

Corruption in Kenya is a story of greedy people who don't know when to stop. When strict power and water rationing was imposed three months ago, the government shrugged its shoulders and laid the blame for the crisis everywhere except at its door.

But Kenyans blame poor management and corruption for the shortages which economists estimate will cost the country billions of shillings and countless jobs.

Since it opened 30 years ago, Charles Waweru's electroplating company has survived all that the ailing economy can throw at it. Power rationing means that his business receives electricity only every other day. He has laid off his part-time staff and his 20 full-time employees could be next. His business - which he has nurtured for three decades - might be the final casualty. 'My business has survived through thick and thin, but this one could finish me off,' said Waweru.

But he still supports the government and does not blame it for the dangers his business faces. 'I don't believe the opposition parties would do any better.'

Last weekend opposition politicians organised a protest rally that ended in battles between supporters of different political factions. But the same opposition politicians who rally popular support by criticising the government 's performance recently voted themselves a huge increase in their travel allowance, taking their monthly stipend to a staggering $5,000 [ £7,100] a month.

'Who do these people think they are?' asked Dominic Ruheni, a taxi driver whose business has been strangled by the ailing economy. 'People put their faith in them and hope that they can force the government to change its ways, but all they seem capable of doing is making themselves richer while we get poorer.'

When primary school students rioted two months ago after a classmate was killed by a speeding bus, they overturned a lorry carrying beer and drank the contents.

'When eight-year-old children are running drunk around the streets of Nairobi when they should be in school, we see that Kenya is not just suffering economic and political decline but moral decline as well,' said the comment in one newspaper.

 Additional reporting by Ian Fisher of the New York Times

The previously vibrant tea and coffee sectors have been ruined by corruption, and the tourist industry, once Kenya's chief foreign exchange earner, has been destroyed by a decaying infrastructure and an increasingly violent society. The International Monetary Fund reopened the aid pipeline this month - suspended since 1997 because of government-sponsored corruption - but the economic crisis continues to deepen. In the last six months the price of corn flour, Kenya's staple food, has increased 50 per cent. A two-kilo bag of sugar which two months ago cost 70p now fetches double that. Until now the government has shown itself to be a master at shirking responsibility for Kenya's woes, and the people have obliged it by suffering their lot in silence. But Father Kaiser was not the only cleric to speak out. Last week, at a memorial service to commemorate the 22nd anniversary of Kenya's first President and founding father, Jomo Kenyatta, President Moi had to listen to stinging criticism from the Catholic priest leading the service. Father Dominic Wamugunda voiced the views of many citizens when he said Kenya had declined so much since Kenyatta died that the former President would be ashamed to be associated with it. 'We pray for this country, but we must also ask questions,' said the priest. When Kenyatta died in 1978, Kenya enjoyed growth rates among the best in Africa, and a development programme that had the country growing faster than some of the countries which later became known as the Asian tigers. 'To think that we were so far ahead then and so far behind now beggars belief,' said Smokin Wanjala, a corruption analyst. 'We had a lot going for us then. Now we have very little.' Corruption in Kenya is a story of greedy people who don't know when to stop. When strict power and water rationing was imposed three months ago, the government shrugged its shoulders and laid the blame for the crisis everywhere except at its door. But Kenyans blame poor management and corruption for the shortages which economists estimate will cost the country billions of shillings and countless jobs. Since it opened 30 years ago, Charles Waweru's electroplating company has survived all that the ailing economy can throw at it. Power rationing means that his business receives electricity only every other day. He has laid off his part-time staff and his 20 full-time employees could be next. His business - which he has nurtured for three decades - might be the final casualty. 'My business has survived through thick and thin, but this one could finish me off,' said Waweru. But he still supports the government and does not blame it for the dangers his business faces. 'I don't believe the opposition parties would do any better.' Last weekend opposition politicians organised a protest rally that ended in battles between supporters of different political factions. But the same opposition politicians who rally popular support by criticising the government 's performance recently voted themselves a huge increase in their travel allowance, taking their monthly stipend to a staggering $5,000 [ £7,100] a month. 'Who do these people think they are?' asked Dominic Ruheni, a taxi driver whose business has been strangled by the ailing economy. 'People put their faith in them and hope that they can force the government to change its ways, but all they seem capable of doing is making themselves richer while we get poorer.' When primary school students rioted two months ago after a classmate was killed by a speeding bus, they overturned a lorry carrying beer and drank the contents. 'When eight-year-old children are running drunk around the streets of Nairobi when they should be in school, we see that Kenya is not just suffering economic and political decline but moral decline as well,' said the comment in one newspaper.  Additional reporting by Ian Fisher of the New York Times

webTitle: Warning to tourists as blazes spread

fields.headline: Warning to tourists as blazes spread
fields.trailText: British tourists escaping a miserable summer risk facing some of the worst wildfire outbreaks the world has seen.
fields.body:
British tourists escaping a miserable summer risk facing some of the worst wildfire outbreaks the world has seen.

This weekend a state of emergency was declared in Greece as thousands of firefighters and volunteers were joined by military personnel from Israel to step up efforts to extinguish blazes that have left at least seven people dead and dozens more injured.

Other southern European countries, including Italy, Albania, Bulgaria, Croatia, and the French island of Corsica, as well as the western states of America, are fighting thousands of fires sparked by high temperatures. Yesterday the Greek government appealed for international help amid fears that increasing wind speeds would fan the flames in the next few days.

'It's a warlike situation out there,' said government Minister Michalis Chrysohoidis. Villages have been evacuated over the past 48 hours, with the government calling states of emergency around the border and in the central Peloponnese.

In America, fires have already claimed six million acres. Fourteen firefighters have been killed.

The Foreign Office advises travellers to affected countries to be 'sensible'.

webTitle: Scientists sound a warning as Etna goes on the boil again

fields.headline: Scientists sound a warning as Etna goes on the boil again
fields.trailText: Mount Etna - the realm of Vulcan, god of fire, and the Cyclops - may be entering a new cycle of catastrophic eruptions, say scientists.
fields.body:
Mount Etna - the realm of Vulcan, god of fire, and the Cyclops - may be entering a new cycle of catastrophic eruptions, say scientists.

In the past few weeks, vulcanologists noted intensifying pattern fissures, and lava pouring from its 11,000ft peak, on the east coast of Sicily.

Nearby towns have been coated with volcanic dust, roads need constant clearing from ash that has settled over the area, which the local government has declared an emergency zone.

'There was a similar pattern of activity in 1978 and 1979, shortly before Etna produced some powerful flank eruptions that destroyed buildings, roads, vineyards and orchards,' said vulcanologist Dr John Murray, from the Open University. 'I think the same thing is set to happen again.'

It is unlikely that Etna will produce a cataclysmic eruption like those that have typified its northerly counterpart, Vesuvius. Nevertheless, it can leak sudden streams of rapidly moving lava. One, in 1928, completely destroyed the town of Mascali. 'All volcanoes have their own distinctive way of behaving,' said Murray, who has been studying Etna for the past 30 years. 'They have different personalities. Etna has a very leaky one. It grumbles along in almost permanent activity, occasionally producing flank eruptions in which lava bursts from fissures low down its slopes.

'When that happens, you have to move very quickly. The lava comes out under pressure and moves very rapidly.

'Villagers can get cut off very easily, though none have been killed in recent times.' In fact, all fatalities on Etna have been tourists. In 1979, nine were killed during a visit to one of its summit cones when it produced a massive eruption, the entire party was overwhelmed by the volcano's hot ash.

fields.headline: Hollywood's rebel stars order 'Cut!'
fields.standfirst: It's High Noon in Tinseltown as actors and writers prepare to strike next June for more money. And neither side is ready to blink
fields.trailText: It's High Noon in Tinseltown as actors and writers prepare to strike next June for more money. And neither side is ready to blink
fields.body:
Hollywood is starting to face up to what is likely to become the first total shutdown in film and television production in its history and is stockpiling cheap, vulgar comedies and teen horror films to keep the world's cinema screens from going dark in autumn 2001 and beyond.

On 1 June next year, it is almost certain that the industry will shut down when the Screen Writers Guild goes on strike, followed a month later by the Screen Actors Guild, unless their members receive higher wages and a bigger slice of revenue from cable TV, foreign rights and whatever earnings the internet may some day produce from big studios and TV networks.

Although there have been strikes in Hollywood before, never have the most powerful unions come out at the same time. The threat of a walkout is taken seriously after the actors' three-month-old strike against TV commercial makers shut down production in Los Angeles. It shows no signs of ending.

The studios and TV networks, actors, agents and managers are urgently planning how to survive a strike that studio chief Sherry Lansing recently told her staff would probably last between six months and a year. 'Over the last two months there's been a realisation the strikes will happen. Agents and managers are advising clients to save money, hold off on buying new property and double or treble book work between now and next June,' says a contract lawyer.

Neither side in the dispute is yet willing to talk openly. But both have seen the future in which the internet and foreign rights play a larger part in film revenue, and each is seeking to maximise its potential share. Neither side can agree on what those future revenues might be.

'Corporate America is riding a tidal wave of expansion and prosperity unparalleled in modern times... It's time we received our fair share of corporate profits and astronomical CEO salaries that our performances made possible,' said the Screen Actors Guild president, William Daniels, recently.

'The studios are saying their margins are getting smaller and they need all the foreign and new media revenue,' says the contract lawyer, who did not wish to be identified. 'The problem is the two sides won't come to the table until the 11th hour and by then it will be too late.'

Screen writers, long marginalised, now want more money, more credit and a curb on the prominent screen credits directors often receive above and below the title.

A strike will come as a democratising shock to an industry catering to the whims of its biggest stars. If the Screen Actors Guild votes to strike, the votes of Tom Cruise or Tom Hanks will have no more influence than the man who plays the caretaker in Ally McBeal.

Hollywood studios are stockpiling film scripts and rushing to make enough films and television shows before next June to fill cinemas and TV schedules at least through to the winter of 2002 and a number of big-director, big-star films are under threat.

Minority Report, an expensive sci-fi film starring Tom Cruise to be directed by Steven Spielberg, is set to begin production next April but that doesn't leave much time to make what is supposedly one of the most expensive and complex movies ever. The same goes for Men in Black 2, a costly sequel to the Tommy Lee Jones-Will Smith blockbuster of three years ago. It has been dogged by delays and salary negotiations and pre-production could stretch into next year.

Though audiences may not be interested in Hollywood's labour problems, they will notice the effect of them next summer whether the strike proceeds or not. Stopgap scores of quick-to-make teen horror films and slapstick comedies are being called into life to fill the gap left by a lack of more substantive fare.

webTitle: Statue of French holy man is cut down to size

fields.headline: French holy man is cut down to size
fields.trailText: At over 110ft high, it's not easy to miss the towering white statue of His Holiness Lord Hamsah Manarah, Patriarch Founder of Aumism, Great Master of the Order of the Knights of the Triumphant Vajra and Master Builder of the Holy City of Mandarom Shambhasalem - aka Gilbert Bourdin.
fields.body:
At over 110ft high, it's not easy to miss the towering white statue of His Holiness Lord Hamsah Manarah, Patriarch Founder of Aumism, Great Master of the Order of the Knights of the Triumphant Vajra and Master Builder of the Holy City of Mandarom Shambhasalem - aka Gilbert Bourdin.

The great man died two years ago, but his legend lives on in the gold-crowned likeness dwarfing the village of Castellane in the Alps of Haute Provence, and of the dozen of his followers who continue to serve the sole and unique Cosmoplanetary Messiah of Synthesis and Instigator of the Pyramid Temple of Unity.

But all is not well in Mandarom. For starters, there's the tax bill: £1.6 million owed on undeclared gifts and donations. That's a lot for a religious organisation whose only official income is the £20 annual subscription paid by its 400 or so adherents.

Then there's the saga of His Holiness's mortal remains, buried in 1998 in a tiny disused cemetery in Castellane, after being refused a last resting place in the village's main graveyard.

To prevent his followers snatching the body and burying it illegally at Mandarom, the mayor had 700lb of reinforced concrete dumped on the grave. But Christine Amory, president of the Association of the Triumphant Varja, believes the messiah will overcome that obstacle. 'He'll come back one day,' she says. 'We'll recognise his presence vibratorially.'

The High Court last month rejected the association's appeal against a ruling by the Aix-en-Provence tribunal ordering the statue's destruction, as it had been erected without planning permission. Now the Aumists are appealing to the European Court of Human Rights. 'They're going to pull down our temples, and put at risk the very lives of our monks,' complains Amory, who is also a staffer at France's National Scientific Research Centre.

Bourdin set up shop outside Castellane 30 years ago to preach Aumism, 'a spiritual revolution representing the ideal of unity for the evolu tion of mankind and the preservation of the golden age'. The holy city became a tourist attraction, with 7,000 visitors a year, and in 1983 the planning authority issued retroactive permits for all buildings on the site. Bourdin stuck up a few more, including the giant statue in 1990.

A decade ago, Castellane, near the Gorges de Verdon, became a centre for alpine hiking, climbing and white-water rafting. It wanted to rid itself of the image as home to the mad Mandarom.

In 1995, Bourdin was charged with the rape of a former disciple. Before a verdict could be given, he died of diabetes, aged 75. His dubious legacy is now being dismantled in the courts, following a campaign by the Association for the Protection of Verdon's Lakes and Mountain Sites. But not everyone is happy.

'This whole region has profited from Mandarom,' a cafe owner said. 'We've all made money out of it. Admitted, it's a hideous eyesore. But I'll miss it.'

webTitle: New York's Ecstasy scene goes upmarket

fields.headline: New York's Ecstasy scene goes upmarket
fields.trailText: In the depths of the Filter 14 club, most people know what Chandler (not his real name) does for a living - and what he does not do.
fields.body:
In the depths of the Filter 14 club, most people know what Chandler (not his real name) does for a living - and what he does not do.

He does not sell drugs to ravers, teenagers or tourists on or anywhere near the premises. He sells only by appointment and only people who supply a business card and the number of a bleeper or a mobile phone. He is a new kind of dealer for a new kind of clientèle, and selling only a single kind of drug: Ecstasy.

The meat-packing district has been an Ecstasy supermarket for several years, but there are no more grubby plastic bags, no more hustlers in the clubs. Everything is more discreet. This is the part of town where the smell of stale blood gave way to wafts of marijuana from the cavernous clubs that opened as the sun set over New Jersey and the Hudson.

But now the scent is of haute cuisine from the kitchens of upscale eateries like Rhone and Pastis.

There is a new kind of night owl, too: dot.com cyber-yuppies, lawyers, media types, music industry executives, advertising people. People who have to get up in the morning, but still want to do drugs, even on a Thursday.

Their recreational drug of choice is that which is no longer the property of raves in warehouses over the other side of the Hudson and East Rivers, the happy pill the authorities trying to stem the tide now call Agony.

On the stage at Filter 14 a woman in lace and leather is having oral sex, possibly simulated, with a bodybuilding hunk. Chandler is admiring 'how her ass works' when his bleeper vibrates. It's a call from a contact he knows well, one of a group moving on from a meal at Rhone to a nearby club called Hell with a vivid red interior. Chandler tells the client, a banker, not to come 'any-fucking-place near'.

Later, down in Hell, the group is pretty easy to spot. Some very rich, very young people from a brokerage company are having a farewell party. 'Yes, we'll be at work in the morning,' shrieks a girl called Tracy. 'That's what is so cool about this stuff.'

A slightly older man called Ray has a couple of hits in his wallet, but is planning on 'keeping them back for a weekend in the Hamptons'. Ecstasy, says Ray, is 'in the 2000s what coke was in the '80s and '90s. It's do-able. You can get a buzz and you can work next day, better than if you'd had a night of whisky sours'. There's an Ecstasy circuit of upmarket locations: Joe's Pub on Tuesdays, the Limelight on Fridays.

Chandler sells stuff with names like 'Mitsubishi', 'Motorola', 'Calvin Klein' and 'Nike', by which different kinds of Ecstasy are known.

Ecstasy is capturing the non-rave US market for all the reasons that have been seen in Europe: it is 'clean', touchy-feely and relatively safe by comparison to its Class A cousins (America has not yet had the wake-up call of a Leah death).

But the most cogent reason for Ecstasy's capture of the non-rave market is that, compared to heroin and cocaine, it has been easier to import and is as easy to buy, at between $20 to $30 a hit, as a packet of cigarettes.

Most of it comes through the two New York airports, JFK and Newark. 'Ecstasy is a much neater business than cocaine or heroin smuggling,' says Raymond Kelly, the Commissioner of US Customs. 'You can invest $100,000 as a distributor and get $5 million back'.

Recent arrests have shown that Israeli crime syndicates account for more than 50 per cent of the traffic. There have been suggestions that they are protected by the Russian mafia, the most powerful criminal empire in New York. Dutch smuggling rings are also importing enough MDMA - Ecstasy's base compound - to manufacture millions of tablets.

But others are joining in, using ever more elaborate smuggling techniques. Men have been found wearing skin-tight body suits under their regular clothing, in which thousands of Ecstasy pills were hidden.

The authorities see Ecstasy spreading socially and geographically. 'The drug is as common in the Bronx High School of Science as it is in haute couture high fashion', says one Customs official.

Back in Hell, the leaving party goes on. Tracy has been asked by the bouncer to do up the buttons of her blouse. 'It's delicious, even if a man just pours water on your skin,' she insists. And it's only Thursday, a whole working, banking day to go before the weekend.

webTitle: Letters to the Editor:  Is racism in education a question of prejudice or pride?

fields.headline: The big issue:  Is racism in education a question of prejudice or pride?
fields.trailText: The response of Lee Jasper to the argument of Tony Sewell that the under-achievement of black youth is the result of the emphasis on consumerism (News, last week), is to label it 'blame the victim', contending that white female teachers often find black boys more intimidating than white.
fields.body:
The response of Lee Jasper to the argument of Tony Sewell that the under-achievement of black youth is the result of the emphasis on consumerism (News, last week), is to label it 'blame the victim', contending that white female teachers often find black boys more intimidating than white.

The thrust of the second article, by Trevor Phillips (Comment), is a reminder of the heterogeneity of blacks but contains the point, almost en passant, that 'the major thing that black people share is the way that they are treated by white people'.

Encouraging Afro-Caribbeans to perceive themselves as victims and shifting responsibility for their under-achievement on to the white 'community' does the former no favours, and worse, hampers the formation of appropriate social policies. The black underclass in the UK share many of characteristics of the white, in terms of their attitude to, and experience of, education, methods of parenting and records of employment. If poor black teenagers can sometimes frighten females and, for that matter, male teachers, so can poor white teenagers. Hence, arguably, many of the issues that have been regarded as race issues are in fact a matter of class.

Dr Graham Hall
Gatley, Cheshire

Those who would shoot down Dr Sewell in flames for suggesting that black youth culture is at least as responsible as racism for the academic underperformance of Afro-Caribbean youths, need to answer one very simple question: do racists, or does institutional racism, make a distinction between the high academic achievements of black Africans and that of Afro-Caribbeans?

Dr Farouk Stemmet
Leeds

Many black Britons have a case to answer about their anti-education attitudes. A black, youth culture has developed around these attitudes with Jamaican patois as its most important aspect. Resistance to white culture has been regarded as heroic and political respectability has been given to it by some left-wing ideas.

Bizarrely, young people's 'black' culture sits next to the high value placed on education by their parents. In the Caribbean, being educated and being black is not a contradiction. Indeed, people living there would regard the rejection of Britain's free education system by black youth as 'mad'.

Simon Hinds
London N4

The truth is that young black people are as interested in doing well as their white counterparts. Racism throughout society does disproportionately undermine their hopes, aspirations and expectations at every stage. It is this, together with endemic institutional racism in the educational system that leads to the exclusion of black pupils disproportionately, not something arising from black youth culture.

Tony Sewell's contribution would be most welcome if he used his special position as a black academic to help the fight against academic racism rather than to provide cover to white liberal stereotypes.

Wesley Walters-Stephenson
NUS Black Students Committee

Paul Mackney
General Secretary, National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education

Milena Buyum
Vice-Chair, National Assembly Against Racism

fields.headline: The Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Haiku
fields.trailText: Haiku
fields.body:
Another type of trendy yoga? No, it's actually a form of Japanese poetry but, much like yoga, it's having something of an impact on our Western minds.

I can't read Japanese. You don't have to. Haikus can be written in any language and take many forms, the most basic consisting of 17 syllables, usually within three lines. The first line contains five syllables, the second seven, and the third five again. Each haiku must contain a kigo - a season word - which indicates in which season the haiku is set (blossoms indicate spring, snow indicates winter, mosquitoes indicate summer). Haikus are used to capture a moment in time or history, and subjects can be taken from any aspect of daily life. There is, however, much debate among haiku scholars over whether this modern form is in fact a hybrid imposter of the 'classical' haiku which was established in the 1600s and had a somewhat more technical form. In the late 19th century, the founding father of the modern haiku, Masaoka Shiki, created an uproar in Japan when he revived the languishing haiku world by simplifying the form.

So can anybody write one? Absolutely - it's seen as a democratic form of poetry, one of the haiku rules being that it has to be accessible to all. And they're catching on in a big way - haiku sites are springing up all over the Net, there are world haiku competitions and even a haiku shop opening in central London.

Where can I find out more? The World Haiku Festival starts this weekend in London and then moves to Oxford later in the week. Haiku poets are expected from all over the world to discuss and present their poems. The overriding aim, according to their website (www.come.to/worldhaiku/), is to 'bind people's minds and hearts together through haiku to open up haiku in every way, especially to new audiences, the wider world and to different branches of culture'. The festival, which runs until 30 August, has exhibitions, haiku readings, public lectures and debates on world haiku. Call 020 7638 0569 for information.

Can I have a go? As a beginner, it might be worth visiting www.booksunlimited.co.uk/games/haiku, which is running a competition to see who can come up with the best topical haiku.

fields.headline: The cost of
fields.standfirst: climbing Mount Everest
fields.trailText: climbing Mount Everest
fields.body:
The Himalayas: you've seen the film, now climb the mountain! The human body can acclimatise to altitudes of up to 17,500ft. At above 26,000ft, it simply starts to shut down: remain at that height without oxygen for more than three days and you will die. This is important because the summit of Everest is at 29,028ft - about the height of a cruising airliner. A task that takes seconds with oxygen can take 20 minutes without, so oxygen is at the top of any Everest climber's shopping list, and Russia has cornered the market in lightweight titanium oxygen canisters (around £50,000 for the average two-month ascent).

Your bags are going to be bulging with climbing equipment: carbiners (£5), harness (£65), rope (£100 per 50m), goggles (£80), climbing pick (£110), crampons (£100 a pair, plus £5 for point protectors), titanium ice screws (£30 each) and the ubiquitous One Sport Everest boots (£300).

Reaching Base Camp (17,500ft) is the easy part. Take a flight to Nepal (£500), then another to Lukla. Hire a yak train and porters (£5,000) and don't forget your visa ($30 for 60 days) and Everest climbing permit ($70,000 per team of seven). It can take two weeks to reach Base Camp and at least another month to acclimatise.

You'll need a bit of a hand on the way up to the summit from sherpas, who earn about $7 per day. A ratio of one climber to one sherpa is the minimum, although a rich Canadian was recently assisted by 15. Including bonuses, a sherpa will earn about £2,000 for a two- or three-month expedition: in 1953, Sir Edmund Hillary's team of sherpas were each paid 100 rupees per month.

Radios are more useful than satellite phones. However, digital cameras (£500), laptops (£1,000) and websites are now de rigueur among the sophisticated Everest set.

A good tip is to take four tents (£450 each) and sleeping bags (£250 each) per person and leave them at each camp for the descent. Maps are not strictly necessary since the route is signposted by footprints, rubbish, ropes and the odd dead body. In 1996, 98 people reached the summit, and 15 died (a ratio of 6.5:1). Everest can be literally breathtaking.

Flights and visa £600
Permit £46,700
Oxygen £50,000
Yaks and porters £5,000
Sherpas £2,000 each
Laptop and camera £1,500
Climbing equipment £2,000
Tents and sleeping bags £2,800
Total not less than £110,600

fields.headline: Four of the best...
fields.standfirst: Popping in pans or on-the-cob, here's where to find the greatest corn
fields.trailText: Popping in pans or on-the-cob, here's where to find the greatest corn.
fields.body:
For an impeccable piece of advice on the way to cook sweetcorn, look no further than the literature of its homeland. It was Mark Twain who recommended making a fire in the middle of a field where maize grew and shucking the ears straight into the pot. More recently, Garrison Keillor recounted how the folk of Lake Wobegone would set a pan of water to boil in the kitchen, walk slowly down to the bottom of the garden, pick their corn and then run back to throw it in the saucepan.

All such stories illustrate the speed with which sugar in the kernels turns into starch as soon as the cob is separated from the plant - but the best city dwellers can do is to buy the cobs with the husks intact, or make a pilgrimage to a PYO farm. Sweetcorn - when not imported from the US, where it is grown in every state - is restricted by climate to southern England. At The Barnyard, Gore Farm, Upchurch, Sittingbourne (01634 388 856) four different varieties of edible maize extend the picking season to two months from the beginning of September, and each cob costs around 20p.

The Barnyard's farmer, Mike Blee, would have liked to grow exotic-coloured varieties for fun, but was put off by the risk of hybridisation. Sweetcorn is a shockingly promiscuous crop, capable of hybridising not merely with other varieties of maize, but also with certain wild grasses. This is why maize kernels may number 16 or 500 on ears the size of a thumbnail or a giant 2ft (in Mexico), and vary in colour from yellow to pink, red, purple, blue, brown or almost black. Seekers after novelty might like to see (and buy) some decorative corn on the cob at Over Farm Market, Over, Gloucester (01452 521 014). Fiesta is a multi-coloured variety, Strawberry is dark red; customers hang these in their kitchens to dry, and pick a yellow-and-white variety called Honey Bantam to eat.

We pick sweetcorn while its kernels are still tender and milky; it is then botanically green, but gastronomically ripe. Popcorn is another variety of maize altogether and is best bought dried from a grocery store. Like freshly roasted nuts, it tastes better made at home than the cardboardy versions available in cinemas. You need only a pan with a close-fitting lid to contain the exciting explosions.

A type of maize widely eaten, yet lacking any discernible flavour in my opinion, is baby sweetcorn. Upmarket caterers Blistering Barbecues (020 7720 7678) say they season them up with Cajun spices to make acceptable canapés, but admit that the best corn is regular-sized and cooked in its husk on a griddle over the coals. The vegetable is suffused with a wonderful smoky flavour and served with a simple sauce of mint-and-parsley butter or just fresh mint, olive oil, Maldon sea salt and pepper.

Barbecuing is probably the most American way to cook corn, if by authentic you mean old-fashioned. At Dakota, however - the acclaimed Notting Hill restaurant at 127 Ledbury Road, London W11 (020 7792 9191), not the state - chef Terry Williamson makes corn fritters, in which the kernels are combined with cornmeal, eggs and herbs and served with chilli jam. Williamson is a cook who works hard with exotic ingredients and says he's thinking of adding a new vegetarian option: red peppers stuffed with spinach and goat's cheese sitting on a creamy corn salsa. Then he blows his street cred by saying there's nothing like corn-on-the-cob 'just with butter on it - you can't beat that, can you?'

fields.headline: A cut above
fields.standfirst: He was friend and hairdresser to the world's greatest stars, including Garbo and Chanel. Now, at 78, Alexandre de Paris has started a new career... as a hotelier in stylish St Tropez. By Lanie Goodman
fields.trailText: He was friend and hairdresser to the world's greatest stars, including Garbo and Chanel. Now, at 78, Alexandre de Paris has started a new career... as a hotelier in stylish St Tropez.
fields.body:
If you've ever sunk your teeth into a Tropezienne tart - a huge triangle of delectable layered sponge cake oozing with custard cream - you soon realise that this quintessential St Tropez dessert captures the spirit of the place: a blend of the excessively rich, decadently pleasurable, and inevitably eyecatching. Everything cries out to be noticed - from the lamé string bikinis in the boutique windows to the dazzling hues of the landscape, captured by the Fauve painters when St Tropez was still a sleepy fishing village.

Ever since the Bardot heyday of the 50s, St Trop's glitzy playground-for-movie-stars image still persists. Which is why it seems appropriate that, when you enter the luxurious, newly opened seven-room Hotel La Mistralée, right in the centre of town, you feel as if you've just walked into a film set. Though it's a lovely but unassuming three-storey white villa from the outside, this extravagant 19th-century mini-palace was formerly the home of the famed celebrity hairdresser, Alexandre de Paris whose decorative flair for explosive colours with a kitsch jumble of styles has remained intact.

If only those Van Gogh-inspired, flowery frescoed walls by the staircase could recount what they've seen and heard. Though now retired, 78-year-old Alexandre (who was born and raised in St Tropez) has had a star-studded list of clients, including Jean Cocteau, Vittorio de Sica, Luchino Visconti, Franco Zefferelli, Sophia Loren, Elizabeth Taylor, Greta Garbo and Audrey Hepburn, and has styled innumerable royal tresses. When he coiffed the Begum Aga Khan for a ball in 1946, the impressed Duchess of Windsor immediately engaged him to remain by her side for the next 30 years as her personal hairdresser. Even today, Alexandre continues to be very much in demand. His numerous designer friends in haute couture - Hubert de Givenchy, Yves St Laurent, Thierry Mugler, Karl Lagerfeld and Jean-Paul Gaultier - still praise him to the skies. 'He's Alexandre the Great,' states Gaultier.

So when Alexandre recently sold his house to Jacques Berville, a legal expert and businessman, and his decorator wife Emmanuelle, the couple decided to transform it into an intimate guesthouse that would preserve the hairdresser's eclectic mix of baroque and borderline high camp, yet make people feel 'at home'. After seven months of renovations, La Mistralée has finally opened its doors, and was booked solid throughout the summer, solely by word of mouth.

'We tried to make it more comfortable without changing the existing decor,' says Philippe Castanier, architect and renovator of the hotel. This meant installing air-conditioning, soundproofing the bedrooms with double windows, and stripping the floor to replace it with intricate geometric mosaic tiles. It also involved finding furnishings that would 'match' the walls, since everything from Alexandre's million-franc bed and precious objets d'art from around the world were cleared out.

Still, the Chanel Room (in homage to Coco Chanel, another of Alexandre's close friends) was too flamboyant. 'You should have seen it! Bright fuschia wallpaper everywhere with silver flecks - very Barbie doll,' smiles Emmanuelle Berville-Aynard. 'We toned down the pink and made the walls pale grey. It's a bit more chic.'

A similar aesthetic decision had to be made for the hotel's suite, an immense bedroom and salon (with a walk-in closet that could easily sleep four) that used to be occupied by Alexandre's associate, the late Gerald Saldi. 'Gerald was crazy about Napoleon and anything that had to do with Empire style,' explains Rosaline Boutron, Alexandre's personal manager. 'The room was inspired by certain exhibits in Paris's Musée Carnavalet.' The fleur-de-lys theme still prevails, but the black-and-deep-violet walls were admittedly 'a bit funeral-like' and changed into a warm ochre.

Fortunately, the spectacular bathrooms - an assortment of gleaming mauve, yellow, pistachio-green-and-aubergine coloured tiles, exotic birds-and-butterfly wallpaper and unusual bamboo-framed showers - needed little restoration. Neither did the Tarzan Room, which boasts elaborate frescoes in both bathroom and bedroom - a Disneylandish jungle scene against a blue sky filled with fluffy clouds.

Undoubtedly, the crowning glory of La Mistralée is the Moroccan Room. How could anyone resist this Arabian Nights dream, lined in glittering red, white and gilded brocade cloth given to Alexandre as a gift by the King of Morocco himself? No detail has been overlooked, from the hand-painted traditional designs on the wooden beams to the splendiferous tiled bathtub and gold net curtains. I half expected the Cheshire cat to appear with a hookah.

Downstairs, beyond the Out of Africa colonial-style salon - adorned with 19th-century stained-glass windows and ornate ceiling mouldings and mirrors copied straight from Versailles - is a lush garden that suddenly catapults you into Asia. At the end of the path, lined with stately red columns and dangling lanterns, is the apogee of Hollywood-meets-the-Orient decor: an electric-blue roof-tiled poolhouse, trimmed expressly in 'the emperor of China's preferred shade of yellow', as Madame Boutron explains.

Breakfast only is served in the spacious glassed-in veranda facing the park, a belle époque wrought-iron structure that Alexandre added to the building. Though the hotel's vibrant kitchen (cobalt blue and sunflower gold, clearly Alexandre's favourites) is certainly well-equipped, La Mistralée wisely prefers not to compete with the St Tropez restaurant scene. However, when your sweet tooth acts up, you can visit the original bakery that invented la tarte Tropezienne, and savour another authentic native delight. Monsieur Alexandre would surely approve.

 Hotel La Mistralée, 1 Avenue Général Leclerc, 83990 Saint-Tropez (00 33 4 9812 9112)

How could anyone resist this Arabian Nights dream, lined in glittering red, white and gilded brocade cloth given to Alexandre as a gift by the King of Morocco himself? No detail has been overlooked, from the hand-painted traditional designs on the wooden beams to the splendiferous tiled bathtub and gold net curtains. I half expected the Cheshire cat to appear with a hookah. Downstairs, beyond the Out of Africa colonial-style salon - adorned with 19th-century stained-glass windows and ornate ceiling mouldings and mirrors copied straight from Versailles - is a lush garden that suddenly catapults you into Asia. At the end of the path, lined with stately red columns and dangling lanterns, is the apogee of Hollywood-meets-the-Orient decor: an electric-blue roof-tiled poolhouse, trimmed expressly in 'the emperor of China's preferred shade of yellow', as Madame Boutron explains. Breakfast only is served in the spacious glassed-in veranda facing the park, a belle époque wrought-iron structure that Alexandre added to the building. Though the hotel's vibrant kitchen (cobalt blue and sunflower gold, clearly Alexandre's favourites) is certainly well-equipped, La Mistralée wisely prefers not to compete with the St Tropez restaurant scene. However, when your sweet tooth acts up, you can visit the original bakery that invented la tarte Tropezienne, and savour another authentic native delight. Monsieur Alexandre would surely approve.  Hotel La Mistralée, 1 Avenue Général Leclerc, 83990 Saint-Tropez (00 33 4 9812 9112)

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst:
When fencing coach Dave Hanrahan (left) first met young James Beevers, he knew he had natural flair. Now, after 14
   years of intensive training in an Essex garage, James has made it to the Sydney Olympics 
   Interview by Sarah Jacobs
fields.trailText:
When fencing coach Dave Hanrahan (left) first met young James Beevers, he knew he had natural flair. Now, after 14
   years of intensive training in an Essex garage, James has made it to the Sydney Olympics 
   Interview by Sarah Jacobs
fields.body:
Dave Hanrahan: In my 22 years as a fencing coach, I never thought I'd get within spitting distance of the Olympics.

James first walked into my club, Cyrano, 14 years ago as an eager eight-year-old. His hand was unusually fast and I could see he had the confidence to win. A year later, I started giving him lessons in my garage in Essex, where I train my particularly good pupils.

By day, I moonlight as a tax inspector in London, but after a quick cup of tea at home, the fencing begins. As well as two club sessions, I do three evenings in the garage, teaching for three hours at a time. It's an ordinary garage - washing machine, freezer, ladders on the wall - but we build up a tremendous atmosphere. Lessons with James are intensely competitive. Whereas an average lesson might last 15 minutes, we train for more than an hour, which often has James on his knees by the end. We're both perfectionists, and our need to achieve the perfect hit keeps us going.

The 2000 Olympics became possible when the British Olympic Association awarded James a scholarship 18 months ago, allowing him to fight on the world circuit. Sydney was still a long shot - only 40 people get to compete - and James still had to get through the Olympic qualifying competition. I knew as long as I could keep him relaxed we had an outside chance.

I am normally Mr Cool at competitions - my job is to watch and analyse the fight - but in the last minutes of James's final qualifying fight, I thought my heart was going to burst out of my chest. I just couldn't believe it. It's such an enormous thing to achieve - it's like the Lottery win.

His success certainly feels like my glory, too. I honestly don't wish that I was the one going to Sydney to fence. I like the buzz of coaching, and I'm very happy to be the Svengali in the background, creating good, fully rounded fencers.

Sadly, Olympic fencing is given very little television coverage in Britain. Because it has a strong public-school background, it is seen as an elitist sport. But the fact that a boy from the back end of Essex has got to this level proves that is not the case. We believe that James has a chance in the Olympics. I don't want to say he's going to win the gold, but anything's possible. James and I are a team with a shared vision - we've developed together, and we're definitely not going to Sydney as tourists.

James Beevers: I did my first fencing in the back of a sick-animal dispensary with my grandad, who was an army fencing coach. My parents are both international fencers and they chose Dave to teach me. Cyrano is a serious club; the atmosphere's highly competitive. But I was enthusiastic, and from the moment I met Dave, I remember I just wanted to hit him!

It felt like a real promotion when Dave suggested lessons in the garage. When I go to the club and train in the big gym, I get tired quickly. But in the garage I could go on all night. Because I come from a fencing family, I've got a natural flair, which gives me an edge over more robotic fencers. Dave also coaches my brother and sister, and my brother is now British under-18 champion.

I won my first national competition when I was 11. Though I've learned to cope with the pressure at competitions, I like having Dave there to relax me and stop my hand from tightening up. My Olympic scholarship has meant I've been to a lot this year that Dave can't afford to attend. I get really annoyed that my coach isn't given the funding to come with me.

Britain is just about the only country that doesn't provide adequate sponsorship for its fencers. I'm one of two British fencers going to the Olympics this year, but the only foil competitor. Before I got the scholarship, the 2000 Games weren't really a consideration, and I was extremely wound up at the qualifier. When I won, both Dave and I were in tears - I've never seen him so choked. It's just as much an achievement for him as it is for me.

The last six months have been intense - I did a degree in English and art history, and I'm looking for a job in the media. As for fencing, it's a case of some intensive technique training and getting really fit. In Sydney, every round is direct elimination, so my entire Olympic career could last three minutes! I'm going as the underdog, but that's how I like it.

Without so much pressure, it's easier to fence your best.

fields.headline: Barefoot Doctor
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to beat the blues, swallowing hard, and being tired of feeling tired
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to beat the blues, swallowing hard, and being tired of feeling tired
fields.body:
Depression is endemic. We've grown accustomed to believing it to be a disease, which in one sense it is - dis-ease. In fact, the term 'depression' is just that - a term: in one way precise, in that one's natural, joyful self is being pushed down (de-pressed), in another, too vague to adequately describe the myriad aspects of anguished existential experience lurking beneath the surface exterior we all present to the world.

I'm not suggesting that we're all 'depressives' (another overly confining term), merely stating, heretically perhaps, that what we term depression is not a disease, but a natural state, given the immense pain (inevitably and inextricably bound to the immense joy) of living life. Or at least a natural state to which our systems default whenever the pressure of life overcomes our natural ebullience and we can't see our way forward, or, if we can, don't feel possessed of the energy or will to go there.

Every day, we are required to manage all the pressures of survival in the modern workplace. Our bodies have to cope with, among other things, fast-moving climate changes, pollution, microwaves, viruses, infections, poor diet, possible substance abuse and media overload. All this while dealing with a complex balance of inherent, genetic, constitutional tendencies.

The stress this generates is huge, and though most of us seem to manage to muddle through most of the time appearing cheerful, if we were all to come together in a large auditorium for a nationwide encounter group, I suggest it wouldn't take long for us to ascertain that we all, beneath our brave exteriors, suffer. Some, hopefully the majority, have found efficient-enough strategies to overcome this natural tendency to default to depressed mode. They somehow create adequate 'space' within for expression of their 'natural, joyful selves', to the extent that most of the time, they feel mostly satisfied with life.

Others, however, find themselves temporarily, and sometimes permanently, without the appropriate inner 'technology' to rise up against the pressure, and are diagnosed as depressed.

Attempting to accurately pin down the cause for any particular individual's depression is like looking for a needle in a haystack. However, Oriental medicine has always recognised that depression, whatever its cause, is in fact often perpetuated by so-called flattened liver energy or depressed liver functions. These may not show up in clinical tests, but will certainly be apparent to anyone trained in Oriental pulse-taking and tongue-inspection forms of diagnosis.

What this implies, both in theory and in (alternative) clinical practice, is no matter the actual cause of depression, treating the liver through acupuncture, herbs, massage, diet and various forms of exercise will, in time, alleviate all the symptoms of depression and facilitate a state of mind positive enough to make the necessary changes for the patient's healthy growth. At the same time, attention would probably be also applied to strengthening the kidneys (thought to generate the will) and the heart (thought to strengthen intention).

Obviously, it is not enough to simply correct the liver energy and hope the cause for depression will be forever banished. The usual stresses and strains of life will still be there, and a workable strategy must be developed to deal with them. The Taoists recognise the perpetual alternation between opposing forces (yin and yang), according to which principle, a period of darkness, if left to the natural course of events, will be followed by a period of light. The Buddhists discipline themselves to always think positively about every situation. In other words, on finding yourself in a slump phase, chronic or acute, have faith that the condition can be reversed. Secondly, apply all the attention you can muster to training your mind to start thinking in a positive manner. Learning to meditate is often the most effective way to grow this positive mindframe and, finally, remember there are no neutral thoughts. As you believe it to be, so it shall be. Make a mental or written list of everything you want to change in your life, then start telling yourself repeatedly, 'I have the intention, will and power to rise up and overcome all negativity. I'm willing to believe I can achieve inner peace.'

And if none of that works, hit the St John's Wort.

Dear Doc, for the past few months, I've been suffering from what I can only describe as a spasm in my throat, which causes so much discomfort, it usually wakes me up at night. I find it hard to swallow and though it doesn't stop me breathing, I tend to panic. I've been for medical tests, fearing cancer, but have been told there's nothing actually wrong. Is there anything I can do for it?
Michelle Hansworth, North Yorkshire

It sounds like you're suffering from spasm of the scalenus muscles in the throat, caused by emotional stress. The throat is ruled by the stomach 'meridian' (energy channel) and sometimes gets physically constricted when there's something occurring in your life which is affecting you profoundly and which you find hard to 'stomach'. The throat is also obviously linked with the ability to communicate through speech. Perhaps you have a troubling relationship issue which needs addressing and communicating about. Meantime, try this: sit straight and tilt your head back gently with jaw wide open. Once the head is fully back, close your jaw. This will produce a stretch through the muscles of the throat. Return your head to the upright position and place a hand either side of your throat and in the manner of someone rubbing their hands together, massage the muscles at the side of your throat gently but briskly for a minute or so to loosen the muscles. You might also consider visiting an Alexander Technique teacher as your posture may be in need of realignment.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, can you suggest any techniques which I could use to break myself out of what has been diagnosed as 'post-viral fatigue syndrome'? Swollen glands, aching limbs, tiredness - the last time I was in this condition, it lasted on and off for five months before abating.
F Crowe, North Shields

From my practice, it appears that what's usually described as post-viral fatigue is in fact severe depletion of energy in the liver, kidneys and often spleen, which then affects the heart and lungs and causes total fatigue. As with ME, cranio-sacral therapy is often surprisingly effective in mobilising your body's defences, probably because it's so gentle and unintrusive and therefore able to penetrate more easily than acupuncture. Up to 10 sessions might be necessary. Yoga is also highly effective in helping you break out of constricting physical patterns and is especially useful for getting to precise spots, like the throat, for purposes of increasing circulation. To overcome any psycho-emotional inertia arising from the physical condition, try a quick blast of hypnotherapy - one session usually does the trick.

 Barefoot Doctor is author of 'Handbook for the Urban Warrior' and teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi. He has been in practice for more than 20 years, specialising in personal-crisis management. If you have any problems you'd like answers to, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him on barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Wake-up call
fields.standfirst: Make that post-lunch slump a thing of the past. Simply eat the right foods, and you'll jump for joy all afternoon
fields.trailText: Make that post-lunch slump a thing of the past. Simply eat the right foods, and you'll jump for joy all afternoon.
fields.body:
I recently took part in a radio programme, during which two listeners rang in to tell me how tired they were. Having given up sugar in an attempt to boost their energy levels, they were now feeling even worse than before. I reassured them that they had taken a step in the right direction, then explained that it takes longer than four or five days for the body to recover from the effects of sugar withdrawal and, indeed, to benefit from any nutritional change.

Nowadays we're far too inclined to expect our bodies to respond instantly to a dietary adjustment or pill. A more realistic view is to compare your body's components to a domino effect: if one falls, it triggers a physiological chain reaction, and it's only at the end of this that you will start to feel better. If, having altered your diet, you're not feeling stronger after a month, consult your GP in case your lethargy is being caused by an undiagnosed problem. Bear in mind, too, that some drugs count exhaustion among their side effects, including antibiotics, beta blockers, antidepressants, anti-epileptic medication and cytotoxic drugs. A few drugs, such as Azothiaprin, may cause insomnia and hence chronic tiredness. So if you think that your medication may be at the root of your tiredness, ask your doctor if a less tiring drug regime is an option.

There could also be a simple nutritional explanation for your feeling below par. You may be: deficient in vitamins and minerals; eating too many sweet foods; consuming starchy foods at unsuitable times; eating too little protein; dehydrated; depending on too many short-term stimulants that are also long-term depressants. One of the most common causes of chronic and acute tiredness is a deficiency of certain vitamins and minerals. The B vitamins, vitamin C, iron, zinc and magnesium have the most profound effect on the body's ability to derive energy from food, and when it does not receive sufficient quantities of these, it is forced to start draining its energy reserves.

The B vitamins are a complex group of substances, including B1 (thiamin), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (nicotinic acid), folic acid, B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine) and B12 (cobalamin), all of which encourage the digestion of food and thus the release of latent energy. Boosting your intake of green vegetables, fish, wholegrain cereals, dried fruits - especially apricots, figs and dates - as well as milk and yogurt should give you a good supply of B vitamins. B12, however, is only found in foods of animal origin, so aim to eat 125g of fromage frais or 150g of cheddar a day, for example. Vegans probably need to take a supplement to ensure that their bodies receive a daily dose of the following: 0.7 to 1.1milligrams of B1; 1.3 to 1.8mg of B2; 15 to 21mg of B3; 1.2 to 1.4mg of B6; 1.5 micrograms of B12, and 200 to 500 micrograms of folic acid.

Vitamin B12 relies on a carrier substance to be secreted by the stomach called intrinsic factor. Some people can lack intrinsic factor and are therefore unable to absorb B12 from foods, in which case they need regular vitamin B12 injections.

Magnesium, a mineral which is found in wholegrain products, brown rice, green leafy vegetables, peas and sweetcorn (fantastic at this time of year) also assists your body in its quest for energy and enables you to absorb vitamin C. A deficiency of vitamin C, which is present in citrus fruits, kiwi fruits, peaches, green leafy vegetables and peppers, can prohibit the body's absorption of iron. This mineral enables the body to manufacture healthy red blood cells, which pick up oxygen from the lungs and transport it to the tissues, where it unlocks food's potential energy. So eat a good-sized portion of an iron-containing food (lean red meat, game, dark-green leafy vegetables, pulses, shellfish, tinned oily fish and dried fruits), along with five portions of vitamin C-rich fresh fruits or lightly cooked vegetables each day. An additional benefit of eating more fruit instead of sugary foods (like chocolate or biscuits, which deliver a burst of energy but ultimately undermine your stamina) is that your body will receive a dose of slow-release, energising fructose.

Starchy foods such as pasta, potatoes, rice and bread encourage the body to produce sleep-inducing hormones, so if your lunch consists of pasta, a sandwich or a jacket potato, it could be causing your afternoon tiredness. In contrast, because protein-rich foods like cheese, fish, lean meat, eggs and pulses tend to boost energy levels, opt for a sandwich with a high protein filling. Or, if your workplace has kitchen equipment, bring some cold roast chicken, lean charcuterie, cheese, hard-boiled eggs or smoked salmon from home to team with a ready-made salad and some fruit or soup. Although it may seem to involve an inordinate amount of effort, this strategy really seems to increase energy levels. Eating something is better than nothing at all: you should start to feel stronger even if you only incorporate more protein into your diet one week and focus on fruits and vegetables the next, for example, or concentrate on eating well over a free weekend.

Because a lack of water prevents the body from absorbing the beneficial nutrients, and hence energy, in food, try to drink 2.5 litres of water a day and limit yourself to two to three caffeine-containing drinks (be prepared for an initial lack of energy, which should disappear after a few days). And resist the urge to drink at night until you have eaten something. Drinking on an empty stomach can send your energy levels plummeting, which might mean you won't muster the strength to prepare something nutritious to eat. Many of my patients who have replaced their pre-dinner tipple with tomato juice, ginger beer or fresh fruit juice have reported that they didn't realise how much post-work energy they could have. Giving up alcohol for a few weeks reaps huge, energy-boosting rewards as well.

Vegans probably need to take a supplement to ensure that their bodies receive a daily dose of the following: 0.7 to 1.1milligrams of B1; 1.3 to 1.8mg of B2; 15 to 21mg of B3; 1.2 to 1.4mg of B6; 1.5 micrograms of B12, and 200 to 500 micrograms of folic acid. Vitamin B12 relies on a carrier substance to be secreted by the stomach called intrinsic factor. Some people can lack intrinsic factor and are therefore unable to absorb B12 from foods, in which case they need regular vitamin B12 injections. Magnesium, a mineral which is found in wholegrain products, brown rice, green leafy vegetables, peas and sweetcorn (fantastic at this time of year) also assists your body in its quest for energy and enables you to absorb vitamin C. A deficiency of vitamin C, which is present in citrus fruits, kiwi fruits, peaches, green leafy vegetables and peppers, can prohibit the body's absorption of iron. This mineral enables the body to manufacture healthy red blood cells, which pick up oxygen from the lungs and transport it to the tissues, where it unlocks food's potential energy. So eat a good-sized portion of an iron-containing food (lean red meat, game, dark-green leafy vegetables, pulses, shellfish, tinned oily fish and dried fruits), along with five portions of vitamin C-rich fresh fruits or lightly cooked vegetables each day. An additional benefit of eating more fruit instead of sugary foods (like chocolate or biscuits, which deliver a burst of energy but ultimately undermine your stamina) is that your body will receive a dose of slow-release, energising fructose. Starchy foods such as pasta, potatoes, rice and bread encourage the body to produce sleep-inducing hormones, so if your lunch consists of pasta, a sandwich or a jacket potato, it could be causing your afternoon tiredness. In contrast, because protein-rich foods like cheese, fish, lean meat, eggs and pulses tend to boost energy levels, opt for a sandwich with a high protein filling. Or, if your workplace has kitchen equipment, bring some cold roast chicken, lean charcuterie, cheese, hard-boiled eggs or smoked salmon from home to team with a ready-made salad and some fruit or soup. Although it may seem to involve an inordinate amount of effort, this strategy really seems to increase energy levels. Eating something is better than nothing at all: you should start to feel stronger even if you only incorporate more protein into your diet one week and focus on fruits and vegetables the next, for example, or concentrate on eating well over a free weekend. Because a lack of water prevents the body from absorbing the beneficial nutrients, and hence energy, in food, try to drink 2.5 litres of water a day and limit yourself to two to three caffeine-containing drinks (be prepared for an initial lack of energy, which should disappear after a few days). And resist the urge to drink at night until you have eaten something. Drinking on an empty stomach can send your energy levels plummeting, which might mean you won't muster the strength to prepare something nutritious to eat. Many of my patients who have replaced their pre-dinner tipple with tomato juice, ginger beer or fresh fruit juice have reported that they didn't realise how much post-work energy they could have. Giving up alcohol for a few weeks reaps huge, energy-boosting rewards as well.

fields.headline: Family values
fields.standfirst: John Smedley has been family owned for  more than 200 years. The royals buy its long  johns and celebrities its classic woollens. As  the company prepares to open its first shop,  meet the team that knits for England, America,  Japan...
fields.trailText: John Smedley has been family owned for more than 200 years. The royals buy its long johns and celebrities its classic woollens. As the company prepares to open its first shop, meet the team that knits for England, America, Japan...
fields.body:
It's taken 226 years. But next month, John Smedley, the British knitwear company renowned from Tokyo to Toronto, will open its first shop. Just along from Issey Miyake's Pleats Please, on London's chic Brook Street, it'll be slick and modern, designed by the cutting-edge architects Soft Room. And the rails will be crammed with brightly coloured New Zealand wool, Sea Island cotton and - exclusive to the shop - a few pieces of Smedley cashmere, the company's first steps into the more luxury end of the market. The Smedley celebrity hall of fame - including Paul Weller, Tom Cruise, Robbie Williams, Guy Ritchie and the Gallagher brothers - will have a new shopping destination. This small, two-storey shop is about to become Fashion Central.

It is the start of a new era for a company that began in 1784 at the onset of the industrial revolution. Many of its staff have been with the company for years, and many are related to each other. Moreover, the business, with an annual turnover of £15m, is family owned - the president is Andrew Marsden-Smedley, the chairman is his cousin Lowry Maclean - but instead of getting bogged down by family feuds, it has a team of professional managers to maintain the quality and tradition that have made the label a household name.

For years, Smedley has manufactured limited editions and small runs for other fashion houses. It has been a secret weapon, quietly making knitwear for such designers as Yves Saint Laurent, Margaret Howell, Paul Smith, Agnès b, Lanvin, as well as some of British fashion's more funky names, such as Antonio Berardi and Sonja Nuttall.

But Smedley has never been seen as directional or trend-setting. Instead, you can always rely on the brand for a perfect polo shirt, a prim crew neck or a classic cardie. Fans will spend a few pounds extra for Smedleys because they won't shrink, turn into a bobbly mess or go all misshapen; they can be thrown in the wash and come out like new. Like Levi's, Doc Martens and Kangol berets, they are made to last. Nor will they go out of fashion. But this autumn, there is a new treat in store. There's the sparkle of Lurex, a sprinkling of sequins, the sexiness of a tie-neck, twinsets cut to cling rather than drape, necklines designed to flatter rather than cover, and colours that will make your mouth water.

It's a radical departure for the Derbyshire-based company, which is still on its original site. The new look is the result of a collaboration between the head of design, Dawne Stubbs, and the London-based stylist Sally Courtis. Designers often use magazine stylists to work on their collections, but it is only in the past 10 years or so that Smedley has used a designer at all. Before that, the business was very technically based. Courtis, previously a fashion editor at Elle , was asked to consult on a capsule collection last year. And London's most fashionable boutiques, The Cross in west London, and Browns Focus on South Molton Street, are very impressed. 'I've used consultants to advise on colour,' says Stubbs, 'but never on style and styling. The idea was to do a capsule collection which would be just a step away from the main collection, but would be the icing on the cake. It has become a test bed for new yarns, designs and surface decoration.'

It is amazing to see the process each Smedley jumper goes through before it is packed and boxed, ready to be shipped to Japan, Italy, America, or - if it hasn't quite made it past quality control - into the factory shop to be sold at bargain prices to coachloads of Japanese tourists. Each week, some 12,000 garments leave the factory.

The process begins with bales of New Zealand superfine Merino wool, which are combed, conditioned and put on to big reels. The yarn is so fine you can't even see it spinning through the machines. It is lubricated to stop it snapping, and then goes into the knitting department, where the sleeve and collar ribs are knitted on ancient machines that are part of the Smedley secret. Next, a team of women put each rib on to machine knitting needles, stitch by stitch. Drop one stitch and the jumper will have a run in it. From there, the jumpers start to take shape on the 70-year-old knitting machines, which are gradually being replaced by new ones from Japan. The pieces are all joined together by hand and sent downstairs into the damp, sheep-smelling bowels of the factory to be washed, pressed and steamed. After that, each jumper has a neckline cut by hand, the trim attached and hand-stitched. After a final inspection under the magnifying glass, the jumpers are pressed and folded into a bag, ready for distribution. Each one goes through 35 different processes. If you unravelled your prized Smedley, you would find that the yarn stretches out for 4.5km.

If the first John Smedley had been set up in America or Italy, it would have a turnover far in excess of £15m. Lowry Maclean would be the chairman of a multi-million dollar empire. His office would be at the top of a skyscraper. There would be sunglasses, luggage, shoes, golf wear. There would be Smedley aftershave. We would have Smedley's jay bird logo coming out of our ears. As it is, the company is more interested in quality than quantity, and is still relatively small and happy to progress slowly into the 21st century. Smedley is determined to be around in another 200 years' time.

But when the shop opens, be sure to get there early. Those capsule pieces with their sequin trims and Lurex threads will not hang around long. As for the cashmere, it could be the start of a beautiful relationship.

Stars who sport Smedley

Paul Weller

Dave Stewart

Vinnie Jones

Tom Cruise

Liam Gallagher

Guy Ritchie

Robbie Williams

 John Smedley opens at 24 Brook Street, London W1 on 18 September
