fields.headline: Soya-bean crisis
fields.standfirst:
Scientists versus the soya industry. Jane Phillimore addresses some of the concerns
raised by new research
fields.trailText:
Scientists versus the soya industry. Jane Phillimore addresses some of the concerns
raised by new research
fields.body:
Twelve years ago, I visited an alternative health practitioner with some non-specific health symptoms. I'd hardly sat down before he told me that my diet needed radical attention - I had to cut out all dairy, wheat, alcohol and caffeine, and substitute protein in the form of soya milk and tofu instead. Nowadays this kind of advice is routine, but at the time, it seemed glamorously radical: I had to trek to Clapham's one health-food shop to stock up on soya milk because Sainsbury's certainly didn't have their own brand (as they do now) and veggie/soya sausages were just a glint in Linda McCartney's eye.

In the event, I lost a stack of weight and felt immensely rejuvenated. So much so that, four months later, I started eating normally again. Just as well, because it has now been found that soya - far from having the magical, health-giving properties that the alternative medicine brigade endlessly bangs on about - can actually be bad for you. Its reputation as an anti-cancer, cholesterol-lowering, osteoporosis-fighting, low-fat all round good egg of a product is based on bad science and superlative marketing by the powerful soya industry.

Worldwide, the evidence is starting to stack up against soya. In this country, MAFF is so worried about the possible health problems of phytoestrogens in soya that they are funding a rolling programme of 19 separate research projects, due to end in 2002. Preliminary findings by Professor John Ashby of AstraZeneca Central Toxicology Laboratory in Macclesfield, for example, confirm that soya infant formula (currently the sole food of 6,500 British babies) has an oestrogenic effect on rats. According to public health minister Yvette Cooper, no new advice will be given on soya until the independent COT (Committee on Toxicity of Chemicals in Food, Consumer Products and the Environment) has reviewed the programme's findings.

This could take several years. Meanwhile, if you've been seduced by the message that soya is the healthy 21st-century superfood, read on...

Is soya bad for you?

It contains high quantities of various toxic chemicals, which cannot be fully destroyed even by the long cooking process. These are: phytates, which block the body's uptake of minerals; enzyme inhibitors, which hinder protein digestion; and haemaggluttin, which causes red blood cells to clump together and inhibits oxygen take-up and growth. Most controversially of all, soya contains high levels of the phytoestrogens (also known as isoflavones) genistein and daidzein, which mimic and sometimes block the hormone oestrogen.

Surely, the Japanese eat huge quantities of soya, and as a result have low rates of breast, uterus, colon and prostate cancers?

That's the big myth on which the idea of 'healthy' soya is built. In fact, the Japanese don't eat that much soya: a 1998 study showed that a Japanese man typically eats about 8g (2 tsp) a day, nothing like the 220g (8oz) that a Westerner could put away by eating a big chunk of tofu and two glasses of soya milk. Secondly, although Japanese people may have lower rates of reproductive cancers, this is thought to be due to other dietary and lifestyle factors: they eat less fatty meat, more fish and vegetables and fewer tinned or processed foods than in a typical Western diet. Thirdly, Asians have much higher rates of thyroid and digestive cancers, including cancer of the stomach, pancreas, liver and oesophagus.

I'm vegetarian and eat loads of tofu and soya milk. Should I stop?

Soya has become vegetarians' meat and milk, the major source of protein in their diet. But eating soya actually puts vegetarians at severe risk of mineral deficiencies, including calcium, copper, iron, magnesium and especially zinc. According to Dr Mike Fitzpatrick, a New Zealand biochemist who runs a soya information website (see below), this is because soya contains high levels of phytic acid, which blocks the absorption of essential minerals in the digestive tract. To reduce the effects of a high-phytate diet, you need to eat, as the Japanese do, lots of meat or fish with tiny bits of soya.

I'm intolerant to cow's milk, so should I drink soya milk instead?

Soya has become the fashionable option for people 'intolerant' to dairy products. It's little known that soya is the second most common allergen. Only 1 per cent of the population is truly allergic to cows' milk and, of those, two-thirds will also be intolerant to soya milk. In addition, soya milk is high in aluminium. That's because the soya protein isolate it's made from is acid-washed in aluminium tanks. No wonder it tastes bad.

Can soya affect your thyroid?

It's been known for years that phytoestrogens in soya depress thyroid function. In Japan, 1991 research showed that 30g of soya a day results in a huge increase in thyroid-stimulating hormone. This can cause goitre, hypothyroidism, and auto-immune thyroid disease.

I'm pregnant. Should I avoid soya?

Probably, and especially if you're vegetarian. A new study of babies born to vegetarian mothers showed that baby boys had a five-fold risk of hypospadias, a birth defect of the penis. The researchers suggest this was due to greater exposure to phytoestrogen rich-foods, especially soya. Inappropriate hormone levels such as that caused by a high intake of soya during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy can also cause damage to the foetus's developing brain.

But surely I can feed my baby soya formula? It must be safe: it's available in every supermarket and chemist.

Soya-fed babies are taking part in 'a large, uncontrolled and basically unmonitored human infant experiment', said Daniel Sheehan, director of the FDA's National Center for Toxicological Research, in 1998. A newborn baby's sole food is the milk it drinks: a soya-fed baby receives the equivalent of five birth control pills' worth of oestrogen every day, according to Mike Fitzpatrick. These babies' isoflavone levels were found to be from 13,000 to 22,000 times higher than in non-soya fed infants.

As a result of this phytoestrogen overload, soya-fed babies have a two-fold risk of developing thyroid abnormalities including goitre and auto-immune thyroiditis. Boys risk retarded physical maturation, while girls risk early puberty (1 per cent of girls now show signs of puberty, such as breast development or pubic hair, before the age of three) and fertility. Researchers have also suggested that diabetes, changes in the central nervous system, extreme emotional behaviour, asthma, immune system problems, pituitary insufficiency and IBS may be caused by high phytoestrogen intake in early life. Last year, compounds in soya were also implicated in the development of infantile leukaemia. Current government advice is that breast is best and that soya formula should not be given to infants unless on the advice of a health professional.

Can soya help with prostate cancer?

Ex-junk bond trader Michael Milken certainly thinks so. He consumes 40g of soya protein every day with that hope in mind. The science is less conclusive - a recent study on Japanese-Americans living in Hawaii showed that men who had eaten two or more servings of tofu a week during mid-life not only had 'accelerated brain ageing', and more than twice the incidence of Alzheimer's and dementia, but also looked five years older than those men who didn't.

My mother died of breast cancer and I've been advised by both mainstream and complementary medical sources that increasing my soya intake may offer me protection against the disease. Is this true?

The evidence is highly inconclusive. In The Breast Cancer Protection Diet , published last year, Dr Bob Arnot states that eating between 35g and 60g of soya protein daily protects against breast cancer by raising intake of the oestrogen-blocker genistein. But this ignores contrary evidence. In 1996, research showed that women eating soya had an increased incidence of epithelial hyperplasia, a condition that presages malignancy. In 1997, genistein in the diet was also found to stimulate human breast cells to enter the cell cycle. As a result, the researchers advised women not to eat soya products to prevent breast cancer.

But surely soya prevents osteoporosis, the bone thinning that particularly affects post-menopausal women?

No. In fact, soya blocks calcium and causes a deficiency of vitamin D, both of which are needed for strong bones, say American nutritionists and soya debunkers Sally Fallon and Mary G Enig.

Is there any kind of soya product I can safely eat?

Yes. Fermented soya products, such as soy sauce, tempeh and miso. The long fermentation process counteracts the effects of natural toxins in soya.

Can I avoid soya?

It's hard. You can stop eating the obvious candidates such as soya milk and tofu, but soya is also to be found in breakfast cereals, ice cream, convenience food such as hamburgers, fish fingers and lasagne, and all manner of baked goods from cakes and biscuits to tortillas and bread. If that's your mission in life, read labels carefully, and eat organic processed foods wherever possible.

Finally, the pro-soya lobby always says that, in the US, a quarter of the population has been fed infant soya formula for 30 to 40 years, with no adverse health problems. So why should I worry?

Scientists are only just beginning to research and understand the harmful long-term effects that eating large quantities of soya can have on the human body. As Fallon and Enig write: 'The industry has know for years that soya contains many toxins. At first they told the public that the toxins were removed by processing. Then they claimed that these substances were beneficial.' Sounds like there's a big battle ahead.

 For further information, contact www.soyonlineservice.co.nz, a detailed information resource on soya run by biochemist Dr Mike Fitzpatrick. Sally Fallon and Mary G Enig's excellent article 'Tragedy and Hype: The Third Soy Symposium' is on www.nexusmagazine.com. 'The Trouble With Tofu: Soya and the Brain' by John D MacArthur is on www.brain.com

In 1997, genistein in the diet was also found to stimulate human breast cells to enter the cell cycle. As a result, the researchers advised women not to eat soya products to prevent breast cancer. But surely soya prevents osteoporosis, the bone thinning that particularly affects post-menopausal women? No. In fact, soya blocks calcium and causes a deficiency of vitamin D, both of which are needed for strong bones, say American nutritionists and soya debunkers Sally Fallon and Mary G Enig. Is there any kind of soya product I can safely eat? Yes. Fermented soya products, such as soy sauce, tempeh and miso. The long fermentation process counteracts the effects of natural toxins in soya. Can I avoid soya? It's hard. You can stop eating the obvious candidates such as soya milk and tofu, but soya is also to be found in breakfast cereals, ice cream, convenience food such as hamburgers, fish fingers and lasagne, and all manner of baked goods from cakes and biscuits to tortillas and bread. If that's your mission in life, read labels carefully, and eat organic processed foods wherever possible. Finally, the pro-soya lobby always says that, in the US, a quarter of the population has been fed infant soya formula for 30 to 40 years, with no adverse health problems. So why should I worry? Scientists are only just beginning to research and understand the harmful long-term effects that eating large quantities of soya can have on the human body. As Fallon and Enig write: 'The industry has know for years that soya contains many toxins. At first they told the public that the toxins were removed by processing. Then they claimed that these substances were beneficial.' Sounds like there's a big battle ahead.  For further information, contact www.soyonlineservice.co.nz, a detailed information resource on soya run by biochemist Dr Mike Fitzpatrick. Sally Fallon and Mary G Enig's excellent article 'Tragedy and Hype: The Third Soy Symposium' is on www.nexusmagazine.com. 'The Trouble With Tofu: Soya and the Brain' by John D MacArthur is on www.brain.com

fields.headline: Nanny state
fields.standfirst: No kidding: one of the great French-style goat's cheeses is made by a Dutchman in Ireland, says Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: No kidding: one of the great French-style goat's cheeses is made by a Dutchman in Ireland, says Sybil Kapoor.
fields.body:
Anyone who has ever met a billy goat at close quarters will know that they are not the most charming of creatures. Aside from their need to assert their authority by butting you, they have a penchant for nibbling anything within reach, including you. To add insult to injury, they smell of rancid socks. In fact, the only thing that redeems goats, in my eyes, is their ability to produce milk that is perfect for cheese. However, Luc van Kampen, one of Ireland's finest goat's cheese-makers, was quick to disabuse me: 'Nanny goats are lovely animals. They are far more gentle than other animals.'

Van Kampen keeps 70 goats on his farm in Ballynadrishoge, County Wexford. They graze his fields and produce milk from February to November, but unlike most modern cheese-makers, van Kampen neither freezes his milk nor makes hard cheeses to sell through the barren winter months. Instead, he concentrates on making a delicious, unpasteurised natural rind cheese called Mine Gabhar, which can only be bought from March to December.

A self-taught cheese-maker, van Kampen does not hold with flowery descriptions of cheese. 'Mine Gabhar is based on an adaptation of the French recipe for Crottin,' is all he will say. It tastes creamy, fragrant and slightly acidic all at the same time.

He is almost mystical when describing how he makes his cheese. You get a sense of warm goat's milk being mixed into the chilled milk from the preceding evening. A hint of the home-made starter, vegetarian (non-GM) rennet and some geotrichum mould being mixed into the rich milk, followed by the cool curds being drained, gently dried, and dusted with salt and Penicillium album mould. Then, three weeks later, the velvety little cheeses are removed from their chilled cellar, wrapped in waxed paper and sold.

Dominic Coytes, retail manager at Neal's Yard Dairy in London's Borough Market, is far more prosaic. 'Luc van Kampen is only interested in producing the best possible cheese,' he says. 'He uses moulds that, as they develop, release enzymes which alter the protein and fat in his goat's milk cheese.' The former changes its texture, making the cheese increasingly silky smooth as it matures, while the latter alters its flavour, converting its initial bitterness into a pungent, earthy taste.

All things considered, I now regard goats in a slightly more friendly light.

 Mine Gabhar is usually sold by weight. Each cheese is about 200g and costs roughly £6. Available from Ian Mellis Cheesemonger, 30a Victoria Street, Edinburgh EH1 (0131 226 6215); Neal's Yard Dairy, 6 Park Street, Borough Market, London SE1 (020 7645 3555); Culina, 12a London Road, Alderley Edge, Cheshire (01625 586 200)

fields.headline: Spiritual guides
fields.standfirst: Gurus: the finishing touch
fields.trailText: Spiritual guides
fields.body:
Column inches devoted to Meg Ryan's split with husband Dennis Quaid often included the delicious detail that they had squabbled, in very spiritually suspect style, over which of them had rights to their guru.

The lady in question, one Gurumayi Chidvilasananda, dispenses Siddha yoga from her ashram in upstate New York, and a bitter custody battle was only averted at the eleventh hour, when Ryan and Quaid decided to get back together. Other celebrity worshippers must have exhaled serenely, knowing that no further bad karma would surround their Chosen One. The likes of Isabella Rossellini, Diana Ross, Lisa Kudrow and, er, Lulu all make regular pilgrimages to receive official blessings from the fortysomething leader, a procedure which involves being tapped on the head with a wand of peacock feathers. It is rumoured that some of her servants hold her in such obeisance that they anoint themselves with her dirty bathwater. It'll come as no surprise then to learn that although gurus traditionally frown upon worldy goods, Gurumayi's ashram is apparently worth a cool £14m.

The rise of the career guru really began in earnest back in 1967 when The Beatles pledged their faith in a Hindu swami going by the name of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the man who introduced Transcendental Meditation to the West. During that period, a rival guru also attracted famous disciples, a sacked Ivy League psychology professor named Richard Alpert, who went to India and returned as Ram Dass, servant of God.

Three decades later, nothing much seems to have changed, except that the word guru (meaning 'dispeller of darkness') is now applied to anyone and everyone who is a so-called expert and has a raft of well-known clients. Nowadays, we have love gurus and money gurus, life gurus and fitness gurus, internet gurus and pet gurus and soon, I daresay, we will even have a guru to advise us on finding the right guru.

These days, laying claim to a guru is an instant signifier of power, wealth and status. For some peculiar reason, entrusting a complete stranger with the wellbeing of one's mind, body and spirit is not only accepted as sensible behaviour, it is positively essential if you want to get ahead. In some cases, it's a guilt thing. Whereas once the goal was to be rich and successful, now it is only OK to brag about those achievements if we also appear to be spiritually evolved human beings as well.

Once a guru gets a celebrity endorsement, the rest of us are right behind buying the books or the beauty regime. Right now, spirituality is omnipresent and seriously chic. Donna Karan gave out Deepak Chopra cassettes instead of programmes at a catwalk show, while ex-supermodel Christy Turlington was so inspired by her yoga teacher that she has launched Sundari, a skincare range based on Eastern philosophy. And who can forget how, a few years ago, the Dalai Lama edited a special edition of that deeply spiritual journal, Paris Vogue ?

So it is that the world suddenly seems to be swarming with deities to address every conceivable dilemma, from how do I wash my face (in your saliva, suggests Deepak Chopra, ayurvedic spiritual maestro and adviser to the likes of Demi Moore), to how do I survive mid-life pregnancy (ask Bharti Vyas, the spiritual beauty guru who helped prepare Cherie Blair for baby Leo).

'Right now there is a tendency to turn to gurus because organised religion is increasingly not meeting people's needs,' says the Rev Dr Geoff Scobie, who has researched the psychology of belief systems at Glasgow University. 'Maybe they feel that the level of commitment demanded by conventional religion is too high, yet they've got to do something to fill the spiritual void.

'This is where the guru comes in. You pay them, they tell you something deep and incomprehensible, and you feel you've had your money's worth. But while people may believe that this equals commitment, it doesn't. You can't buy spiritual development; money is no substitute for faith, time and love. It's a quick fix.'

Psychologist Oliver James, author of Britain on the Couch , believes there are other reasons we are going to gurus. 'Human beings have always put their faith in authority figures to help them work out what to do. Generally, we all want certainty. But in the past 50 years, we've moved from a collectivist society to an individualist society. Our identity is no longer determined on the basis of family position or social role.

'It's no longer so clear who the authority figures are, which is why we're seeking consolation in self-appointed gurus, be they involved in alternative medicine, herbalism, psychotherapy or religion.' James believes followers would be better off spending their money on therapy. 'Shrinks are the opposite of gurus - they're going to be your disciple.'

His scepticism seems well placed. A few years back, two of Gurumayi's most ardent followers gave their baby the middle name of Mayi to bestow spiritual well-being on their family. Alas, even the blessing of a top guru could not save Melanie Griffiths and Don Johnston from getting divorced for the second time.

fields.headline: Paint your wagon
fields.standfirst: It's a bloke thing, a way of showing your colours and making your mark. But there's more to the world of the monster truck than decorating 40-tonne vehicles. Richard Benson rolls up to Truckfest Scotland
fields.trailText: It's a bloke thing, a way of showing your colours and making your mark. But there's more to the world of the monster truck than decorating 40-tonne vehicles. Richard Benson rolls up to Truckfest Scotland.
fields.body:
'Well, you'd spend money doing up your house, wouldn't you?' replies Mrs Danneke O Neale, perhaps a little tartly, when I ask her why a grown man would paint pictures of Princess Diana on a lorry. 'These guys can live in their trucks for four weeks at a stretch, so they get attached to them. Then there's the one-upmanship you see among the boys... and they take pride in what they do, as they should, because it's a skill. You know, like a nurse has the skill to look after a person? Well, these guys have the skill to haul that baby on down the road.'

Mrs O Neale, president of the Lady Truckers' Club of Great Britain, has spent 20 years hauling these 44-tonne babies down the road. She uses language like this because she is a dyed-in-the-wool, embossed-on-the-mudflap trucker, and all truckers speak like country and western lyricists. She is worth talking to about customised trucks because while she is all effusive and poetical, the men who do the customising are rather shy about discussing it with outsiders.

We are sitting amid rig and wagon at Truckfest Scotland, on the Royal Highland Showground just outside Edinburgh. Like the other three Truckfests (Peterborough, Shepton Mallett, Driffield) that convene each summer, it is a two-day festival for people who work with, or who just happen to like, trucks - a head-on collision between the Glastonbury Festival and Convoy. Driver teams from haulage companies and individual owner-drivers come with their families to park up, pitch tents, polish chrome and talk trucker-talk around the barbie. Judges (there are 10 competitons) wander and ponder. Manufacturers come to show off their new models. Ex-drivers and fans haul their families down avenues of exhibits, fairground sideshows and stalls selling scale models, T-shirts and piles of trucking-themed country and western CDs. And then there are the stars of the show, standing tall and imperious like prize bulls: the customised 'units' lovingly sprayed with airbrush artwork, smoothed with spoiler and aerofoil, and bejewelled with airhorn, spotlight-bar and aerial shrubbery.

Most of the custom trucks are owned by private-haulage firms, and have been decorated at the instigation of the owners. Specialist paint shops do the spraying (a cab unit takes about two weeks and costs, on average, £3,000), and workshops or the drivers themselves will add the accessories. Usually, European owners take their themes from films, music or television, choosing one or more recognisable characters - the Highlanders and Bravehearts at Truckfest Scotland, for example. In the US, truckers tend to favour flames, sunsets and eagles.

The most recognisable individual here is the 'Queen of Hearts', technically a DAF 95XF tractor unit but also a 10-wheeled, 12ft, blue-and-silver monument to Princess Di, created by Roy Gill of RD Gill Haulage in Derbyshire. Diana's famous eyes and teeth gleam on the bonnet and side panels; on the back of its cab, Elton John gazes mournfully at the legend 'Goodbye Englands Rose'. If you've driven down the M6, you might have seen it; if you haven't, it will probably take your power of speech away at the first sight.

Why Di? Well, Roy has a truck painted with a different motif every year. 'Queen of Hearts' was his wife Sarah's idea (he 'took some persuading') in 1997. Other models, also on show today, include 'Legend of Rock', 'Comedy Classic' and, most recently, the Winnie-the-Pooh-themed 'Bear Essentials' - a present for his six-year-old daughter, Melissa. Like a lot of the customisers here, he is dead blokey and jokey, until I start asking him serious-ish questions about the artwork. Then he talks a bit about the business justifications - the enhanced profile, the possibilities for merchandising and toys - before handing me over to Sarah. Does she think her husband really gets the trucks painted because they bring more business in? Not really, she says. 'But you know, Roy's trucks are his life, and his hobby, as well as his work.'

Stephen Wilson, who runs a Braveheart Scania out of Peterhead, says the public response made it worth the money ('It is unbelievable... factories come to a standstill when you pick up from them, and one woman chased me through London in her car, to get a picture'). Andy Scott, who has an International Harvester recovery vehicle and who painted several of the trucks here at his South Yorkshire paint shop, thinks it is sometimes about advertising, sometimes about self-expression ('I did a portrait of a dog that had died for one fella. When he saw it the tears were welling up in his eyes. That was worth more than the money to me').

Bob Limming, whose company Live Promotions runs Truckfest, reckons it's about the driver's sense of vocation: 'We started Truckfest in 1983 because our managing director's brother, a driver, had observed that lorry drivers were turning into truck drivers. It was changing from a dirty old job that anyone could do into one that you needed skills for. When you're driving 40 tonnes of truck and you think about those cold rainy nights on your own [cue steel guitar], it feels like you've got quite a responsibility. So it became a vocation. This had already happened in the US, and there was an influence from films like Smokey and the Bandit, which were about drivers who were macho, but who also had vehicles that were their own and that looked good.'

This might sound a little fanciful to urban sophisticates, but less so, I think, to those who grew up in the sort of villages that most of the men and women at Truckfest come from. Because however much living in the countryside teaches you to appreciate nature, it teaches you to appreciate machines with wheels much more. Public transport being what it isn't, they are what allow you meet people, go shopping and make your life more about you than it would be otherwise.

And then there's the work side. There's always lots of big stuff to be moved in the country - bales of straw, tons of coal, piles of logs. It's hard work, and the people responsible for it come to love the machines that make it easier. This love of engines and strong vehicles is in the country air. If you go into rural areas, you find thousands of men who are quietly besotted with fast cars, Land Rovers, tractors and odd-shaped motor vehicles from dragsters to industrial cranes. In most of these blokes, the desire to dress up and show off has been submerged by rugged common sense; in the custom truckers of Great Britain, it has resurfaced.

fields.headline: Car tribes
fields.standfirst: Whether you own a new Nissan, a 1971 Mercedes 280 or a 1957 Nash Metropolitan, you are what you drive, says Tamsin Blanchard (owner of a 1972 BMW 2002)
fields.trailText: Whether you own a new Nissan, a 1971 Mercedes 280 or a 1957 Nash Metropolitan, you are what you drive, says Tamsin Blanchard (owner of a 1972 BMW 2002).
fields.body:
Peter Kent is a design partner with Hosker Moore & Kent, the architecture and interior design company responsible for Harvey Nichols in Leeds and Riyadh. Other projects have included the Valentino store on London's Sloane Street, Patrick Cox, Moschino and the refurbishment of Richard James, Savile Row's coolest tailor. In Kent's business, appearances are everything. Two years ago, when he moved into the streamlined 1937 apartment block designed by Wells Coates, the architect who built London's famous Lawn Road Flats in Belsize Park, he decided to take advantage of the underground car park. He bought his dream car: a silver 1971 Mercedes 280SEL. It was a fantasy on wheels; the ultimate pose.

For Kent, along with thousands of others who shudder at the thought of driving some bland, modern box of a car made by Ford or Toyota, his car is an extension of his personality. Just as he would rather have his fingernails slowly plucked out one by one than be seen wearing a shell suit or a C&A anorak, so too is it vital that when he gets behind the wheel of a car, it is not something he would consider naff or clichéd. As far as Kent is concerned, you are what you drive. When a car ceases to be a machine that gets you from A to B, and instead becomes a fashion accessory, its owners are identifying themselves with a particular style tribe, just as they might if they shaved their hair and wore DMs or adopted a uniform of rugby shirt and deck shoes. In Kent's case, the tribe happens to be a very select one. His is not any old Mercedes. Only 900 of his particular model were ever built. He is not a member of the car club, preferring to go it alone with his silver dream machine - a mark of his impeccable taste and style.

For others, it might be a Morris Minor that gets the pistons going. Or an MG or a Mini Cooper. Certain types of people gravitate towards certain cars. It is no surprise that the man driving the 1991 Nissan Figaro, a round-bottomed, smiley-faced, retro-styled car that you might be forgiven for thinking came out of Italy circa 1959, is wearing a T-shirt that reads 'Art is a dirty job, but somebody's got to do it'. Mick Brownfield is an illustrator. At his Richmond home, he keeps a collection of tin toys in a display case. It is important to him that his car is well-designed, characterful, and functional, too. The Figaro - a car that looks old but has none of the problems of rickety carburettors, patches of rust or condensation on the windows - fits the bill perfectly. And on the rare occasion he passes another Figaro on the road, he blinks his lights and you'd swear they winked at each other.

In the case of Deborah Davis, it really is a lifestyle thing. Dressed in pair of vintage Lee denim dungarees, kitsch flip-flops and pigtails, she is every bit the 50s rockabilly chick. She works at the vintage clothing shop Blackout II, in Covent Garden, and is as excited about a new shipment of box-fresh 50s shoes from America as she is about her two-tone yellow-and-cream 1957 Nash Metropolitan. She and her boyfriend have a stall selling 40s and 50s clothing at weekends at various car rallies and events. It wouldn't really be quite the same if she pulled up in a Ford Fiesta.

While a car can be a fashion accessory, it can also be a way of life. The most hardcore and impenetrable of car style tribes is that of the hot rods. They start them young, too. Children of hot rodders pedal about in miniature versions of their parents' cars. They're known as Hot Tots. The whole point here seems to be to make your car the lowest, baddest, meanest, widest, and kitschest possible. At hot rod rallies, you can buy car stickers that read 'Satan' and 'This is not an abandoned vehicle'. Cars are sawn, chopped, repainted, pin-striped and customised beyond all legal limits. These are the punk anarchists of the car world.

Dean Micetich, the grease-haired guitarist in the psycho-surf band Magnum 500, and a fashion and textiles student at Central Saint Martin's, couldn't imagine life any other way. His hand-painted black hot rod, built from parts shipped over from America, is, in his own words, 'a heap of shit'. It doesn't have any glass in it - no windscreen, no windows. It doesn't even have a roof. And the gear stick is topped off with the head of a Tiki god. Micetich has grown up with 50s cars and music. He's living the life; the car he drives is as important as the air he breathes. And the air reeks of petrol.

fields.headline: Rock and Rollers
fields.standfirst: To jump-start our celebration of car culture, we look at the connection between sex, wheels and rock'n'roll, and why no self-respecting British pop star would be seen without a Rolls-Royce - except Jarvis
fields.trailText: To jump-start our celebration of car culture, we look at the connection between sex, wheels and rock'n'roll, and why no self-respecting British pop star would be seen without a Rolls-Royce - except Jarvis.
fields.body:
Ridin' along in my automobile
My baby beside me at the wheel
I stole a kiss at the turn of a mile
My curiosity runnin' wild
Cruisin' and playin' the radio
With no particular place to go

C 'mon everybody. Sex, fast cars and rock'n'roll. What else do you want, that is you, me and Chuck Berry? The mortgage? Forget that. What else? Pension fund. Yeah yeah. A weekend cottage in Smartshire. Not listening. A Volvo estate. Zzzz... Let's face it, the upbeat images on these pages of hep-cats and rock stars a-cruisin'n'a-playin' hicksville country somewhere between the Rockies and the Appalachians in a time forever 1957 - give or take 10 years- are as far removed from the lifestyle of Sunday-supplement-reading British middle classes as Waco is from Welwyn Garden City.

And yet, there must have been one inter-stice on the school run where you've imagined yourself in a '55 Corvette or a '57 Belair or any big-finned, chrome-laden Cadillac? Snicking the Hurst into top and fusing the loud pedal to the floor, unleashing the horses from a Hemi-headed 350-incher and racing in the street. Stopping for a pre-McDondald's burger at, say, the 66 Diner, Albuquerque. Inching past a high-rolling XK-E on Dead Man's Curve... All these images, reel and rock somewhere in the mental cul-de-sacs if not the cranial interstate freeways of anyone brought up in the age of rock'n'roll, spawned according to most but not all music authorities, in Sun Studio, 706 Union Avenue, Memphis, Tennessee one day in 1954 when the 19-year-old Elvis Presley cut 'That's Alright Mama' for Sam Phillips, the legendary producer who said, 'I never heard a car song I don't like.'

Back in '51, Phillips had produced Jackie Brenston singing 'Rocket 88'. A homage to the brawny Oldsmobile of the same name, 'Rocket 88' was just a chromed fender short of rock'n'roll.

The first thing Elvis did when he made it biggish was to buy a car (not an Olds or a Caddie, but a humble Ford) which he drove down to Tupelo, his Mississippi birthplace, to choff cheeseburgers and deep-fried peanut butter and banana sandwiches at Johnnie's Drive-In at 908E Main Street. When Elvis made it really BIG ('Heartbreak Hotel', number one, 1956) he bought the first of what were to be more than 100 Cadillacs (pink and white, the first one). These mobile gin-palaces changed their look every single year, sprouting ever more deliciously redundant chrome-plating and fins. Every burgeoning rock'n'roll star just had to have one and not just because this is what poor country boys who made it did - buy a big car - but it's what rock'n'roll was and still is about. Just as jazz blew to the rhythm of highballin' express trains and the blues echoed the mournful trail of freight trains whistlin' their way between the cotton-picking poverty of the Mississippi Delta and the promise of a prosperous Chicago to the far north, so rock'n'roll pounded to the insistent, skipping rhythm of, at first Fords, then Chevies and Cadillacs.

As I was motivatin' over a hill
I saw Maybellene in a coupe-de-ville
A Cadillac a-rollin' on the open road
Nothing will outrun my V8 Ford,
The Cadillac doing 'bout ninety-five
She's bumper-to-bumper rollin' side-by-side

Chuck Berry again. And if his lyrics don't spell sex, cars and rock'n'roll, then none ever will. For many got-rich-quick stars, it had to be a Cadillac... for Chuck himself, Roy Orbison, Elvis, Isaac Hayes and Phil 'Wall of Sound' Spector. Rock'n'roll nearly always sounds best chattering from the speakers of a car, best of all an all-American car occupying a lot of road space.

I'm getting bugged driving up and down the same old strip
I gotta find a new place where the kids are hip

Well, the Beach Boys, whose sound was as fresh as chilled cranberry juice, liked their cars, too. Their California sound is inextricably linked with memories of coasting Sunset Boulevard in deuce-coups, whether little or 427-cubic-inch large. Brian Wilson, the genius behind the Beach Boys' inimitable summer surfing sound, says his life was changed forever one day in 1961 when as a 19-year-old he was driving his '57 Ford Fairlane around Hawthorne, his home town in California, and heard the Ronettes cooing 'Be My Baby' from the car's radio. He had to pull over to compose himself. And compose.

You sort of expect singing stars to arrive, when they do arrive, in big American cars. The limo stretched to the point of near undriveability, all chartreuse velveteen plush, smoked windows and unlimited booze.

It's nearly always big, this Yankee car. Sure, it's easy enough to imagine Simon and Garfunkel pootling along wistfully in a VW Beetle or, tragically, Marc Bolan in the passenger seat of a Mini meeting death on Barnes Common, but for most of the rest, size counted. Still does.

Got a '69 Chevy with a three-ninety-six
Fuelie head and a Hurst on the floor
She's waiting tonight down in the parking lot
Outside the 7-Eleven store

Bruce Springsteen - The Boss - is master of the road song, his ability to draw parallels between arcane details of a big car's technical specification and big feelings about love, life lived fast and sex is wilful, wonderful and second-to-none.

She's a hot-steppin Hemi with a four
on the floor
She's a road-runner engine in a '32 Ford

Best of all is if the car is big and looks like a guitar. And they do. Or did - those big, mean mothers of all-American automobilia. Elvis's first Cadillac shared something of the same aesthetic as a semi-acoustic Gretsch. A Chevy Belair hints at a Beale Street Gibson. By the same tollbooth token, a '55 Corvette is a Fender Stratocaster, a shark- like '64 T-Bird, a Rickenbacker. Well, maybe. The point is that the cars, the guitars, the songs, the bass-and-drum beat of rock music go together like Lennon and McCartney.

Baby, you can drive my car
Guess I'm gonna be a star

So, what happened when rock'n'roll made it via Radio Luxemburg and transatlantic ships berthing at Liverpool's Pier Head? Think late 50s and British cars, and what springs to mind? A lumbering of stately Austins and Wolseleys, a voluminous skirt of Rovers and Armstrong-Siddeleys, and sports cars that were only slightly less comfortable than a Beano fakir's bed of nails. Smoky, utilitarian, kitchen-sink, monochrome Britain was much more than a LP's width from Memphis, so much further than 24 hours from Tulsa. It was never really a place to cruise and play the radio, and where on those twisting roads before the arrival of the M1 in 1959 could anyone drive a big American car?

But rock'n'roll stars, until John Lennon made driving a Mini hip, needed a big car whatever the state of the roads. Lennon, in fact, drove (badly) at one point one of the biggest cars ever made, a 1970 Mercedes-Benz 600 Pullman, the same year he recorded 'Imagine'.

' Imagine no possessions. I wonder if you can.' No possessions, that is, save for a seven-seat limo with a 250bhp V8 guzzling gas faster than Pinky and Perky singing 'Awopbopaloobopalopbamboom'. This grosser-Merc was up for sale in Stuttgart this summer. George Harrison was its second owner.

The further one travels
The less one knows
The less one really knows...

George sang this on the B-side of 'Lady Madonna' in 1968. How many miles, I wonder, did he rack up in this Tirpitz-sized, autobahn-stürming mechanical behemoth? For big British stars, though, there was really only one car, despite the diverting allure of Aston Martins and E-Type Jags, the only British car for big stars was, of course, the Rolls-Royce. Strange, really, because these baroque motor-carriages from Crewe were more the stuff of Sir Edward Elgar than reformed Teddy Boys in collarless Pierre Cardin suits singing slushy, catchy love songs for the benefit of the Queen Mum at the Royal Variety Performance - and she probably arrived by Rolls-Royce, too. Rollers never rocked like an Oldsmobile 88 or '59 Cadillac Fleetwood Special, but they were beloved by everyone with a song in his heart and the charts who came from a British valley, 'burb or inner city. Tom Jones had one. Engelbert Humperdinck had one. Even John Lennon had one, a Phantom V, painted in a psychedelic design that had more floral swirls than Colefax & Fowler wallpaper. Keith Moon had his chauffeur drive his Rolls around central London one time with the maniacal Who drummer squatting naked on the roof.

Moon was an inspiration to British punks who spat, snarled and posed defiantly at the wheels of their cars with their cockatoo quiffs and guitars. The Clash sang raucously about the Westway. The Jam sang, ' London traffic going nowhere. London traffic polluting the air .' But they all loved cars. The Cortinas even named themselves after everyman's Ford, a kind of celebration and two-fingers up at middle England at one and the same time.

Trust the British to undermine the whole rock'n'roll-cars-sex thing with understatement and irony.

For the Americans, power and the open road has been what's it's all about: a sense of freedom, material, emotional, sexual. Getting to the top. And in the case of so many road-casualty stars, from the peerless alcoholic country balladeer Hank Williams to the rap artist Notorious BIG, who died in a hail of bullets in Los Angeles riding in a GMC Suburban, helter-skeltering down to the bottom. But a GMC Suburban? Now, that just ain't rock'n'roll.

fields.headline: Magic roundabouts
fields.standfirst: The tale of the circular junction begins in Paris... and ends, of course, in Milton Keynes. Roundabout hub of the world, it boasts 300 of its own. Andrew Martin takes a turn
fields.trailText: The tale of the circular junction begins in Paris... and ends, of course, in Milton Keynes. Roundabout hub of the world, it boasts 300 of its own. Andrew Martin takes a turn.
fields.body:
It was while driving through Milton Keynes in a minicab earlier this year that I first became interested in roundabouts. As we progressed from one side of the city to another, I was aware (a) that I was spending half the journey being hurled from one side of the car to the other and (b) that my minicab driver was becoming increasingly tense. These two factors were not unrelated.

A couple of weeks later, I was watching Ken Dodd at the Empire Theatre, Sunderland. 'Coming to the theatre tonight,' he said, 'I've driven around that many roundabouts that I unscrewed the hubcaps off the wheels of me car.' There are quite a lot of roundabouts near Sunderland, as it happens, but then again there are a lot of them everywhere in this country, and I suspect that this joke of Dodd's has been told in many theatres.

I called the Transport Research Lab in Crowthorne, Berkshire, and was put through to a roads expert called John Pierce, who told me that roundabouts are 'around about a hundred years old' (at which point I began to think he must have the damn things on the brain), and that there are more of them here and around the world than ever before, thanks to Britain's promotion of this type of junction. Mr Pierce then referred me to a book called The Design of Roundabouts, by Mike Brown.

This is a formidable work, stuffed with sentences such as: 'The saturated capacity results of entry and circulating flow Qk and Qz were plotted and a regression line fitted giving the entry/circulating relationship, see Fig 4.3.' Much of the book is given over to mathematical formulae representing car-approach speeds, rates of deflection, etc - all of which put to shame the north of England traffic manager who frankly told me, under the protection of anonymity, that the roundabouts in his town were sometimes designed 'by drawing around the bottom of a coffee mug'. But if you persist with the book, a fascinating - or at least fairly interesting tale - emerges.

The story of roundabouts begins with Haussmann's rebuilding of Paris under Napoleon III. He introduced a number of what Mike Brown cautiously describes as 'circular places', such as the one around the Arc de Triomphe (now the Place Charles de Gaulle). These were not roundabouts in the full Milton Keynes sense of the word, because traffic moved around them in all directions in a completely chaotic manner. The idea of getting all the traffic moving in the same direction around a circular place - no great brainwave, we might think today - is credited to a Frenchman called Eugene Henard. The system was employed around the Arc de Triomphe in 1907, and developers of the English garden city of Letchworth went to see it in action, subsequently creating Britain's first roundabout, which was built at a six-road junction in Letchworth called Sollershot Circus.

By 1925, there were gyratory systems at Parliament Square, Hyde Park Corner and Marble Arch, among others. Although all traffic moved in one direction on these, there was no requirement that you give way to the right, only a recommendation that you do so, which was regarded as patronising and un-British in its authoritarianism.

With the growth in car numbers, however, roundabouts tended to become 'locked' - a log jam would occur wherein no one could move because of everyone else. There's a picture of a locked roundabout in Mike Brown's book, and very forlorn it looks - you can't imagine how it could become unlocked except by a crane coming along and removing a few cars. Today, of course, the photograph would include scenes of people hitting each other, but we were a more civilised nation in the 50s.

The problem of locking led to 'give way to the right' becoming mandatory in 1966, and one can imagine the thunderous condemnation in the Daily Express - but we soon became so keen on roundabouts that the mini-roundabout was also developed for areas where space was limited. (When does a roundabout become mini, you might ask. When it's less than four metres in diameter.) In the late 60s, and 70s, the Transport Research Laboratory conducted a series of boring but important investigations into traffic flow around roundabouts, with the result that the British became the leading experts in the field, and the world's main proponents of roundabouts.

As I look at the mini-roundabout near my house, I wonder why. There seems to be a near-miss, with accompanying swearing, every few minutes. It appears that people do not understand the 'give way to the right' rule, or, if they do understand it they don't agree with it. My north of England traffic manager admits, 'You're not really sure if people are going to give way, so you go around a roundabout quite cautiously. Somebody might pull out a bit early, you have to break, he toots his horn, you shake your fist, and everyone's happy.' If he sounds complacent, that's because roundabouts, while the source of much aggro, are by far the safest kind of junction, generating half as many accidents as traffic lights. According to John Pierce, 'If someone goes through a red light, there's going to be mayhem, but if there's a collision at a roundabout, the angle of impact means it tends to end in bent metal rather than personal injury.'

This is the message Britain is spreading, and Mike Brown allows himself a rare lyrical moment in writing that it has caused a 'renaissance' in the European roundabout. France finally saw sense in 1983, and followed our lead by instructing drivers to give way to circulating traffic, which the rest of continental Europe had been doing for some time. In America, too, roundabouts are becoming more popular, although they're still regarded as a bit prissily English over there, and the bolder flyover remains the favoured kind of junction.

The circular principle, which this country has done so much to pioneer and refine, is nowhere better enshrined than Milton Keynes, for it turns out that not only are there a hell of a lot of roundabouts in Milton Keynes, there are in fact more there than in any other town. 'Well_' says a press officer for the town, 'at least in terms of per head of population. We've got around 300 in all, including mini-roundabouts.'

Milton Keynes was created according to what was rather sinisterly known as a 'master plan' of 1970, a key aim of which was unrestricted traffic flow. So the town was built using a grid pattern of roads, with roundabouts at the intersections. A gloomy man at a Milton Keynes tyre suppliers called Fred the Tread told me that the roundabouts of the town are 'very unpopular'. 'Can you actually screw your hubcaps off by driving around them?' I wondered, mindful of Ken Dodd. 'No,' he said, 'but they do wear your tyres out on the inside.' Well, surely that's good for you, I suggested. 'Suppose so,' he said, but he didn't sound very pleased. Dave Lawson, senior engineer with Milton Keynes council, countered this by saying that in his experience the roundabouts of the town were 'not unpopular', adding, 'If you drive around the appropriate carriageways at the correct speed, tyre wear is not an issue.'

He told me that the major roundabouts in the town had been given names to give them a 'sense of place', I asked him to give me an example of a name, and he said, 'I can't think of any right now.' The first roundabout that I saw on re-visiting Milton Keynes was called Kingston Roundabout. There was a big sign announcing this, alongside another reading 'DSV Samson Transport', for this roundabout, like many others in the town, is sponsored by a local business.

Kingston Roundabout was heavily wooded and quite pretty, but as I passed Marina Roundabout, Hospital Roundabout and Bleak Hall Roundabout - which is named after somewhere nice that was destroyed to make way for Milton Keynes, and sponsored by somebody or something called Brian Currie - the roundabouts were beginning to get me down a bit, prefaced as they are by creepily generic signs reading 'Leisure Plaza', 'Industry', 'Shopping'. Specifically, they were making me dizzy and, as I drove off the main roads, I simply came across many smaller roundabouts. I began to think that the people of Milton Keynes must have roundabouts in their houses, roundabouts in their heads .

Roundabouts might be a great British success story, but all in all it was a great relief to get back on the M1; I wanted to go somewhere fast - ie home - and not in a roundabout way.

webTitle: On the pill and getting pregnant

fields.headline: On the pill and getting pregnant
fields.trailText: When the news came through a few months ago that the male contraceptive pill would soon be with us in all its sperm-zapping glory, the reaction was predictably scathing. Men were feckless, irresponsible goons who could never be trusted.
fields.body:
When the news came through a few months ago that the male contraceptive pill was developing nicely, and would soon be with us in all its sperm-zapping glory, the reaction was predictably scathing. Men were feckless, irresponsible goons who could never be trusted. At best, they were idiots who would never remember to take it. At worst, they were scheming opportunists who would brazenly lie to women that they were on it just to get them into bed. But enough of what men thought - what about women?

The female pill had its 40th anniversary recently, so it seems like a good time to assess just how far women have come in terms of controlling our fertility. A quick look at the facts would suggest not far enough. It would seem that, while the teenage pregnancy rate continues to soar, many women in their thirties are experiencing grave difficulty conceiving. Moreover, a recent study reveals that, far from being ignorant about contraception, three out of four teenage girls fall pregnant after receiving advice about contraception. Many of these girls are actually on the Pill, but keep forgetting to take it once a day, preferring their own scientific systems - say once every Brookside episode, every day with an 'r' in it, or, that old classic, three months' supply at once, desperately washed down with Vimto the morning after the night before.

I'm not sneering at these girls - we've all been there, done that, and bought the testing kit. There can't be many women around who haven't walked the tightrope of the youthful pregnancy scare. The fact that your own somewhat abstract approach to contraception is to blame doesn't matter a fig when you get The Fear. That panicky stillness as you try to discern whether a twinge is just a twinge or a menstrual cramp. The mournful gazing at tampon dispensers: how they mock you! The surreal huddling together with friends who all solemnly promise to babysit forever and ever, but, first things first, could you lend them your lip gloss? Then, relief, euphoria, maybe a quick hushed lap of honour around the parental bathroom. All of a sudden, it seems rather funny. However, in 1998, 101,500 teenage girls weren't laughing.

The main problem seems to be that the average 15-year-old girl never really believes she will get pregnant. Likewise, the 35-year-old woman never really believes she won't. Indeed, many women have a tendency not to believe in their fertility as a biological reality until they're forced to. Unfortunately, evolution moves slowly, and women are forever getting caught out or left behind. Our bodies haven't caught up with the new feminine penchant for post-career motherhood. Our ovaries haven't been told to remain dormant, only exploding in a kind of gynaecological firework display when we've got the career, the house, and the man in situ. On the contrary, for many women, fertility is a simple case of feast followed by famine. So it is that girls shiver in their bedrooms, contemplating motherhood or abortion, while nurseries remain empty, as shocked thirtysomethings undergo IVF to kick- start their clapped-out ovaries.

The infertile older woman seems the worst hit by the fertility blight, simply because there's little she can do except wait, hope and spend a lot of money. However, surely a lot more could be done for young girls. Maybe we should take a leaf out of New Labour's book and try bullying them. My first feeling was that sexually active teenage girls might benefit from those twice-yearly contraception jabs - whereupon they would be forcibly 'inoculated' against pregnancy just as they are against mumps and rubella. I was quite pleased with this idea, and ready to stand for government, until a surely overexcited male colleague pointed out that this put me in the same happy ethical company as the Nazis. And so we return to the condom, which guards against STDs, and the Pill, which men can't refuse to put on. The Pill is safe these days, and said to be 99 per cent effective. The hard bit seems to be getting teenage girls to become 99 per cent effective at taking it.

Maybe we could start by trashing the long-held assumption that young females are genetically more inclined to be responsible where contraception is concerned. I wasn't when I was a teenager. Were you? Whereas men of all ages have all but admitted that they would probably be useless at remembering to take the male pill, women never seem to put forward the 'controversial' theory that young girls might be just as daft, as hormonally addled, as young boys. But they must be. Something has to explain why, despite navigating a veritable ticker parade of Family Planning leaflets from the age of 12 onwards, young girls are still getting pregnant before their time. While it's probably true that men have proven themselves to be idiots who simply can't be trusted to take a pill every day, it might be time to accept that the female track record isn't an awful lot better.

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ... bra
fields.trailText: ... bra
fields.byline: Serena Rees, co-owner of Agent Provocateur
fields.body:
The perfect bra is sexy. There are lots of different ideas of sexy, and the perfect bra has to suit the individual. Some bras are quite frivolous, but if a woman wants to wear a crop-top bra, that's fine.

The important thing to remember is that the bra is the first layer next to the skin, so it should feel good; it should be lined with velvet or satin so it doesn't rub. It should also make you feel good and do the job in terms of support and sensuality, which might be something to do with the colour, the fabric or the trimmings - maybe rosebuds, bows or frilly lace edges. A bra should bring out the woman in you. I think it's terribly sad when women wear those minimiser bras because it means that they're not enjoying their femininity.

People should also bear in mind that foundation underwear isn't just for grannies and that the idea behind it is to create a good shape under an outfit. And if a little bit of bra shows, then so much the better.

The perfect bra should also be well fitted. Sometimes you see women with half a boob in the bra and the other half out; people really do need to be shown how to wear them properly.

Another golden rule when bra-buying is to go for the best quality you can afford.

As far as taking it off is concerned, I don't think front-tie bras lend enough support. The perfect bra should just unclip at the back. Women have learned how to do it, and men are getting quite good at it as well.

fields.headline: Go see..
fields.standfirst: ... Jah Wobble
fields.trailText: ... Jah Wobble
fields.body:
Jah Wobble's just getting out of the bath. I wonder if I shouldn't call him back later: 'Nah, mate,' he says, in his gloriously throaty East End rasp. 'We're all multi-taskers now, aren't we?'

None more so than Wobble himself. The former best mate of Sid Vicious, bass virtuoso with Public Image Ltd and collaborator with Brian Eno and Primal Scream, among others, is now invading the hallowed halls of the British Library to present a show based on his most recent album, The Inspiration of William Blake - in which he set some of Blake's poems to his trademark hallucinatory soundscapes - as part of the British Library's Thousand Years of English Literature celebrations.

It'll be slightly more than a gig: there'll be visuals, plus an onstage printing press, ensuring that everyone who attends will go home with an exclusive Blake engraving - but Wobble rejects the Library's use of the word 'workshop' to describe the event: 'That conjures up images of people in raffia tops talking gender studies. We just want people to come in and close their eyes while we conjure up the spirit of Blake.'

How did Wobble hook up with the artist/poet/mystic/ romantic/revolutionary, author of 'Tyger Tyger' and 'Jerusalem', illustrator of the biblical apocalypse, the 19th century's own multi-tasker? 'I think Blake found me,' he says. 'People started telling me about him, and I really responded to the dark luminosity, not just in his paintings, but throughout his work.'

Wobble is also taken with the way that Blake made little distinction between the conscious and the unconscious - 'As a musician, you're playing the two off all the time' - and is quick to reclaim him from patchouli-scented Pre-Raphaelite groupies: 'Blake was very hard-working and rigorous, not just some dippy romantic. He'd have told those hippies to go off and get jobs.' Good to see that Wobble's punk roots are still gloriously intact 30 years down the line.

Jah Wobble will be playing the British Library Auditorium on 29 August at 7pm. Tickets are £7.50, concessions £6. Call the British Library on 020 7412 7332 or email them at boxoffice@bl.uk

webTitle: Life's not a gas for customers caught between suppliers

fields.headline: Life's not a gas for customers caught between suppliers
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I pay for my gas by monthly direct debit to Eastern Energy and was surprised to receive a final bill earlier this month. Eastern Energy said it was because I had changed my supplier to Norweb Energi. This is categorically not the case but Eastern said that, if Norweb had become my supplier incorrectly, Norweb was responsible for transferring me back.

As I have not signed any gas supply contract with Norweb, I assume it cannot charge me for the gas it supplies, and presumably Eastern cannot charge me either as my contract ended with the final gas account.

I am baffled about how my gas supplier can change without my knowledge, but, from talking to these two companies, I gained the impression that this may not be an uncommon problem.
SC, South Molton

Norweb confirms that erroneous transfers happen frequently. Switches from one gas provider to another take place through Transco where, if an account number is mistyped, the wrong customer is moved to a different supplier. But Norweb admits that Transco is not to blame on this occasion. Rather, its own staff typed in your meter reference number when they should have been transferring someone else, probably with the same surname.

It then assumed you were still getting your gas from British Gas and tried to send you back there, which confused British Gas. This has all happened within the 28-day cooling-off period, so you never stopped being an Eastern customer and Eastern will charge for the gas you have used in that period. If the confusion had lasted longer and you had lost money through Norweb's mistake, the company confirms that it would make good its error.

Woolwich windfall: Perpetual problem

My Woolwich windfall shares are held within Perpetual Pep and I do not receive any communications from Woolwich. With the proposed takeover by Barclays Bank, there will soon be important documents from Woolwich to its shareholders on significant issues. I would like to receive and study all such communications to decide my options about accepting shares or cash and the like.
DN, West Kilbride

Shares in all Peps and Isas are held in nominee accounts, which is why you do not receive anything directly from the Woolwich. When details of the offer are known, Perpetual will send you a synopsis and, if there is a choice between cash and shares, will ask which you want. If there is no choice, it will simply send new documents. You can ask Perpetual to send you the full takeover pack but it might charge £20 plus VAT.

Investors who kept their Woolwich shares in the Woolwich Pep will automatically receive the full offer pack.

Shares muddle: Halifax hassle

I have tried to place my wife's name on my Halifax shares so that she will inherit without hassle on my demise. I assumed this would be a simple task but Halifax sent back the transfer form asking me to fill in an exemption code and saying I should contact the Inland Revenue Stamp Office for help. I visited the Stamp Office in Newcastle but they said they were not allowed to give advice and I should not have been sent there, although they pointed out that the form had been completed incorrectly. I am now mesmerised. Please could you jolly the Halifax along?
BC, Whitley Bay

There must have been some misunderstanding because the Stamp Office staff are the people to advise you.

The Halifax is sending you new forms to fill out, and the head of shareholder services says he will personally make sure the shares are transferred. You still need to find the right code but, instead of making the journey to Newcastle, telephone the Stamp Office's central helpline on local-rate number 0845 6030135. They will run through a list of questions to find the right category.

Corporate bonds: Worth the risk?

My National Savings Pensioners Guaranteed Income Bonds mature in September. The rate paid now is less than I have been getting, and my inclination is to invest elsewhere. I am wary of the stock market, and want an investment that is relatively safe but which pays a better monthly income than Pensioners Bonds.

Can you suggest something?
GH, Bradford on Avon

No investment is safer than National Savings, which is why its Pensioner Bond rates (5.75 per cent fixed for five years) are comparatively low.

With £5,000 in a bank or building society monthly-interest account, you can earn 6.78 per cent with Abbey National eSaver or 6.36 per cent with its Direct Saver; 6.7 per cent with Northern Rock Direct Tracker 90; 6.59 per cent with Bristol & West Easy Life 30.

They are all taxable but mini cash Isas are tax-free. Smile pays 7.25 per cent on the internet and a few pay 7 per cent but some have penalties on withdrawals. A riskier option are corporate bond funds which are unit trusts where, as well as earning interest, your capital changes in value.

You might end up with more capital or less and some are riskier than others. A safer corporate bond fund pays around 6 per cent (tax free in an Isa); riskier ones pay more than 8 per cent.

Take guidance from a financial adviser who knows the difference between individual corporate bonds before investing in one.

Mortgage query: Must-have cover?

I want to buy a property, for which I will require a mortgage. As I am a German national (but resident in the UK) and already have life insurance in Germany, I am looking for a lender who will not require me to take out further life insurance in the UK.

My bank, HSBC, has given me a quotation but will not recognise my German life insurance. For ethical reasons, I prefer a mutual society.
AK, Aylesbury

HSBC says it is confused because life insurance is not compulsory with its mortgages. Any UK resident or EU national can apply for an HSBC loan. Its only warning is that, if you rely on life insurance in a foreign currency to repay your home loan, exchange rates might fall, leaving insufficient money to repay the loan.

Few lenders demand life insurance these days so you can apply wherever you choose. All building societies are mutuals and the largest include Britannia, Chelsea, Nationwide and Yorkshire. Local societies are the Buckinghamshire and Chesham.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

What's the catch?

Be Free Promotions, or B3 as it also styles itself, sent a leaflet to a reader, saying: 'Thank you for recently taking the time to take part in a survey. You have been selected to receive one of the fabulous free gifts shown below.'

These were a three-day European cruise with mobile phone thrown in, a pay-a-you-go mobile, a personal CD player and a £10 Marks & Spencer voucher.

The reader phoned to claim her prize. She was informed she had won the cruise and phone.

She says: 'After a lengthy description of the cruise and of the telephone, I asked what I had to do next. It emerged that I had to sign up to the Orange telephone network in order to claim the prize. I was then asked whether I wanted to claim it or not.

'As I could not claim the cruise without being tied to a telephone I did not want, I had to turn it down.'

The reader wondered how many people had won prizes that were not linked to Orange's network.

B3, a promotions administrator that works with mobile phone distributor Ten Communications, says 'some' prizes are given without strings - because the law requires this. Most callers are offered the cruise if they sign up to Orange. B3 refuses to reveal the exact numbers involved, calling this market-sensitive information.

It claims its line charges for the Orange service are the same as if clients go directly to the company.

 Seen a mailshot or advertisement that looks too good to be true? Write to: What's the Catch, Observer Business Section, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

Eastern Energy said it was because I had changed my supplier to Norweb Energi. This is categorically not the case but Eastern said that, if Norweb had become my supplier incorrectly, Norweb was responsible for transferring me back. As I have not signed any gas supply contract with Norweb, I assume it cannot charge me for the gas it supplies, and presumably Eastern cannot charge me either as my contract ended with the final gas account. fields.headline: A new life for leaseholders
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott  looks at  the reforms aimed at improving the lot of the 2 million people in thrall to their landlords
fields.trailText: Maria Scott looks at the reforms aimed at improving the lot of the 2 million people in thrall to their landlords.
fields.body:
Anyone who has 'owned' a leasehold flat and dealt with an unscrupulous or incompetent landlord will have found that this can be a short route to near-madness.

Last week the Government announced its Commonhold and Leasehold Reform Bill, whose proposals aim to help the 2 million people living in leasehold flats and houses. But will they work?

First, the problem. Flat dwellers do not own the right to live in their homes forever. This stays with a landlord, or freeholder, and the building is often managed by a third party.

The Government-backed Leasehold Advisory Service (LAS) receives 16,000 calls a year. Among the most common issues are:

 Freeholders who do not carry out repairs.

 Exorbitant repair and service charges. Failure to pay them can put at risk an owner's right to their home.

 Shoddy repairs and maintenance.

 Problems with buildings insurance. Freeholders set themselves up as 'brokers' to receive commission on the premiums and take a discount which is not passed on to the leaseholders.

Often lenders will refuse to advance mortgages on flats with leases that still have a lifetime - up to 80 years - to run.

 Red tape facing those buying freeholds from landlords. Two thirds of the flat owners in a block must agree. Half of the participating leaseholders must have lived in their flats as their main, or only, home for the last year, or periods totalling three years in the last 10. Peter Hayler, LAS chief executive, says this process is 'slow and cumbersome'.

 Criticisms of the length of time tribunals take to settle disputes over service charges and extending or buying freeholds. Sly landlords and their solicitors know how to milk the system.

The Government aims to solve the problems by:

 Allowing flat dwellers to take control of the management of their buildings as long as half of them agree.

 Letting leaseholders buy their freeholds if half of them want to. There will be no requirement for those voting in favour to have lived in the properties for a certain period.

It will be easier for flats in blocks that are part-commercial, part-residential to buy their freehold.

 Simplifying the complicated mechanism for valuing freeholds and extensions to leases.

 Introducing a new form of ownership, called commonhold. Leaseholders can convert to commonhold, but only if 100 per cent of those in a property, and the landlord, agree. Developers on new blocks can choose commonhold or leasehold.

But Joan South of the Leasehold Enfranchisement Association is unhappy about the planned reforms. She called them 'a disgrace' because they fail to abolish leasehold altogether.

And the measure that would give flat owners the right to manage their properties will be ineffective because the landlord must remain involved, Smith said.

'In most blocks where people want the right to manage, the relationship would have broken down already. It will end in endless litigation.'

Another campaigner, who asked not to be named because of a legal dispute he is having with his freeholder, described the proposals as 'absolutely inadequate'.

The LAS's Hayler, who has been involved in a working party assisting with drafting the Bill, said the campaigners' demands are unrealistic. Unless the Government put up money to buy out every landlord's freehold, it would be impossible to abolish this form of tenure overnight.

However, he identified some weaknesses. It would have been preferable to outlaw leasehold ownership in new blocks. Hayler would like to have seen statutory regulation for managers of flats.

David Hewett of the Association of Residential Managing Agents agrees, although he is generally positive about the proposals. Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy of the National Association of Estate Agents believes the changes would enhance the saleability of flats. A solicitor who acts for developers of new blocks agrees.

With so many members of the property 'establishment' lined up in favour of the Bill, there must be a suspicion that the landlords have won again. As long as leaseholders feel compelled, out of dissatisfaction with the way their homes are being cared for, to confront freeholders there is potential for conflict.

Campaigners can be forgiven for fearing that landlords will prove themselves adept at flouting the new legislation.

But it is not just landlords that flat owners have to fear. As they obtain increased powers to manage their properties they also take on heavier responsibilities. Many a flat owner is familiar with the difficulties of obtaining agreement among fellow residents to buy out freeholds and have repairs done.

Hayler accepted that this is a problem, and will remain so. In other countries where the commonhold system is well established, co-owners are much more willing to attend meetings and participate in decision-making.

In the US there are even special management courses for commonhold managers.

Last week's Bill skews the balance of power a little further in favour of flat dwellers in England and Wales (leasehold does not exist in sensible Scotland). But it will take time to become effective. Meanwhile, buying a flat will require vigilance about how the building is run, and by whom.

The Bill can be seen at www.open.gov.uk/lcd

fields.headline: A Soldier's Song of fighting and successful writing
fields.standfirst: But don't mention finances to Ken Lukowiak, Sarah Macaulay's former boyfriend, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: But don't mention finances to Ken Lukowiak, Sarah Macaulay's former boyfriend, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Ken Lukowiak remembers the day in 1982 when he saw a fellow Paratrooper bent double and laughing almost hysterically as he opened a letter from Access. It was threatening legal proceedings for the non-payment of a bill.

But to the soldiers in 2 Para in the Falklands Islands, fighting their way through Goose Green and Wireless Ridge, the letter could hardly have seemed more ridiculous. 'Friends had just been killed,' says Lukowiak, who wrote this story in his first book, A Soldier's Song , 'and we were wondering if we would get killed tomorrow. In war, you just don't have the time for bills and money. It just doesn't enter your head.'

Lukowiak, 41, who became the partner of Sarah Macaulay, now married to Chancellor Gordon Brown, has just published his second book, Marijuana Time, which talks about the end of his army career and the time he spent in prison when convicted of having 4lb of marijuana. As with the story about the Access bill, he combines humourous writing with profound sadness.

Marijuana Time is dedicated to the late Guardian writer Jill Tweedie 'in the name of love'. It was Tweedie and her husband Alan Brien who read the manuscript of A Soldier's Song when he was doing his post-prison day job as their painter and decorator. The Guardian published excerpts, and two days later he had offers from publishers. He has come a long way from the council estate where he was brought up.

But he thinks his five army years may be partly responsible for him being 'terrible' with his finances. He was well-paid and pensioned and 'didn't have to think much about money'.

'I'm one of those chaps who has to be rationed by his girlfriend, no matter how much I earn. If you send me out with £100, I'll come back with nothing.' And there is a deeper legacy.

'I've always had problems looking ahead,' he says. Doing so is potentially threatening and a waste of time for a soldier risking his life in combat. Now, however, 'maybe I've got to start saving for the future'.

With longstanding attitudes like these, however, it is not surprising that he and his friends have been astonished that his former girlfriend should have married the champion of financial prudence and saving for the future. 'To go from someone like me to Gordon Brown is kind of unbelievable,' he says. 'Friends who know me are amazed. The only thing that we've got in common is that we bite our nails.'

Yes, one cannot imagine the Chancellor using marijuana, let alone sending it to friends by a supposedly safe route in the army mail.

Since the end of the deeply affectionate but troubled two-year relationship with Macaulay in 1994, Lukowiak has lived away from London, now in Truro, and concentrated on writing. The two years living with her in London were 'fabulous', but he prefers the Cornish pace of life - and there, 'you need to earn a third of the money that you need in London'.

He is now working on his third book about his trips as a journalist to Bosnia, Rwanda and Argentina.

His life will probably never be a rags to riches story because he is unlikely to become a big convert to financial prudence. But he has escaped the bleak financial trap that threatened to stultify his creativity forever after he completed his six-month prison sentence.

He is engaged, and plans to marry his fiancée some time next year. Clearly, forward planning is starting to become possible.

 Marijuana Time is published by Orion at £9.99.
