fields.headline: Wise ways with a windfall
fields.trailText: The long-awaited payouts to Scottish Widows' policyholders from the insurer's takeover by Lloyds TSB are being posted now. More than 1.6 million people are sharing the £5.8 billion proceeds.
fields.body:
The long-awaited payouts to Scottish Widows' policyholders from the insurer's takeover by Lloyds TSB are being posted now. More than 1.6 million people are sharing the £5.8 billion proceeds. Payouts of £500 will go to 700,000 policyholders, another 100,000 will get more than £10,000 and a few will receive more than £100,000.

But where to put the money? Much depends on individual circumstances. Payment of the windfalls coincides uncomfortably with letters to 7,000 Scottish Widows policyholders warning of possible shortfalls on their endowments.

Craig Wetton of Chartwell Investments says putting the windfall towards paying off a shortfall 'wouldn't be the worst idea. It would certainly be fairly near the top of my priority list'.

James Dalby, of Bates Investment Services, says: 'Get rid of credit card debt. Create an emergency fund - a cash Isa could be ideal as most provide a decent rate of interest and you can take the cash out any time.'

If the windfall is more than £7,200 you will have to pay capital gains tax, unless you opted to take your payment in the form of a loan note, a type of bond, in which case the money can be encashed in stages. You may also have a CGT bill if your windfall is less than £7,200, but you have sold other investments during the year for a profit that takes you over the £7,200 limit. CGT on gains over the limit must be declared on next year's tax bill and paid by 31 January 2002. Craig Wetton of Chartwell Investments says a few investors are already worried about tax penalties. 'We have received several anguished calls from people saying "this is far more than I anticipated". One lady I spoke to was expecting £5,000. Lo and behold she now has £12,000.'

Wetton points out that investors may be able to offset investment losses this year against the windfalls to reduce the bill.

After perhaps a small spending spree, many of Scottish Widows' 1.62 million qualifying members will want to invest some of their cash. Kim North of IFA Calkin Pattinson says: 'For the longer term, you could top up your pension.'

North believes income funds are worth considering. 'Aberdeen Fixed Interest's Isa is giving 7.3 per cent, or there is Perpetual's monthly income Isa, which is also very competitive. If you've used up your Isa allowance, look at high-yielding unit trusts or Oeics [open-ended investment companies].' She suggests looking at Aberdeen and Perpetual.

Dalby says: 'A good collective fund would be Fidelity International. It's a good core holding either through an Isa or a standalone Oeic investment. The Fidelity International fund is also relatively low risk with a 43 per cent UK weighting, with the rest split between Europe, the US and Japan.'

Drive for cover

Motorists facing increases of up to 25 per cent in insurance premiums may take comfort from the knowledge that it could be worse.

The arrival of internet-based insurance operations is helping to maintain competition. Rebecca Hadley, of AA Insurance, believes that the internet has the potential to reduce costs in the same way as telephone technology revolutionised the market during the Nineties. Car owners should not renew their policies without checking at least two or three other companies' prices.

Insure.co.uk, backed by a large broker, Cox Insurance, is offering drivers a refund of their first year's premium provided they stay claim-free for five years.

But Philip da Silva, managing director of People's Choice, which claims to be saving people hundreds of pounds, points out that one in five people has an accident every year. 'So more than half of those people are likely to be unentitled to their refund.' People's Choice (tel: 0800 11 22 33).

Other internet sites include Egg, and Tesco, which said last week that it would not be putting its prices up by 'anything like 25 per cent'. The AA's site is at theaa.com.

A new guide, The Top 200 web sites for Personal Finance, by Christina Daniels (Kogan Page, £9.99) recommends www.autobytel.co.uk, www.norwichunion.co.uk, www.carsource.co.uk and www.carquote.co.uk.
fields.bodyText: The long-awaited payouts to Scottish Widows' policyholders from the insurer's takeover by Lloyds TSB are being posted now. More than 1.6 million people are sharing the £5.8 billion proceeds. Payouts of £500 will go to 700,000 policyholders, another 100,000 will get more than £10,000 and a few will receive more than £100,000. But where to put the money? Much depends on individual circumstances. Payment of the windfalls coincides uncomfortably with letters to 7,000 Scottish Widows policyholders warning of possible shortfalls on their endowments. Craig Wetton of Chartwell Investments says putting the windfall towards paying off a shortfall 'wouldn't be the worst idea. It would certainly be fairly near the top of my priority list'. James Dalby, of Bates Investment Services, says: 'Get rid of credit card debt. Create an emergency fund - a cash Isa could be ideal as most provide a decent rate of interest and you can take the cash out any time.' If the windfall is more than £7,200 you will have to pay capital gains tax, unless you opted to take your payment in the form of a loan note, a type of bond, in which case the money can be encashed in stages. You may also have a CGT bill if your windfall is less than £7,200, but you have sold other investments during the year for a profit that takes you over the £7,200 limit. CGT on gains over the limit must be declared on next year's tax bill and paid by 31 January 2002. Craig Wetton of Chartwell Investments says a few investors are already worried about tax penalties. 'We have received several anguished calls from people saying "this is far more than I anticipated". One lady I spoke to was expecting £5,000. Lo and behold she now has £12,000.' Wetton points out that investors may be able to offset investment losses this year against the windfalls to reduce the bill. After perhaps a small spending spree, many of Scottish Widows' 1.62 million qualifying members will want to invest some of their cash. Kim North of IFA Calkin Pattinson says: 'For the longer term, you could top up your pension.' North believes income funds are worth considering. 'Aberdeen Fixed Interest's Isa is giving 7.3 per cent, or there is Perpetual's monthly income Isa, which is also very competitive. If you've used up your Isa allowance, look at high-yielding unit trusts or Oeics [open-ended investment companies].' She suggests looking at Aberdeen and Perpetual. Dalby says: 'A good collective fund would be Fidelity International. It's a good core holding either through an Isa or a standalone Oeic investment. The Fidelity International fund is also relatively low risk with a 43 per cent UK weighting, with the rest split between Europe, the US and Japan.' Drive for cover Motorists facing increases of up to 25 per cent in insurance premiums may take comfort from the knowledge that it could be worse. The arrival of internet-based insurance operations is helping to maintain competition. Rebecca Hadley, of AA Insurance, believes that the internet has the potential to reduce costs in the same way as telephone technology revolutionised the market during the Nineties. Car owners should not renew their policies without checking at least two or three other companies' prices. Insure.co.uk, backed by a large broker, Cox Insurance, is offering drivers a refund of their first year's premium provided they stay claim-free for five years. But Philip da Silva, managing director of People's Choice, which claims to be saving people hundreds of pounds, points out that one in five people has an accident every year. 'So more than half of those people are likely to be unentitled to their refund.' People's Choice (tel: 0800 11 22 33). fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Birmingham Midshires Guaranteed Investment Account
fields.trailText: Birmingham Midshires Guaranteed Investment Account
fields.body:
Contact 01902 302832

Aim To equal the growth of the FTSE 100 over five years, up to a maximum of 100 per cent, while guaranteeing full return of capital if the index falls.

Bells & whistles The bank says this account is a 'safe bet' alternative to investing in shares and provides savers with the chance to double their money over five years, earning an annual interest rate equivalent to 14.63 per cent. It says: 'This potential return is higher than any equivalent fixed-rate bond available and beats the average return on many unit trusts.'

How it works Birmingham Midshires has agreed a swap with a third party to provide a derivatives-based link to the FTSE 100. The bank pays the third party a sum based on interest rates, and in return the third party will pay Birmingham Midshires a sum equivalent to any rise in the FTSE 100 up to a maximum increase of 100 per cent. To protect investors from sudden falls in the index, its growth will be calculated as the difference between two averages. The starting average is worked out from the FTSE's performance over three months (from 14 November 2000 to 14 February 2001), while the final average is calculated from one year's performance (from 28 October 2004 to 28 October, 2005). No withdrawals are permitted during the investment period, which ends on 11 November 2005.

Offer period This offer ends on 31 October.

Minimum £1,000, maximum £500,000.

Charges An initial fee of 2 per cent.

Tax Returns are taxed as income in the tax year 2005-2006, when the account matures.

Risk Low/medium.

Should you buy it? Jeremy Hulbert of Norwich independent financial adviser Hulbert Financial Services believes that this type of investment product is more risky than implied in the marketing literature, and he particularly dislikes the linking of this one to the FTSE 100. 'The FTSE is very reliant on the performance of a few large shares. That would worry me as an investor placing my money for five years.' He believes investors wanting a safe home for their money would be better off putting it in an ordinary high-interest account. Alick Howard of Woking-based Berry Birch & Noble says the account is suitable for investors who want share-type returns without risking their capital. However, he points out that the 14.63 per cent AER quoted is a maximum.

Points out of 10 Hulbert - 3, Howard - 6.

fields.headline: 'I can play golf now'
fields.standfirst: The man who went fishing and caught himself a post office
fields.trailText: The man who went fishing and caught himself a post office.
fields.body:
Mervyn Jones went on a fishing trip to the Scottish Borders nearly 20 years ago and stayed. At the age of 21 he had already sold one business, a record shop in Belfast, and was taking a break.

'On the first morning's fishing I caught two salmon and I didn't want to fish anymore. I bought a local newspaper and there was a post office for sale. I looked at it and ended up buying it.'

He built that business up and sold it in 1989, moving on to build up a dilapidated sub-post office in Hawick.

'Three years ago we bought the old Co-op store in the town and moved the post office in there and opened the gift side of the business.'

Mervyn says he thought the area was beautiful, but this was not the only reason that he moved. He was also looking for a new business opportunity and it was coincidence that his holiday provided the answer. He has never regretted the move. If he had stayed in Belfast he would not have been so content. 'There comes a time when you stop working for money,' he says. Now Mervyn has staff in his shop so he can take days off to play golf if he wants.

'You won't become a millionaire by running a sub- post office,' he says, but you can obtain a comfortable living. The Government pays commission to sub-postmasters for each PO transaction they carry out. The offices can also build up businesses on the side, such as news agencies, or sell gifts and souvenirs.

'Some have bakeries attached,' explains Mervyn. Anyone attracted to the idea of escaping city life to run a post office needs to be aware that at present they are under a cloud because of the uncertainty over income from the Government in future. Ministers want to pay benefits directly into benefi ciaries' and pensioners' bank accounts and this will cut income substantially; Mervyn Jones stands to see his cut by 35 per cent.

Nevertheless, he believes this is the time to buy because he feels confident that the Government will find solutions, such as developing post offices as local e-commerce centres, to replace the lost income.

Christie & Co (unrelated to the auctioneer of the same name), an agency that specialises in buying and selling village post offices, agrees. Mark Sheehan, national retail director at Christie, says: 'We think the future is pretty good. The strength of the post office is its network.' Christie & Co has post offices for sale starting at £29,500 for a leasehold property in east Kent, rising to more than £400,000. Freehold properties start at around £80,000.

webTitle: Farewell to all that, and hello Crete

fields.headline: Farewell to all that, and hello Crete
fields.standfirst: Richard Rooney found himself on his own at 48. He decided he wanted to escape grey cold Blighty for the Med
fields.trailText: Richard Rooney found himself on his own at 48. He decided he wanted to escape grey cold Blighty for the Med.
fields.body:
When Richard Rooney's elderly mother died a little over a year ago and the family house was sold he was faced with choices about what to do with his future.

Richard, 48 and single, had cared for his mother for several years before her death. One option was to stay in England 'buy a matchbox and keep working eight days a week, but never get further ahead'. The other was to move to the Mediterranean, where he has been holidaying in Greece for several years. Richard had also lived in Italy as a child when his father was in the RAF.

He feels he has researched his new home well enough to feel confident that his decision to leave England will pay off. He did not return to his Greek holiday spots to live, but chose Crete, where he had not lived before, because it was large enough to have plenty to do.

'Other islands were a bit too small.' He is determined to become integrated into Greek life and chose his home, the town of Agia Fotia, because it is not in the thick of the tourist trade. He believes that learning Greek will be 'absolutely essential'.

'The town is a Cretan working town that also allows tourists. If you want to buy a length of hosepipe you have to talk to the local shop owners. I haven't met many English people.'

Richard, who worked in a warehousing and distribution business before he left England, says he does not have to work for two or three years, but probably will so that he does not get bored. He is thinking of investing in olive trees and may work with a local English teacher who hopes to pay him to help her students with conversation. Richard says he talked to people who had moved abroad and was told about the pitfalls.

If Greece can be a financial struggle for the under-researched, those with relatively modest pensions can do well there.Barbara (who does not want to be named) moved to Crete five years ago after taking early retirement. She has a pension of about £6,000 a year, on which, she says: 'I manage very well.' She drives a second-hand car and she finds utilities inexpensive.

'Water is metered, but it's not expensive. Electricity is not expensive as long as you don't have every room air conditioned. Two or three times a week I go out with friends to eat. We avoid tourist places but the food is excellent and never costs more than £3 a head.'

Barbara says newcomers can come unstuck when renovating houses.

'With my first house I came a cropper. I had to cash in various insurance policies. I wouldn't want to say anything against Greek artisans but they do seem to think that foreigners have money trees.'

Bills can spiral out of control because estimates are set at what builders think the homeowner wants to hear, not what the job will actually cost.

fields.headline: Better late than never
fields.standfirst: Heavily in debt at age 44, Kevin Weedon  wants to clean up his finances, writes Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Heavily in debt at age 44, Kevin Weedon wants to clean up his finances, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Kevin Weedon

Age 44

Lives in Nottingham

Occupation Trainer for retail group

Earns £17,000

Mortgage None

Debts Credit card balance and store account

Investments Share save scheme and cash Isa

Pension Recently joined employer's scheme

Aims To buy a house and invest for retirement

Kevin realises that at 44 he has left it rather late to get his finances sorted, but he is now anxious to do so as fast as possible. He is particularly keen to buy a house and invest for his retirement.

On the home-buying front, however, he faces a potential problem. Not only must he save up for the deposit, but he is concerned that a debt that he is repaying may have an impact on his chances of obtaining a mortgage.

The debt saga started at the end of last year, when Kevin's credit card company claimed it had not received any repayments from him towards his £2,000 outstanding balance for the previous four months. Kevin says he thought minimum repayments were being made by direct debit from his bank account, but admits he had not been checking his bank statements.

Unfortunately, a letter that the credit card company sent warning him of the situation also went astray. In the end, the company passed his case to a credit recovery agency and Kevin is now paying off £150 a month as a result. At this rate, the debt will be cleared in full by next March.

At present, Kevin lives in rented accommodation, which costs £325 a month, but his aim is to buy a three-bedroom house. These properties are currently selling locally for about £50,000 and he hopes to have built up a 5-10 per cent deposit by next year in order to to make his purchase.

To save for this, he has set up a cash Isa with Nationwide to which he contributes £25 a month, plus any extra he has remaining in his current account at the end of the month. When he does eventually buy the property he is planning to take lodgers for the first couple of years to help out with the mortgage.

He also contributes to a share-save scheme through his company. This is due to mature in March next year. He estimates that, at current prices, the shares he will be able to purchase will be worth between £5,000 and £7,000. He wonders whether it would be better to use the money from the scheme towards his house purchase or retain the shares a bit longer. His current plans are to start another three-year share-save scheme when the first one finishes.

His other main concern is to build up his retirement savings. He has recently become a member of his employer's final salary scheme, to which he is contributing 5 per cent of his earnings.

Once he has cleared his credit card debt, he would like to save more towards his pension but he is wondering whether additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) or a stakeholder pension would be better. He says: 'What I have read about these schemes in the press so far has left me thoroughly confused.'

Adviser 1: Ray Boulger

Based on Kevin's current salary, and the fact that this may increase by the time he is ready to buy a property, mortgage affordability should not be a problem. However, damage limitation on his existing default is the most important factor.

He should pay off his credit card default as soon as possible. The longer it has been paid off before applying for a mortgage, the better chance he stands of getting a decent rate.

If he doesn't have the cash to pay the default off in full, he should consider diverting his Isa savings and even use the cash he has saved to pay off this debt. Once it has been repaid, he can then concentrate on his other debt and, after that, saving.

For advice on whether Kevin should sell the shares from his share-save scheme or not, he should approach a stockbroker or his bank. The decision will partly depend on the share price. However, it could be a useful way of generating a house deposit.

It is easy to understand Kevin's confusion regarding pensions, as there are many conflicting comments on government initiatives and some aspects of these new schemes have still to be decided.

It is probable that he will be able to pay into a stakeholder pension alongside a company pension scheme. However Kevin should not worry about which pension arrangement until next year, when he'll have the information necessary to make the choice.

 Ray Boulger is senior technical manager at John Charcol.

Adviser 2: Dan Kemp

Kevin's key objective over the short term should be to pay off his debts. There are mortgage companies that specialise in lending to clients with a poor credit history, but Kevin needs to think carefully before dealing with such a lender as he may pay far too much.

The best deals are with high street lenders, so approach these first. It may be that they will look favourably when the debt has been cleared. When choosing a mortgage, I would recommend that Kevin selects a fixed rate.

Although a discount rate or a product with a cashback can look appealing, given the extra expenditure he will have it is important that he knows exactly how much his mortgage will cost him each month. Once he has repaid his debts, he should save at the start of each month. I would suggest a system of two current accounts and one savings account. The amount Kevin decides to save should be transferred the day after he gets paid. An amount to cover his bills should be transferred to the second account. The money left in the first current account he can spend over the next month.

After he has purchased a property, his priority will be a pension. Contributions to a stakeholder pension will have the same tax advantages as those to an AVC scheme. However, a stakeholder pension can provide a tax-free cash lump sum as well as a monthly income. The stakeholder scheme is likely to provide him with greater freedom.

 Dan Kemp works for Holden Meehan. Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Ray is ill. Chon Wang has no excuse
fields.trailText: Some Voices | Shanghai Noon | Cherry Falls | Gossip
fields.body:
Some Voices (101 mins, 15) Directed by Simon Cellan Jones; starring Daniel Craig, David Morrissey, Kelly Macdonald

Shanghai Noon (110 mins, 12) Directed by Tom Dey; starring Jackie Chan, Owen Wilson, Lucy Liu

Cherry Falls (92 mins, 15) Directed by Geoffrey Wright; starring Michael Biehn, Brittany Murphy, Candy Clark, Jay Mohr

Gossip (91 mins, 15) Directed by Davis Guggenheim; starring James Marsden, Lena Headey, Norman Reedus, Kate Hudson

Adapted by Joe Penhall from his play staged at the Royal Court six years ago, Some Voices is a sensitive, unportentous film about Ray (Daniel Craig), a schizophrenic released into the community after a decade or so in a psychiatric hospital. It treats Ray's own perception of the world, as well as his close but complex relationship with his brother Pete (David Morrissey), who runs a small café in west London, and his loving friendship with Laura (Kelly Macdonald), a free-spirited Scottish woman, pregnant with the child of an abusive ex-boyfriend.

This is not a case history (the actual disorder is never named), Ray's life isn't a metaphor for the human condition or anything like that, and he's not presented as saintly or possessing a superior vision. Ray is a mass of contradictions. He wants to be trusted, but acts wilfully, often irresponsibly. He knows he's ill, but rejects the regimen of drugs that will help him retain his balance, and in a terrifying gesture he grinds up his tranquillisers and bakes them into a pizza served in his brother's restaurant.

A visual motif running through the movie is the spiral, the device through which Ray attempts to impose order on the chaotic world he experiences. It's first seen from a train as a corn circle in a field, then as a giant Catherine wheel, as a pattern drawn on a beach, and finally, when he spins out of control, as a sculpture he creates from plastic binliners in a Shepherd's Bush street.

Craig's sad, unsentimental Ray is complemented by Morrissey's concerned, frequently exasperated brother, whose own life as hard-working café owner, diligent son and rejected husband has been no bed of roses. The film's final sequence, in which the pair are reconciled as they cook an omelette together, is reminiscent of the end of Stanley Tucci's Big Night. Some Voices is accompanied by Bring Me Your Love, a short directed by Morrissey, also set in a mental hospital. This brief study in bad faith and self-deception stars Ian Hart as a journalist visiting his troubled wife. It's well worth seeing, though less impressive than Morrissey's earlier short, the historical anecdote A Secret Audience.

Every comedian from Chaplin and Keaton through Laurel and Hardy, Abbott and Costello, Bob Hope and Martin and Lewis, down to the Carry On team and Mel Brooks has made a spoof western. Now Jackie Chan, though at 46 a trifle old to respond to the injunction 'Go west, young man', has followed the trail with Shanghai Noon. It's virtually a transposition to Nevada of his last movie, Rush Hour , where he played a Hong Kong cop assisting a member of the LAPD to find the kidnapped daughter of a Chinese consul.

Here he's Chon Wang (pronounced 'John Wayne'), a member of the Imperial Guard, lowliest member of a team sent from the Forbidden City in 1881 to rescue a Chinese princess (Lucy Liu of Ally McBeal fame) whisked away to Nevada. His first act there is to frustrate a train robbery and join forces with one of the thieves, a laidback outlaw played by Robert Red ford lookalike Owen Wilson. The ramshackle plot links a succession of carefully choreographed fights, there's a comic reprise of the finale of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid , and there are patronising jokes at the expense of Native Americans of a sort we haven't heard for years. Terence Young's Red Sun (teaming Toshiro Mifune and Charles Bronson) and the TV series Kung Fu handled the idea of an Asian on the American frontier with greater dignity and more wit. The best thing about Shanghai Noon is its title.

Exactly 40 years ago this month, Hitchcock's seminal Psycho exploded on the world, and its latest grandchild, Cherry Falls, arrives as a birthday present. It's an unpleasant creature that comes knife in hand and tongue in cheek, a version of those slasher flicks, usually starring Jamie Lee Curtis, in which revenge for some depredation of 10 or 20 years back is taken on apparently innocent teenagers, usually while they're having, or have just had, sex.

The joke here is that the remorseless killer (a woman or a man in drag) is deliberately targeting virgins in the comically named Cherry Falls, Virginia. The principal of the local high school (who is one of the half-dozen or more suspects) fears that if word gets out 'we'll have a goddam fuck-fest on our hands'. It does, and 'we're talking hymen holocaust here' as one female pupil says, while her friends are preparing a 'Pop Your Cherry Party'. Australian filmmaker Geoffrey Wright directs as if swinging a cleaver, and a typical joke has a cop being cut in twain with an axe half-a-second after he's said: 'This is my post, I can't just split.' There are just two killings in Psycho. Cherry Falls has upwards of a dozen; I lost count.

In Davis Guggenheim's slick, empty, dislikeable thriller, Gossip, a trio of smart undergraduates at a New York university concoct a story about two fellow students as a class exercise (they're studying the way rumours circulate). They unleash a horrific train of events in a convoluted movie in which the emphasis is on the 'con'.

webTitle: Film of the week: There's Only One Jimmy Grimble

fields.headline: Fuss in boots
fields.standfirst: A footballing fairy tale plus social realism? Bit of an own goal
fields.trailText: There's Only One Jimmy Grimble
fields.body:
There's Only One Jimmy Grimble (110 mins, 12) Directed by John Hay; starring Robert Carlyle, Gina McKee, Ray Winstone, Lewis McKenzie

According to British cinema's rite-of-passage movies, there are three ways for the Northern male teenager to react to the brutal macho culture in which he's being reared - to be crushed by it as in Ken Loach's Kes, to flee from it as in Stephen Daldry's forthcoming Billy Elliot (aka Dancer) or to embrace it as in John Hay's directorial debut There's Only One Jimmy Grimble.

All three have similar plots, backgrounds and central characters, but it's Jimmy Grimble, a self-proclaimed 'feel-good comedy-drama', I find most depressing, as both a work of art and as a reflection of society. Jimmy (appealingly played by Lewis McKenzie) is a lonely 15-year-old living on a housing estate with his attractive single mother Donna (Gina McKee) in a somewhat underpopulated area of Manchester. He's a natural underdog who inevitably supports Manchester City and is tormented at his sink school by a gang of United-supporting bullies who'd not be out of place on the Shankill Road or marching with Hitler's Brownshirts.

Jimmy's great footballing gifts can only be indulged in private because he loses his nerve in public. To his relief comes a fairy godmother out of a story book. She's disguised, so we're initially led to think, as an old crone living in the basement of an abandoned terrace, and she's imbued with a numinous quality by Jane Lapotaire.

This bag lady gives him a pair of old football boots, supposedly the property of a long-forgotten City star, and seemingly possessed of magical properties. Jimmy first discards them on a skip, then retrieves them when the bullies steal his proper boots. Predictably he comes on as a last-minute substitute in a crucial cup game and scores a miraculous goal with a kick that flies from his own half to drop over the head of the opposing goalkeeper who's speaking on his mobile phone. Will Jimmy's boots take the team to the schoolboy final at Maine Road? Do Wolves wander in the woods?

This traditional aspect is amusing and touching. The trouble is the film can't make up its mind whether to go for a stylised social realism or to be a fairy tale, part Grimm, part Roy of the Rovers. I'm not asking for Sons and Lovers , but the characterisation is too thin, the plotting perfunctory. Key scenes are underwritten. Except for the school's P.E. teacher, a man with a secret big-league past played with his customary authority by the ubiquitous Robert Carlyle, the adults have a cartoonish simplicity.

Jimmy's mum is courted by an exploitative leather-clad biker, all swaggering narcissism, and a kindly removal man (Ray Winstone), the embodiment of caring, City-supporting decency, and she works for a slimy cab company whose manager has whisky on his breath and rape on his mind. Jimmy's weak headmaster is under the thumb of a garbage tycoon, whose son is the chief bully and the school's striker.

Children aren't fleshed out any better, with Jimmy's potentially interesting girlfriend, a pugilist with a passion for history, left undeveloped. Moreover the football matches don't carry much conviction and the most crucial goal looks off-side.

What makes Jimmy Grimble really disturbing, however, is the uncritical way it capitulates to the yob culture of today's Britain. There are lumbering gestures in the direction of character building. 'Maybe you've got to keep trying if you want something,' Jimmy's told, as well as 'Come on kid, make your own luck.' But no one is remotely interested in education and the picture celebrates the triumphalist aspect of soccer with the kids and their teacher aping the behaviour of their footballing heroes. Being signed up by a scout for Man City or United is the ultimate form of success, and in seeing this as the perfect feel-good ending, the film's makers are endorsing the same fantasies the Lottery encourages.

There is, however, a surprise in the movie. This is probably the one occasion when Winstone doesn't say: 'You're out of order.' The line goes instead to the headmaster - well it had to be there somewhere.

fields.headline: August is the cruellest month
fields.standfirst: Big Brother is so last week. That leaves big hugs on Sky One, geishas playing Twister, and Lenny Henry
fields.trailText: Once and Again | Geiko Girl | Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure
fields.body:
Once and Again Sky One

Geiko Girl BBC2

Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure BBC1

Last week was the week for which I'd been steeling myself for some time. The week when a television critic may be found pacing Beachy Head with specific, solitary intent, or wondering how best to affix the garden hose to the exhaust.

This is the nadir of summer scheduling and the point when even those summer hits we loved as recently as, ooh, seven whole days ago, are suddenly dismissed with a sneer: ' Big Brother ? So the week before last - surely you're not still watching!'

In any week other than this, spotting the name W.G. Snuffy Walden on the titles of a new show might have provoked the tiniest smile of fond recognition coupled with warm nostalgia. But this week - and this week alone - it was an event of considerable televisual magnitude.

When the name W.G. Snuffy Walden first impinged on my consciousness it was attached to the credits of thirtysomething, back in the Eighties. At that time, W.G. was an infarction-inducing in-joke between myself and my then partner: how did anybody get to have a name like a Dick Bruna character? And if they were comfortable with revealing Snuffy in a professional capacity, what on earth could the W.G. stand for?

As a kid I had a rabbit named J. Piers Grundy whose J just stood for J, so perhaps Snuffy Walden's W.G. stood only for W.G., though eventually I decided it should be Wily Grinder. Anyway, Wily's job is providing mournful, tinkly piano scores for the productions of Ed Zwick and Marshall Hershkovitz who became famous, via thirtysomething, as dramatic chroniclers of the middle- class suburban American Dream gone sour, though was there ever a time when it wasn't?

I am not embarrassed to admit that, in my twenties, thirtysomething's Hope and Michael were something approaching aspirational role models (stripped wood floors, a verandah, wash-and-go hair, cute kids...) despite (though some may say because of) the fact that, as characters, they were terminally miserable and self-obsessed. When the final episode was broadcast in the early Nineties, it was one of those invite-all-your-mates-round-for-a-pizza TV moments, and though we had a great evening, oddly I can't remember the plot.

And now it's back! Well, not thirtysomething and not Hope and Michael and their angsty chums, but a new Wily Grinder Snuffy Walden/ Zwick/ Hirshkovitz production called Once and Again . And yes, I'll repeat that - Once and Again - because you will have forgotten it already. What does it mean, precisely?

Well, what it means is that Hope and Michael's younger siblings (in spirit, if not flesh) are now grappling with challenging new thirtysomething dilemmas. They have the same wood floors and verandahs; the sun slants fetchingly through the white shutters just as it did a decade ago; but now they've traded their marriages for divorces, rickety station wagons for shiny Jeeps, careers in advertising for ones in architecture and instead of those mewling ankle-biters on the limed oak floors there are teenage kids (an academically under-achieving drop-dead gorgeous jock; an allegedly fat, plain girl, necessarily played by a thin, pretty girl wearing a baggy T-shirt) slumped over the breakfast bar.

This time around the Hope and Michael characters (she: a sort of Sandra Bullock by way of Carol Vorderman; he: Jim Carrey as if remodelled by Gepetto from a chunk of cheddar) are a pair of newly single parents playing the dating game: 'Mommy's really nervous. Mommy hasn't done this in a very long time. Can I have a bit of support, please!' Cue group hug.

The show's Unique Dramatic Selling Point is a series of docusoap-style talking head inserts, filmed in black and white, in which the lead characters confess candid emotions like 'I was amazed by my body. I wanted him so much', and 'I just don't know where I fit in my own life any more'. At one point the would-be couple were serenaded by a very, very special Wily Grinder number: Inside my skin/ There is this face/ It twists and turns/ It bleeds and eeeeuuuurrrggghhh [Well, that's what it sounded like]/ Inside my heart/ there's an empty room/ It's waiting for lightning/ It's waiting for yooaaarrgghhooooowwww...

Once and Again confuses humourless soundbite sanctimony with profundity, making thirtysomething look like Das Boot. Time, methinks, for Wily Grinder to push the Boot out by pitching for something challenging, like a Lars von Trier movie or a new theme for the Intel Pentium Processor. How the mighty are fallen, or - scary thought! - was thirtysomething also this bad all along and we just didn't notice because we were so distracted by the sun dappling on the highly polished floors?

It turns out that Arthur Golden's bestselling novel, Memoirs of a Geisha, got it all wrong. Not that you can tell underneath all that inscrutable slap, but the geishas of Kyoto are furious because, it turns out, they're not geishas at all - they're geikos. Which is why, after considerable negotiations, they finally agreed to allow a documentary camera to strip away all the mystique and set the record straight.

Unfortunately, once deprived of both mystique and a plot (an antique kimono being stolen by a rival geiko, say, or a bit of extra-curricular love interest with the MD of a vast widget-making conglomerate), life as a geiko turns out to be an interminable round of pouring tea and sake, bowing, playing the oriental version of Twister, laughing at the jokes made by the MDs of vast widget-making conglomerates and singing godawful songs. Hearing the young star of Geiko Girl, Mamehisa, tackle The dream of that night together/ Cannot be extinguished/ I am filled with the memory of it/ My emotions are deepening/ Like the white snow outside... really made you yearn for the emotional range of something by either Wily G. Snuffy Coyote or Steps.

Geiko Girl was a disappointingly dull film, not through any fault of the director, but because we now know what we really didn't want to: that far from being a highly paid wind-up erotic doll trained in the mysterious arts of pleasure giving, a career as a geisha-geiko is pretty much that of a nun with some of the perks of an airline cabin crew.

Mamehisa's parents - father an engineer, mother a life insurance salesperson - turned up for their daughter's graduation from Maiko (a trainee) to geiko ('a woman of art') but barely hid their disappointment at her chosen career. They'd probably hoped she'd grow up to be the MD of Widget International and were justifiably disappointed to discover instead a young woman with an extraordinary lack of imagination devoted to a life in which there was 'no room for innovation or artistic freedom' but ample opportunity to create 'a discreet and uninhibited environment in which men are made to feel good about themselves'.

Lenny Henry always gives a convincing impression of a man who feels pretty good about himself, but a trip across the Atlantic from Plymouth to Jamaica in a trimaran that looks like Thunderbird Six proves otherwise. After Joanna Lumley as a castaway and Ross Kemp in a tent in the Canadian wilderness, Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure is the latest in the occasional let's-send-a-celebrity-off-to-do-something-a-wee-bit-scary documentary genre, but was more revealing than the others because while Lenny couldn't sail, his partner, the buoyant and heroic Tony Bullimore - who can - still famously nearly died after capsizing in a Perfect Storm.

Last night's video diary saw our star inside the cabin 'praying for the first time since Sunday school' during a Force 8 squall he described as 'the longest 48 hours of my life', while Bullimore got on with the rough, tough and macho George Clooney stuff outside. The adventure concludes tonight and I don't think I'm giving much away by saying that, after the excitement of Part One, Part Two is scuppered by some plot twists that give far more insight into BBC management than they do the celebrity sailor's existential and elemental battles, which is a shame. Still, we can only hope the BBC continue to exploit the limitless possibilities of this genre. Who wouldn't want to watch Anthea Turner Trains as a Geiko?

Last night's video diary saw our star inside the cabin 'praying for the first time since Sunday school' during a Force 8 squall he described as 'the longest 48 hours of my life', while Bullimore got on with the rough, tough and macho George Clooney stuff outside. The adventure concludes tonight and I don't think I'm giving much away by saying that, after the excitement of Part One, Part Two is scuppered by some plot twists that give far more insight into BBC management than they do the celebrity sailor's existential and elemental battles, which is a shame. Still, we can only hope the BBC continue to exploit the limitless possibilities of this genre. Who wouldn't want to watch Anthea Turner Trains as a Geiko?

fields.headline: Putting the pose back into pictures
fields.standfirst: Action and snapshots are out. To get into the galleries you need production, parody and pastiche
fields.trailText: Knut Asdan | Hellen van Meene | Catherine Opie | Breathless! Photography and Time
fields.body:
Knut Asdan Tate Britain, London SW1 to 17 Sept

Hellen van Meene Sadie Coles HQ, London W1 to 2 Sept

Catherine Opie Photographers' Gallery, London WC2 to 24 Sept

Breathless! Photography and Time V&A, London SW1 to 17 Sept

What kind of photograph qualifies as contemporary art these days? Not the rapid snapshot, it seems. Walk the galleries, and the images you see are rehearsed, staged, digitally enhanced, as post- produced as any Hollywood movie. Some of them want to look like ads or video stills or old master art. Others want the ghostly overtones that come from using glass plates or pinhole cameras. As with painting, practically every past technique has been parodied or pastiched - there are even pseudo snapshots, like the sham-casual work of Wolfgang Tillmans, shortlisted for this year's Turner Prize. But fast-action shots, contemporary equivalents of Cartier-Bresson's masterpiece of a man leaping a puddle behind the Gare St Lazare, these rarely make it into white cube galleries.

Knut Asdan, the young Norwegian photographer, has filled a whole room of Tate Britain with massive images of high-rise apartment blocks and skyscrapers. These are hung two-deep along the walls so that they seem to imitate the grids of windows in each photograph.

Asdan works at night. The windows in his pictures are mostly dark, except for those solitary lights you see in the small hours as the city sleeps, or just before dawn when it begins to stir. In one, a rooftop party glows like an ember in the blackness. In another, the only light comes from the moon and its earthly rival, a single streetlamp intensified by Asdan's flash.

This is cinema's romantic repertoire - deserted streets, empty gas stations, lone insomniacs out there in the darkness. But Asdan wants to depict the buildings themselves as actively restless, an idea surely borrowed from Alfred Stieglitz's great photograph of the Flatiron Building in 1903. The Flatiron seems to move through the Whistlerian snowstorm, as Stieglitz said, like 'the bow of a monster steamer'. He waited for hours to freeze this perception. Asdan tries to force it with artificial lighting and low-density prints. The effect is fumbled and unconvincing.

Hellen van Meene's work is also contrived - though to a better purpose. Like many contemporary photographers, van Meene is fascinated by Vermeer. She loves the reverberating mystery of his women, motionless in their tableaux of angled silver light. One of her photographs reprises 'Girl With a Pearl Earring', reversing the pose and updating the garments. The girl's sheeny hair swathes her brow and shoulders like the headdress in the painting. But her expression suggests profound melancholy, as if she knew that her face didn't fit Vermeer any more than the matronly clothes ill-suited to her gawky physique.

Van Meene is Dutch. Her adolescent subjects are not the dime-a-dozen Lolitas of American photography but genetic descendants of the girls in northern European art. She might photograph a high-breasted Cranach Eve in her mother's bathing costume, an under-age Rubens or a snub-nosed Brueghel in a pointed hood. Her girls are listless, restive in the long school holidays, uncertain how to dispose their limbs for the camera. Misfits in their own world, they're too unsettled to understudy old masters either - a tension perfectly reproduced in the mismatch between van Meene's wary photographs and the paintings on which they draw.

Dignifying the misrepresented - that's the routine claim made for Catherine Opie's photographs, as if a full-length shot of a nude transvestite in wig and heels, coyly clutching his genitals, was likely to give you more of the soul beneath the skin. In America, where she lives, Opie's work hangs in many art museums - portraits of dominatrixes in leather masks, pierced and tattooed lesbians and other scarified bodies, including Opie's own. Her pictures are big, formal and highly Technicolored. It may be that her studio subjects assume their own positions. If not, Opie is dealing in outsize clichés.

Opie also makes detailed 'portraits' of Beverly Hills houses and miniature platinum prints of empty free ways that look, as you might expect, like Victorian travel photographs. With the exception of these delicate, faux-antique pictures, her approach is baldly conventional. The mere fact of photographing the subject seems to be an end in itself, as if, like the Dutch masters who painted women scraping carrots, she felt she was representing the overlooked. In a media thick with images of tattooed torsos and LA décor, that is just not enough any more.

The great advance of hand-held cameras with high-speed shutters - so often undervalued in contemporary art - was, of course, that they transformed the circumstances and thus the content of photography. Exposure times decreased from 40 minutes in 1839 to a fraction of a second by 1950 - the difference between the unnatural stasis of Victorian portraits and Harold Edgerton's famous shot of a milk drop exploding into a fabulous coronet.

This photograph, along with Cartier-Bresson's leaping man and many other classic snapshots - to use John Herschel's term from 1852 - are included in Breathless! Photography and Time at the V&A. The show begins with early speed-shutters, demonstrating their own ability to freeze cresting waves and ticking clocks. It concludes with contemporary photographs of light, speed and momentous human life. The images are breathtaking - as technical feats, but also as art.

webTitle: 'Beneath his skintight cords, Jarvis is a changed man...'

fields.headline: 'Beneath his skintight cords, Jarvis is a changed man...'
fields.trailText: Pulp, Edinburgh Corn Exchange
fields.body:
Pulp, Edinburgh Corn Exchange

He hasn't grown his hair out and his clothes are still more Stayin' Alive than Easy Rider, but there are definite signs that Jarvis Cocker is, at the age of 36, entering his hippie phase. Performing a one-off show prior to their headlining appearances at the Reading and Leeds festivals, Pulp sound like a very different band to the pin-sharp, acerbic social critics who became famous in the mid-Nineties. Beneath his skintight corduroys and black silk shirt open to the sternum, Jarvis Cocker is a changed man.

First of all, though, it is great to welcome him back. The vacuum left by Cocker's two-year absence from the British pop scene was so huge that we had to fool ourselves into finding Robbie Williams interesting. Cocker is not only a better showman and more intelligent chronicler of fame's twilight horrors, but he writes his own tunes and dances like Travolta rather than a football hooligan. Unfortunately, the public's love for Pulp seems to have waned since the glory days of Different Class: their last album, This Is Hardcore, was a commercial disaster, and there is a curious flatness to this comeback concert, a sense that Jarvis and his fans don't know what to expect of each other any more.

We go through the motions - chanting along to 'Common People', bouncing up and down to 'Sorted for E's and Wizz', marvelling once again at the taut perfec tion of 'Babies' - but there is a lack of real excitement in the audience, and Cocker doesn't inhabit these songs the way he used to. He still moves like a gazelle on heat, still gasps and heavy-breathes like a dirty old man with asthma, but the whole show feels weirdly anaemic, more flaccid than before.

It could be nerves, but whatever the reason, the only tracks Cocker sings with true conviction are 'The Fear' and 'Party Hard' - both taken from his nervous breakdown period - and the new ones. And the new ones are_ a little strange . It's not that Pulp have taken the Radiohead route of dispensing with choruses - if anything, the new material is more conventional, less edgy than This Is Hardcore - but that they have added guitar solos, unironic positivity and a sort of Sixties psychedelic vibe that seems utterly alien to them.

This new sensibility is most apparent on 'Sunrise', which hums dazedly along to Jarvis-filmed video footage of, um, the sun rising through the clouds. 'I Love Life' is more poppy, but still dissolves halfway through into epic guitar noodling, while 'Mini Timperly' is mid-tempo chart mush. Has Jarvis been smoking too many herbal cigarettes? Has he got religion? Has he fallen in love? Or maybe it's all tongue in cheek, and the new album - due early next year - will be as witty and pointed as ever?

'This is the sound of someone losing the plot,' Cocker sings on 'The Fear'. We must fervently hope that he isn't. Because that would mean we were stuck with Robbie Williams as our national showman. Snap out of it, Jarvis - your country needs you.

fields.headline: Urban worrier
fields.standfirst: Leigh Kenny was teased at school (red hair, black granddad) and spent time in an asylum. No wonder he's anxious
fields.trailText: Leigh Kenny was teased at school (red hair, black granddad) and spent time in an asylum. No wonder he's anxious.
fields.body:
A likeable 29-year-old with close-cropped red hair, a cautious smile and words that gush out in torrents of vivid imagery, Leigh Stephen Kenny is a bit of a worrier. We've met to talk about the album he has released under his initials LSK - a polished collection of smooth, strong songs that confidently blend reggae, soul, hip hop and rock in a way that is unmistakably urban and British, all held together by his sweet, soulful voice. I like the record a lot. Almost every critic so far has. Yet Leigh is worried. He's worried that the bad reviews will hurt even more when they come. He's worried that the record may be misunderstood. He's even worried that it may be too successful, that he'll be left with no new sadness to write about.

For underneath the seductive melodies, there are dark, jagged edges here. Songs about drugs, jealousy, racism, about failed relationships, about going to the very edge of sanity and looking into the abyss. It's written from experience, he says.

Everyone has defining moments in their childhood, memories that helped shape the way they are. Leigh tells me two of his. When he was three, he stood in his home in Kent watching his father beat his mother. She ran into the street to get away, leaving Leigh behind, and he vividly remembers his feelings of fear, of abandonment. Soon after, his dad went away, leaving his mum to bring up him and his older sister alone.

A few years later, he was playing Action Man in the garden with his friend David until David's dad came and shouted, 'Don't play with him - his mum's a nigger!' When he asked his mother what it meant, she explained that his grandfather was a black man. No one seems to know a great deal about him. His name was Donaldo. He played in Edmundo Ross's Latin-American Jazz Band. And he once said he came from Cuba.

Bringing up two children on a nurse's wage was a struggle, and Leigh was always teased at school: for his red hair, his hand-me-down clothes. The National Front was big in Kent at the time, and there were a lot of NF stickers and leaflets. He was a withdrawn child, always doodling and staring out of the window. He wet the bed for years, and it seemed like there were always social workers asking him questions. He was a failure academically, he wasn't good at sport or fighting, but he found refuge in music. He learned to break-dance, and at home his mum played the sounds which echo now in his music: Third World, Marvin Gaye, Sly and the Family Stone, Bill Withers.

Just before Leigh turned 14, his mum married a northerner and they moved to the Swinnow estate in Bramley, Yorkshire. It was a difficult time: starting a new school, talking differently from everyone else. His sister couldn't handle it. She turned 16 soon after, and went back south on her own (their difficult relationship since is charted in 'Love and Hate', a track featuring younger sister Rhianna on vocals). But Leigh slowly made friends on the estate. He went to hip hop clubs and reggae sound systems, began making black friends, meeting their families and finding that many of them had mixed blood too.

His art skills also began to find an outlet. Like many cities after the acid house boom, Leeds enjoyed a surge of creativity at the start of the Nineties. It had its own form of home-grown techno known as 'bleep', and local groups like LFO and Nightmares on Wax enjoyed national hits. Leigh's hand-painted T-shirts and jeans were in demand locally, and he drew flyers for many of the new club nights, even designing the sleeve for the Nightmares on Wax album Smoker's Delight .

Inevitably, there were drugs, which made Leigh even more sensitive and introverted. Then when his long-term girlfriend left him, his world caved in. 'I take things to heart anyway, and when you mess with drugs you open doors that shouldn't be opened,' he says. 'I just dug a hole that got deeper and deeper, and I didn't have the balls to say anything to anybody. If you're the bloke in a house, you've got to be a certain way, haven't you?'

He tried to kill himself, and ended up at the age of 22 in a psychiatric hospital. It was the patients there, he says, who pulled him back from the brink. Many had serious mental health problems, and he came to see that his own troubles were relatively minor, that being a bit messed up needn't stop him getting on with his life.

When he left hospital two months later, things moved fast. He met electronics whiz Phil Naylor in a pub, they wrote some songs together, and within a month all the major labels were showing interest. 'I'd been told I was shit all my life, and I didn't know how to handle a compliment. I'd find myself going to the toilet even though I didn't need to, just to get out of the room - I felt so anxious sitting around these people and almost being analysed again. People buying you food and giving you CDs... it just happened so quickly.'

Phil and Leigh hastily formed a band, and Bedlam Ago Go signed to Sony. Fusing hip hop and hardcore rock, their album, Estate Style Entertainment, came out in 1997, a scream of frustration and anger. When I wonder what happened to Leigh between the aggressive shout of Bedlam and the mellow whisper of LSK, he answers without hesitation. His partner, Caroline, is what happened, and their three-year-old daughter Ella. Finally, it seems, he's found a fragile happiness, and the music he is making now reflects that. 'It's more mature, I suppose. There's still some aggression. But having a kid, you learn that to get your point across, you haven't always got to shout.'

 LSK is out on 4 September

webTitle: Betrayed by the bores who run Channel 4

fields.headline: Betrayed by the bores who run Channel 4
fields.trailText: Betrayed by the bores who run Channel 4
fields.body:
When Channel 4 was set up, it was a model for a new type of television production process. All programme proposals were to come from outside companies, with a team of commissioning editors to choose the best ideas. Up to 400 new production companies were formed, believing that if their ideas were good enough they would get commissions from the new channel.

Over the last few years many of those companies, who owe their existence to the promises of Channel 4, have found that they have been betrayed. Tim Gardam, the director of programmes, has been heard to say that he is not very interested in ideas that come from outside. He wants his commissioning editors to have the ideas and select tame production companies to make them.

What is wrong with this, you might say? It seems to be harking back to the way the BBC used to work, where all ideas were originated in-house. But in the BBC people were appointed to senior programme posts because they knew something about their particular area of programming. The head of arts or music would be well informed about those topics, often actually spending his or her leisure time on them. There was no problem, then, if the ideas sometimes came from the top. Nowadays, the people who commission fact-ual programmes for Channel 4 know about nothing except television itself. There is a disdain for the intellect and a concentration on producing programmes for people with three GCSEs and an attention deficit disorder.

I used to be a documentary television producer. I went into television in the early Eighties because I was interested in the world and how it worked and wanted to tell a large audience some of the stories I found intellectually stimulating or entertaining. I decided to give up television production earlier this year, unable to find a market in Channel 4 for ideas worth producing.

Of course, even to use the word 'intellectual' in connection with television programmes might seem laughable in a Channel 4 context, the channel that brings you Big Brother and a history of the word 'fuck'. How has this situation come about? Why is it the case - as I believe - that people who read books and broadsheet newspapers are finding fewer and fewer programmes to interest them on television?

The only explanation I can offer is the nature of the people who now run the channels, people who appear to be less interested in the message than the medium. It is rather as if we no longer had writers but only people who were fascinated by pens, collecting many different types, from Biro to Rollerball, competing to devise ever more innovative pens, with little care for, or interest in, the words those pens could write.

A tiny selection of personal experiences gives just a hint of the sorry situation. I hear many similar stories from producers who don't wish to speak out since they still hope against hope for a programme commission in the future.

In 1996 I sent Channel 4 a proposal for a series, to be filmed over several years, following the design and construction of the Eden Project, a huge and important ecological and botanical research laboratory and visitor attraction soon to be opened in Cornwall. The Channel 4 commissioning editor for science rejected it. 'I feel the series has more of a plants and gardening edge than a science and technology one,' she wrote to me, and passed the proposal to the gardening department. To me this was rather like referring a major documentary on, say, GM foods or BSE to the editor of cookery programmes.

In a series I made last year about the Interna tional Space Station, I was told that I should have asked a (woman) engineer whether her children had problems when she was away on business.

During the production of a series about the design and construction of Tate Modern I was told that I couldn't use the word 'odyssey' in the narration, presumably because the channel thought the audience it was seeking would be too stupid to understand it.

In a series I made about the Boeing 777 airliner I included an interview with the chief engineer, describing his belief that, by 'working together', people and organisations could achieve more. But Channel 4 is only interested in things going wrong, so the commissioning editor leaned back in her chair and said: 'What a wanker!' With one bound, an entire philosophy of management was dismissed. (The 'wanker' is now head of Boeing's commercial airliner operation. The commissioning editor is still a commissioning editor).

The sadness of all this is twofold. First, none of this comment will surprise Channel 4 executives - this change in objective can only have happened by design. So it is clear that the channel no longer wishes to be in any sense a public service broadcaster, appealing to all levels of taste and intellect.

Secondly, once 'dumbed down', a channel will find it much more difficult to 'clever up'. Even if Michael Jackson and his colleagues do suddenly have a Damascene conversion, people like you (the average Observer reader) will have given up the habit of even considering that there might be programmes worth watching, and people like me will certainly no longer be around to produce them.

fields.headline: Have you any experience?
fields.standfirst: Jimi Hendrix died 30 years ago. When Gered Mankowitz photographed the shy guitarist for his first album cover, he little realised that the picture would become the most famous image of a rock legend
fields.trailText: Jimi Hendrix died 30 years ago. When Gered Mankowitz photographed the shy guitarist for his first album cover, he little realised that the picture would become the most famous image of a rock legend.
fields.body:
On 18 September 1970, the rock world was shaken by the news of Jimi Hendrix's death. It had been known for some months he'd been in an increasingly bad way due to the escalating amount of drugs he was using, and his recent appearance at the Isle of Wight Festival had been largely panned, but nobody was prepared for this. In a basement flat in Notting Hill his girlfriend, Monika Dannemann, woke up, couldn't rouse him and called an ambulance. Hendrix was pronounced dead upon arrival at St Mary's Hospital, Paddington. Possessed of an extraordinary musical talent that was still developing, he'd only been in Britain for four years.

His death, on 18 September 1970, stunned a business that, apart from Brian Jones's drowning in 1969, hadn't yet been hit by the relentless overdose toll of the Seventies. The anniversary will be marked next month by a flurry of reminiscences in the mainstream and music press. I was working on a music paper when it happened and had met Hendrix a few times. Contrary to his initially scary appearance - so cool, so wild, so amazingly dressed - and powerful on-stage presence (I've seen his opening chord cause a nosebleed), he was gentle, courteous (a door opener, a stand-up-when-you-entered-a-room guy) and shy.

Probably the most famous image of him is the one here, taken in calmer and more lucid times for Hendrix back in 1967. It was a photo session organised for his first album Are You Experienced , taken against a plain backdrop one lazy afternoon. Nobody, particularly the photographer Gered Mankowitz, could realise what an iconic image it would become.

The session had come about through a mixture of location and Mankowitz's growing reputation as a rock photographer. His tiny studio in Mason's Yard, just off Piccadilly, was next to one of the hippest clubs of the time, the Scotch of St James, and close to the offices of Hendrix's manager, Chas Chandler.

Says Mankowitz: 'Chas was a hard-assed Newcastle bloke, nice, straight who had been the bass player with the Animals. I'd never photographed them, but done some work with him. He told me he'd found this phenomenal guitarist who was extraordinary looking, who he reckoned was going to be huge.

'I went down to the Bag O'Nails to see him. It was a seething mass of people because word had got around: Pete Townshend, Jeff Beck, Jimmy Page and Eric Clapton were all there. And Jimi was mesmerising. I'm not sure if it was his music as much as his style - he was doing things with a guitar that had never been done before.'

In the late Sixties and early Seventies the music business was small and contained. Everybody knew each other and hung out together, so news of this remarkable new guitarist went round like wildfire. A friend, Yardbird bassist Paul Samwell-Smith, remembers a hilarious impromptu evening jamming with Hendrix as a background to some Scaffold poetry with, incredibly, Jane Asher's mother on violin. There were no VIP areas in clubs, no bouncers, no security guards. You were quite likely to run into Hendrix or Jagger buying clothes in Granny Takes a Trip, or rummaging for antique shirts and coats in Chelsea Antiques Market.

Mankowitz, 20 in 1967, in his Take Six velvet suits and perennial dark glasses was very much part of the scene. He was truly cool because he was never starstruck due to growing up surrounded by the stars that inhabited the world of his film-producer father, Wolf Mankowitz. Gered had done film stills on sets, toured America with the Rolling Stones in 1965 and photographed Marianne Faithfull.

He'd acquired his first floor studio in Mason's Yard when he was 17. Painted brown and white with orange water pipes, on the landing there was a blown-up comic image of Batman with a bubble coming out of his mouth saying: 'It's as well to remember that evil is a pretty bad thing.' It was a hip hangout. Rock stars would often call in on their way to the Scotch, smoke some dope and carry on their way.

For the Are You Experienced session Hendrix arrived with bass player Noel Redding and drummer Mitch Mitchell at around midday: nobody ever got up much before about then. They were wearing the clothes they were to be photographed in and wore them to a gig later (they weren't well off and didn't possess that many) and make-up artists, PAs and stylists were unknown commodities then.

'It was all very relaxed. I always got some food in from Fortnum and Mason round the corner, and we smoked some dope and took the pictures. It wasn't difficult to capture Jimi's image because he exuded this extraordinary power and charisma - the guy just took hold of the camera.

'People are naturally nervous in front of a camera and Jimi was no different. He didn't like it much, and he didn't smile because the whole idea of it was to appear cool and moody - we wanted to be the antithesis of the publicity photograph. The famous smoking shot was with an ordinary cigarette - you had to be really careful in those days and it would have been irresponsible to publish a picture of someone smoking a joint, although I do have a picture of Keith Richards with one.'

A couple of months later, Mankowitz did the second Hendrix studio session - an indication of how intensively he was being worked. 'I'd seen him around in clubs and he'd always pop in to the studio for a smoke on his way to the Scotch. We'd chat, gossip. I liked him a lot. He had no side to him, no hidden agenda. He was a good guy.'

Little did Mankowitz realise the value of his photographic archive which moved from studio to studio in plastic carrier bags. His father had advised him to never throw anything away, so he stowed the bags in the corner and gradually the Sixties and Seventies began to gain iconic status. Mankowitz started to exhibit the pictures of Hendrix, the Stones, Marianne, Kate Bush, Eric Clapton and many others. He organised the prints into limited editions and collectors started to pour in. He also got together with graphic designer David Costa (son of DJ Sam) and produced a series of silk screen prints from the pictures. Inevitably there is piracy. Sometimes Mankowitz is successful in reclaiming or charging for the use of his images, more often in the case of T-shirts and posters the process is too complicated. The Hendrix legacy is now big business run by his family, and there is a museum in his birthplace of Seattle.

For the older generation remembering how you heard of Hendrix's death ranks alongside Lennon and Kennedy.

'By the time he died a lot of people were accidents waiting to happen,' says Mankowitz. 'Hendrix was appallingly overworked and not cared for properly. The whole cult status thing is a madness, not an easy thing to live with and he could have gone on to do extraordinary things.'

Hendrix: The life

Born 1942 Seattle

Died 1970 London

Music: Self-taught guitarist who become one of the biggest musical influences of all time. Played Fender Stratocaster. Released four albums during his lifetime

Girlfriends: Lots. Monika Danneman in whose bed he died, committed suicide in 1996. Kathy Etchingham who lived with him when he first came to London wrote a book about him last year. His prowess was legendary and vital statistics nearly defeated the famous Plaster Casters who hadn't brought a large enough receptacle.

The legacy

The Experience Music Project is a new museum that opened this summer in Seattle, Hendrix's birthplace, largely financed by Microsoft's Paul Allen. Designed by Frank Gehry (Guggenheim, Bilbao) its shape echoes a smashed guitar. Says Gehry: 'The culture of rock 'n' roll is messy, explosive, over-the-top, good taste, bad taste, so I tried to make a building that did that.'

Sotheby's rock auction 19 September has a Hendrix jacket (estimate £18,000); concert programme (est. £2,000). Christie's auction 26 September has a handwritten set of Hendrix lyrics for Crosstown Traffic (estimate £25,000).

Online auctions of Mankowitz photographs from www.icollector.com or visit Focus Gallery, London WC1A 1LY

fields.headline: Shall we schmaltz?
fields.standfirst: Texan diva Betty Buckley will make you cry. And herself
fields.trailText: Betty Buckley
fields.body:
Betty Buckley Donmar Warehouse, London WC2 to 2 Sept

Betty Buckley comes on stage - to open the Donmar's 'Diva' season - as if into a Manhattan cocktail party for one. She is of uncertain age and certain elegance, with cropped grey hair and a marvellous sequinned garment of sea-blue, silver and green that she gathers round her like some kind of sparkly weather, some new element. She has amazing charm: it is something to do with her mixture of homeliness and glamour and the rapport she establishes with her audience.

She is quintessentially American (from Texas originally), and while she seems spontaneous, is, I am sure, rehearsed to within an inch of her life. I was sitting in the front row close enough to count the garnets hanging from her ears (a change of costume in the second half to black and dark red); close enough to study her with an almost anthropological curiosity.

Buckley is a Broadway star (best known here as Norma Desmond in Andrew Lloyd Webber's Sunset Boulevard). Her own show ought to carry the message: if music is the fast food of love, play on. This is not for people who dislike instant surrender to emotion. It is a sauna of schmaltz to which some fans return night after night. I tried to steel myself against her songs (some of which I regard as bilge) but was like someone losing their handhold, about to fall off a cliff. Buckley could make you think an unroad worthy car was a brand new Mercedes just by smiling.

She sells the lyrics of country music singer-songwriter Mary Chapin Carpenter as a 'cut above divorce in the trailer park'. She sings Carpenter's 'Come On, Come On' - a song about loss - beautifully. Is the song any good? Maybe. She lightly wiped the tears away from her own face during this number. (How did she get away with that? I wondered, in the cool retrospect of morning.)

Her band look as though they never sleep: a rumpled trio of men. Kenny Werner is her tumultuously accomplished pianist. He sways to his own music like a rapt blancmange. Jamey Haddad, the drummer and virtuoso percussionist, shows what he can do in a solo introduction to Stephen Schwartz's soaringly sentimental ballad 'Meadowlark'. His hands are like trapped birds banging against his tropical tambourine. Buckley's hands also dip and glide - she has many songs about flight; she keeps a musical aviary.

She was, mysteriously, showcasing the work of a young American composer called Ricky Ian Gordon. His settings of Dorothy Parker and Emily Dickinson were especially dismal. Dickinson, one of the most sublime poets that ever lived, was at her winsome worst, revealed to be a duff lyricist, while Dorothy Parker's wit seemed to have come out in the wash. Only Tennessee Williams survived, but he was adapted by Buckley herself. The best new song was 'Stars and the Moon' by Jason Robert Brown, a cautionary tale about seeking celebrity at the expense of soul. Not a lesson that Betty Buckley needs to learn.
