fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: Why didn't friends buy me wedding presents?
fields.trailText: Why didn't friends buy me wedding presents?
fields.body:
My husband and I had a beautiful wedding four weeks ago. We received more than 100 gifts. However, there are about six close friends who apparently have not sent us presents. Obviously we are very hurt that they did not acknowledge our marriage with a gift and I would like to let them know how I feel. Not for reasons of acquisitiveness, but as a matter of principle: the wedding was an expensive affair, undertaken as much for our friends' enjoyment as our own. My husband thinks that I should keep quiet and not judge. Who is right?
J.K. of Luton

I would be presumptuous if I believed that my views are the 'right' ones. The essence of moral dilemmas is that even after clearing away the deadwood of hypocrisy and faulty logic, there is still not a clear-cut solution.

Your little piece of insincerity is that you set up this expensive ceremony as much for friends' gratification as your own. Now come on. Your wedding was your gift to yourselves; and the inviting of friends who are expected to wear new clothes, come in a spirit of happiness, lavish affection on you and make complimentary speeches is a harmless form of self-deception. You bribe your friends with lavish hospitality to come and play their part. The bargain is completed by the present.

Arguably, by the time a guest has bought an expensive outfit and a gift, he/she will have paid out more than the cost to you per head. Such calculations do go on in people's minds.

So what can we say of those six good friends who did not come up to scratch? I'll suggest a few possible reasons. If any of them are single they may be oblivious of the custom. Present-giving on all such occasions is mainly car ried out by women, and a widower or male divorcee has probably never had to think about this before.

If this is a second marriage people may not have felt gifts were required. Presumably, you have all the household paraphernalia you require, of which the need is greatest with the first home.

Then again, some people are just mean and might be hoping that with the plethora of good things heaped upon you, you won't notice who didn't give at all.

Some might be short of money; others will have done you a valuable service in the past and feel that no additional token is required. Friends are infinitely more valuable than tokens and principles. There may be reasons which, if you knew, you would acknowledge, and even if you didn't it's better to accept people as you find them. Making an issue of this will only alienate those you challenge, and perhaps others too. Everyone has shortcomings, and you can't reject everyone who is not perfect. If you do you will soon find yourself very lonely.

Readers' replies

The idea that a wedding is undertaken for your friends' enjoyment is a bit rich. Have you ever been to a wedding reception? By their very design, they're awful.

Maybe your 'friends' thought it was, by their standards, a cheap affair not worthy of a gift.

Or maybe they don't think it will last. A person could drive themselves mad on such petty thinking. Thank them for sharing your special day and then get on with your sad, empty life.
S.O. of London

I've an idea. Next time you get married, how about charging an entrance fee? That way they you can reap back the cost of the festivities and perhaps make a profit.
D.B. of Brighton

A month after her large and expensive wedding the bride starts whingeing about a few guests who did not give her anything. Is this the real reason for her upset, or is she feeling a sense of anti-climax now the excitement is over?
T.B. of Bournemouth

Next week's dilemma

My friend has suffered from anorexia and bulimia since she was a teenager. She was hospitalised when younger and saw a variety of specialists during her twenties and early thirties.

She married during a 'good' spell, but her eating disorders returned and drove her husband away. Now almost 40, she seems to have given up trying to recover and continues to binge and starve herself. Her health is deteriorating: her teeth are becoming discoloured and she has bowel and intestinal problems. I am worried that unless she gets help soon she may not survive more than a few more years.

But although we are close, it is almost impossible to discuss her eating disorder with her.

I have considered getting together with two or three friends and confronting her with 'tough love' and insist that she checks into a clinic, but I fear she would see this as intrusive and cut off contact with us.What should I do?
L.F. of Bristol

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.
fields.bodyText: My husband and I had a beautiful wedding four weeks ago. We received more than 100 gifts. However, there are about six close friends who apparently have not sent us presents. Obviously we are very hurt that they did not acknowledge our marriage with a gift and I would like to let them know how I feel. Not for reasons of acquisitiveness, but as a matter of principle: the wedding was an expensive affair, undertaken as much for our friends' enjoyment as our own. My husband thinks that I should keep quiet and not judge. Who is right? J.K. of Luton I would be presumptuous if I believed that my views are the 'right' ones. The essence of moral dilemmas is that even after clearing away the deadwood of hypocrisy and faulty logic, there is still not a clear-cut solution. Your little piece of insincerity is that you set up this expensive ceremony as much for friends' gratification as your own. Now come on. Your wedding was your gift to yourselves; and the inviting of friends who are expected to wear new clothes, come in a spirit of happiness, lavish affection on you and make complimentary speeches is a harmless form of self-deception. You bribe your friends with lavish hospitality to come and play their part. The bargain is completed by the present. Arguably, by the time a guest has bought an expensive outfit and a gift, he/she will have paid out more than the cost to you per head. Such calculations do go on in people's minds. So what can we say of those six good friends who did not come up to scratch? I'll suggest a few possible reasons. If any of them are single they may be oblivious of the custom. Present-giving on all such occasions is mainly car ried out by women, and a widower or male divorcee has probably never had to think about this before. If this is a second marriage people may not have felt gifts were required. Presumably, you have all the household paraphernalia you require, of which the need is greatest with the first home. Then again, some people are just mean and might be hoping that with the plethora of good things heaped upon you, you won't notice who didn't give at all. Some might be short of money; others will have done you a valuable service in the past and feel that no additional token is required. Friends are infinitely more valuable than tokens and principles. There may be reasons which, if you knew, you would acknowledge, and even if you didn't it's better to accept people as you find them. Making an issue of this will only alienate those you challenge, and perhaps others too. Everyone has shortcomings, and you can't reject everyone who is not perfect. If you do you will soon find yourself very lonely. Readers' replies The idea that a wedding is undertaken for your friends' enjoyment is a bit rich. Have you ever been to a wedding reception? By their very design, they're awful. Maybe your 'friends' thought it was, by their standards, a cheap affair not worthy of a gift. Or maybe they don't think it will last. A person could drive themselves mad on such petty thinking. Thank them for sharing your special day and then get on with your sad, empty life. S.O. of London I've an idea. Next time you get married, how about charging an entrance fee? That way they you can reap back the cost of the festivities and perhaps make a profit. D.B. of Brighton A month after her large and expensive wedding the bride starts whingeing about a few guests who did not give her anything. Is this the real reason for her upset, or is she feeling a sense of anti-climax now the excitement is over? T.B. of Bournemouth Next week's dilemma My friend has suffered from anorexia and bulimia since she was a teenager. She was hospitalised when younger and saw a variety of specialists during her twenties and early thirties. She married during a 'good' spell, but her eating disorders returned and drove her husband away. Now almost 40, she seems to have given up trying to recover and continues to binge and starve herself. Her health is deteriorating: her teeth are becoming discoloured and she has bowel and intestinal problems. I am worried that unless she gets help soon she may not survive more than a few more years. But although we are close, it is almost impossible to discuss her eating disorder with her. I have considered getting together with two or three friends and confronting her with 'tough love' and insist that she checks into a clinic, but I fear she would see this as intrusive and cut off contact with us.What should I do? L.F. of Bristol Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

webTitle: The first time I went travelling abroad

fields.headline: I went travelling abroad
fields.standfirst: 'Astrid couldn't speak English. Though, by then, neither could I'
fields.trailText: Phil Hogan continues a new summer series on firsts for Observer writers.
fields.body:
Looking back, 1973 was definitely one of my better years. Not only had I almost fulfilled my ambition to grow my hair down to my waist and rid myself of a bout of chronic virginity, going back to early adolescence but by the end of the summer I could also boast an impressive record of exotic travel. I still have a photograph of me at 18 sitting at the side of a sunny, foreign byway strumming a guitar, as telling an image of gormless youth as you could wish to disown even by the standards of an era in which the market for embroidered, flapping trousers was close to saturation.

My journey of discovery started in the pub with Keith and Roy, who had decided to escape to Rotterdam in their annual break from the dyeworks and asked if I wanted to come. Rotterdam! Naturally, I leapt at the chance, because although I wasn't really interested in canals and tulips, I'd heard the stories about loose women who sat in their living-room windows half-naked and combing their hair. I was so giddy with expectation that I wittered on about the trip until I was gently corrected on my uncertain grasp of geography by one of the mechanics at the tyre depot in Leeds where I'd had a job since I left school at 16, answering the phone and being sent out for lard sandwiches.'That's Amsterdam, you twat,' he said.

Keith and Roy had decided on Rotterdam for no better reason than that was where the ferry stopped. The 'idea' was that we would make our way back to England through, er_ whichever countries were on the way back to England. Plus, it was only £9.25 from Hull, they said, which meant more mileage for our money. Luckily, the mechanic at work had to go to Hull to do a big installation (air ring-main, not conceptual art) and he gave us a lift in the back of his van, which he'd specially fitted out for the three of us with heaps of metal tubing, grease-producing equipment and a rubber hose leading to the exhaust pipe.

The overnight ferry was more promising, mainly because of the cheap beer and disco, and though the crossing was a bit rocky it did provide us with the unending novelty of uphill dancing and having to walk sideways to the bar. I don't know what happened to the others but Igot talking to a German girl called Astrid who couldn't speak a word of English, though, by then, neither could I. Then one of the deckhands kindly offered to lend us his cabin for half an hour. Yesss! The downside was that he had invited his shipmates to watch us through a little window above the door, which was a bit off-putting for Astrid, especially the noise of people falling off the chair. So, instead of being able to celebrate my first lewd encounter with a foreign woman, (not including ones in magazines), I ended up on the sleeping-deck surrounded by snoring drunks, until eventually one of them was me.

The rest of our trip was quite good. In the absence of our not having planned anything in the slightest, we left Rotterdam on the first train going somewhere none of us had ever heard of. But we were soon befriended by some girl students who mistook us for someone more intelligent and took us back to their house to listen to jazz records, before ferrying us to a remote campsite, where we were trapped for days listening to Keith's radio. Eventually, we walked back to town and Roy took the photograph of me at the side of the road.

Back in the station, we decided to move on to France before we ran out of guilders, but none of us could pronounce 'Boulogne' to the satisfaction of the ticket seller. Some days later, we arrived in Beauloeuilgne, a town known only to its 14 inhabitants and a dog that barked at us from a yard across from the platform where we pitched our sleeping bags. Things were fraught. Keith said it might help the situation if I put the guitar away and stopped singing 'Homeward Bound', especially the bit about sitting in a railway station. Next morning, we located France on Keith's map and spelled out 'Boulogne' to the ticket seller in an attempt to reduce the chances of our ending up in Bologna or Bulawayo.

At last we arrived in Boulogne. We camped on the dunes with the white cliffs of Dover just across the water. We swam in the sea with our clothes on. We listened to Keith's radio ('Rock On' by David Essex was at No 1). We played table football in a bar.And we went home with our travellers' tales. Three countries in 10 days for less than £50, including fares, beer, food (well, crisps), and 200 fags each from duty free. Beat that, Thomas Cook.

fields.headline: True confessions
fields.standfirst: Having children turned my friend into someone I couldn't like
fields.trailText: Having children turned my friend into someone I couldn't like
fields.body:
Joseph used to be my best friend. Our friendship had, for 20 years, survived our incompatible tastes in music, clothes, politics, cars and wives. Lying dormant, however, was a deeper, more threatening incompatibility than any of these. Our friendship dissolved in a puddle of sterilising fluid, the time he and his wife Mary brought their two little girls for the weekend. Since then it's been just Christmas cards.

Not just any Christmas cards of course. The Good Tidings that these cards bring are all of my ex-friends themselves, or more particularly, of their children. We learn that Cherish, the elder, in her second year at school, is already able to point out her teacher's spelling mistakes. And the nursery says Dimity, the younger, is 'unusually gifted' academically and socially. And that's certainly something, as this nursery, we learn, is the most selective in the area.

Looking back, the omens were bad from the beginning. Joseph arrived with a huge pink padded bag across his shoulder. At tea time, I discovered what it contained. I set out the plates for my children, and for Dimity and Cherish. 'Have they been sterilised?' asked Joseph. 'Well, more or less,' I quipped back. 'We can always share out any dried-on food so it's fair.' Then I realised he wasn't joking. Out of the pink bag came a Porton Down emergency pack. Sterilising fluid and a vast plastic jug. Into the jug went Dimity's and Cherish's plates. I felt the first chill flickers of distaste as I examined Dimity's and Cherish's innocent faces. They looked sickly, I thought. Their immune systems were probably shot.

Joseph fished the plates out of the steriliser. I deposited a small helping of food on each girl's plate. They stared at it in horror. 'I'm afraid the girls have quite strong preferences in food,' said Mary. 'You don't really like that, do you, girls?' Dimity and Cherish shook their heads. 'Dimity only eats Turkey Dinosaurs,' said Cherish. 'And I only eat chicken breasts. And turkey sometimes.' I searched in the freezer. 'Would chicken nibbles do?' I asked hopelessly. 'We could always try them, couldn't we, girls?' said Mary.

I looked at my watch. Only an hour till bedtime, I sighed. But the hour passed, and Dimity and Cherish made not a move towards bed. By this time they were tired and irritable. Dimity pinched my son. He reciprocated with a deep scratch across her face. Mary and Joseph were outraged. 'Is he always like that?' they said, shocked.

That evening, we had some other friends round. During dinner, Mary fed Dimity the Turkey Dinosaurs my wife had fetched from the corner shop. Later, the girls hung around, interrupting conversations or shouting at their father. They were exhausted and blameless. I wanted to kill them.

I shouldn't judge, I know. Anxious protectiveness may well be better than my fecklessness. But I can't stand what my friends have made of their daughters. So it's just Christmas cards, from now on.

 If you have a true confession; e-mail kim.bunce@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: An American in London
fields.standfirst: Elaine Showalter
fields.trailText: Elaine Showalter
fields.body:
I'm a proud, even patriotic, American who can't survive without ice cubes, Diet Coke, air-conditioning and manicures. But after 30 years of coming to London every summer and renting all over the city, my husband and I have bought a flat. We've finally got a permanent London address and hope to qualify for a Freedom bus pass. As daily users of public transport, we plan to explain to American friends that we're moving to London for the bus pass alone.

Not entirely, of course, although the routes to our new home in Islington are pretty nifty. From the moment I first arrived in London in 1964, my heart beat faster here, although in those days we would have starved to death without the Chinese and had to wear mittens to work in some of the libraries. In the Seventies we came back for two sabbaticals, sent our kids to London schools, became addicted to Coronation Street , and developed an attachment to the culture and lifestyle of the place that has become deeper every year.

London is a great city first of all because things that are scattered all over most countries are located here in one place: government, the arts,fashion, medicine, the financial centre, sports, the film and television industries, publishing and journalism. There's a concentration of creativity and talent which is unequalled anywhere else in the world. It also has a truly liveable scale, in part because of its history as a set of villages,and in part because the skyscrapers are mainly along the river in the second, twin London that has sprouted magically in the past decade.

My husband (whose name, believe it or not, is English Showalter) and I are among that much-ridiculed group of American tourists who come for the theatre, and our son's early exposure to great performers like Ian Charleson, Antony Sher and Jonathan Pryce helped convince him to become an actor. I have grey hairs to show for that. But London theatre also has an intimacy, continuity, and scope that American theatre painfully lacks, and the London cultural boom offers as much to Americans as to Brits. There is no American national theatre in the States, but here we can see Miller, Mamet, Williams, Rodgers & Hammerstein and O'Neill. In the reading rooms of the new, state-of-the-art British Library, American professors and graduate students fill half the seats. The Tate Modern has one of the world's great collections of contemporary American art.

Over the years we've tried to give back some of the pleasure we've received by becoming members and supporters of various theatres and museums, an effort that provides much more in the way of acknowledgment and real opportunity to connect than the over-priced nominal boards of their New York equivalents.

There are things I don't admire about London. I think that street beggars have gotten out of hand and that there must be a better way for the Government to handle homelessness than to have five young men and two dogs sitting outside the supermarket (as they are in my neighbourhood), drinking beer, cooking sausages over a campfire, and harassing the shoppers for change. I don't like the Tube, or the traffic, although compared to New York's subway the former looks pretty good, and my husband swears that English drivers are the most courteous in the world.

But I love it when a cab driver entertains us with imitations of Russell Crowe and Elvis, and gets us to our remote destination with dispatch as well. I'm dazzled by British classiness at Wimbledon, because if Americans hadn't won a sports competition for 65 years they damn well would stop hosting it. I'm excited by the cultural variety of London, and the ferocious energy of the British press, and soothed by living in a city where I can hear seagulls as well as pigeons, where a quarter-inch of snow seems like a blizzard and 80 degrees Fahrenheit is called a heatwave. I don't plan to move to London permanently. My dream would be an Atlantic tunnel, where I could zip back and forth and have the best of both worlds. But I've given my personal papers to the Fawcett Library so that in the future, if there's another young American feminist who wants to know about me, she will have to come to London to find out. I like thinking about that as my best legacy to my country.

fields.headline: TV's Eastern promise
fields.standfirst: There are 3 million Asian viewers with spending power of £5bn. No wonder digital channels are chasing them, writes  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: There are 3 million Asian viewers with spending power of £5bn. No wonder digital channels are chasing them, writes Faisal Islam
fields.body:
It's just like the first days of TV-am - warm colours, comfy sofas, cooking, chatting and swapping anecdotes. But there's no Rusty Lee, and this tried-and-tested formula for mid-morning telly is now scheduled as prime time evening entertainment for households across Britain.

Cook and Chaat, hosted by ex TV-am presenter Lisa Aziz, features British Asian celebrities with their mothers. Dr Raj Persaud, the media-friendly psychologist, was interviewed in one edition while his mother cooked his favourite Guyanese Asian dish and chatted about Raj's childhood.

It's no Big Brother, despite the maternal confessionals - and viewing figures for Cook and Chaat, the prime slot on the digital Channel East, are unavailable. But it is an unlikely weapon in an increasingly bitter battle for viewers among a growing number of niche channels for ethnic minority viewers.

This is driven partly by the huge demand for Asian-specific media content, ranging from Bollywood films to cricket and religious programmes, for which users pay a subscription. But it is also increasingly fuelled by advertisers looking for ways to reach attractive niche markets missed by conventional campaigns.

Previously, these channels were noted more for the unintentional comedy of home-videoed ads for butchers' shops in Leicester than for the consumers they could deliver. But now blue chip brands such as Mercedes and BT, as well as the Government, are using them to target a previously neglected market of 500,000 households - 3 million people with a purchasing power said to total £5 billion.

The proliferation of channels over the past year - Channel East is one of 14 catering for Britain's Asian community and sub-communities - could not have happened without digital satellite technology. The cost of putting a channel to air is now around £1 million a year, under a fifth of the pre-digital price.

The leading stations operate as premium channels, like Sky Sports or Movies. Zee TV, part of a media empire based in India, is the market leader with around 150,000 subscribers and enjoys the benefits of a seven-year headstart over competitors. Last year saw the launch of Sony TV Asia and a film channel, B4U, which have attracted, respectively, about a half and a third of Zee's numbers. The anticipated arrival of Star TV, part of the Murdoch empire and run by his youngest son, James, would further shake up the sector.

The channels provide a staple diet of south Asian entertainment: Bollywood films, sport, fashion, music and popular Indian soaps. 'It's amazing - we are often surprised to see that the top 10 programmes in India are often the top 10 in the UK,' says Monica Dalton, chief executive of Zee TV Europe. 'This is a thread of commonality linking India and UK Indians.'

Some 70 per cent of Zee subscribers installed a Sky system for the sole purpose of watching Zee. Around 80 per cent of programmes are imported direct from India, mainly from Zee's parent network run by Subhash Chandra. The Sony venture is similarly connected in India, and among B4U's backers is Eros films, one of the biggest UK distributors of Indian films.

'Previously many parents were forcing their children to watch such channels,' jokes Dalton, 'but they are now watching voluntarily.'

Zee has the worldwide TV rights for the Miss World contest at the Millennium Dome - an important strike back at Sony which was behind the recent high-profile Indian film awards ceremony, also at the Dome. Sony has scored notable success in securing UK rights to cricket matches involving south Asian teams.

All three leading channels pour energies into sponsoring cultural festivals, or melas . They all claim extremely high levels of customer feedback and loyalty, won through careful cultivation of community links.

The strength of Zee's brand loyalty is such that the two major new entrants - Sony and B4U - forged a marketing alliance in the UK, despite being bitter rivals in India.

The spend for fierce marketing is available because margins are so high: much of the content is available cheaply from existing Indian and Pakistani television, so production costs are low.

But the battle for subscribers is subsumed within an emerging struggle for advertisers. In the longer term, expectations of production quality will increase, just as they have in India, and the myriad channels will become more dependent on advertising revenues rather than cheap programmes.

This reinforces the need to attract professional Asians who would not necessarily subscribe to the specialist music or film channels.

Channel East's promotional material suggests there is more to being Asian than Bhangra and Bollywood. They are going for the second and third generation communities and the 'burgeoning Asian white-collar sector'. But the project is beset with difficulties.

A recent attempt to switch to subscription was postponed, and it still goes out free to air. It has an impressive roster of advertisers - sales are handled by Carlton - but the portents are not great because Channel East is attempting something very ambitious: targeting an entire, heterogenous community without offering the must-sees such as cricket and movies that attract a critical mass of viewers. Unlike the other channels, most of its production is done in-house at its HDS Studios in west London.

If it succeeds, the viewership would be tremendously attractive to advertisers. But there is considerable social, religious and cultural diversity within what is regarded as the Asian community. Cook and Chaat, hosted by ex TV-am presenter Lisa Aziz, features British Asian celebrities with their mothers. Dr Raj Persaud, the media-friendly psychologist, was interviewed in one edition while his mother cooked his favourite Guyanese Asian dish and chatted about Raj's childhood. Sony has scored notable success in securing UK rights to cricket matches involving south Asian teams. All three leading channels pour energies into sponsoring cultural festivals, or melas . fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: What does TI Group, one of the few world-class engineers left in Britain, have to do? Interim results this month easily topped market expectations and TI also promised double-digit profit growth for the year, after a cracking performance from automotive components.
fields.body:
What does TI Group, one of the few world-class engineers left in Britain, have to do? Interim results this month easily topped market expectations and TI also promised double-digit profit growth for the year, after a cracking performance from automotive components.

Yet the shares have since dropped from 370p to 333.5p - 40 per cent off their value just 12 months ago. Blame it on the dog days of August if you like; now looks a good time to buy, before the market gets back into full swing after the holidays.

Trading at just nine times earnings, the shares are cheap on fundamentals. But there may also be rumblings on the corporate front. Frustrated by the market's measly valuation, chairman Sir Christopher Lewinton is canvassing all options, including disposals, splitting the automotive and aerospace arms in two and even a management buy-out. That, in turn, means TI is up for grabs if a serious bidder emerges. And there are plenty of US and European engineers who'd surely love to grab TI's strong market positions. Broker Henderson Crosthwaite puts a 450p valuation on the shares. UBS Warburg thinks 550p is right.

Sherwood spurt
take a look at Sherwood International, the software group. Despite a tough industry background, the interims showed solid growth. Yet the shares have eased to 725p.

That's not to say, by conventional yardsticks, that the shares are cheap. But, trading on around 50 times earnings, Sherwood stands at a discount to its peers. And it has similar growth prospects to the likes of Sage and London Bridge, thinks broker HSBC.

Analysts are most excited about prospects for e2-One, the venture set up to market Sherwood's Aeos online broking software outside the insurance industry.

HSBC has set a target price of 900p and ABN Amro also rates the shares a 'buy'.

Emap hits form
Publisher Emap is another whose shares have eased over the summer when there is little to grumble about.

New circulation figures for Emap's magazines are ahead of market expectations. FHM continues to widen its lead over IPC's Loaded . Smash Hits is benefiting from cross-promotion with The Box, Emap's TV music channel. Emap has also aggressively raised cover prices on its strongest-growing publications, which bodes well for revenue growth.

Broker UBS Warburg values the shares at 1700p, while rival Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette's 12-month price target is not far off at 1680p. Those values match Emap's peak at the start of the year and represent a 50 per cent upside on today's 1117p.

S&N bubbling
Scottish & Newcastle, our biggest brewer, has had a busy year. After buying Kronenbourg from French food group Danone last month, last week it snapped up Portugal's biggest brewer. Now the group is on the verge of flogging off Center Parcs holiday camps to another French outfit for £700m or so.

New executive chairman Brian Stewart must be hoping that that deal perks up S&N's share price. The stock has slipped 20 per cent since June, when the Kronenbourg euphoria was overtaken by worries that the £1.7 billion price tag was too high.

But Kronenbourg, remember, gives market leadership in France, plus Alken Maes and Peroni, the number two beers in Belgium and Italy. And there's also the chance of taking Danone's interest in Spanish number two San Miguel in due course.

Strategically, it's hard to fault S&N's footwork. If it doesn't perform, the group will be an attractive target for giants such as Anheuser Busch. The shares should be tucked away for the medium term.

webTitle: A little regulation goes a long way for net tipsters

fields.headline: A little regulation goes a long way for net tipsters
fields.trailText: The day traders are restive. The bulletin boards are up in arms. The internet is positively revolting. What's sparked the outcry?
fields.body:
The day traders are restive. The bulletin boards are up in arms. The internet is positively revolting. What's sparked the outcry? An end to share tips on Sharepages.com and Digitallook.com, two of the burgeoning number of financial websites, courtesy of the suits in hobnail boots at the Financial Services Authority (FSA).

From some of the press reports last week, readers may indeed have gained the impression that the regulators were now cracking down in the most cackhanded, discriminatory and Canute-likefashion on the net. And why pick on just these two? After all, they were simply printing round-ups of newspaper tips. So why should that constitute giving 'unauthorised financial advice'?

What about the papers themselves? And other websites, like Breakingviews.com, Sharecast.com and TheStreet.com? And, for that matter, FT.com, GuardianUnlimited.co.uk and all Fleet Street's online shadows? Or, indeed, the venerable Reuters news agency, which produces its own round-up of Sunday newspaper tips for traders at the start of every week.

The reality, however, is less dramatic. For a long time the FSA has been concerned about the net. It would be nonsensical if it weren't. After all, a year ago there were no online brokers and now they number 30-plus. Flotations are being handled over the net. And, of course, insider information - or juicy titbits dressed up as such - is increasingly being posted anonymously on the web, with share prices gyrating wildly as a result.

The travails of Dan Wagner's old Dialog site (now Brightstation.com, see graph) through the net rumour mill are legendary. Deals like Reckitt & Colman's merger with Benckiser have broken on bulletin boards, prompting hasty announcements. So the FSA is quite right to try, at least, to 'police the net'. It's nothing to do with stopping free speech. It's about stopping market manipulation. And market abuse usually means it's the ordinary punters, including many now mouthing off on the net, who get suckered.

Since its inception three years ago, the FSA has been in constant dialogue with financial websites. And what happened last week was that, in the course of talks, Sharepages voluntarily withdrew its own summary and spin on newspaper tips. Digitallook.com, meanwhile, had altered its service nine months ago. So, presto, there was no 'crackdown' or 'net blackout', despite the dramatic headlines. And importantly - if you do use the web for tips - there's also no implication, therefore, that one site is 'safer' or more reliable than another simply because it's not been 'cracked down on'.

The truth is, in this greyest of areas, that the FSA has to make do with legislation - the Financial Services Act 1986 - drawn up when the world wide web was but a twinkle in a spider's eye. At the moment - for the protection of investors - no one can give 'investment advice' unless they are registered with and regulated by the FSA. Newspapers and magazines are specifically exempt and can tip shares, as long as this is not their principal business. It's an anomaly, certainly, and one highlighted by the antics of the Mirror 's ex-City Slickers. But it's one the FSA, for now, has to live with.

So, for financial websites, there are two ways to go. Register with the FSA, as some popular sites like Hemscott.net and Interactive Investor already have and others, such as Sharecast and Sharepages, are now doing. Or get yourself registered as a newspaper. This, however, is where the present law falls down. Websites have taken to scribbling issue numbers in page corners to try to satisfy definitions of what constitutes a periodical or publication under present law.

Pragmatically, the FSA exempts the likes of FT.com, because it is part of a newspaper group. Pragmatically, too, Reuters poses no problem as it has a long track record of objective reporting. But the FSA appreciates that in today's environment this is arbitrary, to say the the least. And that's why there's been no crackdown, but rather a behind-the-scenes dialogue.

Not before time, the law is now finally about to embrace the net. Next month, the Treasury will consult on an updated list of exemptions before the new Financial Markets Bill becomes law next year. So there's no reason why online news services shouldn't be treated like their newsprint rivals. Furthermore, either by legislation or through tightening of the Press Complaints Commission's Code of Practice, share-dealing by press tipsters is either going to be restricted or better disclosed. And everyone - in the markets, in Fleet Street or on the net - will be caught by new civil powers to prevent 'market abuse'.

Naturally, there are many on the net who say, why bother? Let caveat emptor apply. People are smart enough not to be taken in by scurrilous rumours. That, however, is an argument against any regulation at all and, the trouble is, people do get taken to the cleaners.

Clearly, investors who use bulletin boards should always be wary, and realise that a website's registration with the FSA is no guarantee of either good advice or a con-free zone. Before dealing on internet tips, readers should see FSA's succinct warning about bulletin boards. Go to www.fsa.gov.uk, click on 'Consumer Help', then 'What's New' for 'Consumer Alerts'.

Shake-out survivor
Whither Durlacher, the pioneering broker whose fortunes are most closely identified with the net? After a breathtaking rise at the height of dotcom mania, Durlacher's shares have since plummeted in the shake-out. To phrase the question in quite those terms, however, is to miss the point.

The broker, headed by Geoffrey Chamberlain, is no more finished because the market's come to its senses than any pilot who makes a safe landing. And, remember, investors have still done exceedingly well out of Durlacher's impressive seven-year rise as nurturer of internet start-ups and flotations.

Known for backing success stories like Autonomy and 365 Corp, Durlacher is now using its expertise to mould and take far bigger stakes in technology companies. The latest is KVault Software, which helps firms archive and retrieve emails using technology first developed at Compaq. There's life, therefore, in Durlacher yet. Like the internet, the firm's developing all the time.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Never mind the sex, we're Americans | Nick's Currant affair
fields.body:
Never mind the sex, we're Americans
Who said the British are prudes? Robert Hughes, whose landmark documentary on Australia, Beyond the Fatal Shore, is chock-full of sex, nudity and more sex and nudity, is about to be revealed in all its glory on BBC2. But when Oxford Television, which made the programme, tried to sell it to the American networks the censors had to lie down in a darkened edit suite.

'They threw a fit and said there could be no willies, no tits, no bums,' wails Nick Kent, head of Oxford. 'It's full of nudity and I have no idea what will be left after they have made the cuts. I can barely bring myself to watch it.'

Nick's Currant affair
Nasty Nick Bateman was living up to his oh so bad boy reputation last Tuesday night. Clearly tired and very emotional, the instant celeb was sandwiched between two very burly but extremely taciturn 'friends' (from Wapping apparently) while sat in the bar of the Surrey hotel where he had been hidden away by the Currant Bun.

For the delectation of scores of advertising bods enjoying a free junket at the hotel, Nick held forth on the pressing issues of the day in a full and frank way. Having slagged off all of his fellow Big Brother members - sadly all his comments were unprintable - he then seemed to become a little more thoughtful. Bateman begged his enthralled audience not to take his photo 'because I'm under contract with the Sun'. A case of horses and stable doors, Media Diary thinks, given the way he had inadvertently given an 'exclusive' interview to the Mirror several hours before.

Dotcom dancing
We get many worried emails from anxious newspaper hacks asking us whether they should take the dotcom shilling. OK, the bylines might not be so big and you'll probably have to wear three-quarter length combat trousers and ride to work on a chrome scooter, but think of the share options. Erm, on second thoughts, given the dotcom crash, maybe not.

No, what any ambitious (surely avaricious) newspaper hacks need to do now is follow the wily example of the FT 's top US correspondent, Louise Kehoe. With 25 years' Valley experience under her belt it was inevitable that a dotcom firm would ask her to join the firm. Apparently, Kehoe 'let it be known' to the bods back at Southwark Bridge that she was considering the move, only for desperate FT executives to snap on the golden handcuffs with a vastly bumped up salary.

NB: This approach only works if you have any dotcom credibility. Key words to start dropping into the conversation should include Nasdaq, assymetric digital subscriber line and cash burn rate.

webTitle: Welsh steel plant off death row

fields.headline: Welsh steel plant off death row
fields.trailText: Steel giant Corus is expected to secure the future for its Llanwern steel works in South Wales this week, safeguarding 2,500 jobs. The crucial decision has been whether to invest £35 million in relining the plant's No 3 blast furnace.
fields.body:
Steel giant Corus is expected to secure the future for its Llanwern steel works in South Wales this week, safeguarding 2,500 jobs. The crucial decision has been whether to invest £35 million in relining the plant's No 3 blast furnace.

The company has been negotiating to extract reductions in its £2 million-a-year business rate bill from local authorities and to gain grants from the Welsh Assembly before committing itself to having the work done.

Sources indicate that it has achieved reductions in the rate bill, and that the Assembly has 'been helpful' in discussions, although it is unlikely that direct grants will be possible under European state aid rules.

The breakthrough comes despite frosty relations between Corus and Assembly leader Rhodri Morgan, who criticised the deal between British Steel and Hoogovens of Holland which created the company. He said it put City interests before jobs and investment.

Corus has announced a savage series of job cuts totalling almost 4,000 in the past two months, including 450 at Llanwern and 400 at its sister strip mill in Port Talbot.

webTitle: Soon everyone will be able to recognise you...

fields.headline: Soon everyone will be able to recognise you...
fields.standfirst: Putting a face, fingerprint or signature to a name will be easy as the recognition sector takes off, reports  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Putting a face, fingerprint or signature to a name will be easy as the recognition sector takes off, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
The machines that watch our every move are about to get a lot smarter. Take the petrol forecourt, for example. A Cambridge firm has developed a software system which reads car registration numbers and then checks them off against a database of known petrol bandits, allowing forecourt cashiers to freeze their pumps.

Some might fear the system could have more intrusive applications, but its creator, Neurodynamics, argues that its technology, which has been tested at 26 garages in Northampton, benefits the consumer. The company says by helping to eliminate petrol fraud - which totals £1 million a year in London alone - its technology helps keeps petrol costs down.

Welcome to the world of Advanced Recognition Systems (ARS), a market set for explosive growth over the next five years. Neurodynamics' Automatic Number Plate Reader Technology, originally developed for the Ministry of Defence, is only one example of how ARS is about to enter our lives.

The Abbey National, for example, hopes to replace its CCTV video security systems with a new system which transmits images over the internet or ISDN lines. Because all the data is stored on computers, there is no problem with 'fuzzy' video pictures caused by re-recording tapes.

Dave Humphrey, manager of Neurodynamics' Vision & Imaging Division which is developing the technology, says the really clever thing about the technology is that the cameras are 'trained' to watch for irregularities. If they spot something unfamiliar then the system will alert other banks or email the police.

'A security guard monitoring loads of cameras won't be able to monitor them properly, but this system changes that,' Humphrey said.

The company also has a Biometrics division which has patented a fingerprint recognition system used by police forces in Algeria, Jordan and Malta. It is now developing a 3-d facial recognition system which allows cameras to analyse subtle features on the subject's face, such as eyes and nose, by emitting patterns of light and then recording the reflection. It can identify a person from any angle, even if their physical appearance has changed or they are not looking at the camera face on.

There is even a system under development to identify people by body odour.

ARS works by combining neural network technology with probability theory. The result is a system which allows computers to recognise patterns in any media - video, text or human form - and analyse the information intelligently. The potential applications are almost infinite. 'It could be used for computer log-ons or replacing signatures on credit cards. A lot of major financial institutions are conducting pilot tests using this technology,' said Mike Dell, technology manager with Neurodynamics' Biometrics division.

According to research conducted by analysts at Salomon Smith Barney, the biometrics market will be worth around $1billion by 2003, although predictions vary wildly because of the sector's infancy. 'It's very much an issue of user take-up. It's a question of persuading users this is something they want and trust,' Dell said.

As for the future, mobile phones and palmtop computers might soon incorporate the technology. 'If fingerprint recognition was built in, not only would it protect your device but it would also protect its data,' Dell said.

It is all very Star Trek, and some argue that ARS will never get off the ground. Given the substantial research and development costs, not to mention the difficulties in finding skilled staff, ARS companies like Neurodynamics are still the minnows of the security sector. Launched in 1991, the company employs only 15 people, of whom 12 are in the UK and three in the US.

Nevertheless, the firm's activities are bound to provoke huge interest in the next few years because of the way Neurodynamics acts as an incubator for high-tech companies, nurturing each of its divisions before spinning them off. Its most famous success has been Autonomy, the $6bn internet software company, which specialises in text recognition systems. The company's stellar rise made its chief executive officer, Mike Lynch (also the founder of Neurodynamics), the UK's first internet billionaire - a pattern the company's backers hope it will repeat.

webTitle: Go-ahead says go away to French bidders

fields.headline: Go-ahead says go away to French bidders
fields.trailText: National Express and French rail giant SNCF could be approached as potential white knights by Go-Ahead, the UK transport group that became the subject of a hostile takeover bid last week.
fields.body:
National Express and French rail giant SNCF could be approached as potential white knights by Go-Ahead, the UK transport group that became the subject of a hostile takeover bid last week.

Go-Ahead has pledged to fight for its independence and this week will spell out expan sion plans in an attempt to keep shareholders on board in the face of the bid from obscure French transport group Caisse des Dépts-Développement (C3D).

But sources close to the company have hinted that if it were forced into an alliance it would rather choose its own 'compatible' partner.

UK coach-to-trains group National Express was described by a source as a company Go-Ahead could more easily see itself 'affiliated' with. SNCF is already teamed with Go-Ahead in its effort to take over the London rail franchise; it was described as 'bringing more to the ongoing business than C3D'.

Go-Ahead was informally approached by the French consortium of C3D and Rhone Capital last month and rebuffed its offer of 650p per share, which values the company at £326 million.

C3D returned last week with a hostile bid at the same price, rejected as 'cheeky'. City observers said the offer of 650p was unrealistic, but anything above £7 would probably oblige the directors to negotiate.

On Friday Go-Ahead will report flat pre-tax, pre-excep tional profits of £42m for the year just ended, on turnover up 10 per cent to £500m.

Managing director Martin Ballinger will tell analysts how Go-Ahead aims to double its turnover in the next three years, expand the bus business and bid for additional rail franchises. It is also hopeful of winning the South-central operation from Connex in October.

fields.headline: Smith aid lacks cutting edge
fields.trailText: Passionate supporters of lower-league clubs deserve a better deal.
fields.body:
At Euro 2000, I bumped into a couple of Rochdale fans who, like so many supporters from the lower divisions, follow England with a passion. They were disgusted with England's performance and even suggested that Rochdale could do better.

When I saw Kevin Keegan's latest squad to take on the world and European champions, I thought that this must be some kind of sick joke. Of all the garbage from the tournament in Belgium and Holland, he had voluntarily discarded only one player, the Ipswich keeper Richard Wright.

It's as if Keegan is living in a different world from the rest of us. Most managers who failed in Euro 2000 did the decent thing and resigned; even Italy's Dino Zoff went. Germany, who were on a par with England, apologised to their supporters for their inept performance. No such apology from Keegan.

What would the Rochdale fans think of Keegan now, I wondered? So I rang the Rochdale supporters club chairman, Frank Bishop, to find out. 'I could do better than Keegan for free,' he told me.

Actually, the real reason I rang was to find whether it was true that Rochdale fans were organising fundraising events to buy the club a new lawn mower. It seemed to me that the state of the Rochdale pitch was probably of more importance to their fans than whether or not all referees were prima donnas.

In the Third Division, they get even worse refs than in the Premiership. Patrick Vieira probably wouldn't last five minutes at that level.

Rochdale finished tenth in the Third Division last season or, as Frank Bishop put it, 'in the top half of Teletext'. After the last home game of the season against Barnet, the fans all invaded what was left of the pitch to salute their heroes. The problem was there was no grass. 'It looked more like Southport sands,' said Frank.

Some supporters thought the state of the pitch had contributed to their failure to reach the play-offs and asked the groundsman what was needed to rectify the position.

'What I really want is a TORO MC10 Multicore machine as used by Manchester United,' he replied. 'If it's good enough for Manchester United then it's good enough for us.' The machine costs £13,000 or a couple of hours of David Beckham's time, but Rochdale don't have that sort of money. As the club couldn't afford it, the supporters' club decided to raise the funds.

The first event they have planned is a sponsored walk to their away match with Halifax tomorrow - about 20 miles. I don't know if it's a bad omen, but the walk starts from the Cemetery Hotel at 8.15am with a complimentary breakfast thrown in.

The story of the Rochdale pitch may seem amusing, but it really is a scandal that a club have to rely on supporters to raise funds when there is so much money in the game. Next month, Chris Smith launches Supporters Direct, an organisation to help fans have a say in how their club are run. Funding for this is just £250,000 over three years. If the Government are really serious about helping fans then they will have to do a lot better than that. Supporters of smaller clubs like Rochdale deserve a better deal.

The Rochdale lawn mower broke down last week and it seemed that they were in danger of having too much grass on the pitch. The groundsman managed to borrow a machine, and did such a good job the team held Blackburn to a midweek draw.
